Name: Barb
Mnemonic: This radical is shaped like a barb. Kind of like the barb you'd see on a barbed fishing hook. Imagine that thing getting stuck in your arm or something. Not exactly pleasant. Say out loud, 'Oh dang, I got a barb stuck in me!' Alright, relax, it's only a little barb.

Name: Big
Mnemonic: This radical looks just like a stick figure—more specifically, a really big guy with his arms stretched out nice and big. When you see this radical, just think big, because this guy is really BIG!

Name: Construction
Mnemonic: You know those big steel girders that are used for the frame of big buildings? This is like the end of one of those, and has a very distinct shape, just like this radical. These girders are used in construction, which is why this radical means construction. Funny thing is, you use these girders to put together buildings just like you're going to use this radical to put together kanji!

Name: Cross
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a cross. I mean, just look at it. Two bars going through each other = a cross!

Name: Drop
Mnemonic: This little radical is a drop, maybe of water or some other liquid. Notice how it's only one drop? Sometimes radicals and kanji will have more than one drop in them, but don't let that throw you off.

Name: Enter
Mnemonic: Watch out! This isn't the person radical, it's something else. What's the difference? The right side is longer than the left. This radical also has that extra part sticking out at the top. See it? It kind of looks like a person lowering their head to go inside a tent or something. That's why this radical is enter.

Name: Fins
Mnemonic: These look like fins. What's a pair of disembodied fins doing here?! Some fish must have left them here by accident. Bet they're really missing these fins right about now.

Name: Ground
Mnemonic: This radical consists of a single, horizontal stroke. What's the biggest, single, horizontal stroke? That's the ground. Look at the ground, look at this radical, now look at the ground again. Kind of the same, right?

Name: Gun
Mnemonic: This looks a lot like a gun pointing to the right. You have a handle on the left, and the barrel pointing to the right. Imagine it hanging in a case on the wall in a museum.

Name: Lid
Mnemonic: This looks like something you'd put on a kettle or a pot, right? It even has a little handle to make sure you don't burn yourself. This is some kind of lid.

Name: Mountain
Mnemonic: This is a mountain. See the big peak in the middle and the smaller ones on either side? This totally looks like a mountain.

Name: Mouth
Mnemonic: A big, gaping, square hole represents someone opening their giant mouth to tell you something stupid.

Name: Nine
Mnemonic: If you look at this radical in just the right way, you'll notice that it kind of looks like the letters 'n' and 'i' (the 'i' comes from the little flippy-up stroke on the right side). What do the letters 'n' and 'i' start spelling? Why, the word nine.

Name: Person
Mnemonic: This is a person. They're standing with their arms down at their sides and their legs spread out, which kind of makes them look like a torso with a pair of legs. Think of 人 as highlighting the bipedal nature of people. Walking on two legs? Probably a person.

Name: Power
Mnemonic: Imagine a guy flexing his arm downward to show off his steroid-pumped arm. It's huge. It's so full of power. RARRRWWWRRR!!

Name: Prison
Mnemonic: This looks like an enclosure of sorts — that's why it's a prison. Imagine a tiny prisoner curled up inside, staring off into space, completely convinced they're trapped forever. Ironically this prison is actually wide open. They're just so consumed with self-pity that they haven't realized they've been free to leave all along.

Name: River
Mnemonic: This radical already looks like a river. See how the lines represent the flow of the river? There's even a slight bend in this river. So when you see this radical, you should think 'river.'

Name: Seven
Mnemonic: What does this radical look like? Hmm, nothing much. What about if you turn it upside down? Now does it look like a 7 with a line through it? Close enough to help you to remember that this radical is seven, right? Just remember, when you see this radical, flip it over and see what number it looks like. If you can do that, you can remember the meaning!

Name: Slide
Mnemonic: Close your eyes and imagine you're a kid again. Now open them and... look! It's a slide! Imagine little you sliding down this slide over and over, having a great time. Imagination + emotion makes for good memorization!

Name: Stick
Mnemonic: This is a stick, sticking straight up. It even looks like a stick.

Name: Sun
Mnemonic: Since there are no circles in Japanese characters, sometimes rectangles or squares have to make do. In this case, this big rectangle is the sun. The middle line is a cloud, moving across the sun. Picture it, but don't actually look at the sun and burn your eyes!

Name: Toe
Mnemonic: This radical kind of looks like a toe. See the one weird toe coming off the side of it? This also looks like the katakana character ト (to), which sounds like the word 'toe.' So whenever you see ト, just think toe.

Name: Tree
Mnemonic: Do you see the tree in here? It has branches, and then it has the foliage coming down diagonally from it, spreading out like a tree would. That's why this radical is a tree.

Name: Two
Mnemonic: One line plus another line equals two lines. This radical represents the number two. Pretty simple, right? Can you guess what three looks like? I bet you can...

Name: Woman
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a woman curtsying. Another way to think of it could be as two stacked Xs, since women generally have XX chromosomes.

Name: Above
Mnemonic: You find a toe on the ground. It's weird, because it's above the ground, not where toes belong.

Name: Below
Mnemonic: There's a toe below ground. So, where is the toe now? It's below ground. Imagine yourself digging it out, and thinking... ugh, why does it have to be below ground like this? So irritating. Will I be able to sew it back on in time to save it?

Name: Big
Mnemonic: The big radical and the big kanji are exactly the same!

Name: Construction
Mnemonic: The construction radical and the construction kanji are the same! This kanji also means industry, which is what construction is, if you think about it. It's all part of the construction industry.

Name: Eight
Mnemonic: This isn't exactly the same as the fins radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen… How many fins? Eight fins. Because you caught four fish with two fins each.

Name: Enter
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning… If you know the radical, you know this kanji means enter as well.

Name: Mountain
Mnemonic: The mountain radical and the mountain kanji are the same.

Name: Mouth
Mnemonic: The mouth radical and the mouth kanji are exactly the same!

Name: Nine
Mnemonic: The radical is nine and the kanji is nine, making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first.

Name: One
Mnemonic: Lying on the ground is something that looks just like the ground, the number One. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live.

Name: Person
Mnemonic: Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant person because it looks like a person with their arms down and their legs spread out? Well this is a person too!

Name: Power
Mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are power.

Name: River
Mnemonic: The river radical and the river kanji are the same!

Name: Seven
Mnemonic: Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is seven and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also seven. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.

Name: Ten
Mnemonic: This cross is the symbol for the number ten. A good way to remember this is to think about all the religions that have crosses and also important sets of tens.

Name: Three
Mnemonic: This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for 'one') and the radical for two. Combine one and two together and what do you get? Three!

Name: Two
Mnemonic: The kanji two and the radical two are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!

Name: Woman
Mnemonic: The woman radical and the woman kanji are the same!

Name: Book
Mnemonic: What's something useful you can get out of a tree? A book! Just cut that book right out of the tree trunk. If you think about it, every tree contains unlimited book potential. It's just a shame they have to be cut down to make the books…

Name: Bow
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a fancy composite bow people would use to shoot at targets and definitely not any normal living animals. See how the middle part is being pulled back? Imagine holding this bow and firing it at a target shaped like a giant alligator-crab monster.

Name: Child
Mnemonic: This is the radical for child. Aww, see how they're wearing a cap and have their little arms stretched out? You can almost hear them saying 'pick me up!' A very child-like child.

Name: Cow
Mnemonic: This is the cow radical. It kind of looks like the long face of a cow, right? Specifically a boy cow, since you can think of that top horizontal line as its horns. Seeing it yet? It's got a little tuft of hair on its head, and some kind of accessory on the horn to your left, so this is a very stylish cow.

Name: Dirt
Mnemonic: At first this looks like a cross in the ground, but it's actually something growing in the dirt. It's a little sprout, already rocking three leaves. And it's all thanks to that dirt! When you see this radical, think about how amazing it is that things just, like, grow in the dirt.

Name: Dog
Mnemonic: Remember the big guy who helped you with that big radical? Now you've got his big DOG! You know it's a dog because he's lying down, legs all spread out, with his favorite bone right beside his head.

Name: Evening
Mnemonic: This is the top half of a moon peeking out as it begins to rise. When does that happen? In the evening! Don't confuse this with the moon radical 月. 夕 is for the evening, when the moon's still low enough to be partly covered (by a mountain, for example).

Name: Eye
Mnemonic: See the iris in the middle of the eyeball? Remember that there are no round things in kanji, so square things take their place. That makes this a pretty realistic, square eye. You just have to squint with your real eyes a bit.

Name: Fire
Mnemonic: This is the radical for fire. It's got three little flames on top and even a couple logs underneath. But if it helps you can also focus on the person radical here. See it? It's got things coming off of it... What are those thi— OH MY GOD IT'S FIRE!!! Help, help! Put the fire out! Wait, it's fine… It's just the fire radical.

Name: Five
Mnemonic: If you use your imagination, this radical actually looks like the number 5. You just have to remove the vertical line in the bottom left, plus a few extra ends that stick out here and there. Once you do that, you have an easy way to remember that this radical means five.

Name: Flag
Mnemonic: See the flag in this radical? There's a pole with a flag on the end of it, blowing in the wind. Basically, this radical looks just like a flag.

Name: Hair
Mnemonic: These three streaks look like the flowing locks of someone's hair. Pretty easy to see and remember that this is the hair radical, right?

Name: Hand
Mnemonic: This is the hand radical. If you look at the palm of your right hand, the lines in it probably kinda look like the lines in 手. Sure it's not a perfect match, and everyone's got different hands, but basically this radical looks like the lines in your hand. You could also think of the horizontal lines in 手 as fingers. That would make for a pretty alien-looking hand, but still a hand… of sorts…

Name: Head
Mnemonic: This is the outline of a head. A really square head, admittedly, but try to imagine it facing to the right. The left side is the back of the head, and the barb-like part on the right shows the curve of the chin. See the head?

Name: Heaven
Mnemonic: Remember the guy from the big radical? This is him again, but this time he's so big his head is touching heaven. He's looking up and has his arms stretched open toward heaven, and his big hair is poking into those heavenly clouds.

Name: King
Mnemonic: This is the king radical. Picture this king sitting on his solid, squarish throne. The top stroke is the high back of the throne. The cross in the middle is his body, with his arms spread out on the arm rests. The bottom stroke is the ground. See him sitting there now, looking all dignified. Talk about a kingly king.

Name: Leaf
Mnemonic: There's a leaf on top and a stem going down out of it, making this the leaf radical. It's a pretty wide and flat leaf, so if it helps you can imagine it as a lily pad leaf.

Name: Legs
Mnemonic: This radical already looks like a pair of legs. There's even feet on these legs. That's how you know these are legs and not fins (or something else).

Name: Middle
Mnemonic: This is a stick going through the middle of a mouth. What kind of mouth? Mouth of a cylinder, mouth of a box, a human mouth — whatever kind you want to imagine, as long as the stick is going through the middle of it, since this is the radical for 'middle.'

Name: Moon
Mnemonic: This is the moon radical. See how it looks like a crescent moon with a couple of little clouds floating by? Try not to mix this up with the evening radical 夕 — you can see the whole crescent moon this time, so obviously this should be the radical for moon!

Name: Narwhal
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a narwhal. See the tail at the bottom, and the majestic narwhal horn poking out at the top? It also looks like the katakana character ナ (na), so you can remember it that way too. Na-na-na-narwhal! Just be careful not to confuse this with the treasure radical (メ). The sideways line for that one is at more of a downward angle, like an 'X.' But the sideways line for narwhal is horizontal (ナ).

Name: Private
Mnemonic: This is a little triangle that's almost completely closed off. When you want to be alone, you hide in a place where you can be in private. That's why this is the private radical. You're closing yourself off to the rest of the world, with just a little peephole.

Name: Rice Paddy
Mnemonic: In Japan rice paddies are made up of square fields with irrigation lines going between them. See the four rice paddies with water flowing between and around them? That's why this radical is rice paddy.

Name: Small
Mnemonic: You see two fins around a barb, but when you look closer, you realize those fins are actually two tiny fish. Think how small these fins (and fish) would have to be to look so much smaller than an already small barb. Talk about small fry… Yeah, that's why this is the radical for small.

Name: Stand
Mnemonic: This looks like someone in a standing position with legs planted firmly on the ground, spreading their arms out in a T-pose to maintain balance. So that makes this the radical for stand.

Name: Stop
Mnemonic: There's a stick and a giant toe stuck in the ground. Imagine walking along and seeing these things in your path. What would you do? Most likely come to a complete stop. You know, because of the toe. I guess a normal stop sign wasn't good enough, so they also put up this big toe to really get people to stop.

Name: Street
Mnemonic: Imagine viewing this one from above — looks like a couple of streets, right? Maybe a three-way intersection at the top there? Well, that's why this is the radical for street.

Name: Sword
Mnemonic: This is the sword radical. Imagine you're looking at the top of someone's head. They're swinging a sword. The horizontal part is the blade, and the legs are the afterimage.

Name: Thousand
Mnemonic: You have a slide supported by a big cross, which makes it so strong it can hold a lot of people at once. How many? A THOUSAND! Imagine a thousand people going down this slide. You can hear a voice trying to count them as they go: 'ONE! TWO! THREE HUNDRED! FIVE HUNDRED!' and so on. Finally the last person slides down and the voice calls out: 'A THOUSAND!' You think it's over, but just as that group finishes, in come another thousand…

Name: Treasure
Mnemonic: This radical is treasure because 'X marks the spot,' as they say. Doesn't it look like the X on a pirate treasure map? You want to go find that treasure now, right?!

Name: Water
Mnemonic: This is the radical for water. It's the water radical because it kind of looks like water coming out of a faucet and splashing everywhere. See how it flows off in different directions too? Very water-like! As water-like as a radical can be, anyway…

Name: White
Mnemonic: Add a drop of the sun to something and it will turn it white. The sun is really strong, so even a single drop will burn anything white. Why do you think so many beaches are white? Even the drops of sunblock you use to stop the sun's rays is white. So when you think of sun drops, think white.

Name: Writing
Mnemonic: This looks like a stool with a lid on it, but it's actually a desk for writing. Do you see it? You can even see the pen sticking up in the middle. Think of all the beautiful writing that's been produced here. Letters, novels, essays — any kind of writing you can think of.

Name: Ball
Mnemonic: The king has a big drop of liquid in his hand... but then he bounces it! The drop was really a ball.

Name: Book
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for book first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means book as well. Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are origin, real, and main. You can figure this out by thinking about how books mainly have their origins in real life.

Name: Child
Mnemonic: The child radical and the child kanji are exactly the same.

Name: Circle
Mnemonic: What's something with nine sides? Just add a drop and you'll have something that's almost a circle.

Name: Correct
Mnemonic: There is a line on the ground so you stop, making a giant sign pop up that says CORRECT! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you.

Name: Dirt
Mnemonic: The dirt radical and the dirt kanji are the same!

Name: Dog
Mnemonic: The dog radical and dog kanji are exactly the same!

Name: Evening
Mnemonic: The evening radical and the evening kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.

Name: Exit
Mnemonic: There are two mountains in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the exit before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.

Name: Eye
Mnemonic: The eye radical and eye kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.

Name: Fire
Mnemonic: The fire radical and the fire kanji are the same as each other.

Name: Five
Mnemonic: The five radical and the five kanji are the same.

Name: Four
Mnemonic: Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your legs end up inside your mouth. You have bent your body in all the wrong ways in order to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with four sides.

Name: Hand
Mnemonic: The hand radical and the hand kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!

Name: Heaven
Mnemonic: The radical heaven is the same as the kanji heaven, making this an easy kanji to memorize.

Name: King
Mnemonic: The king radical and the king kanji are the same!

Name: Left
Mnemonic: Narwhals do construction with their left hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!

Name: Middle
Mnemonic: The radical middle and the kanji middle are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.

Name: Moon
Mnemonic: The moon kanji is made up of the moon radical. This kanji is also used to mean month. This should be EZPZ as long as you know the radicals already!
ReadingMnemonic: The moon really gets (げつ) to your guts (がつ). Staring at the moon for too long will give you terrible indigestion, so be careful! Use the げつ reading when this kanji means "moon", in words like "moonlight". Use げつ for counting months, and saying things like "last month and "next month", too. Go for がつ in the names of months, like "January".

Name: Rice Paddy
Mnemonic: The rice paddy radical and the rice paddy kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise. Just know your radicals, and you will know your kanji as well.
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading た, we use the word "taco." Smell the tacos. Touch the tacos. Taste the tacos. This is definitely a very strange rice field.

Name: Right
Mnemonic: Narwhal mouths are on the right side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake. Imagine looking at a narwhal from the front. No mouth. Now look at it from the right. Mouth!
ReadingMnemonic: How did we know to look from the right, though? Because the youths (ゆう) figured it out. Youths think in ways that older people usually don't. That's why they can see the swirls on cereal, hear the music behind noise, and of course, look at things from the right side. Imagine a bunch of youths walking in a group and looking at everything from the right. You remember when you were a youth and you used to look at everything from one side too.

Name: Six
Mnemonic: Just imagine a beast with a lid for a head and fins for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number six is the devil's number. Imagine this beast doing various crazy things, the crazier the better (to help you remember). Make sure all these things are associated with the devil and the devil's number (six), so you can remember the meaning of this kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word rock. Sing along with the monster, if it helps you to remember the reading of this kanji.

Name: Small
Mnemonic: The small radical and the small kanji are exactly the same. Knowing radicals sure is nice, huh?
ReadingMnemonic: This small kanji would be the perfect gift to give to the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun loves little things, and the little kanji represents all of that. You read that right, shougun is written with a long う sound. Make sure you spell it right from now on!

Name: Stand
Mnemonic: The radical stand and the kanji stand are the same thing, so now you know them both. If you're keeping up with your radical studies, you're also keeping up with your kanji studies!
ReadingMnemonic: Think of someone who has to stand up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the Ritz (りつ). Imagine the doormen being extra straight… too straight in their standing. On their uniform is “The Ritz” written in fine lettering, and as you walk past them, they stand up straight and say “Welcome to the Ritz!” Whatever you do, while you’re thinking about it, make sure you think about how they stand up so straight, and associate it with these doormen, who work, specifically, at the Ritz. If you effectively imagine all this, you should be able to remember this on’yomi. Go through it like it’s a movie in your head!

Name: Street
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both street. As long as you know the radical street, you know the kanji street.
ReadingMnemonic: So you're walking down this street, and off in the distance you see the silhouette of somebody. A lady. Big, black curly hair and red eyes. It is the street-woman, Mrs. Chou (ちょう). Mrs. Chou is a character you'll see a lot throughout WaniKani, anytime the reading is ちょう like this one. A lore will develop around her, so the more vividly you can imagine your Mrs. Chou right now, the easier things will get later. In general, she's a mean, evil woman, so as long as you imagine her within those parameters, you're good. And, when I say she is a "street-woman" in the mnemonic, I don't mean she is homeless. She has a nice, middle-class home that's not outside of her financial means. What I'm saying is she wanders the streets looking for evil things to do. These are HER streets. So whenever you see the street radical, know that Mrs. Chou is probably going to show up!

Name: Sun
Mnemonic: The sun radical and sun kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember day as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky. The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!
ReadingMnemonic: There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち. This reading will be easier to remember if you know of Friedrich Nietzsche... so do your research and learn about him if you don't. He's a pretty historical dude. Imagine the sun totally pissed off, too. It makes a grunting noise as it builds up a sun beam to blast him off the face of the earth.

Name: Sword
Mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is sword, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese sword? That's right, the most common is a katana, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well. This kanji also looks a lot like the kanji 力. To avoid getting them confused, remember that this one is missing the little nubbin at the top, because 90% of the power comes from the sword to cut your enemies down (which is why the sword kanji is 90% of the power kanji).
ReadingMnemonic: So now you have this sweet katana in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to とうきょう (Tokyo). とうきょう has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to とうきょう. Imagine trying to travel to とうきょう with your katana. Airport security is not happy with you trying to take a katana on the plane, so you get a full cavity search. I hope you don't have any other swords hidden anywhere.

Name: Talent
Mnemonic: On the ground you put barbs at the bottom of a slide. This is your special talent. When you go down the slide, you fly right past the barbs like some kind of daredevil. Any normal kid would land on the barbs and get hurt, but you have this talent. Imagine yourself placing the barbs in front of the slide, thinking about how talented you are. It took years of training to perfect this talent. But it was worth it. Everyone on the playground respects you now.
ReadingMnemonic: But then people start to say that no human could have so much talent, that you must be a cyborg (さい). Are you really a talented cyborg? Cyborgs have brain implants and cool bionic limbs, so they're basically the most talented people around.

Name: Thousand
Mnemonic: This kanji looks like and means the same thing as the radical, which makes it particularly easy to remember. As long as you know the radical thousand then you know the kanji thousand as well!
ReadingMnemonic: Remember the thousand people going down the slide on a cross in the radical 千? Turns out each one of them was carrying a thousand cents (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what a thousand times a thousand cents would come out to. It's quite a lot, actually. Problem is, as they all tumble down the slide the change falls out of their pockets, so there's a thousand times a thousand cents scattered all over on the floor under the slide.

Name: Tree
Mnemonic: This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both tree and tree are the same in looks and meaning. So, how are those radicals doing? Do you know them well?
ReadingMnemonic: You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Suddenly, you trip and fall. The trees start to mock (もく) you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked as you pull yourself up off the ground. Feel the shame, feel the irritation. Make yourself want to run away from those dumb trees that are mocking you.

Name: Water
Mnemonic: The water radical and the water kanji are the same. So as long as you know the radicals, you know the kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine a lake (i.e. a whole bunch of water). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire swing (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you are swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very sweet. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is). I know that was a long one, but try to imagine all the different bits. Try to feel the feelings (cold, smell, etc) too. The more you create in this fake memory (which you’re using to remember and associate water with すい (swing)) the more likely you are to end up remembering enough to make it happen. Especially when it comes to the senses part, the more vividly you imagined it, the more likely you are to remember the on’yomi.

Name: White
Mnemonic: The radical white and the kanji white are the same. Study your radicals hard! Most important thing!
ReadingMnemonic: The white team was the first to be able to hack (はく) the white iPhone. Imagine two teams (black and white), wearing their team colors, working really hard on hacking the iPhone. It is a huge contest, and people are watching with a lot of tension, to see who will hack the white iPhone first. Feel that tension, and see the colors separating them so vividly. The colors are important, and the excitement of the winner holding up the hacked iPhone is too.

Name: Writing
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for writing first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means writing as well. If you can't remember the radical for writing, maybe you could try… writing it down?
ReadingMnemonic: This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine writing a big X (or even a big 文) on all your buns, then showing them to the bun monster. Watch as he turns and goes at the sight of the writing, all disappointed. Not today, bun monster.

Name: Yen
Mnemonic: The combination of radicals for this kanji may not be obvious at first, but if you look carefully you'll see it. The lid is inside the head for this kanji because it's holding something in. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of yen coins, the currency of Japan! Another thing that will help is to associate the word round to this kanji, because it has both of these meanings. Both are right, and if you learn one that's better than not learning either, but maybe if you think about how round the coins themselves are inside this person's head, you'll remember this one too.
ReadingMnemonic: What does the word yen sound like? It sounds like えん. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a "ye" sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an "e" sound, which is why yen = えん! Picture these round えん in your mind. Maybe look some up online too, just to be safe.

Name: Arrow
Mnemonic: This is a gun on top of a big person. The gun is big too, obviously. Why is this big guy's gun so big? Because it shoots arrows! Bullets are pretty small, so the guns that shoot them can be any size. But you need a big gun if you want to shoot a big arrow, right? That's why this is the radical for arrow.

Name: Canopy
Mnemonic: This is a canopy. See the cloth draping down and the little point at the middle holding it up? You could sit under here and enjoy a bright summer day without getting any sun!

Name: Direction
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a dude running off to the right. He's heading in a very distinct direction. Which direction was it again?

Name: Door
Mnemonic: This one looks like a flag, but don't be fooled — it's got a line over the top of it, kind of like a door frame. That makes this a little door. Specifically a swinging door, with the vertical line on the left being its door hinge. Kind of a weird door, it's true, but you can see it, right?

Name: Dry
Mnemonic: This looks like a clothesline pole you would dry clothes on. It's got two very straight horizontal poles, for maximum drying efficiency. If you were gonna dry your clothes, you'd dry them on this thing.

Name: Father
Mnemonic: This is the father radical, since you can see a very fatherly face in it — two droopy eyes at the top, a big nose in the middle, and a mustache flaring out at the bottom. Sort of a generic older gentleman father-type face, isn't it?

Name: Fingers
Mnemonic: This looks like a long index finger bent at the bottom, with several other stubby fingers growing out of it on either side. That makes it the fingers radical. A bit creepy, but imagine how easily you could grip something or scratch your back with fingery fingers like these. Pretty nice, right?

Name: Fur
Mnemonic: Do you remember the hair radical? This is like that, except now the hair is attached to a tail. Animals don't usually have hair though. Instead, they have fur.

Name: Hat
Mnemonic: Do you know those rice paddy hats? The ones shaped just like this radical? That's why this radical is a hat.

Name: Heart
Mnemonic: Take a good look at this one. It kind of looks like a heart. Not the heart emoji kind, but a real-deal beating heart. Basically, there's a lump in the middle (the heart), and three lines that make up the arteries. Okay, so it's not the most anatomically correct heart, but just look at those floppy arteries going in and out, doing their thing and keeping you alive. What's not to love?

Name: Ice
Mnemonic: Remember the radical for drop (of liquid)? Looks like it's shattered into two pieces here, which means it must be ice now. You know, since a drop could only break in two after turning into ice.

Name: Life
Mnemonic: Remember the sprout from the dirt radical? This looks like that, but wait a minute… there's some extra growth now! This thing is so full of life! It's even got a big, slide-shaped leaf growing on the top left. That's why it's the life radical.

Name: Now
Mnemonic: This is the radical for now. It's a bit tough to see, but it kind of looks like a fancy clock. The 𠆢 is the top part hanging over the clock. The ラ shows a triangular clock face with a little cuckoo on top, peeking out to tell you this means now — right now!

Name: Old
Mnemonic: Put a cross in the mouth of a container full of all the old things you no longer need. They've all served their purpose but have gotten old, so it's now time to let them rest in peace under the cross. Goodbye, old things!

Name: Poop
Mnemonic: For better or worse, this looks enough like the poop emoji (💩) to make this the poop radical. Try to remember it for its distinct outline. If it helps you can also note the private radical on the bottom of this one, since you should probably be in private when you poop…

Name: Roof
Mnemonic: This is a roof ー a flat roof with a little chimney sticking out. How cute!

Name: Spoon
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a spoon! Well, a spoon that's been bent a lot by an angry person or a psychic. Go grab a spoon and try to bend it into this shape. Then hold on to it so you'll never forget that this is the spoon radical!

Name: Stone
Mnemonic: A leaf growing out of a… mouth?? Look again and see the mouth is actually made of stone. The leaf here was just growing out of a crack on the side. Makes this stone mouth sculpture look kinda elegant, if you ask me. And obviously leaves don't grow on mouths, so whenever you see a leaf on a mouth, remember it's gotta be stone.

Name: Stool
Mnemonic: This looks just like a folding stool, am I right?

Name: Task
Mnemonic: This looks like a little whiteboard to keep track of your tasks for the day. It's got three little legs on the bottom. And see those blank squares? They're sticky notes you can write your tasks on. Work tasks, school tasks, WaniKani reviews… So what are your tasks for today? Imagine putting them in those little squares.

Name: Towel
Mnemonic: There's something draped over that stick. It's a towel! It's the kind of towel you clean with, so it's sort of old and crusty, which is why it holds its square shape even when it's hanging on the stick like that.

Name: Triceratops
Mnemonic: The three horns represent the triceratops, one of the most awesome dinosaurs ever.

Name: Window
Mnemonic: See the criss-cross in the almost-square shape? That's the frames of a big window you can look out of. It's not perfectly shaped like a rice field, it's more artistic. That's why this is a window and 田 is not.

Name: Winter
Mnemonic: This is the radical for winter. It looks like a skier going downhill (to the left), with their skis out in front and their poles out behind them. And when do people ski? In winter!

Name: Arrow
Mnemonic: The arrow radical and the arrow kanji are the same. Sort of a "straight" shot to memorizing this kanji, you know? Just know your radicals and you'll know this kanji!
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the reading や we use the word “Yankees” (like the evil baseball team, go M’s!). Imagine the arrow as a human-sized living thing with legs, arms, and clothes, though. Strangely, it’s able to walk around even though it's an arrow. It has some kind of agenda. Make it a bit evil, if you can. What a strange thing…

Name: City
Mnemonic: You lift the lid off a manhole and there's a towel with the name of a city on it. Picture this towel with the name of a city on it. Any city you like. Maybe it's your city!
ReadingMnemonic: This city must have a lot of sheep (し) because there is a sheep monogram on the towel. It's the sheep city. Imagine a city that has a sheep for its mascot. This city was built on sheep, don't you say a bad word about sheep when you're there.

Name: Cow
Mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for cow are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough. To distinguish this from the "noon" kanji (午), try thinking of the bit poking out of the top of this kanji as a tuft of hair on the cow's head — a cow lick, if you like.
ReadingMnemonic: Have you ever heard of わぎゅう (wagyu) beef? That ぎゅう is this ぎゅう. I hope you know what わぎゅう beef is, otherwise this will be a difficult one to learn.

Name: Cut
Mnemonic: If you have seven swords, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to cut something. Take these seven swords and swing them around. Cut everything in your path, including yourself. Then, think about how dumb it was to try to use seven swords at once, and then feel the pain of the cut you gave yourself. Ouch, ouch ouch.
ReadingMnemonic: Because having seven swords for yourself is too much, you decide to take the swords and divide them up amongst pairs of people. You cut them into pairs, and give sets (せつ) to everyone who needs them in the village. Just make sure you think about how you need to give them away in sets, and not anything else. This is the most important thing to think about in your head as you're trying to establish the mnemonic for your kanji reading memory. It's gotta be sets.

Name: Direction
Mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for direction are the same! Huzzah! The only direction you need to go in is forward, it's always the right way.
ReadingMnemonic: What direction do you always know? Which direction do you always want to go? Home (ほう). Something about your home always stays with you, no matter how far away you go. So if you're lost and you don't know which direction to go, just think of home! Close your eyes and picture your home in your mind. Can you tell which direction it is from where you are?

Name: Door
Mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for door are the same! Time to open the door to the reading part of this mnemonic.
ReadingMnemonic: You open the door and immediately get it closed back on your toe (と), literally causing your toe to explode. Feel the pain of your toe going away. Think about the other side of the door, where your toe is probably rolling around after it blasted off your foot.

Name: Fat
Mnemonic: You have a big person here, with an extra drop of something below their thigh, hanging down. That's fat right there. This person has fat hanging off their fat. Maybe you should touch the fat to see what it is... feel it, and squeeze it. It'll help you to remember that this kanji means "fat."
ReadingMnemonic: This fat person also has a fat tie (たい). It's really thick and luxurious. Imagine them tying their lovely fat tie. Or imagine them trying to tie the tie, but they just can't get it, so you have to help them out. You've never held such a fat tie before!

Name: Father
Mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for father are the same. No, I am not your father... but this kanji / radical set is!
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine your father is Cheech (ちち) from Cheech and Chong. Hopefully you know who they are. If not, think about your father laughing like this: ちちちちちちちち〜！

Name: Few
Mnemonic: You have a small slide. The thing about small slides is that they can only fit a few people at a time. Imagine a small slide (how could you not, after you see the radicals?) with only a few people on it, trying to move forward. Only a few people are required to create a slide traffic jam, though. :(
ReadingMnemonic: Why is there a little traffic jam on the slide? Because the Shougun (しょう) is using the slide and he loves little things. He's forcing everyone to stop and watch, even though there are people backed up behind him. How inconsiderate. Imagine this in your head. A traffic jam on a little slide, all because the shougun is using it. Picture some caution tape, orange cones, and Japanese secret service members all making sure no one gets close to the shougun while he slides. A few people are crying. They want to slide, they want to leave.

Name: Friend
Mnemonic: A narwhal sitting on a stool is your friend. Imagine that narwhal sitting there. It waves its flipper and says "hi friend" to you.
ReadingMnemonic: "Hi friend," says the narwhal. "I must warn you about all the youths." (ゆう) Your narwhal friend goes on to warn you about all those youths, and how they will try to take away your friendship with their good looks and young ages.

Name: Fur
Mnemonic: Fur and fur are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean hair, too, though more like furry hair. Just make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise it won't be as simple as I'd hoped.
ReadingMnemonic: With fur, whisk your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, it's fur). You're surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel and smell like? Now it's time to get rid of it. There's just too much hair! To get rid of it, you'll need to mow (もう) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (they're loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think "fur → in the fur → get rid of the fur → mow the fur," in that order. That'll get you to "mow," which will help you to remember the on’yomi. Smell the fur as you mow it down. Feel it flying everywhere. It's giant, so it must be pretty intense. Make it more intense to help yourself to remember the reading of this kanji better.

Name: Half
Mnemonic: A triceratops is lying out to dry. But it's so big, and it's laying on its side, so only half of it gets dry. Imagine the triceratops on its side, then imagine it getting up. When it stands up normally, half of its body is soaking wet still. It's a half-n-half triceratops right now.
ReadingMnemonic: "You're half wet and half dry! I will cut you in half with my laser blaster so you're proper again," a voice says. It is  Han Solo (はん), the anti-establishment guy who hates when things aren't even. Imagine him using his blaster to shoot the poor triceratops in half, perfectly down the wet-dry line of its body.

Name: Heart
Mnemonic: The radical heart and the kanji heart are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free! Also, make sure you know the radicals by heart, it'll help you to learn more effectively, just like with this kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: The heart, where is it stored in your body? Most people thought it was in the chest, but in reality, your heart is stored in your shin (しん). This is when I start kicking you in the shin and you imagine feeling the pain of getting kicked there. As I kick you in the shin, the stress is getting too much for your poor heart inside your shin. Poor shin, and poor heart.

Name: Inside
Mnemonic: Your head has a person inside it! And, you have no idea how to get them out. They're inside for good, and it's freaking you out. As in, there's a little person in there, running around, controlling your brain. People think you're crazy, but you know better... He's inside there, doing evil things.
ReadingMnemonic: You know this kanji means inside, so you can keep thinking about the person that’s inside you, running around. You finally discover him, and try to take him out, but before you can, he pulls out a knife (ない) and threatens to cut you if you do anything irrational. Imagine him holding the knife out, threatening to stab your brain. You’re in a conundrum here. If you don’t take him out, you’re in trouble, but if you do try to take him out, he might stab you in the brain with his knife. Try to think a way around this situation, focusing mainly on his knife.

Name: Letter
Mnemonic: The roof child stands upon the roof, holding up a single letter, a single character, a single symbol for the world to see. More people can see this character since the kid is on the roof.
ReadingMnemonic: The character that is being shown is "J," which stands for Jesus (じ). The kid wants everyone to see this letter and symbol. Imagine the child holding up the letter yelling at everyone who passes that the "J" stands for "Jesus." And yes, this kid just loves the Big Lebowski.

Name: Life
Mnemonic: The life radical and the life kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both. Study your radicals and you'll read good.
ReadingMnemonic: You can save life or take it away with your new saber (せい). This is the saber you got from doing the correct thing (remember?), and now you need to figure out how to use it with this life. So what do you do? Imagine having someone's life in the palm of your hands. It's up to you whether you protect it with your saber or... well... do the other thing sabers are for.

Name: Machine
Mnemonic: You have a private mouth that's a machine. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you. Doesn't this kanji look like a machine mouth? Now wouldn't you want to keep that private from the people you know?
ReadingMnemonic: To make sure they can't tell what's machine and what's human, you dye (だい) the mouth to make it look like skin. You find dye the same shade as your normal mouth and just slap it on there. Imagine being so afraid that people will find out about your machine mouth that you have to dye it to match a normal human mouth. Oh, when will this discrimination against machine-kind end?!

Name: Mother
Mnemonic: Someone breaks part of your window. Who did this? It was your mother! See how the vertical bar is broken and your window frame is all messed up now? Why would your mother do such a thing?! Her hand is bleeding too…
ReadingMnemonic: Suddenly your mother points her bloodied finger at you and laughs, "Haha (はは)!" She keeps laughing, haha haha haha, over and over. You feel even more alarmed. You thought your mother was going to explain or apologize, but instead she's pointing and saying, "Haha," over and over.

Name: Noon
Mnemonic: The slide is dry at noon. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide. Picture all the kids out sliding on the slide at noon during their lunch break. It's hot and dry and they're very happy.
ReadingMnemonic: Noon also happens to be the time Godzilla (ご) decided to attack for the same reasons: it's dry and kids are using the slide. Watch in horror as Godzilla's giant foot crushes all the kids and their slide at exactly noon. You'd better go...

Name: North
Mnemonic: If you rub an ice stick against a spoon, the spoon will always point north. This is because the ice stick creates a magnetic field that makes the spoon act like a compass needle. That's science, friends! Imagine rubbing a stick made of ice against a spoon. Now watch the spoon spin and spin and spin until it stops, pointing directly towards the north. This is a very handy trick if you get lost on your way to the north pole. Plenty of ice sticks around there, after all.
ReadingMnemonic: You go north, and notice that everyone has a keytar (きた). You know, those keyboards that people hold and play like a guitar? Yep, those things are called keytars. And for some reason, in the north, everyone has a keytar. They're basically obsessed with them. North = keytar. Quite simple.

Name: Now
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for now first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means now as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Right now the condors (こん) are in danger! Not next week, not next year, right now! Haven't you heard that deforestation and pollution are killing all of the condors?! Go outside right now and do something to save the condors. If you don't do something right now there won't be enough time left!

Name: Old
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for old first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means old as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Old things are misunderstood by the 子s (こ) of the world. Imagine a 子 looking at old things. A record player. A Game Boy. A cassette player. Kids just don't get old things.

Name: Outside
Mnemonic: You're known to get the ailment evening toe, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go outside. After imagining your evening toe overheating, rush outside to fix it. It's the best way to prevent fire toe, which is way worse. In the evening it's nice and cold outside too, so feel this on your skin, and feel the cold air on your toe, which is starting to get some relief.
ReadingMnemonic: You go outside (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, Guy (がい) Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him! If you don’t know Guy Fawkes, you should do a little reading up on him to make this mnemonic make sense. Also, Anonymous People wear a Guy Fawkes mask, if that helps any.

Name: Part
Mnemonic: The fins that fell onto my sword were sliced into many parts. Following this logic, this also means minute, which is part of an hour, and divide, which is the action of splitting something into many parts. Picture the fins falling onto the sword, and being divided into many parts. And if those fins represented hours, they’d be divided into minutes. Makes sense, right?
ReadingMnemonic: Now that the fins have been cut into neat parts, it's time to cut something else: buns (ぶん). This is how you feed your people: neatly divided, delicious buns. Picture these delicious buns divided into perfectly shaped parts. Yummy.

Name: Pull
Mnemonic: If you have a bow and a stick you need to pull the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything. Imagine taking a stick and pulling it back into your bow. Imagine how hard you have to pull. This thing is really strong!
ReadingMnemonic: When you pull the bow back, your body strains and you feel an immense heat (ひ) rise inside of you. You keep pulling and the heat grows hotter and hotter. Imagine using all your strength to pull on this bow. Imagine the heat rising in your body. There's sweat dripping down your face. It's so hot, but you have to keep pulling!

Name: Stop
Mnemonic: The stop radical is the same as the stop kanji. Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: You have to stop because there is a sheep (し) in front of you. You try to walk around the sheep, but it moves to stop in front of you again. Every time the sheep stops you stop too. Imagine the fluffy wool of the sheep, stopping you from moving forward. You can't push past it, no matter how hard you try.

Name: Task
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for task first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means task as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Today, your task is to eat yogurt (よう). It's nutritious, it's delicious, and I'm telling you to do it, so you have to. A task is basically just something you have to do, so that's what this is. Eat your yogurt. (Gogurt doesn't count, don't @ me.)

Name: Ten Thousand
Mnemonic: You cut the leaf with your sword into ten thousand pieces! If you can get to ten thousand different pieces, then that means your sword is absolutely perfect. If your sword dulls before you get to ten thousand, you have to throw it away.
ReadingMnemonic: Now that you have ten thousand pieces of tiny leaf paper, you decide to turn them into a manga (まん)! Each little leaf piece will become a panel. Carefully draw your manga onto these ten thousand leaf pieces. Maybe you even use your sword again to give them some textured details. You're so creative and talented!

Name: Wide
Mnemonic: The canopy you use in private is very wide. You want your private canopy to be wide so you can sprawl out under it as much as you want. No one's going to come in and tell you to close your legs or sit up straight. So it can be as wide as you like!
ReadingMnemonic: You like being wide because it makes you feel like a different person. But not just any person, like a super hero (ひろ)! Picture yourself lying under your wide, private canopy pretending to be a super hero on the ground. You're stretching a nice, wide super hero pose, like you're flying through the sky.

Name: Winter
Mnemonic: You’ve got a winter with lots of ice. But doesn't any winter have lots of ice? Exactly. That's why this is just winter. You go outside. There's ice everywhere. It's freezing cold. Yep, this is definitely winter.
ReadingMnemonic: Winter is also the time of year you give out presents: "One fu' you, one fu' you and… one fu' you (ふゆ)!" Your pronunciation might be a little weird. But that’s okay. People still love your presents, and the way you say "fu’ you!"

Name: Alligator
Mnemonic: See the mouth and long, fang-like teeth of this alligator, which is facing to the right? You wouldn't want to get your hand stuck in there, that's for sure.

Name: Bamboo
Mnemonic: See how tall the stalks are with little bushy things at the top? It kind of looks like bamboo, if you use your imagination.

Name: Bed
Mnemonic: You'll have to complete the line on the right side in your mind, but see the rectangle bed and the pillows? This is totally a bed. That missing line is where you pulled back the covers when you got up this morning.

Name: Beggar
Mnemonic: Doesn't this look like someone on their knees, holding their clasped hands out and begging for something (forgiveness, their life, a promotion, etc.)? That's why this radical is known as the beggar.

Name: Branch
Mnemonic: There's a cross branching off of this stool. Since it's branching out, we'll just call this the branch radical. I guess the tree this stool was made of is coming back to life in the form of a branch.

Name: Car
Mnemonic: Doesn't this look like a top-down view of the frame of a car? There are the axles at the top and bottom, and the body in the middle between them. That's why this is the car radical.

Name: Center
Mnemonic: Remember the guy from the big radical? Here he's bending his arms up to fasten some kind of belt, right across the center of his body. It's one of those belts that just goes across your waist, which is actually perfect for such a big guy, since he really needs to secure his center (of gravity).

Name: Ceremony
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a person with a long dress running behind them. That's because they're all dressed up to go to a ceremony. You usually have to wear a long dress (or something formal) if you're going to a big ceremony, right? So when you see this radical, think of all the different ceremonies you might have to go to in your life and what you'll need to wear.

Name: Cliff
Mnemonic: See the cliff? It's facing to the left. What do you think this cliff is jutting out over? Maybe an ocean, or a valley? Cliffs love to jut out over things like that.

Name: Ear
Mnemonic: This is the ear radical, since it looks like an ear. As much as a radical can, anyway. Those two middle lines are the ridges that guide the sound into your ear, and the lines that stick out to the right are where the ear attaches to your head.

Name: Energy
Mnemonic: This is the radical for energy. If you imagine a train under this radical, then the lines would be steam bursting out of it, flowing back from the front of the train (on the left) as it goes chugging along. Steam was the best way to generate energy back in the day, you know? That's why this is the radical for energy.

Name: Flowers
Mnemonic: See the little things sticking out of the ground? Those little things are pretty little flowers.

Name: Foot
Mnemonic: This is the foot radical. See the person doing a flying dragon kick to the right? What do they hit the target with? Obviously their foot. Imagine that foot coming straight at your face. At that point, your only hope is that it's clean. Nobody wants a foot to the face, especially not a filthy foot.

Name: Forehead
Mnemonic: Sure, this forehead is a bit square, but that's because it's the top part of the head (冂) radical. This is just the forehead part of that! You can even imagine this as the forehead of Frankenstein's monster, since his forehead was pretty square too.

Name: Hole
Mnemonic: You have a roof on top of what looks like a volcano. What's the roof covering? It's definitely covering the hole at the top. I guess someone thought if they built a roof on the hole, none of the lava could come out. But isn't there a hole in the chimney? Guess their theory had some holes in it… Oh no, now lava is coming through the hole. RUN!!! RUN!!!!!!!!

Name: Horns
Mnemonic: Can you see the horns? You could put these horns on anything. Donkeys, people, monkeys, and so on. That's exactly what we'll be doing when we learn kanji that have horns too.

Name: Insect
Mnemonic: This looks like the middle radical on top of a sideways leaf. What can you often find sitting on the middle of a leaf? An insect. Insects looove sitting right in the middle of leaves. That's why this is the insect radical.

Name: Leader
Mnemonic: This radical technically means person (like 人), but we're going to shift the meaning a little bit. It's kind of like the person radical, but it's taller and skinnier, standing above the others and raising its fist to lead them. That's why this is a leader, not a regular person.

Name: Loiter
Mnemonic: The leader (ｲ) radical has a little something extra on top of him — he's got a casual cap on because it's his day off. And what does he like to do on his day off? He likes to loiter. Look at him just loitering around. What a loiterer.

Name: Man
Mnemonic: A rice paddy needs power, and that power comes from a man. Picture a rice paddy full of thick, wet mud. It's no easy field to work in, but this powerful man will bend over to rake and hoe tirelessly to make sure it thrives. What a man!

Name: Master
Mnemonic: The king is hovering a drop of water over his head. He's acquired the ability to manipulate water at will, making him the master of all water! If you think about how all life depends on water, that really makes him the master of everything…

Name: Measurement
Mnemonic: Have you ever used one of those triangular rulers? This looks just like one of those, because this is the measurement radical. Just think of all the angles you could measure with this thing!

Name: Not
Mnemonic: This looks like a regular arrow, but it's not. Let's call it the "not arrow." It can not move forward, because it's been stopped by some kind of line above it. Every arrow wants to fly, but this one is not going anywhere. Look at it, being all negated like that. Well, that's just what this radical does. It nots things.

Name: Origin
Mnemonic: You have two lines with legs below them. And what is that bit above the legs? Well, it's where you came from — your origin. Yep, between two legs is where you originated, no matter how you look at it.

Name: Pi
Mnemonic: Obviously, this looks just like the good ol' 3.14 something-something all people are supposed to learn about. It's the math symbol that has to do with circles... pi!

Name: Plate
Mnemonic: This is a few plates drying on a rack. They're stacked together in a line. Imagine reaching out and grabbing one of those plates for yourself. And you only need one, so let's call this radical plate.

Name: Red
Mnemonic: A pile of dirt fell on you and now your legs and (scuba) fins are sticking out from under it, turning red. You know, because you've been stuck in the sun so long. Everything's all sunburned and red. Can scuba fins get a sunburn? Yeah, when it's red hot outside. That's why this means "red."

Name: Rice
Mnemonic: This is the radical for rice. Specifically raw rice, like the grain that grows out of the ground when rice is raw and fresh. When rice is particularly ripe, it'll kind of look like this at the top of the stalks. See the long leaves and the little rice tufts at the top? That's why this radical is "rice."

Name: Samurai
Mnemonic: The samurai radical looks a lot like the dirt radical. The difference is this one has a longer top horizontal line, which is for those broad warrior shoulders. The bottom line is also shorter, since it's the little cushion the samurai is sitting on. Samurai didn't just fight, you know. They sat on cushions and wrote poems and stuff too. This is a very sensitive samurai.

Name: See
Mnemonic: This eye has legs, since you have to let your eyes run over something in order to see it. That's why those eyes need legs — to see. They're wandering eyes, they want to see the world!!

Name: Shellfish
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a shellfish. What looks like the eye radical is its long spiral shell. The bottom part that looks like fins is its little legs poking out, helping the shellfish move around.

Name: Spikes
Mnemonic: On the ground there are a bunch of spikes coming out. You wouldn't want to step on those now, would you?

Name: Spirit
Mnemonic: This radical looks like some sort of spirit. It faces to the left with a big hood over its head, and creepy arms slanting downward at the sides. Can you picture it?

Name: Thread
Mnemonic: In some poop you find something small. You lean in, carefully pull it out, and realize it's a thread. What's that doing there? Well, it came from a cat, and cats love to eat thread when you aren't looking. And floss and hoodie strings and mouse tails… But this time, just thread.

Name: Umbrella
Mnemonic: This radical looks like an umbrella, specifically just the handle part. A good old curvy umbrella handle, so you can hang that umbrella on your arm when it stops raining.

Name: World
Mnemonic: Use your imagination to draw a circle outside this shape. The grids from the radical start to look like longitude and latitude lines on a globe, don't they? That's why this is the world.

Name: Bamboo
Mnemonic: The bamboo radical and the bamboo kanji are exactly the same! Just make sure you know your radicals!
ReadingMnemonic: Today is free bamboo day, so just take (たけ) all the bamboo you want. Really take as much bamboo as you could possibly hold. Take some bamboo, then take some more, and take more… It’s free after all.

Name: Car
Mnemonic: The radical car and the kanji car are exactly the same. Make sure you study your radicals... though don't do it while driving.
ReadingMnemonic: When we need to remember the reading しゃ, we use "shaman". The more fantastic you make this car, the better. Also, feel the surprise of a shaman getting out of this car. What a cool dude that shaman is.

Name: Center
Mnemonic: The radical for center and the kanji for center are exactly the same. That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji as well! How swell.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember that guy from the 央 radical fastening his belt across the center of his body? This guy always secures his belt at the center — not slightly to the left, not slightly to the right, but dead center. His precision is so mind-blowing that everyone watching can't help but say, "Ohh!"(おう). Next time you put a belt on, make sure it's in the exact center of your body. Heck, try it now. And don't forget to say "Ohh!" as you do it. It'll keep the reading for this kanji front and center in your mind.

Name: Copy
Mnemonic: The forehead of this beggar is on the ground. Except it’s not exactly the ground, it’s a giant copy machine, and he’s making copies of his forehead! Picture how ridiculous this beggar looks, taking copies of his forehead with the ground copy machine.
ReadingMnemonic: This ground copy machine can only be the work of one person: a shaman (しゃ)! This particular shaman’s specialty is being able to turn any surface into a copy machine at a swirl of his little shaman wand. Picture him running around in circles, doing a little dance and chant, and then the ground suddenly turning into one giant copy machine.

Name: Doing
Mnemonic: The leader samurai didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by doing. Imagine the leader samurai doing things. He's doing more than anyone else, no one can keep up with what he's doing.
ReadingMnemonic: He was doing things with sheep (し). He is the leader of the sheep clan, and he was able to do more with sheep than anyone else. That's why he's the leader. Picture the leader samurai doing lots of sheep things. He's shearing sheep. He's feeding sheep. He's doing everything you could possibly do, because he's the sheep samurai.

Name: Ear
Mnemonic: The ear radical and ear kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning. Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!
ReadingMnemonic: Put your hand to your ear and sing... "Mimimimimimiiiii!" (みみ) and listen to your tone with your ear. This is sort of a stereotypical singer sort of image. Make sure you concentrate a lot when you're listening to your mimimimiiii tone. In fact, why don't you do it out loud right now - make a little fool of yourself. It's fun, and it'll help you to remember!

Name: Early
Mnemonic: When the sun is over the cross it's time to go to church... which is so darn early. And if you want to get to church early, you need to be fast, otherwise you'll be too late. Imagine the sun coming up slowly, over the horizon. It then lines up with the cross, and at that moment, your alarm goes off, waking you up. You check the alarm clock, and instead of displaying the time, it just says EARLY and FAST on it, flashing in big red letters and alternating.
ReadingMnemonic: To remember the そう reading we use the word "soul." But you get your soul up early and head to the church fast anyway, because you're doing all of this for your soul in the first place!

Name: Energy
Mnemonic: You're looking for a treasure, but no normal treasure... a treasure that's a stash of energy. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine yourself finding it, and opening up a treasure chest. Out bursts a spirit ball of energy like you've never seen. Try to touch the energy spirit, it's pretty amazing. Is it solid? Does it shock you? What does it feel like? Be sure to imagine it out.
ReadingMnemonic: As you reach inside the energy spirit, you feel something hard inside. It's a large key (き) that gives you access to another treasure. You take the key and open another treasure that's nearby. Open it up and see what's inside. Imagine something spectacular.

Name: Flat
Mnemonic: If you want to dry your horns you need to lay them flat. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's peace. Imagine carefully taking off your horns and laying them flat on a paper towel. You have to smooth them out so they're as flat as possible.
ReadingMnemonic: Being flat isn't enough, so you cover the whole thing in hay (へい). Hay absorbs water, so you add a flat layer of it. Imagine carefully laying a flat layer of hay on top of your flat horns. You feel really at peace and... you're tired now. You decided to lie on top of the hay and take a nap while you wait for your horns to dry.

Name: Flower
Mnemonic: All these flowers were planted by your leader with nothing but a spoon. Now the whole place is absolutely full with beautiful flowers. Flowers everywhere. Your leader is a nice guy who wants there to be flowers for even future generations to enjoy. That’s why he’s painstakingly planting all these flowers with his spoon. Imagine watching him dig hole after hole with his little spoon just to plant some flowers for everyone.
ReadingMnemonic: But for some reason, the leader just can't stop planting flowers... He's going crazy. Maybe it's the pollen? Now there’s only one person that can save him: Hannah (はな). Hannah is the most reliable person you know. Whenever someone’s in any trouble, Hannah shows up and sets things right. Everyone needs a person like Hannah in their life. Especially the leader…

Name: Foot
Mnemonic: The radical for foot and the kanji for foot are exactly the same. Same kanjis and radicals make Jack a happy boy. You should also learn the other meaning as well, though, if you can.
ReadingMnemonic: What do you wear on your foot? You wear a sock (そく). Just think about your bare feet. Think about them too much. Feel how cold it is on your feet. Now, put on a sock to make it feel better. Ahhh, so nice!

Name: Hit
Mnemonic: Take your fingers to the street to hit some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting! Imagine: it's just you, your fingers, and the wild street. It's hitting time!
ReadingMnemonic: As you hit one chump after another, suddenly your dad (だ) comes marching out of your house. Uh oh. Dad caught you hitting, which, honestly, isn't a very nice thing to do, so he has every right to stop you. Now imagine your dad saying, "Don't do a hit!" over and over at you. "I'm sorry dad! But the streets were calling me!"

Name: Hole
Mnemonic: The hole radical and the hole kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular! Imagine yourself laughing at Ana while you point at her, continuing to jeer as Ana struggles to escape the hole. You’d help Ana out of the hole, but you’re too busy laughing at her.
ReadingMnemonic: Ana (あな) fell into a hole. Laugh at Ana and her unfortunate misfortune of having fallen into a hole like a ninny. Haha, Ana – you’re stupid and clumsy! Imagine yourself laughing at Ana while you point at her, continuing to jeer as Ana struggles to escape the hole. You’d help Ana out of the hole, but you’re too busy laughing at her.

Name: Hundred
Mnemonic: There is a leaf growing out of the sun! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a hundred! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth. Imagine flying toward the sun to see a hundred leaves growing together in the shape of one big leaf. You want to go closer!
ReadingMnemonic: You fly closer, counting all one hundred leaves when you hear a strange sound. You take off your space helmet and hear, "GUH HYUCK (ひゃく)!" You know that laugh... it's Goofy! On top of the hundredth leaf is Goofy laughing and waving around. He must have built this leaf tower to get your attention. Imagine hearing Goofy guh-hyuck over and over after you save him from being stranded on the sun. How would you feel being stuck in a cramped ship with laughing Goofy and his hundred leaves? Oh, you thought he would leave those behind? Nope, they saved him so you have to take them back too. Happy travels!

Name: Ice
Mnemonic: Add a drop of something magical to water and suddenly it turns into big block of ice, just like that. Imagine yourself adding that drop. What is it exactly? Something pretty potent, that's for sure. Now go ahead and touch the block of ice... wow, it's really cold — and only from one drop, too. Feel the burn on your finger from where you touched the ice.
ReadingMnemonic: When you think of ice, I want you to think of someone frozen with ice. Do you know anyone named Corey (こおり)? Anyone famous named Corey, perhaps Corey Feldman? Imagine this Corey person frozen solid with ice. How did this happen? Was it your fault? Imagine the situation that would get Corey frozen like this.

Name: Insect
Mnemonic: The insect radical and insect are the same in looks as well as and meaning. It's times like these when you gotta hope you're studying your radicals!
ReadingMnemonic: It's an insect! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A mush (むし) sound. Imagine little words that say "mush" flying out from under your foot as you mush the poor thing. What does a "mush" sound sound like? You'll have to come up with something unique to yourself, and focus on it to remember this reading.

Name: Man
Mnemonic: The radical for man and the kanji for man are exactly the same. That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji too! Man, kanji are easy sometimes.
ReadingMnemonic: When you think of a man, think of dawn (だん), because that man has to get up at dawn to power his rice paddy every day. Picture the man watching as the first light of dawn tints the sky pink and orange. Time to get to work, man!

Name: Master
Mnemonic: The radical master and the kanji master have the same meanings! Picture this master of water controlling the droplet as it flies around inside these chutes, like he's solving a difficult puzzle with it. Astounding!
ReadingMnemonic: Do you remember back to the radical mnemonic, where the master is floating a water drop above his head? Imagine back to there. Once you do, the most amazing thing happens. The master sends the drop of water into a chute (しゅ) and it goes careening through an intricate series of them. Picture this master of water controlling the droplet as it flies around inside these chutes, like he's solving a difficult puzzle with it. Astounding!

Name: Name
Mnemonic: What is the evening mouth? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so famous that everybody knows his name (“Evening Mouth.”). Imagine yourself going to the area you chose, and watching “Evening Mouth” speak. There are thousands of others there, wanting to see the giant floating mouth in the night sky. “Evening Mouth” then says “Everyone, what’s my name!?” and everyone shouts back “Evening Mouth!” in unison. “Evening Mouth” has certainly gotten really famous.
ReadingMnemonic: So, when does “Evening Mouth” appear? Turns out, “Evening Mouth” only comes out to talk in May (めい). You know this because it’s just starting to be spring, and when you look around (you’re watching “Evening Mouth” again) you see some spring flowers come up. You know what they say. April showers bring May Flowers. What do May Flowers bring? They bring “Evening Mouth,” baby.

Name: Not
Mnemonic: The radical not and the kanji not are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not! Actually, it does make it easy — the radicals make kanji wayyy easier, no?
ReadingMnemonic: To remember ふ we'll use the word "fool." Be sure to feel irritated at that person. Think in your head as they're telling these dumb "not" jokes how much of a fool they are... and how much of a fool you are for sitting here and listening to them.

Name: Number
Mnemonic: There's a mouth in the ground (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of prison you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of numbers that you don't understand. What are these numbers? What do they mean? Think over it for a while, get frustrated, and try to figure it out. You can't, though, so you probably won't ever get inside.
ReadingMnemonic: "You want to know the number to the hatch?" yells an old voice from inside. You say "yes," and the voice gives you the numbers and you're in! You go down into the prison, where there is one prisoner: Grandpa ごういち. Grandpa ごういち keeps saying numbers as you free him from the prison. Just one after another. Numbers numbers numbers. Hopefully old man ごういち isn't crazy.

Name: Origin
Mnemonic: The origin radical and the origin kanji are the same! Know your radicals!
ReadingMnemonic: The origin of everything can be found in Genji (げん). Genji is the name of the main character in the world's first ever novel, "The Tale of Genji." Genji's origin story is pretty important when it comes to mnemonics and Japanese literature. He's going to keep popping up on your kanji journey, so make sure you remember him!

Name: Other
Mnemonic: The leader of alligators... she's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. She's not a politician.. she's not a queen... She's one of the Other Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals. Imagine different groups of leaders - they're all dressed nice and normal.
