ReadingMnemonic: You want to get the valuable thing from inside the shellfish, but it's locked and you need to find the key (き). Search for the key! You find a bunch of keys, so you try to jam them all into the shellfish one by one, hoping one of them is the right key to get the valuable, hidden treasure.

Name: Vertical
Mnemonic: You see a thread that wants to loiter from some horns and you would be correct to assume that it would hang vertical. The thread wants to loiter and hang from one of the horns. When things hang from things, they usually hang vertical, so that’s what this thread is going to do. Look at this vertical thread as it hangs from the horns. Take hold of it and pull on the vertical thread. Feel it in your hand.
ReadingMnemonic: For some reason, Channing Tatum (たて) is strangely attracted to vertical pieces of hanging thread. Channing Tatum starts batting at the vertical thread like a cat. Look at Channing Tatum playing with this thread. He’s like a cat playing with a piece of yarn. Look at Mr. Tatum bouncing around batting at the thread like some silly feline.

Name: Work
Mnemonic: Boots give you the power to work! That's why so many professions require you to have work boots. Imagine putting your boots on and suddenly being filled with the power and energy to work hard and efficiently.
ReadingMnemonic: You need boots to give you the power to work for the King (きん) of England. Really, all work is for the King, since everything is for him. But even he wears boots. And they give him the power to uh... king over things. Picture yourself in work boots. Now picture the King in work boots. Yours are worn and beaten up and his are clean and look brand new. But at least you both have them, which means you both work at least a little!

Name: Worship
Mnemonic: Take your fingers and dry them. Then dry them again. This is what you do when you are in  worship. Once you go into your place of worship, and again before you leave. You have really sweaty fingers, and you can't worship anyone or anything if you have wet hands. So you dry them! Picture your sweaty, sweaty fingers. Dry them off before you enter a place of worship! No god wants to deal with your weird, damp hands.
ReadingMnemonic: Once you're dry and in wherever your worship is, you begin with a haiku (はい). Really all places of worship have their own version of the haiku, and heck, the 5-7-5 rule is just a guideline, so everyone is doing it pretty close to right anyway. Imagine being in your place of worship. Close your eyes and say a haiku:

Name: Belt
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means belt.

Name: Commander
Mnemonic: Who wears cleats and takes your measurements for so long that icicles start forming on your body? Your commander. The commander is very, very particular. And everyone knows the commander has to get everything exactly right. So taking your measurements takes SO long that icicles grow out of your nose. But that's okay. You have to impress your new commander, darn it!

Name: Sake
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a big, weird caterpillar bug thing. But, for the sake of everyone's sanity, we'll just call it sake, okay? Keep in mind, we mean sake as in "for the sake of X," not as in the alcoholic beverage!

Name: Shuriken
Mnemonic: See the shuriken stuck into the ground? In case you don't know, a shuriken is just a throwing star. Awesome ninjas use them. That's what's in this radical.

Name: Turtle
Mnemonic: There's a turtle shell inside this turtle radical. You can tell because there's a whole head and tail on this thing, making it a real turtle, not just a turtle shell.

Name: Bear
Mnemonic: The ability to boil is one of the main abilities of a bear. I bet you didn't know this, but a bear can boil whenever it wants. Imagine a bear heating itself up and boiling, its fur and skin bubbling and letting off steam.
ReadingMnemonic: A bear boiling in front of you should fill you with great honor. Or, as they say in Latin: Magma cum (くま) laude. You can also imagine a bear graduating in the top 5-10% of its class. Or, just imagine a bear saying "Cuma here!" to you.

Name: Boisterous
Mnemonic: Your mouth is wearing a mask so people won't realize you're the one being so boisterous as you eat your miso. If you cover your mouth with this mask, no one will know you're such a boisterous eater of miso. Okay, this kanji doesn't actually mean "miso," it just means "boisterous." But you'll pretty much only ever see it in the word for miso, so I figured I'd sneak it in here to prepare you for that… Thank me later.
ReadingMnemonic: You're being boisterous and having your miso outside when suddenly someone shoves soap (そ) in your mouth. "Even your mask can't hide that boisterous miso-eating. Quiet down and wash your mouth out with that soap!" they yell. Using your boisterous mouth, taste the disgusting soapy soap. The soap bubbles are already filling your mouth and stinging your tongue. This is the punishment for those who eat boisterously.

Name: Carve
Mnemonic: There is a circumference around someone's hair, as in, you can see a circle drawn around the top of their head. As you examine it closer, and pull at it a bit, you realize that someone has carved the hair off someone's head! Their hair has literally been carved out of their head, and you discovered it. Of course, the nastiness, the smell, and the feel should be applied to your imagination to make the mnemonic stronger.
ReadingMnemonic: When you think of all the people who could have done this... all the people who could have carved out someone's hair, only one person comes to mind, and that is Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She's the only person evil enough to do something like this. You can also imagine Mrs. Chou doing the act of carving someone's hair out, but that may just be too much.

Name: Cedar
Mnemonic: There’s a tree in your hair, I think it’s a cedar. How did that cedar tree get in your hair? Imagine having a cedar tree in your hair. It’s just a little tree, a sapling, but it’s pretty strange and awkward. It does smell nice though. Mmm… cedar.
ReadingMnemonic: Once the cedar is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A Sue guitar (すぎ), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it. Give Sue her Sue guitar. Hear Sue squeal with glee as she receives her Sue guitar.

Name: Chat
Mnemonic: The mouth of the World Tree, all it does is chat and talk. You'd think the World Tree's mouth would talk wisdom, but all it does is chat, chat, chat.
ReadingMnemonic: To chat or talk with the World Tree, just head over to Shaman Bay (しゃべ). The locals shorten Shaman Bay to "Sha Bay," because they always go there to 喋る with the World Tree. Imagine all the shamans hanging about in the bay.

Name: Cooking Pot
Mnemonic: You toss a pair of gold mustaches into your cooking pot and begin simmering them. Some people use bay leaves and whatnot, but where you're from, there's no seasoning you'd rather have in your cooking pot than a couple of gold mustaches. Smell the aromatic vapors as you simmer these gold mustaches in your cooking pot. You can see the gold whiskers slowly melting and turning into a delicious, shimmering broth.
ReadingMnemonic: Your spouse asks you if they can have a taste of what's in your cooking pot, but you say, "Nah babe (なべ), this is all for me." Undeterred, your spouse keeps trying to sneak a spoon into your cooking pot, but you relentlessly box them out, shouting "Nah, babe" over and over.

Name: Copper
Mnemonic: Gold is not the same as copper. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper. Take a piece of gold in one hand and a piece of copper in the other. Bang them together furiously as you shout. “GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER! GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER!”
ReadingMnemonic: Smashing the copper against the gold has made you tired. You should eat a doughnut (どう). Go get yourself a doughnut. Mmm… doughnuts. Eat the doughnut and taste its yummy flavor as you look at the piece of copper. It’s shiny.

Name: Cottage
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both cottage. As long as you know the radical cottage, you know the kanji cottage.
ReadingMnemonic: You got this cottage from a shaman (しゃ). In fact, everyone you know got their cottage from a shaman. One day you're just walking in the woods, and the next thing you know, a shaman is giving you the keys to their old cottage. I guess shamans are moving out a lot around here. Why don't you go look for a cottage you can buy from a shaman! I bet you'll get a pretty good, totally not cursed, deal!

Name: Desert
Mnemonic: A tsunami hits the greenhouse, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a desert. The greenhouse was your only hope in turning the desert into a green forest. Now it's all washed away by salt water, meaning nothing will grow anyways. Feel disappointed about this.
ReadingMnemonic: See the sun come up over the desert, then go back (ばく) down. Up, back down, back up, back down. You stand here for days watching because you're so depressed. Stop being so vague in your approach, sun! You’re weirding everyone out! Up, back down, back up, back down. Move your head up and down to keep up with the sun’s movements. Will it ever rise like normal?

Name: Drunk
Mnemonic: You have an alcohol nine times stronger than any other drink, in a bottle shaped like a cross, and you drink it all and become drunk. You're like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before. Feel how drunk you are as you look at the cross shaped bottle that once held the alcohol. See the cross start to blur in front of you from how drunk you are.
ReadingMnemonic: Everything's spinning now, you're so drunk it feels like you're on a swing (すい). Lurching back and forth in your drunkenness, feeling more and more nauseated by all this horrible swinging. Ugh. Imagine that vertigo that comes over you if you lean your head back when you're drunk. It feels like leaning back on a playground swing, in a way. Oh, wait… what if we got drunk and swung on the playground swings? Double swing effect! Actually, never mind. Bad idea.

Name: Flame
Mnemonic: Fire, fire, flame! There’s flames everywhere! Feel the fire all around you, the flames licking at your body. It’s really hot!
ReadingMnemonic: The flames gets bigger, surround you, and then everything ends (えん). Sorry, but standing in a blaze isn't the best idea. Flames are pretty efficient at ending the lives of the things in it. Maybe you should do this kanji lesson over and try not to stand in the flames next time.

Name: House Counter
Mnemonic: Your car is dry because you kept it under the eaves of your house. One eave, one house. Two eaves, two houses.
ReadingMnemonic: On top of the eaves of your house Ken (けん) the samurai is counting houses too. Ken hops down and explains that he's been hired to count all the houses in his lord's domain just because his name is the same as the counter for houses. It isn't really fair, he complains to you, as you try to sneak by and lock him out of your house.

Name: Introduce
Mnemonic: You create a thread with someone by calling out to them to introduce yourself. You literally call out, and when they turn around, tie a thread to them, so you'll never forget that you introduced yourselves to each other.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to introduce yourself to the Shougun (しょう) but no matter how much you call out, he won't come close enough for you to tie your introduction thread to him. You call louder and louder, "SHOUGUN LET ME INTRODUCE MYSELF!" Finally the Shougun sighs and turns toward you. You call out your name and get the thread around him. Uh oh. He doesn't look happy.

Name: Jammed In
Mnemonic: The jammed in radical and the jammed in kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Look down! You're jammed into something. You can't move your feet. What is this?! Oh, your body's been jammed in a kayak (かい). Picture yourself jammed into a kayak. Your pants are bunching and sticking out the sides and top. You really don't fit in here.

Name: Lake
Mnemonic: The tsunamis during the old moons (many moons ago) were responsible for the world's lakes. Where did lakes come from? They are the residue of tsunamis from many moons ago.
ReadingMnemonic: "That's where lakes come from," you tell the 子 (こ). This is just a stupid story to get this 子 to stop asking "why, why, why?" about everything. Earlier, the 子 asked "where do lakes come from?" and you had to come up with a crazy story to quiet them.

Name: Lecture
Mnemonic: Try to say something to a lifeguard and you'll just end up getting a lecture. A lifeguard's favorite part of the job is telling people what to do, where to swim, when to get out of the water, and they love saying it in a bunch of words.
ReadingMnemonic: This lecture loving lifeguard is none other than こういち! I mean, look how long winded the stuff on this site is? Can you imagine him trying to give you a talk about proper swimming etiquette? Close your eyes and picture こういち lecturing you. Ugh, it's the worst!

Name: Lifespan
Mnemonic: In spring, your measurements will reveal your lifespan. Only in spring can you measure your lifespan, just as easily as you measure your height and weight. On the first day of spring, all the girls and boys line up to measure their lifespans.
ReadingMnemonic: If your lifespan measurement isn't as long as you'd like, you need to drink more small juice (じゅ) boxes this year. They're good for your health, after all! Look at Salmon, over here. She drank a thousand small juice boxes last year and now her measurement says she's gonna live another hundred years!

Name: Measure
Mnemonic: A tsunami will pick up a bunch of shellfish and dump them on your shore, so you take a knife and measure them. You can't eat shellfish that are too small, so you place your knife along them to measure them. If they're big enough, you stick the knife in and eat them raw.
ReadingMnemonic: All of the shellfish you measure that are too small go into your sock (そく). Once the sock is full, you swing it around your head and lob it back into the ocean. If you measure one of these shellfish and it's too small, stuff it right into your sock. Then once the sock measures about 12 shellfish long, toss it back to sea!

Name: Misfortune
Mnemonic: If you're on the edge of a cliff with a snake, that's a misfortune. You're hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can't pull yourself back up. Then you notice a snake approaching your fingers, looking like it's gonna bite you. What a misfortune! What will you do? You can either let go and fall off the cliff, or hold on and get bitten by the snake. Man, talk about misfortune.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to let go, but at the bottom of the cliff is an even greater misfortune: yak (やく). A whole stampeding herd of yak is passing just as you fall. Oops! You've accidentally committed yourself to the ultimate misfortune, death by yak trampling. Imagine the glittering maze of hooves and yak horns that enclose you now. Ahhh! Then the yak pass, and you find yourself alive but beaten. Life is one misfortune after another, but misfortunes, like the yak, eventually pass…

Name: Mutual
Mnemonic: The ground and a shuriken have mutual respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here. Pick up the shuriken and throw it into the ground. Hear it whizz through the air and then plunk into the ground. This act of aggression causes their mutual respect to waver.
ReadingMnemonic: Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the mutual respect is out of balance. This summons Godzilla (ご) up from the depths of the ocean once more. He always shows up when something is out of wack, to show humans the error of their ways. He picks up the shuriken and flings it into a city, which explodes, leaving a crater in the ground. You give Godzilla a thumbs up, you see what he's trying to do. He looks down at you and nods. Now you have a mutual respect for one another too.

Name: Oil
Mnemonic: This tsunami is the reason we have so much oil now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. Thanks tsunami! Watch as this tsunami crashes over the land, pushing earth out of the way. Once the tsunami passes, hear the spewing geysers of oil as they erupt out of the ground.
ReadingMnemonic: Now that oil is so abundant, everyone lives in yurts (ゆ). They're light and mobile, so people can just move from oil well to oil well, collecting oil. Look at how this oil has changed the world. Instead of living in big homes, condos, or skyscrapers, everyone lives in a yurt at night and travels with all the oil by day.

Name: Oneself
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for oneself first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means oneself as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Oneself. Who only thinks of oneself? Every 子 (こ) in the world. Kids can only think of oneself. Until a certain age, that's literally all they can care about.

Name: Prison
Mnemonic: You have an animal and you say it’s a dog to prevent it from going to prison. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison. Imagine any animal that’s not a dog. Now imagine dressing it up like a dog so it doesn’t have to go to prison. Practice throwing your voice by saying “woof woof” aloud to help convince people that your animal is actually a dog.
ReadingMnemonic: What is the name of your animal? Your animal is named Goku (ごく). Yeah, like Goku from Dragon Ball Z. You don’t want your little Goku to go to prison, so you say that he’s a dog. Poor little Goku doesn’t want to go to prison either so Goku does his best to act like a dog even though he isn’t. How adorable.

Name: Relatives
Mnemonic: There's a slide with a drunkard above it, and they're making you feel small. And the worst part is that the drunkard is one of your relatives. A slide isn't the safest place for a drunkard to be. You try to help your relative down but they just keep shouting at you and making you feel small. Drunk relatives are the worst.
ReadingMnemonic: As if things couldn't get worse, your relative seems to think they're sexy (せき) when they're on the slide drunk. Sexy? More like irresponsible! Imagine your intoxicated relative shouting about how sexy they are on that slide. Someone get them down from there!

Name: Sake
Mnemonic: The sake radical and the sake kanji are exactly the same! Sweet. For goodness sake! Please remember this isn't "sake" as in お酒! It's the English "sake," that rhymes with "bake," "cake," and "steak." Oops.. now I'm hungry.
ReadingMnemonic: For the sake of convenience, companies will use eagles (い) for delivery jobs in the future. Just put in an order, and it'll be at your doorstep in no time flat. Eagles are like, super fast at delivery. See this eagle as it comes to deliver your order just for your sake. Scree! Hear its wings flap and your package plop down on your porch as it's delivered.

Name: Shame
Mnemonic: Your ear listens to your heart and feels shame. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too. Feel the shame. Feel the shame in both your ear and your heart. Imagine the things you’ve done to make you feel so much shame.
ReadingMnemonic: You must cleanse your spirit of this shame. You decide to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “HAHAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before. You’re super embarrassed for bringing so much shame on yourself again. But then you think of another joke. “Hahaha!” Better luck with the next Haj, I guess.

Name: Slow
Mnemonic: Next to the scooter, there's a flag warning you that there are sheep around here, so you should go slow. That means you might be late, but at least the sheep will be okay! It's also a warning to the sheep that if they want to ride scooters they should also slow down, because as we all know, sheep are speed demons.
ReadingMnemonic: You follow the flag, but the sheep refuse to slow down so you have to get creative. You place cheese (ち) every ten feet or so, that way the sheep slow down to bend down on their scooters and take a bite. Picture all of the sheep finally going slowly because there is yummy cheese all over the road.

Name: Soup
Mnemonic: A tsunami carries a cross into your soup. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup! Picture a bowl of soup, but now there is a cross and some tsunami water in it.
ReadingMnemonic: You pull the cross out of your soup and see that the cross' jewels (じゅう) fell off and are in there now. The jewels sparkle, shine, and dissolve into the soup! You're curious so you take a sip of this jewel soup and... it's delicious! You should make more and sell it!

Name: Soy Sauce
Mnemonic: The commander's alcohol is really just soy sauce. When he goes out to drink with his troops and they all get drunk together, he manages to have fun and stay sober by drinking down a tasty, non-alcoholic pint of soy sauce. The next time you go to a bar, order yourself a commander's alcohol. It's like saying you want a Roy Rogers or a Shirley Temple, except it isn't pretty and it tastes horrible.
ReadingMnemonic: Soy sauce also happens to be the Shougun's (しょう) favorite drink. Unfortunately, he can't just tell people he likes drinking glasses of soy sauce, or they'll look at him weird. Instead he orders it as a commander's alcohol too. Picture the Shougun sitting on his throne, guzzling down some salty, brown soy sauce. It's splashing on his robes and the smell is making his assistants gag.

Name: Stagnate
Mnemonic: A tsunami, once stopped by a belt, will begin to stagnate. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate. Watch this belt as it stagnated the tsunami. See the belt glow as its enchantment activates, immediately stagnating the tsunami water.
ReadingMnemonic: While you watch the tsunami stagnate, you get ready for work. While you were watching this whole thing happening, you were tying your tie (たい). Once the tsunami stagnated, you were all done tying your tie. And since the tsunami is no longer a threat, you’re ready to go to work. Look in the mirror at you in your tie. Put the finishing touches on your outfit and imagine going out into the world with your tie on, no longer afraid of any tsunamis. They’re all stagnant now thanks to that magical belt.

Name: Sword
Mnemonic: Tie a squid to a knife and you get a sword! Knives are too small to be considered a sword on their own. That's why you strapped a squid to it. They're the right shape, kinda pointed, so no one will know it's just a knife. Imagine creating your own sword out of a knife and a squid.
ReadingMnemonic: You learned how to make swords this way from Ken (けん) the samurai. He put his own little squid buddy on his knife and now no one realizes it's not a sword! Picture Ken swinging his squid sword at you. *Squish* it squirts ink on your shoulder. But it doesn't really hurt.

Name: Tear
Mnemonic: If you scrape a sharp stone against your skin, it will tear. The sharp stone tears your skin. It hurts! Imagine this sharp stone. Feel its weight in your hand. Now drag the sharp stone against your skin. Feel your skin as it begins to tear. The pain is agonizing.
ReadingMnemonic: The moment your skin tears you can't help but yelp "Ha (は)!" It sounds like a laugh, but it's more like a pained bark. You make this noise when you tear other things with the sharp stone too, but now it's more of a HA! TAKE THAT! Feel the same pain I feel!

Name: Teardrop
Mnemonic: A tsunami goes through a little door, and plops down a big drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the teardrop coming down your eye. Imagine a teardrop going through this process to get out of your eye, though in a more miniature teardrop size.
ReadingMnemonic: Your teardrops are like little waves. What are they? They're 波だ (なみだ). Feel each teardrop rolling like a little wave down your cheek. You've never paid such close attention to them before. Teardrops really are just 波だ, you think. Little, ticklish waves.

Name: Turtle
Mnemonic: The turtle radical and the turtle kanji are exactly the same! Nice! See this turtle as he gathers energy, shaking the earth around him, gathering chi for his Kamehameha blast. He releases it in a mighty blast of energy. Kamehameha!!
ReadingMnemonic: You know Dragon Ball Z, right? Imagine this turtle doing a Kamehameha (かめ). The turtle charges up his energy and releases a mighty Kamehameha blast. Shwooom! See this turtle as he gathers energy, shaking the earth around him, gathering chi for his Kamehameha blast. He releases it in a mighty blast of energy. Kamehameha!!

Name: Vinegar
Mnemonic: To make alcohol the key is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become vinegar. Imagine making a bunch of vinegar. You use a key to change it from alcohol to vinegar, yum!
ReadingMnemonic: You are demonstrating this practice in front of an audience. You want them to take you seriously so you wear a suit (す). A very nice suit. Surely they will now believe that you can turn alcohol into vinegar. Imagine yourself doing the same thing as before but you are now wearing a suit. Dang, you look good.

Name: Bright
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means bright.

Name: Dance
Mnemonic: You see a cow in the evening. You get closer and realize it's doing a dance. All cows dance in the evening. Can you picture it? The cow is dancing, so majestic, in the setting sunlight.

Name: Departure
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means departure.

Name: South
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means south.

Name: Sweet
Mnemonic: This radical is the sun with its hair sticking out. Why is the sun's hair sticking out like this? It ate wayyy too many sweet things causing it to have too much energy, making its hair stand on end. It also kind of looks like a sweet, sweet candy with the wrapper sticking out. Remember it how you'd like.

Name: Valuable
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means valuable.

Name: Agreement
Mnemonic: You say something and the flowers are right in agreement. The flowers see where you are coming from when you say what you say. You and the flowers are in complete agreement. What did you say to the flowers that you are so in agreement about? Think about what you said.
ReadingMnemonic: You and the flowers are in agreement on the fact that neither of you like when a duck (だく) walks across the flowers. You don’t like having a duck walk on the flowers because the duck will poo in the flowers and then you have to worry about stepping in it. And the flowers just don’t like having duck poo in their face. Imagine you are the flowers. There’s a duck. It’s making a poo. On you. Ew, man, that’s disgusting. Bleh.

Name: Alliance
Mnemonic: I’ll give you this bright plate if you agree to an alliance with me. I know you like things that are bright, and I know you like plates too. Therefore, this bright plate should be more than enough to convince you to enter into an alliance with me. Look at this bright plate. Look at it. It’s awesome. It’s blinding. Hold it in your hands. Marvel at it. Wow. This plate is sweet.
ReadingMnemonic: The person you are trying to get in an alliance with you is the captain of the Mayflower (めい). You want to be in an alliance with the captain of the Mayflower because you really like boats. You want to ride on the Mayflower like, so bad. This Mayflower boat is the best boat you ever did see. Hear the ocean around it as it bobs in the water, full sails billowing in the wind. Boats are cool.

Name: Commander
Mnemonic: The commander radical and the commander kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Who is the commander of Japan? The Shougun (しょう)! And if you ever say anyone else or vote for someone else or even THINK about someone else being the commander, he'll find you and cut off your head. You better remember the Shougun is the commander of everything... or else...

Name: Dance
Mnemonic: The nothing dance is still a dance! If you want to do the nothing dance, just clear your head so there's nothing in it, and then dance!
ReadingMnemonic: To help you do this dance you need some booze (ぶ). Just enough so it's easier to think of nothing, let all your fears go, and dance. Feel the booze coursing through your veins as you dance like no one is watching.

Name: Debt
Mnemonic: Your leader gets the blame if your company is in debt. They're the one who led you all into that debt, so they should get the blame too. Picture the leader standing up in front of everyone as they blame him. He's holding a plaque with the amount of debt you're all in. Try to imagine what that number would be.
ReadingMnemonic: To pay off this debt your leader says you need to sell your cyborg (さい) to help the company. You fight him! You yell! You scream! The cyborg puts a half-human half-robot hand on your shoulder and shakes its head sadly. Watch as your cyborg saves your company, even though it wasn't even his responsibility, from crippling debt. *sob* I can't believe your cyborg is gone!

Name: Deed
Mnemonic: The leader of your branch became the leader from doing deeds. You can't rise to the rank of branch leader if you don't perform a certain number of deeds! Most of them good, I hope. Picture the leader of your branch doing deeds around your office. Pulling out chairs for people sitting down, emptying the trash, balancing spreadsheets. All good deeds.
ReadingMnemonic: The deed he's currently working on is finding your lost key (き). He doesn't have to help, you're the one who lost your own house-combination-car key. But he's so used to doing deeds, he can't help but help. Picture him doing this deed. He's crawling around on the floor looking for your key. You aren't really helping, you're just watching him do the deed of key-searching for you.

Name: Deer
Mnemonic: A canopy and a helicopter are being compared by a deer. The deer is standing very still (as deer do) and looking very slowly between the empty canopy and the helicopter sitting next to it. Picture the deer comparing the two structures. It probably has no idea what they are, but it's trying very hard to understand what it's seeing anyway.
ReadingMnemonic: You walk forward, about to call out to the deer, when a car (か) suddenly appears out of no where and runs the deer over! Was this all just a trap set up to murder the deer?! Deer get hit by cars all the time, but it was still really shocking . I mean it was right in front of you. The car could have hit you too!

Name: Exchange
Mnemonic: In prison, when you have access to a big number of fingers, mouths, and legs you can exchange them for things that are worth more to you. What are you gonna do with all these body parts in prison? You should exchange them for cigarettes and toilet alcohol. You just have so many fingers, mouths, and legs you've pummeled off of the other prisoners. Exchange them for better loot!
ReadingMnemonic: You learned this type of exchange from the mighty Genghis Khan (かん). You read a book or watched a show about him once and you're pretty positive that Genghis Khan would exchange the body parts of his enemies all over the continents of Asia and Europe for nicer stuff. Think back to when you were a kid and they would roll out those TVs on stands into the classrooms. Imagine watching a documentary on Genghis Khan's exchange routes where he bought and sold body parts. Educational!

Name: Family Name
Mnemonic: If there's a special woman in your life, she might eventually take your family name and make it her surname too. In Japan and other countries, tradition dictates that women change their last name when they get married and keep that name for the rest of their life. Their partner’s family name becomes their family name too. Imagine having your surname changed for the rest of your life. How do you feel about having a different family name? Is it a big deal to you or does it not matter much?
ReadingMnemonic: Picture this special woman in your mind. She's changing her surname to yours and taking hold of your special saber (せい) as well. And it's... it's splitting in two! Now you share a family name AND a holy blue saber! You can protect your legacy (and surname) hand in hand and saber in saber. (Or something like that.)

Name: Fang
Mnemonic: The fang radical and the fang kanji are exactly the same! Fantastic. Oh, also it means tusk. It means fang and tusk. Since the fang radical is the same as the fang kanji, that should be easy to remember. Tusks aren’t too different from fangs, so that shouldn’t be too hard to remember either.
ReadingMnemonic: Lots of animals have fangs, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the gecko (げ)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out. Picture a gecko with cute little fangs. You can keep thinking they're cute as long as one never bites you. They may be little, but gecko fangs are no joke!

Name: Former
Mnemonic: There’s a stick next to the sun, reflecting on its former glory. The stick used to be a great tree, and the stick thinks that if it stays by the sun long enough it might return to its former form as a towering tree. Pretend you are the stick. Really focus on your former self as you feel the sun warm you with its rays. Imagine yourself growing, larger and larger.
ReadingMnemonic: It's working, it's working! The stick is returning to its former state and... w-wuh? It sprouted a cucumber (きゅう). I guess this stick was formerly a cucumber tree. Or maybe it just tried so hard it pooped a cucumber. I don't care which one is true, you pick whatever you want to believe.

Name: Fry
Mnemonic: Fire is one of a few things you'll need to fry things. You need a few other things like a pan and some oil too, but fire is gonna be the most important for frying!
ReadingMnemonic: You love to fry things and are also an adventurous eater (いた). This means you'll fry and eat just about anything. Fried ostrich, fried alligator, fried chocolate, you name it! Your being an adventurous eater of all things fried truly knows no bounds. What cursed combination of foods will you fry up tomorrow?!

Name: Generally
Mnemonic: A boat will have at least one weapon, generally. In general, you can assume a boat will have a weapon, but not all of them will.
ReadingMnemonic: Generally a boat with a weapon will be owned by Han (はん) Solo. So of all the boats out there, generally all of them have weapons, and generally Han Solo will be on one.

Name: Harbor
Mnemonic: There’s a huge tsunami, caused by a giant brush, fast approaching you and your harbor. This harbor is all you’ve got, it’s the backbone of your life. So how are you going to defend it from this tsunami caused by a giant brush?!
ReadingMnemonic: You’ll defend your harbor with your two (つ) best friends, that’s how! Luckily, your two friends specialize in defending harbors from giant brush-caused tsunamis. Quite the occupation. “How are two of my friends going to stop an entire tsunami from destroying my dear harbor?”, you might ask yourself. Well don’t ask us, we don’t specialize in brush-caused tsunami harbor defence—we’re just a kanji learning website!

Name: Heal
Mnemonic: If someone is sick feed them charcoal to heal them. Okay, so maybe you shouldn't feed it directly to them, but charcoal has amazing water filtration powers. So put charcoal in their water and the water will heal them right up. Imagine being sick. Like sick as a dog sick. And then you take some charcoal, put it into your drinking water, and then you're healed!
ReadingMnemonic: You aren't the only one that needs to be healed, so you take your row (りょう) boat out onto the lake where your town gets its drinking water and you dump a bunch of charcoal into it! Now everyone will be healed when they drink. Picture yourself rowing your row boat into the lake with huge chunks of solid charcoal. You carefully break them up and toss them over the side, so you can heal everyone.

Name: Inherit
Mnemonic: With a thread, a lion sews together all the rice he'll inherit from his parents one day. He's convinced his parents are going to try to keep some of his inheritance from him, so he's linking it all together so it can't go anywhere. Picture this lion surrounded by the thousands of grains of rice he'll inherit from his parents. He's carefully threading them all together.
ReadingMnemonic: If you're going to inherit something from your parents, try to convince them to make it cake (けい), not rice. A single cake is much easier to keep track of and probably tastier (though it will be super stale by the time they die). I'd much rather inherit a cake than a ton of hard to keep track of rice, like this poor lion.

Name: Leave Behind
Mnemonic: When you go on a scooter, anything valuable, you need to leave behind. Rings, necklaces, wallets, phones? Don't take them on a scooter. Leave behind all that valuable stuff!
ReadingMnemonic: Anything you don't leave behind will be stolen by eagles (い). Eagles like shiny, valuable things, especially ones that are bouncing around on you while you scoot by on a scooter. If you keep too many of your valuables on you, the eagles might not leave you behind either! They'll just pick you up off the scooter and carry you and your valuables off to their nests!

Name: Maintain
Mnemonic: You tie a piece of thread to your turkey in order to maintain proximity to it. The turkey likes to run away, so you tie a thread to it. This way you can hold the other end and maintain your turkey. Imagine holding onto a thread that is attached to a turkey. Feel the turkey tug against the thread as you struggle to maintain control.
ReadingMnemonic: The reason the turkey is tugging is because there’s an eagle (い) swooping down to attack the turkey. You try to maintain control, but once you see the eagle as well, you let go of the thread. Now you and the turkey and the eagle are all bumbling about in pandemonium. You try to maintain order but it’s not possible. What a kerfuffle.

Name: Nara
Mnemonic: There is a big jackhammer in Nara. That jackhammer is the biggest in all the land and is on display in Nara, Japan. Look at this big jackhammer. Look at it. It’s so big. Also it’s in Nara. Imagine being in Nara and looking at this big jackhammer. You’re all like, dang – that’s a big jackhammer.
ReadingMnemonic: What’s the first part of Nara? Na (な). Well that’s easy. Just keep in mind what the first part of Nara is. The first part of Nara is “na” so you’ll have no trouble remembering this one.

Name: Nucleus
Mnemonic: You take a tree and slice it until you reach its nucleus. To get to the nucleus of the tree you have to make many a slice, but it’s possible. Imagine slicing this tree smaller and smaller until you finally get to the nucleus of it. It’s super tiny so you have to view it in a microscope. What does it look like?
ReadingMnemonic: It looks like a cock (かく). And by cock I mean a male chicken – a rooster. Why does the nucleus of a tree look like a cock? Science is weird. Look at this tree nucleus that looks like a cock. While you’re watching it, the nucleus goes “Cock-a-doodle-doo!”

Name: Obsolete
Mnemonic: This canopy, after your departure, will become obsolete. The canopy was here to protect you, but no one will need it once you're gone. During your departure you look back at the obsolete canopy just once. It's standing there, still and alone. It's a really sad sight.
ReadingMnemonic:
When something becomes obsolete, you must write a haiku (はい). Honestly, the best haiku are about something ending, so this is perfect. My sweet canopy
I don't need you anymore
You are obsolete

Name: Offer
Mnemonic: The South Dog gives you an offer. None of the other dogs in the North, East, or West offered you anything. It is well known that dogs in the South are famous for their kindness and hospitality. It's customary to always offer something when a guest arrives.
ReadingMnemonic: The South Dog offers you the services of Ken (けん) the samurai as you traverse his lands. Ken offers to carry you, too. Imagine him offering this. You can choose whether or not to accept in your mind.

Name: Open Sea
Mnemonic: There is a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Luckily there are no ships around, so the tsunami in the middle of the open sea is not damaging to anyone. Look at this tsunami in the middle of the open sea. When the tsunami isn’t destroying things and is just out there in the open sea it looks really majestic and pretty.
ReadingMnemonic: Someone dares you to go out to the open sea and surf on the middle of the tsunami. “Oki (おき) doki,” you reply. You can’t refuse a dare. Every time someone dares you to do something, you always respond with “oki doki”. You really regret saying oki doki this time. You don’t want to surf on a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Imagine doing so. It’s terrifying and wet and you don’t even know how to surf. You’re going to die.

Name: Pickle
Mnemonic: Tsunamis get blamed because they pickle everything in their path. That means that everything smells of pickles after a tsunami. Imagine a tsunami crashing over the land, being blamed by everyone. In its path are piles and piles of pickles, as far as the eye can see!
ReadingMnemonic: Looking at all those pickles, you bend down and pick up two (つ) of them. One in each hand. You look at the pickles in your hand and wonder whether to try one. Picture the two pickles and imagine what kind of pickles they are.

Name: Pluck
Mnemonic: Stick your fingers in your mohawk and pluck each hair out, one by one. Imagine plucking the hairs out of your mohawk with your fingers. It's kind of hard to grab onto them at first, but eventually you're plucking them like it's nothing.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to pluck all your mohawk hair out because you're a techie (てき), and everyone at your techie job keeps making fun of you for your hair choices. "Techies should be bald!" your boss screamed. So here you are, plucking your hair out to fit in. You didn't realize techies were so inclusive... but they just plucked and plucked at your self-esteem, until you decided to pluck your hair out of your own head.

Name: Reach
Mnemonic: Escalators are used to reach things. Imagine yourself on an escalator. What is up above that you’re trying to reach?
ReadingMnemonic: You're riding the escalator trying to reach a delicious cucumber (きゅう). Cucumbers grow on trees sometimes, so you need to take escalators to get up there and reach them.

Name: Reliant
Mnemonic: A leader has clothes that he is quite reliant on. The leader needs his clothes to make him look like a leader. The leader has become more reliant on his clothes than he is on his actual skills as a leader! Imagine this leader in his clothes. Look how reliant he is on them. Imagine what he would be without his clothes – nothing! And also, naked.
ReadingMnemonic: The leader has become so reliant on his clothes that his judgment has been clouded. His kingdom has become infested with eagles (い) but the leader does nothing, trusting that his clothes will rout out the eagles if it is something that needs to be done. He’s become so reliant on his clothes that he’s started to become not so good a leader anymore. Look at the leader as he shouts at his clothes he’s become so reliant on to do something. Hear the countless eagles screeching around as they terrorize the neighborhood. People scream and weep in the streets.

Name: Rope
Mnemonic: Someone threaded a turtle into long skinny pieces, making a rope. A rope made of threaded turtles. Go ahead and grab onto it and see how it feels. A little rough, but strong.
ReadingMnemonic: The person making these threaded turtle ropes is none other than the local farmhand Joe (じょう). You watch him stretch and peel pieces of turtle off of turtles, then thread them together into a rope. Besides being awful, where did Joe learn to thread turtles into ropes? Why does he have so many turtles despite living on such an inland farm? These are nice ropes that Joe is making though, and you kind of want to buy some.

Name: Salmon
Mnemonic: What kind of fish jumps from dirt to dirt? A salmon! When you're at the river watching salmon jumping up stream, they keep jumping onto the dirt, flopping back into the water, then doing it again.
ReadingMnemonic: You make a drinking game out of watching the salmon going up stream. Every time one jumps onto the dirt, you drink a shot of 酒 (さけ). You realize you're drunk when you ask for more さけ but it comes out as しゃけ. Salmon. Drink さけ. Salmon. Drink さけ. Salmon. Drink...

Name: Step
Mnemonic: You soak each foot in water before going out in the sun to take your first step. Stepping on the ground when it's been baking in the hot sun can burn your feet, so you're careful to make them wet with water before stepping outside even once. Imagine each step on hot, sun-baked asphalt. The water under your feet sizzles, leaving steaming footprints where you stepped from.
ReadingMnemonic: Each step you take brings you closer to とうきょう. Unfortunately, the sun keeps getting hotter, meaning you have to take breaks between steps more often, to get your feet wet with even more water. But you're determined to reach とうきょう, no matter how many steps it takes. Each step is taking you closer to とうきょう. Don't forget that, no matter how hard it seems, don't lose your motivation to keep stepping forward toward your goal. ♡

Name: Stretch
Mnemonic: A leader who's humble will stretch in front of everyone. They'll show that they have to get up every hour or so and stretch just like the rest of us. The leader is humble and human, just like the rest of us, and has to stretch to stay healthy too. He's not some kind of god!
ReadingMnemonic: The leader is currently working hard to stretch in front of all of you, and as he does, he munches on some nori (の) seaweed snacks. Then he starts stretching the nori too. Watch as the leader stretches his body and the nori seaweed. He takes a bite, stretches the other way, then stretches out a piece for you to eat too. How humble of him!

Name: Sweet
Mnemonic: The sweet radical and the sweet kanji are exactly the same! Double sweet. Put on the armor! Feel the sweetness begin to reflect off your armored body. Only a little gets through — just enough for the sweet flavor on your tongue to taste sweet, but not too sweet.
ReadingMnemonic: The sweet, sweet sensation is almost overwhelming. You gotta put on some sweet-resistant armor (あま) to protect you from all that sweetness. The armor will prevent you from having a sweet, sweet sweetness overload. Put on the armor! Feel the sweetness begin to reflect off your armored body. Only a little gets through — just enough for the sweet flavor on your tongue to taste sweet, but not too sweet.

Name: Trade
Mnemonic: You send your private sword man out with your shellfish so he can trade them. Shellfish were used as currency back in the olden days. And you aren't going to go out trading and dirty your own hands, no no. Trading your shellfish is the job for the private sword you hired! Imagine your private sword holding a big bag of shellfish and going off to market to trade them.
ReadingMnemonic: While he's out making the trade for you, you decide to relax and do some bowling (ぼう). In fact, you can't wait for the trade to be done because you're hoping he's going to come back with a new bowling ball for you. Oh boy, I hope my private sword trades my shellfish for that new bowling ball I heard about!

Name: Trust
Mnemonic: A bundle of geoducks is something you can always trust. A bundle of geoducks will never lie, never let you down, and never disappoint you. You can trust them completely.
ReadingMnemonic: While you can trust a bundle of geoducks, never ever trust rye (らい) bread. Imagine a bundle of geoducks and a piece rye bread. Think about how you can trust the geoducks but you can't trust the rye bread.

Name: Ultra
Mnemonic: You run and call out to people at the same time because you're super ultra excited right now. You have a super crazy amount of energy you need to get out with your running and calling. You're going for an ultra run, calling out with your super loud voice right down the middle of the street.
ReadingMnemonic: You're just becoming ultra tired when you hear a terrifying sound. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) barreling down toward you. "WERE YOU CALLING FOR ME, CHILD?!" she screams. Mrs. Chou is super ultra scary. And if you don't kick it into super ultra high gear she's going to catch up to you and make you super ultra dead.

Name: Uncle
Mnemonic: There were lots of things that were above you when you were small that you would need a stool to reach, so you just asked your aunt or uncle to get them for you. Your parents didn't want you having those things, which is why they put them up high, but your aunt and uncle would always spoil you and get them for you.
ReadingMnemonic: You ask your aunt and uncle to help you reach your special obi (お) from high up in the closet. You aren't supposed to wear your obi unless it's a special occasion, but your aunt and uncle don't know that. Now you can run around with it on your head and your parents can't stop you by putting it up high!

Name: Well Up
Mnemonic: When you see a tsunami coming, courage will well up inside you, giving you the power to save everyone before you get washed away! Really feel the courage welling up inside of you in the face of this terrifying tsunami. Connect it to some physical feeling—perhaps you can feel it welling up in your chest.
ReadingMnemonic: Whom does that courage well up inside of? You (ゆう)! In fact, YOU feel like there is a never ending well of courage bursting out of you now. You are going to be a hero! Who wells up with courage? You do!

Name: Width
Mnemonic: You want to put this towel over this scarecrow, but you have to measure its width first. If the towel doesn't have a greater width than the scarecrow, some of it will be showing. Which you definitely don't want. The scarecrow creeps you out. You don't want to look at it anymore, so you're standing eerily close to it measuring its width, so you can hide it forever.
ReadingMnemonic: You finish measuring the width of the scarecrow and the width of the towel, and you realize you're the width of a habanero (はば) pepper short. This is fine, you grow those. This is a whole field of habaneros! So you pluck one off the nearest plant, tape it to the cloth, and cover that scarecrow right up. Do you know the width of a habanero? It's one scarecrow minus one cloth.

Name: Omen
Mnemonic: There's an explosion around your legs. It was just as the fortune teller warned. This is the omen she was talking about. Think about what happens after the omen hits. What horrible fortune teller magic will happen???

Name: Prize
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means prize.

Name: Skewer
Mnemonic: There's a stick going through some juicy meat. This is a skewer.

Name: Violence
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means violence.

Name: Wrap
Mnemonic: Yourself (oneself) is in prison. Look at the prison as it wraps around you. It wraps you up and holds you tight. That's why this is the wrap radical!

Name: Afflicted
Mnemonic: A skewer to the heart has afflicted your health. You’ve been afflicted with a disease from the skewer to your heart. Your affliction is death. You’re dying. You did not wish to be afflicted as such. Feel the skewer in your heart and the great pain it gives you. You know you’re dying.
ReadingMnemonic: Since you’re afflicted with the death, you start to hallucinate and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) appears before you. "Ah, I was afflicted of the same disease. It killed me, you know." You look on in horror as the affliction grabs hold and everything starts to fade, but Genghis Khan still floats before you, watching you closely.

Name: Aim
Mnemonic: You see an animal wearing a top hat and decide to aim at it. The top hat is a perfect, giant target you use to take down this animal. It's much easier to aim for an animal wearing a top hat than one without.
ReadingMnemonic: Ready, steady, aim... fire! You throw a bar of soap (そ) at the animal. Yes, soap. You were sitting in your bathtub, washing and scrubbing, then the animal in the top hat caught your eye. Your aim with the soap is perfect! The soap knocked the animal's hat right off.

Name: Army Camp
Mnemonic: This building is full of cars because it's an army camp. The cars (and tanks and planes) need to be ready to go at any moment just like the soldiers. Picture an army camp housing all of the different cars the army needs at any given time.
ReadingMnemonic: All of the people in the army camp are wearing jeans (じん). You thought soldiers were supposed to wear uniforms, but it looks like when they're in the camp they have to wear jeans. Jeans are pretty durable, now that you think about it. And if the soldiers are working on these cars in the camp while they're there, it makes sense to wear a nice pair of jeans.

Name: Base
Mnemonic: There's an explosion in the dirt under a rice paddy, exposing the hidden base under there. A base from baseball! I guess this rice paddy was built on top of an old baseball field... Picture a serene rice paddy. Now watch the whole thing explode, rice and dirt going everywhere, and a secret, underground baseball base is left there, smoldering.
ReadingMnemonic: Unfortunately, thanks to the explosion, the base is in ruins (るい). It's dark and smokey and kinda half burned. You probably can't get this in a regulation game. Hold this ruined base in your hands. Darn, you love baseball. At least it's a collectible.

Name: Bullet
Mnemonic: What's more simple than a bow? A bullet. Bullets just have to be shot out of a gun and somebody dies. Bows you have to load with an arrow and pull it back and aim, yuck. Bullets are the new bows, people. Imagine how simple life would be if we replaced all the bows in the world with bullets. (Insert sarcastic crying face here.)
ReadingMnemonic: If you want to shoot bullets, you need to do it at dawn (だん). Back in the old days, it wasn't bright enough to shoot arrows at dawn, but you can shoot bullets at dawn because they're simpler to use! Imagine shooting bullets into the sun at dawn. Pow pow, take that history! Blam blam, take that dawn!

Name: Burial
Mnemonic: You brought flowers to place on top of the place where a yakuza took a spoon and killed twenty people, and there is now a burial happening. You carefully toss the flowers in with the dirt and everything is buried together. This is the biggest burial you've ever seen. The hole is huge. It has to fit twenty people, after all, and the spoon didn't cut them up to make things any easier.
ReadingMnemonic: Once the burial is complete the souls (そう) of all the dead people come floating up and out of the ground. "Thaaannk YooOoOO~" they moan, as they ascend to the sky. I guess the twenty souls couldn't go up to... wherever... until they had a proper burial.

Name: Confront
Mnemonic: You take your fingers and slam a lid on the table. You make this big noise to confront the person in front of you. They weren't listening, which is why you slammed that lid down. You'll have to confront them more directly.
ReadingMnemonic: You are trying to confront Emperor こういち. You're confronting him about all the kanji he's forcing you, and everyone else, to learn. "Look here こういち! I know you said I'd learn like 2000 kanji in no time, but this is way too efficient! What will the people do when they're done? Do you think they will sit idly by?" こういち is laughing at you as you confront him. Which makes you angrier, so you bang the lid on the table some more.

Name: Crumble
Mnemonic: Below this mountain, a moon and another moon crash into each other and the entire thing crumbles to pieces. Watch as the moons crumble together, and then the mountain slowly crumbles down into them too.
ReadingMnemonic: As the mountain crumbles you see your home (ほう), which is at the very top of the mountain, come crumbling down too. Your home crumbles like a dry cookie until it's nothing more than a bunch of dust, mixed in with the mountain and the moon. Now where will you live?

Name: Dispatch
Mnemonic: On the scooter is an insect and a bear. The bear immediately stomps the insect, squishing it flat. "My god, the insect is smashed. Someone call dispatch!" Imagine the conversation with emergency services. They say they will dispatch an ambulance immediately.
ReadingMnemonic: Out of the dispatched ambulance jumps Ken (けん) the samurai. "Dispatch sent me! I'm here to fix that insect." He takes out a very tiny katana and performs surgery right there. The insect dies on the scooter. "It looks like I've dispatched this insect to the afterlife."

Name: Display
Mnemonic: You're in prison, but you can use your fingers and a spoon in the light of the sun to display little moving pictures on your cell wall. It's like a shadow puppet display except you can only make a few characters with your limited hand tools. Imagine displaying your two favorite characters in the shadows on your prison cell walls. This one is mister fingers and this one is missus spoon. They're best friends.
ReadingMnemonic: There is one thing you display more than anything else and it's cake (けい). You smush your fingers to make a cake shape and use the spoon to pretend you're eating it. Imagine displaying cake on the wall. Now pretend to eat the shadow cake with your spoon. You can almost taste it. Except you can't, because this is still prison.

Name: Explode
Mnemonic: If you combine fire with violence, it will explode! A fire, once full of violence, will surely explode. The fire can’t handle all that violence so the fire just rumbles and shakes and then finally explodes. BOOM! Imagine the fire explode. Feel the heat of the fire and the explosion. It’s very violent. BOOM BOOM BA-BOOM!
ReadingMnemonic: As you watch the fire explode, you start to back (ばく) away. I don’t blame you. You need to back away or else you’ll get caught in the violent explosion. Back away a little more just to be safe. Imagine yourself as you back away from the explosion. As you back away, see the fire dance and feel the heat of the explosion on your face.

Name: Eyebrows
Mnemonic: You're holding a flag on a stick above your eyes to imitate eyebrows. You can't grow any of your own, but you really love eyebrows, so this was the best you could do. Look at yourself in the mirror. You can see the stick holding up the flag and it's very clear you drew some eyebrows onto the flag with some markers, but you still look pretty good (in your opinion).
ReadingMnemonic: Underneath your fake eyebrows are two slabs of meat (み). Meat helps hair grow, according to many Internet specialists who also happen to sell meat. You're waiting for this meat to foster eyebrow hair, and when that sweet day comes you won't need these flags. Imagine walking around town, holding your eyebrow flags. You can feel the meat sticking above your eyes. They stink and they're weirdly lukewarm, but you know your real eyebrows will grow under them any day now.

Name: Favor
Mnemonic: You carry a cross across a rice paddy with a heart on it to return a favor for your friend. The heart needs to be purified so that’s why you have it on the cross and your friend lives on a rice paddy farm so that’s why you’re running through that. The favor you are paying your friend back with is getting him this heart. He needs a new one and you’re providing it. This is a pretty big favor. Imagine running through a rice paddy carrying a cross with a warm beating heart on it. Thump thump. Thump thump.
ReadingMnemonic: You arrive at your friend’s place and you can finally return the favor you owe him by presenting him with the heart. “Eh (え)? What’s this? I didn’t ask for this!” “Eh!?!?” you reply. Apparently he didn’t want a real heart, he wanted a candy one. He wanted a Valentine! Imagine how dumb you feel at this miscommunication. Eh? You don’t feel dumb? Well you should!

Name: Fight
Mnemonic: At this gate you're trying to get some beans through, but your measurements were off, leading to a big fight. The bean authorities at the gate always want to fight about bean sizes, and now you have to fight to get those beans through. Imagine having to fight against the bean bureaucracy. It's so absurd! Who can say a bean is too big or too small, in this age of diversity?! Your fighting pays off though, and they let you squeeze your beans through the gate. Well fought, bean brethren. Well fought.
ReadingMnemonic: The gate you put up a fight at leads to とうきょう. The people of とうきょう need those beans for sustenance, and that's why you fight — for them! How are you supposed to get your beans into とうきょう if a fight breaks out at the gate every time? What a struggle. Fortunately those bean-counting bureaucrats of とうきょう were no match for your fight.

Name: Fishing
Mnemonic: A tsunami pushes all the fish closer to land, making for some easy fishing. The tsunami starts out in the middle of the ocean and pushes all the fish towards the coast where everyone does their fishing. With all the fish pushed closer to land and closer together, it’s very easy for people to go fishing in one spot and catch a lot of fish. Imagine going fishing for fish in a fishing spot after a tsunami. There are SO many fish here. Your hook barely touches the water and there’s already a fish on it. Man, fishing like this is easy! Smell the smell of fish and sea air around you.
ReadingMnemonic: To get to the best fishing spot you need to go (ぎょ) row (りょう) out to the middle of the ocean. You go by means of rowing. To get to the fish and do the fishing, you need to go and row out to sea. Go! Go row! Go and row for the fishing! How do you go? You row! The row part should be pretty easy to remember since you gotta row your boat out to sea, but if you’re having trouble with the go part, just remember that it has the same reading as 魚.

Name: Fragrance
Mnemonic: Grain left in the sun blossom and give off a wonderful fragrance. They smell fresh and delicious. There's nothing better than the fragrance of fresh, sun-kissed grain. Imagine this warm, grain fragrance. What does it smell like to you? Cooked rice? Gentle flowers? A warm summer's day?
ReadingMnemonic: As you sniff this lovely fragrance you get lost in the smell. When you open your eyes again, you see a farming こういち standing in front of you. With... his... arm... up. "Do you like my fragrance? I was genetically modified to have a unique fragrance compared to the other こういちs." This fragrance was こういち's armpits the whole time. You thought it was warm grains. Or... maybe he smells like... grains?

Name: Gulf
Mnemonic: Tsunamis hit these lands again and again, molding it into some kind of bow shape. Or in other words, creating a gulf. Picture these extremely violent tsunamis hitting a shore again and again, turning it into a bow-shaped gulf. That's how gulfs are created in this part of the world!
ReadingMnemonic: How many gulfs will this create? Just one (わん). Many tsunamis, again and again, for just one gulf? Yep, that's just how life goes. Gulfs are in high demand, but you'll need many tsunamis to create just one.

Name: Hop
Mnemonic: Your foot heard an omen and now it's making you hop over things. Imagine your foot hearing this omen, "If you step on a crack, you'll break your mother's back." Now your foot hops over all of the tiny cracks in the street and the sidewalk and you look really silly.
ReadingMnemonic: As you hop you start to hear an awful scream coming down the street. It's Mrs. Chou (ちょう) and she's running straight for you yelling, "STEP ON MY STREET'S CRACKS! STOP HOPPING OR YOUR MOTHER WILL NEVER BREAK HER BACK!" Now you're hopping away in fear from Mrs. Chou!

Name: Hug
Mnemonic: Take your fingers and wrap them around another person. This is called a hug. Just make sure you include all the stuff attached to your fingers, like your hands and arms too, otherwise it's more of a squeeze, and we don't want to do that to people. Picture it like you're a baby who is new to hugs. You start with your fingers, spread them out and move forward. Now wrap all that stuff attached to your fingers around another person. You did it! You're hugging now!
ReadingMnemonic: Who do you love to hug the most? Your dad (だ)! He gives the best hugs. They're warm and big and tight and comforting. The kind of hug dads are really good at giving. Imagine getting a nice, big hug from your dad. Mm. It's cozy and feels like home.

Name: In Season
Mnemonic: When a prison holds the sun inside it, everything will always be in season. Obviously if the sun is in prison, the seasons can't change. Want to eat perfect apples all year round? Just put the sun in prison when they're ripe — usually a short window of ten days. You're welcome. Now you know how to keep everything in season. Lifehack!
ReadingMnemonic: When things are in season for more than ten days, people are going to wonder what's going on. When's Christmas? When's Golden Week? Soon (しゅん), you say. Soon enough, it's June (じゅん). Which is the middle of the year, so now everything is soon. Joke's on them though. Soon it will be apple season. Soon it will always be time for apples. Soon June will end and people will forget about everything else, living forever inside that period of ten days when apples are most in season.

Name: Listen
Mnemonic: When your ear is crossed with sound, it catches it like a net, and sends it to your heart for processing. Because you're using your heart to process this sound, it means you're giving it a proper listen. Imagine the whole process of sound going through your ear and to your heart, then the gears turning to really understand what someone is saying. It's a real listen, not a fake non-heart listen.
ReadingMnemonic: You are listening so well to what someone is saying. What are they telling you that is so important? They are telling you of the omen of Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who will destroy the earth. Focus on listening, and focus on their message about Mrs. Chou. Feel afraid about the future because of it.

Name: Look To
Mnemonic: You give your servant a gun along with some other products to look to. You can’t look to them yourself since you are very busy. You allow your servant to look to your gun and the other products. Imagine your servant as he looks to your gun and products. You can always look to him to take care of your menial tasks. You feel smug.
ReadingMnemonic: After your servant is done with your gun and other products you want him to look to your car’s o-ring (りん). There’s something wrong with the o-ring so you want your servant to look to that as well. Imagine your servant as he looks to your car’s o-ring. Hear him clinking and clanking around in the garage as he does so.

Name: Omen
Mnemonic: The omen radical and the omen kanji are the same! If you know the omen radical, you know the omen kanji as well!
ReadingMnemonic: You listen to the omen, in it, it tells of an event in the future when Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will destroy the world. You can clarify with the person telling you the omen several things: "Do you believe in the omen about Mrs. Chou destroying the world?" "When will this omen about Mrs. Chou come true?" etc. As long as you're associating omen with Mrs. Chou you should be good, so keep harping on that.

Name: Pledge
Mnemonic: The weight of life on your sword is big when you pledge to protect your city. That's the big, big weight of every single person's life in that city pressing down on you every time you take out that sword. Imagine holding up your sword and pledging to protect the lives of everyone in this city. It's a big deal!
ReadingMnemonic: Until the city is safe, you pledge to give up cake (けい), your favorite food. Would you pledge to give up cake to show everyone how serious you are about protecting life?

Name: Punish
Mnemonic: Destroy a lantern with your knife and you'll be punished. Even if it was your own lantern, why stab it with a knife? You could have recycled that. I will punish you for lantern stabbing and pollution!
ReadingMnemonic: I will punish you by taking away your cake (けい)! You'll never eat cake again. Not for birthdays, not for holidays. This is your punishment. The next time you want to stab a lantern with a knife, think about how good cake tastes and stop. Remember, DARE (Don't Attack Reusable Electronics)!

Name: Recruit
Mnemonic: A greenhouse is the newest power of the city you decided to recruit. You’re trying to recruit all the buildings in town and the greenhouse was the next on your list. It adds just a little bit of power to the town, but it's important nonetheless. Imagine what you had to do to recruit this greenhouse. Imagine schmoozing with the previous greenhouse owners to recruit them to your cause and sell you the greenhouse.
ReadingMnemonic: After you recruit the greenhouse, you recruit Bobo (ぼ) the clown to guard it for you. Bobo the clown has a terrifying amount of power so he’ll make an excellent guard for the greenhouse. Recruit Bobo the clown. Look at him. He’s terrifying. Bobo will make for a great deterrent for entry to your greenhouse.

Name: Reparation
Mnemonic: The leader presents you with a prize as reparation for his past deeds. This leader wronged you in the past and wishes to make amends. Therefore the leader presents you with a reparation in the form of a glittering prize. Imagine receiving your reparation prize. Feel the prize in your hand. It’s all wrapped up but it’s heavy and feels expensive. What could it be?
ReadingMnemonic: The leader who presented you with this reparation is the Shougun (しょう) of Japan. He's trying to make up for all the threats he made to you and some of the things you saw (which he's now trying to cover up for). Imagine receiving your reparations from the Shougun himself. You're angry at him for threatening you, wounding people, and cutting off the heads of people who go against him, but you take it anyway.

Name: Resist
Mnemonic: Everyone from your clan puts their fingers in the ground as a way to resist their lords. Your clan is made of a bunch of peasants, but you aren't going to work the land for other people anymore. You're going to resist. This is a protest! Your fingers work for no one but yourselves from now on! Imagine your entire clan putting their fingers in the ground in unison as a form of resistance. It's a moving sight.
ReadingMnemonic: You're all resisting with your fingers in the ground, when the lords appear, angry. "You resist us by hiding your fingers with potatoes in the ground?! You want your fingers to be useless potatoes so badly? We'll chop them up and turn them into tater (てい) tots!" You make your choice to resist. He orders his guards to pull your fingers out of the ground, chop them into the size of tater tots, and then deep fry them. After they're done, the lord pops one in his mouth and says, "Oooh, resistance is delicious."

Name: Return
Mnemonic: This door is big and you need to return it to its rightful owner. This door is too big and important looking to not belong to someone. You need to find its owner and return it to them. Heft this big door in your arms. It’s very heavy. Feel your arms tire as you look for who to return the door to.
ReadingMnemonic: You are in return mode (もど). When you enter this mode, you concentrate only on returning something. Nothing else matters in this mode. You’re in full on return mode. You’re obsessed with returning this big door. Once you enter this mode, the only way to get out is to return the thing you have.

Name: Shining
Mnemonic: The sun calls out to the earth by shining down on it. The sun doesn't have a voice, unfortunately, so it calls out the only way it can, with its shining rays.
ReadingMnemonic: This shining is aimed directly at the Shougun (しょう). The sun is shining on the Shougun to not only show its support for his leadership, but to let him shine brighter than anyone else in Japan. Picture the Shougun standing in the shining sunlight. He's so bright and beautiful!

Name: Silk
Mnemonic: Put thread in the mouth of a worm while the moon is out and it will poop out some silk. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen. Picture feeding some thread into the mouth of a worm as the light from the full moon shines in on you. See the silk come out of the worm's butt and into your hands.
ReadingMnemonic: Wearing silk is the key (き) to not being nude (ぬ). Wear it! Picture yourself wearing nothing but silk. Silk shirt, silk pants, even silk underwear. It feels great against the skin! And most importantly, you're not nude.

Name: Skewer
Mnemonic: The skewer radical and the skewer kanji are exactly the same! Know your radicals, yo.
ReadingMnemonic: Uh oh, this skewer is really... cushy (くし). It's so soft and cushy you can't get any meat or vegetables onto it. Imagine trying to use this cushy skewer. It's the right shape (long, thin, pointy at one end), but every time you try to put something on it it squishes in on itself like a long marshmallow.

Name: Tenacious
Mnemonic: Happiness is a circle that's tenacious. In other words, we're all in this circle/cycle where we do whatever we can to grab onto happiness and hold it as tightly as we can. Be tenacious about happiness in your life. No matter how many times it slips away, don't give up. Keep going after it, because it will absolutely come back if you're tenacious enough.
ReadingMnemonic: Happiness is as tenacious as a shih tzu (しつ) with a shoe (しゅう). That little dog does not want to give up on the shoe, no matter what's happening around it. Will someone take the shoe sometimes? Yeah, but the shih tzu doesn't give up. That's how you need to be with happiness. Kids, be tenacious!

Name: Traces
Mnemonic: When you're stepping around with your foot again and again, you'll leave behind traces all over the place. Picture yourself stepping around with your foot again and again, leaving traces all over the place. Anyone would be able to trace you like this, but you just love a good little stomping around.
ReadingMnemonic: Turns out you leaving traces everywhere is quite sexy (せき) to a lot of people. You're absolutely surrounded by all these people attracted to your sexy stomping around with your foot, again and again. Look, no shaming here, whatever floats your boat.

Name: Whittle Down
Mnemonic: A triceratops with a moon knife can whittle down anything. Imagine the triceratops with its little moon knife, doing some whittling. Hand it anything and it will whittle it down.
ReadingMnemonic: Everything it will whittle down shall be put in a sack (さく). Check out the sack that holds all the things that the triceratops whittled down. Go ahead and look through it, it's quite filled.

Name: Have
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means have.

Name: Hot Pepper
Mnemonic: You see something with a flag on it and put it in your mouth. It was spicy! You look at the little flag and it says... hot pepper.

Name: Prefecture
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means prefecture.

Name: Think
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means think.

Name: Tooth
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means tooth.

Name: Accompany
Mnemonic: A leader asks half of his men to accompany him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him. Imagine you are one of the leader’s men who volunteered. What made you want to accompany him? Imagine the good qualities of this leader and how he inspired you to accompany him on this mission.
ReadingMnemonic: The leader you decided to accompany is none other than Han (はん) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome. Imagine yourself as you accompany Han Solo. You try to stay calm, but you’re just so excited to be around Han Solo.

Name: Age
Mnemonic: You get tooth orders. You get these tooth orders various times in your life, depending on your age. You get baby age tooth orders (to get your first teeth). You get child age tooth orders (to get your adult teeth). Then you get old age tooth orders (when you start losing your teeth). There are tooth orders for every age.
ReadingMnemonic: Gaining and losing teeth aren't the only things dependent on age. There is also an age in which you get your first ray (れい) gun. Decide what age you have to be to get your first ray gun, and then imagine getting it when you hit that age. Perhaps you use this ray gun on your teeth, to keep them clean.

Name: Best Regards
Mnemonic: By showing the roof of your top hat you send your best regards. Giving your best regards is basically just tipping your hat and showing the roof of it.
ReadingMnemonic: When you give your best regards you always yell YOLO (よろ) to the other person. YOLO means "you only live once," so in a way that's a good way to give your best regards. At the very least, it's an interesting way.

Name: Bite
Mnemonic: Your mouth has a tooth that you use to bite and chew with. Imagine that one tooth in your mouth chewing through everything. It's not easy to chew with only one tooth, but luckily yours is huge and razor-sharp, so it helps you to bite and chew your way through anything you like.
ReadingMnemonic: Your one tooth is so strong that you can even use it to bite and chew up a whole  car (か). Some people like eating cars, and you're one of them. You can't get enough of those delicious cars. You just bite them apart and chew.

Name: Bribe
Mnemonic: Someone is offering you a shellfish in exchange for a kiss. This is a bribe! You don't want to kiss them, but that shellfish sure looks tasty. "Come on, don't you want this shellfish?" they ask, shaking it up and down at you.
ReadingMnemonic: You go through with the bribe and kiss the person, but then they snatch hold of the shellfish and run straight down the road (ろ). No!! This is why you never accept a bribe. One second you're staring a yummy shellfish in the face, and the next you're standing alone in the road feeling used.

Name: Bribe
Mnemonic: The more shellfish you have, the more you can bribe people. That worked in the olden days when shells were money, and today too if the people you want to bribe really like seafood. Imagine bribing a bunch of yakuza and politicians with all the shellfish you have. Ohohoh, you'll never be caught!
ReadingMnemonic: Welp, the cops found out about your bribe, that didn't last long, and now your entire family is watching you get put into the police car screaming, "WHY (わい)?! Yeah really, why? Why bribe people at all. You could have just been rolling in shellfish dough. Why risk everything?
