Name: Cluster
Mnemonic: The door in that direction is among a cluster of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it. Imagine seeing all these doors, this cluster of doors. You feel confused at which one to enter but finally pick one. Hear the door creak as you open it.
ReadingMnemonic: After you make it through the door, you come across another cluster of doors. Which one to choose? There's a loud thunderous sound coming from behind one and you decide to open it. Behind it, there's an entire bowling (ぼう) alley and people bowling, loudly! Watch as clusters of pins fall when the bowling balls hit them. You back up and peek through one of the other doors in the cluster and it also houses a bowling alley. Huh.

Name: Consider
Mnemonic: A tiger needs to think and consider its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation. Look at this tiger as it approaches you. Think what things it has to consider. It has to consider how big of a threat you are and so on. You need to consider how you’re going to escape from this tiger.
ReadingMnemonic: It's considering you for so long that it takes out a robe (りょ), a pipe, and an armchair and starts puffing away, staring intently at you. You didn't even know tigers could wear robes, but this one seems to use it to help itself think. Consider this! Tigers look great in robes.

Name: Consign
Mnemonic: They say if you put things on a slide, seven things to be exact, that’s the best way to consign goods to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em. Imagine what seven things you consign over to this other person for safekeeping. Visualize them in your head as you slide each one down the slide.
ReadingMnemonic: One of the seven things you consign over to this guy is a tack (たく). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt. Let’s imagine what it would be like to hit this tack while sliding on the slide. It would hurt. Good thing you are consigning it over to someone. Probably safer for everyone that way.

Name: Contrary
Mnemonic: Past stamps usually depict images contrary to current views. Look at this stamp. There's Columbus being hugged by a bunch of South American natives. Yikes, that's contrary to how things went, that's for sure.
ReadingMnemonic: Don't be the type of person who acts contrary to how they should and instead be like Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. They're always so nice and polite and they don't give diseases to entire populations of people. Be contrary to the evildoers of the past and be like Kyaku instead.

Name: Cord
Mnemonic: The kind of thread you'd wrap around someone would have to be a cord. A regular thread wouldn't be strong enough, so you'd definitely use a cord. Imagine taking that cord and wrapping it around someone (with their permission, of course). Feel your fingers tightening a knot in the cord. Then tie the other end around yourself. Is this some freaky ritual to deepen your connection to them, or… ? Hey, no judgment from me.
ReadingMnemonic: Actually, you're tying this cord around someone as part of a show (しょ). What kind of a show? I really shouldn't say. This cord show isn't free, I'll tell you that much. Imagine doing this cord show on stage. Feel the heat of the stage lights and the gaze of the audience as your tie your cord. What are they expecting? Why did they pay to see this? Must be some kind of modern performance art — let's go with that.

Name: Demand
Mnemonic: In the rain I take my rake and shake it, making a demand that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it! Go out into the rain and shake your rake. Imagine shouting your demand at the sky as the rain pelts you from above.
ReadingMnemonic: Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's juice (じゅ)! You shake your rake harder, and demand that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box. Picture yourself demanding more rain from the sky, trying to fill up your tiny juice box with what little juice rain you were able to get.

Name: Disc
Mnemonic: You offer a hot pepper to the king, and he gives you a drop of something. You look down at the drop to see it transforming into a disc. And not just any old disc at that. It's a jade disc. You took a long time to pick out the perfect hot pepper. Only the best for the king, right? It burned your hands a little as you held it on your way to the palace. You were hoping for something pretty special in return, but you never imagined it would be a drop that magically turns into a disc. Wow!
ReadingMnemonic: Wait, did a drop really just change into a disc? What the heck is (へき) going on? You start to realize just how crazy the situation is. Seriously. How the heck is a drop able to turn into a jade disc?

Name: Do
Mnemonic: A mole in winter will do whatever you ask, if you know how to ask it. They do most of their own chores during the rest of the year, so winter is when you should ask them to do things for you.
ReadingMnemonic: To get the mole to do what you want, just give it a nice big hunk of cheese (ち). Moles will do anything for cheese, but honestly, wouldn't we all?

Name: Dodge
Mnemonic: You're on a scooter and suddenly someone throws a hot pepper at you and you have to dodge it. Imagine riding your scooter, dodging multiple hot peppers as they're tossed at you. A few of them get stuck in the wheels and keep coming around and around, and you have to dodge them too.
ReadingMnemonic: As you dodge the hot peppers, you feel a strong heat (ひ) fill your body. You can't tell if this heat is from the effort from dodging or if you didn't dodge right and one of the hot peppers touched you. Or maybe the scooter is overheating. Feel the heat flow through your body. It's getting harder to dodge as the heat grows and you start sweating!

Name: Draw
Mnemonic: When you see flowers in a rice paddy you can't help but use your fingers to draw them. Have you ever seen rice paddy flowers? They're beautiful. And if you can draw them you can capture that beauty and show it to everyone. Imagine using your fingers to draw these rice paddy flowers. Don't worry about how well you can draw, this is so beautiful, anyone could capture it.
ReadingMnemonic: Even though you tried to draw the flowers as best you could, whenever someone looks at it they smell B.O. (びょう). Maybe it's because you were drawing for a really long time and kept sweating. Maybe it's because you are just a stinky person. But no one wants to look at your drawing for long because all they can smell is B.O. To be fair, would you want to look at a drawing that makes you constantly smell stinky B.O.? I didn't think so.

Name: Edition
Mnemonic: You got your copy of "The Dry Knife." It's the newest edition of the magazine you love on keeping your knives dry. You're really into this magazine, and when you heard there's a new edition of it, you went out and bought it right away.
ReadingMnemonic: In this edition of "The Dry Knife," there is a huge article written by Genghis Khan (かん) on how he kept his knives dry while campaigning. The article on Genghis Khan was perhaps the best written article in the Dry Knife series to date. How did this magazine get such a big interview?

Name: Escape
Mnemonic: You use your scooter when the omen comes so that you can escape. Unfortunately, the omen is riding a scooter too, so you're going to have to be crafty to escape this omen properly.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to escape this omen by weaving in and out of the busy streets of とうきょう. By now, you know とうきょう like the back of your hand, so you're sure you can escape this way. Imagine scooting in and out of とうきょう traffic, the omen looming ever further back behind you. You're doing it! You're escaping!

Name: Handle
Mnemonic: Where do you put your fingers when you're on an escalator? On the handle! Okay, so maybe it's not a handle and more of a railing, but for the sake of this kanji, picture a handle instead. Imagine being on an escalator and wrapping your fingers around a small handle on your way up or down. It's still a bit precarious, truth be told.
ReadingMnemonic: You put your hand on the handle and an old person leans in close to you and says, "暑か?" (あつか). He wants to know if the handle is ... hot? Before you can respond he says it again, and again! “暑か？！ 暑か？！？！ 暑か？！？！？！” he's shouting as you slowly ride the escalator away from him. 暑か? Is the handle hot? Think about it. Is it? What does your imagination tell you?

Name: Interior
Mnemonic: If there’s a drop on your head and the rice is big, you know you’re in the interior. And by interior, I mean you’re actually inside someone. The rice is big because you’ve shrunk to a tiny size and are inside someone’s stomach. The drop on your head is actually digestive fluid. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s tummy. See the big pieces of rice all around you as drops of stomach fluid continue to drop down on your head.
ReadingMnemonic: While you’re in the interior of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “Oklahoma” (おく) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!” If you’re unfamiliar with this Oklahoma song, check it out on YouTube. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s belly as you hear this song booming all around you.

Name: Join
Mnemonic: A leader with horns takes a lantern and searches for people to join him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern. Imagine this shady leader approaching you in the night. The lantern light shines in your face. Would you join him?
ReadingMnemonic: The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to join him. You look around and spot a large haystack (へい). You quickly jump into it and hide from him. The last thing you wanted to do was join that guy so you hid in a haystack to avoid him.

Name: Knee
Mnemonic: Under the moon beneath a tree there is a hat filled with water. You stare down into the water and decide to stick your knee in it. Feel the water splash over your knee as you stick it into this hat. It fits really well, the hat is the perfect size for your knee. Now look up at the moonlight filtering through the tree above.
ReadingMnemonic: Suddenly, in your knee, you feel heat and a zap (ひざ)! Your knee is simultaneously burned and electrocuted by the hot water!! Imagine the heat then the zap going through your knee. It isn't a nice heat, it's a hot heat, then BZZZT zap! Your knee was heat zapped pretty bad.

Name: Lean
Mnemonic: You change this geoduck because you want it to lean. Right now it's standing up straight, but you want it to lean to one side instead. Why do you want this geoduck to lean? Try to come up with your own reason. And why don't you look up what a geoduck looks like one more time for good measure. You don't want to be able to get this image out of your head.
ReadingMnemonic: To get the geoduck to lean you put a piece of cake (けい) on one of its sides. Watch as the geoduck slowly leans toward the cake, trying to get at it for a taste. But don't let it eat any! Keep putting the cake further and further away so the geoduck has to lean more.

Name: Loose
Mnemonic: The thread on this football is loose. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing. Look at this football. The thread is loose on the football and needs to be tightened. Attempt to tighten the loose thread on the football as you hold it in your hands.
ReadingMnemonic: You finally tighten the loose thread and all of your friends cheer, “You rule!” (ゆる) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man! Listen to your friends shouting “You rule!” and hear their cheers echo in your ears as you toss the football around again.

Name: Play Music
Mnemonic: When it's spring in heaven they play music. To your mortal, human ears it sounds more like snow melting, birds chirping, and plants waking up. Close your eyes and imagine all of the spring sounds that come down to you from heaven in the springtime. Mmm, you can almost smell the damp soil and rain.
ReadingMnemonic: In heaven, the ones that play music are the souls (そう) of the dead. They have a huge band up there, and even though it just seems like normal spring sounds to you, up there in heaven when the souls play music it's more like a huge, 100-part band! Picture all of the souls in heaven playing spring music together!

Name: Pregnant
Mnemonic: A woman who has a landslide getting ready inside her is pregnant. And that baby is gonna come out like a landslide. Picture an ultrasound of the pregnant woman, but instead of a little baby heartbeat, you hear a scary roaring sound. That's what being pregnant is like. Waiting for the landslide to come.
ReadingMnemonic: When you're pregnant the baby is constantly kicking you with their shins (しん). Not their feet, their shins. And shins are really hard, let me tell you. Imagine being pregnant and getting kicked by the shins of your baby all day, but especially all night. You're so tired. Please let this landslide come already.

Name: Pregnant
Mnemonic: A woman sleeps with the king and becomes pregnant. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby! The king radical is slightly altered in this kanji, so just remember that the king is a strange alien and not human. Imagine being this woman and having this half-breed alien baby inside you. Feels weird.
ReadingMnemonic: Being pregnant with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play Nintendo (にん). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore. What game are you playing on the Nintendo? Maybe it’s a game where you kill alien invaders? That’s messed up.

Name: Presents
Mnemonic: You put on the shellfish mask once per year and break into people's beach houses, leaving behind presents. You're like beach santa, except you're real and you wear a mask made of shellfish.
ReadingMnemonic:
The "presents" you leave? They are actually just zombies (ぞう). You leave zombies in people's houses. Ooh hoo, it's me! the Shellfish Mask Man!
I go to beach houses and leave presents where I can!
The presents are not clothes, or anything good.
I don't even care if you leave me some food.
Try whipping some up, try cooking me peas,
It matters not, I'll leave you zombies!

Name: Select
Mnemonic: Shove your fingers into a bowl of shrimp to select the best one. You know your shrimp and you know them well, so you won't settle for anything less than the best. Put your whole arm in there and feel around until you can select the one you want most. Feel your fingers touching each and every shrimp, one by one, until they graze the one you select as the perfect shrimp. Slowly pull it out and lower it into your mouth. Munch munch... ahhh! The perfect shrimp.
ReadingMnemonic: You do this at every restaurant, party, and indoor sporting event and people start getting wise to your shrimp selection methods. One day, as you attempt to select your shrimp, a sharp pain shoots through your finger. Ow! You pull your hand back to find... a tack (たく)! Oh, woe is me! How will I select the perfect shrimp with my fingers if there are tacks in the shrimp bowls! Boohoohoo!

Name: Send Back
Mnemonic: There's a scooter coming toward you with a net trapping a weird zombie on it. You don't want this here, so you decide to send back the zombie. (It's a weird zombie because it has the ground on top of its head instead of dirt!) You want to send back this zombie the way it came. You definitely don't want it loose in your neighborhood.
ReadingMnemonic: As you prepare to send back the zombie, you imagine yourself as Genghis Khan (かん). On your horse (it's just your own scooter) you stab forward with your spear (stick), swing the scooter the zombie is on, and send it back from whence it came! You managed to send back the zombie, good for you! Genghis Khan would be proud.

Name: Spin
Mnemonic: You have thread and some syrup and you need to spin them together. Drip the syrup onto the thread and spin it around and around over your head. Imagine carefully dripping syrup onto a thread and then spinning it in a circle.
ReadingMnemonic: As you spin the syrup, it begins to change shape and forms into a cookie (く)! Haven't you ever made syrup-spun cookies before? The spinning forms and cooks them in the air. Imagine eating a syrup cookie you made by spinning it yourself. Homemade is always better than store-bought.

Name: Suppress
Mnemonic: Use your fingers on the cat pirate to suppress him. The cat pirate was attacking you, so you took your fingers and pet his head and scratched his chin. Now he's calm and suppressed. He doesn't even remember why he was attacking you. Imagine suppressing a cat pirate with your own fingers. His fur is so soft, but his nails are so sharp!
ReadingMnemonic: He forgot, but you know you had to suppress the cat pirate because he was trying to steal your egg yolk (よく). You were making breakfast on your ship and the cat pirate boarded you out of nowhere, and tried to take it by force. Defend the yolk! Smell the smell of eggs in the air as you suppress the cat pirate. Maybe even share the yolk with him, once he's done trying to kill you for it. And then enjoy breakfast while petting your new cat friend.

Name: Suspend
Mnemonic: In your prefecture, you come from a long lineage of people who share one heart. When the heart is passed on to the next in line, it flies out of their body, and suspends itself in the sky, for you to take. You see the suspended heart in the distance, and make your way towards it.
ReadingMnemonic: You arrive at the suspended heart. There in front of it, protecting it, is Ken (けん) the samurai. "I've protected this suspended heart for you, for you are next in the lineage to receive it." He grabs the heart and throws it into your body.

Name: Title
Mnemonic: You take a grain and fashion it into a gun that is small, earning you the title of Small Arms Dealer (or SAD). Congratulations! This isn't exactly a title you're proud of, in fact, you're really embarrassed. Maybe you can make a name for yourself in something else so you can get a new title.
ReadingMnemonic: Word of your SAD title makes it all the way to the Shougun (しょう) and he travels out to see you. When he arrives at your door, with all of his fancy escorts, he hands you a plaque with your title on it. The plaque says, "No one is more deserving of this SAD title." - Love, the Shougun.

Name: Tray
Mnemonic: Your boat holds your weapon like a plate. So in a way, it's just a tray for your weapon. A big boat shaped like a plate is just a tray. You keep your weapons on it, nice and flat.
ReadingMnemonic: Unfortunately, this boat tray is so huge, it's gotten you banned (ばん) from the Small Boat Tray Association. Those pesky small boat tray enthusiasts... Your ban from the Small Boat Tray Association has led to a massive feud between large boat tray enthusiasts and small boat tray enthusiasts, and it seems like it'll never end—leading to bans all over the place. If only we could all come together as enthusiasts of boat trays of all sizes...

Name: Buddy
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means buddy.

Name: Former
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means former.

Name: Hill
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means hill.

Name: Nurse
Mnemonic: This radical is made up of blackjack and clothes with the six kanji on top. If you see six people playing blackjack and wearing the same clothes you should know that they're all nurses. Nurses play blackjack together to cool down between shifts and they usually don't have time to change out of their uniforms. That's why this radical is nurse.

Name: Reality
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means reality.

Name: Scroll
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means scroll.

Name: Sky
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means sky.

Name: Three
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means three.

Name: Abstain
Mnemonic: Raise your fingers to the sky to symbolize that you abstain from something. If someone offers you fur coats, raise your fingers to abstain. If someone tries to get you to bully someone, raise your fingers to abstain. Abstaining from doing what other people are doing is important sometimes. So make sure you never forget the universal abstaining symbol.
ReadingMnemonic: This symbol to abstain comes from the hicatee (ひか) turtle. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its meat, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee are endangered. So people started to rally around them, abstaining from hurting them anymore. They raised their fingers to the sky and shouted, "I abstain from harming these hicatee!" Picture yourself in Central America. Standing in the water, blocking poachers from the hicatee turtles. "Abstain!" you shout at them.

Name: Address
Mnemonic: On your roof every evening you meet with snakes. All snakes know your address. You're snake famous. Snakes go on a pilgrimage to your address every evening. Your address is passed down from snake generation to snake generation.
ReadingMnemonic: The snakes come to your address every night to receive the greatest gift you can give a snake: a 手 (あて). "You only give a 手 a night. Newcomers might have a 手 or two, but some snakes who have been coming to your address for years have hundreds of 手s.

Name: Allocate
Mnemonic: The allocate radical and the allocate kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: If you allocate your funds correctly you'll be able to buy as many precious jewels (じゅう) as you want! However, jewels are expensive, so if you don't allocate any money, you won't be able to afford any. Ever. Picture all the jewels you were able to buy because you allocated your funds correctly. Imagine swimming in these jewels. Like a rich duck.

Name: Bitter
Mnemonic: There's a tsunami coming and you can't stop the explosion of bitterness in your mouth. You're scared. Your mouth tastes bitter and astringent. You're reluctant to face this bitter end at the hands of a tsunami.
ReadingMnemonic: With the bitter taste in your mouth, you reluctantly gather up all of your jewels (じゅう) and wait for the tsunami to take you away. At least with your jewels with you, there may be some hope of selling them and building a better life if you make it. Try to stuff some of the jewels into your bitter mouth before the tsunami stops you.

Name: Branch Off
Mnemonic: A mountain branch will branch off from the rest. Picture this part of the mountain, branching off from the rest, into a mysterious path of its own.
ReadingMnemonic: If you want to branch off from your hiking group and explore this branch of the mountain, you need a special key (き). Just don't get caught down there or you'll get the guillotine (ぎ). If you branch off from the beaten path, you need 1) access, and 2) to be really careful so you keep your head.

Name: Buzzer
Mnemonic: You take gold in exchange for executing orders to construct a buzzer. You are a small bell maker and someone orders you to make one into a buzzer in exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living. Imagine the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you construct this buzzer with your bare hands. Feel the cool metal clink around in your hands as you put it together.
ReadingMnemonic: Finally the buzzer is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes ring (りん)! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do. Wait, should this buzzer be buzzing or ringing? Oh well, you got your gold. It’s the client’s problem now.

Name: Cape
Mnemonic: There is something odd sticking out of the dirt. Oh wait, it's just the cape jutting out into the water below. Phew. It's just the cape sticking out into the sea. Haha, for a second... you thought... no...
ReadingMnemonic: The cape below looks just like your cyborg (さい). Or rather, the cyborg you once had, before you had to give him up. It's kinda cross-shaped, it has a slide part, and lots of little fleshy bits. Ah, the memories. Picture the cape (the land mass that sticks out into water) but it's shaped just like your old cyborg. Weep a single tear.

Name: Chess Piece
Mnemonic: A tree crab breaks into your games cabinet and steals a chess piece. He’s trying to impress all his tree crabs back home by showing how not afraid of humans he is. Plus the rest of the tree crabs need one last chess piece to complete their set. Imagine finding this tree crab in your games cabinet trying to make off with your chess piece. This tree crab is big and you weren’t expecting to find it in your games cabinet so you’re kind of terrified. You scream in horror.
ReadingMnemonic: Before the tree crab can make it out with the chess piece, you shut the door to the games cabinet and lock it with a key (き), trapping the tree crab inside. Now what? You put the key in your pocket and call animal control. They unlock the cabinet with the key and remove the tree crab from your home. But who’s to say he won’t be back??

Name: Criminal
Mnemonic: Inside this giant mouth is a person, trapped, because they're a criminal. They did something bad (they touched the mouth of another person without consent) and now they're in mouth jail for criminals. Picture the criminal, trapped inside the mouth. They don't even look sorry!
ReadingMnemonic: The criminal is only wearing shoes (しゅう). They're completely naked otherwise. They have to wear shoes because the mouth jail would be too slippery for them to stand otherwise. Wearing nothing but shoes is also really uncomfortable too, so it's actually part of the criminal's punishment. They don't seem to know that though.

Name: Defer
Mnemonic: When you say "Nurse!" you're probably asking to defer to them in some way, shape, or form. There's many situations where you'd want to defer to a nurse, like when somebody is seriously hurt and you don't know what to do to help them. Just imagine yourself saying "Nurse!" in order to defer to them for their medical knowledge.
ReadingMnemonic: The reason you’re trying to defer to a nurse is because you’re trying to save the local farmhand, Joe (じょう). He’s seriously injured, and you don’t know how to help him, so you’ll have to defer to the knowledge of a nurse. You’re starting to panic because you don’t know to help Joe, so you’re just going around saying “Nurse! Nurse!” repeatedly, desperately looking for someone you could defer to. Nurse!!!

Name: Employ
Mnemonic: Whenever a turkey comes in the door, you employ them. Imagine hundreds of turkeys walking in. The word has gotten out amongst the turkey community that if they walk through your door, you'll employ them.
ReadingMnemonic: Although you employ turkeys, when a 子 (こ) walks through your door, you send them away. "I will employ turkeys, but I will never employ children!" you exclaim.

Name: Excuse
Mnemonic: The excuse radical and the excuse kanji are exactly the same! Dandy! Know your radicals, stop making excuses.
ReadingMnemonic: Who always makes excuse after excuse? Men (めん)! They have an excuse for everything. Why didn’t you take out the trash? Why did you forget my birthday? It’s just excuse after excuse with men. So I’ve heard, anyway. Imagine all the men you’ve talked to in your life. Think of every excuse they’ve told you. Think of the worst excuse you’ve ever heard. Remember that.

Name: Flock
Mnemonic: Your buddy the sheep is part of a flock. A flock of sheep. Your sheep buddy is a member of a flock. Imagine following your sheep buddy back to his flock. Feel the soft fur of all the sheep around you as they baa peacefully.
ReadingMnemonic: Now take out your gun (ぐん) and murder every sheep in the flock. Except for your buddy. You’re incredibly jealous of your buddy and you don’t like the attention his flock gives him so that’s why you decided to murder them all with a gun. Feel the recoil of the gun in your hands and the ringing of the shots in your ears as you slaughter the flock without remorse. BANG BANG BANG!

Name: Frame
Mnemonic: In a tree on nine branches are some cross frames. Each cross frame is hung on the branches of the tree. You don’t know who decided to hang the frames there, but you think it might be some new wave art or something. Actually you need a frame, and there are already nine up there, so you decide to take one. Feel the tree bark under your palms as you climb up the tree to take a frame. You get a splinter from grabbing the frame. It really smarts.
ReadingMnemonic: You realize that the frame isn't half as nice as you thought it was, in fact it's totally wack (わく). How disappointing. Why is this frame so wack? Think about what makes it wack, to help you remember this reading.

Name: Gun
Mnemonic: You need to allocate enough gold to buy a gun. Guns are weapons of the old world, so you can't just buy them with paper money. Guns have to be bought with gold coins and slabs and bricks. Picture yourself handing over an armful of gold bars to buy a single gun.
ReadingMnemonic: You need this gun so you can steal some jewels (じゅう)! Why didn't you just use your gold to buy the jewels, you ask? Because! That's not how we did things in olden days. When you want jewels you buy a gun with gold and rob a jewelry store! Picture an old fashioned hold up. You're holding a gun and shoveling jewels into a burlap sack. The heist of the century!

Name: Hermit
Mnemonic: A leader who lives in a mountain is a hermit. The only thing this hermit is a leader of now is mountain goats. This hermit dislikes people so that’s why he lives in a mountain now. Imagine this odd hermit leading mountain goats around the mountain, marching to the beat of a drum. It’s a strange sight indeed.
ReadingMnemonic: One day the hermit was leading the mountain goats around and he ran into a centaur (せん). The centaur said that he was the rightful leader of these mountain goats so the centaur challenged the hermit to a duel. Picture this old hermit fighting this centaur in a duel. Who do you think is gonna win? Hear the hermit screaming in agony as the centaur demolishes him.

Name: Home Country
Mnemonic: There are three slides sticking out of this building that lead to your home country. The rest of the slides go to other places, but three are yours. Imagine standing at the top of the building and looking down at the three slides that stretch off toward your home country. It takes a few hours to slide all the way there, but at the end you'll be home.
ReadingMnemonic: Your home country is your home (ほう)! Even if you move, even if you haven't been back in years, your home country will always be your home in some way, deep down.

Name: Honorable
Mnemonic: You loiter around with a gun while your friend tries to correct a stamp to make it more honorable. Someone messed with the stamp machine and your friend is trying to correct the error. You’re loitering around with a gun since you’re his bodyguard. To have an error on the stamp would not be honorable, so that’s why your friend is going to correct it. Feel the weight of the gun in your hands as your friend works to make the stamp honorable again. Listen to your friend complain about how there are so few people left in the world that are honorable. Also keep in mind that the correct radical is a little different with the vertical line going through the top, so just think of that as the error trying to be corrected.
ReadingMnemonic: Just as you’re pondering what it means to be honorable, your friend gets shot by Godzilla (ご). Godzilla must have been the one who ruined the stamp! "Go, go, save yourself, Godzilla got me!" your friend cries. You run, leaving your friend and Godzilla to their honorable battle. A single tear runs down your cheek.

Name: Humility
Mnemonic: When someone wants to view the reality of your soul, show it with humility. Because the reality is... our souls are all a little dirty. And we haven't been the best versions we could be. So make sure when you show all of yourself you do so with some humility. Focus on the feeling of humility here. You're putting it all out there, you know? With nowhere to hide.
ReadingMnemonic: As humility washes over you, you feel a shaking in your shins (しん). Humility lives in your shins, so now they're shaking and trying to bring you down to the ground. Imagine humility literally moving through your shins. Can you still stand or do you need to fall to your shins, in humility?

Name: Leap
Mnemonic: You use your foot to kick Wolverine in the face so a turkey can leap to freedom. This turkey is trying to escape from Wolverine by leaping over a fence. Wolverine doesn’t want the turkey to escape, but you kick him with your foot and the turkey is then free to leap to safety. Imagine kicking Wolverine in the head with your foot as the turkey makes turkey sounds in the background. He’s taller than you so you must leap as you kick.
ReadingMnemonic: After you kick Wolverine and the turkey is safe, you leap onto a yak (やく) to make your getaway. This yak is really fast so you’ll have no problem outrunning Wolverine while riding it. Leap! Leap onto the yak. Feel the yak fur beneath you as you ride away to safety, wind in your hair.

Name: Modesty
Mnemonic: They say Mona Lisa had more modesty than any other woman at the time. Leonardo da Vinci picked her for her modesty. She's so modest she shows no emotion.
ReadingMnemonic: The modesty of Mona Lisa inspired Ken (けん) the samurai to become more modest. Have you met Ken the samurai in person? He never smiles, and will never show you his emotions. He's too modest for that.

Name: Mound
Mnemonic: A drop of rain falls on a bear leaning up against a cross stuck into a mound. The drop wakes the bear up and he rolls down off the mound. After the bear rights himself, he assumes that the cross pushed him off the mound so he charges into the cross atop the mound and knocks it over. Imagine this whole scene. A drop of water rouses the bear and he becomes enraged after he rolls down the mound. Hear the bear roar with anger as he charges up the mound and violently smashes the cross into the ground.
ReadingMnemonic: Once the bear fully wakes up he realizes that he just rolled down the mound on his own and the cross was not to blame. What a fool (ふ) this bear was. He knows it too. The bear feels pretty foolish. Now look at the bear sitting atop the mound with his head in his paws, looking like a fool filled with regret. This bear feels like a fool for attacking the cross like he did.

Name: One Sided
Mnemonic: The one sided radical and the one sided kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Think of anything that is one sided. A battle. A sports game. A relationship. What makes them so one sided? One side always has a catapult (かた). Imagine a one sided situation that you've had. Now imagine the winning side with a catapult. For example, a baseball game where one team is destroying the other. That's because instead of a pitcher, they have a catapult.

Name: Paragraph
Mnemonic: Construction for geoducks doesn't require as much paperwork as construction for humans, but you still need to write at least a paragraph to explain what you're doing. Actually imagine yourself writing one paragraph of explanation to the city so you can get the permits to construct housing for your geoducks. On the form, it specifies you should only write a paragraph.
ReadingMnemonic: You turn in your paragraph, and it is given to Emperor こういち, who insists on being involved in all construction projects. Surprisingly, he approves your construction project, thanks to that paragraph you wrote in the application. In that paragraph, you praised こういち for being a great emperor, and you said that this construction project would help you to have more time to do your WaniKani reviews. Clearly you were pandering to Emperor こういち when you wrote it. But hey, it worked!

Name: Patterned
Mnemonic: Criminal writing is always patterned. That is to say, there is a pattern to it, lots of ARGS and GONNA STAB YAs, but it's also patterned beautifully, with a collage of cut out letters. Can you see the patterns in the writing this criminal did? It looks like a quilt or some plaid. It's almost beautiful, the way those death threats are arranged!
ReadingMnemonic: As you look closer at the patterned writing you realize that it forms the shape of an eagle (い). The most American bird of them all! Maybe this guy isn't a criminal after all! Picture an eagle patterned out of cut out letters. What the words say isn't important (though it is asking for a ransom on your grandma), but the underlying image is gorgeous.

Name: Prosperity
Mnemonic: A building in winter will allow life to have prosperity. Before we had buildings it was impossible to have any prosperity in winter because everything was cold and most of us died. Picture a dark, bleak winter landscape. No life anywhere. Now turn around and look at the prosperity on display in the building you're in. Everyone is happy and eating food and not freezing to death.
ReadingMnemonic: This prosperity isn't good for everyone though. You look over and see Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter sitting in the corner. He's got everything he could ask for. He's won the tournament, he's got money, he's got this nice big building, but now he's depressed. Ryu's prosperity has made him realize that having things isn't always enough. Now he's looking wistfully outside at the winter weather, missing the rough times.

Name: Range
Mnemonic: Your mouth contains a scroll, which you pull out and look at. On the scroll is a map, showing the range of the sphere of your mouth. On the map, there is a circle drawn around your mouth showing what range your mouth exists in. Thankfully, your tongue and teeth are within that sphere.
ReadingMnemonic: Looking at the range of your mouth on the map, you notice a tiny samurai marked near your molars. It is Ken (けん) the samurai. Everything else on the map was accurate, so you take a close look in the mirror, and there he is: a tiny Ken the samurai, protecting the range that is your mouth. He gives you a small nod and goes back to his post.

Name: Refuse
Mnemonic: Show your fingers to a giant to show you refuse him. Giants are very big. So big that when you talk they can't really hear what you're saying. Hold up all your fingers so that he can see what you mean. Imagine holding up your fingers to show a giant you're refusing to let him do something. Yeesh, you're brave!
ReadingMnemonic: What do you refuse? You refuse to let him stomp all over Little Kyoto (きょ). Little Kyoto is your home! And if the giant comes any closer he's going to destroy all the little buildings and shrines and soba noodle shops. Imagine standing in front of a giant, refusing to let him crush Little Kyoto. I hope he doesn't stomp on you instead.

Name: Rice Plant
Mnemonic: The grain stuck in your cleat had a former life. In that life it was a rice plant. It was a happy little rice plant, minding its own business, when it was yanked up, cleaned, and put in a bag for people to buy and cook and eat. That was so long ago. Now all that's left is this sad loose grain in the bottom of your shoe. When you look at a grain of rice, you should think about how it used to be a rice plant. That rice plant had a family! いいね, you think — that rice plant had a good life.
ReadingMnemonic: The grain of rice thinks about its former life as a rice plant and, like you, mutters "いね." What's that, little rice grain? Are you trying to say life was good? As it reminisces it wants to say "good," but the いいね is tragically cut short… much like the rice plant's life. It doesn't even have the strength to say it properly, it has to say いね. Yes, little grain, your rice plant life really was いね. Because you… were an いね. I'm sorry.

Name: Rob
Mnemonic: A big turkey has to measure a safe before he can rob it. If the safe is too big it won’t fit in his getaway van and the robbery will have been a failure. So before the turkey robs the place he needs to measure the safe. Imagine this turkey as he tries to rob this safe. See him with the tape measure as he determines whether or not the safe is too big.
ReadingMnemonic: The safe that the turkey is trying to rob ends up being uber (うば) big. Like, really uber big. So uber big that the turkey can’t even measure it with his tape measure. There’s no way he’s gonna be able to rob this place. Imagine the size of this uber big safe. What could be inside? Probably something good.

Name: Steel
Mnemonic: You come across a gold hill. You think you hit it big! You start digging, only to find out that it is merely a paper-thin layer of gold covering a hill of steel. Dig out many other spots. Every time, it's just steel under there.
ReadingMnemonic: You report your findings about the steel you found to Emperor こういち. He is displeased that it is a hill of steel. "I suppose I can use this steel, even if it is not a hill of gold," he says. "We will make steel weapons, which we will use to subjugate other nations. The whole world will learn kanji using the WaniKani system!"

Name: Turtle Shell
Mnemonic: The turtle shell radical and the turtle shell kanji are exactly the same! Oddly, this can also be used to talk about the first item in a list, so to mean A out of A through D, for example. Cowabunga! You get an A!
ReadingMnemonic: With a turtle shell on his back, imagine こういち. Because this is WaniKani, こういち has probably set the turtle shell on fire, too. "Burn those turtle shells, burn those kanji!" he yells.

Name: Void
Mnemonic: A tiger, clad in spikes, exists in the void. This tiger is from another dimension where tigers rule the earth, clad in armor with spikes. The void has allowed this tiger to cross dimensional planes. Tigers are pretty intimidating just on their own, let alone with spikey armor. Imagine this tiger, covered in spikes. It’s roaring at you. Pretty scary, huh?
ReadingMnemonic: The aforementioned void has opened up in Little Kyoto (きょ). The spiked void tigers chose to come here in order to face off against the Hanshin Tigers baseball team in battle. It will be a vicious match here in Little Kyoto. Since this is taking place in Little Kyoto and not Japan itself, the Hanshin Tigers won't have the home field advantage. Who will win? Picture this grand match taking place in Little Kyoto. Actual tigers versus the Hanshin Tigers. It’s truly a sight to behold. The void tigers are armed with their spikes and the Hanshin Tigers are armed with their bats. Hear the crack of wood and the roar of tigers in the air as the battle commences.

Name: Wall
Mnemonic: There are hot peppers hiding in this dirt, so you build a wall to protect yourself from them. Have you ever stepped on a really hot pepper? The oils bleed into your shoes and burn your feet! You don't want anyone stepping on these so you wall them up. Picture yourself walking around and seeing a wall around some dirt. You look inside and there are some hot peppers hiding just below the surface. Phew! Good thing this wall was here to protect you from them.
ReadingMnemonic: On the other side of this wall there are much less threatening cobs (かべ) of corn. Corn isn't spicy. It's delicious and sweet, so it's free from being walled in. Picture some corn cobs. Now picture some hot peppers. Put a wall between them.

Name: Welfare
Mnemonic: When a spirit stops protecting you, you'll have to go on welfare. If you can't rely on your family spirit, you'll have to have the help and protection come from somewhere else. The next time you see someone on welfare, be nice. Their spirit stopped protecting them, so they need a little more help right now.
ReadingMnemonic: While on welfare, you have to do the only job available to you: herding sheep (し). Sheep can help you out when you're having a rough time. Sheep provide warmth, wool for clothes, and even food, if you wanna get dark about it. If you've ever been on welfare you probably already know about the sheep.

Name: Employ
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means employ.

Name: Every
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means every.

Name: Preserve
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means preserve.

Name: Rejoice
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means rejoice.

Name: Wheat
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji, but you learned that a really long time ago, so here's a reminder of the mnemonic, just in case:

Name: Abduct
Mnemonic: Your fingers have to stand up straight, to protect you from being abducted, or pulled away against your will. You're convinced someone is trying to abduct you, so you need to keep your fingers standing at all times, ready to defend yourself. Your fingers are feeling pretty stiff, but you still keep them standing, just in case.
ReadingMnemonic: Suddenly, someone really is trying to abduct you. They're pullling you away. It's the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). Help! Luckily, your fingers were standing to attention and you were able to fight off the mighty Ra. He won't try to abduct you again in a hurry. Thank goodness for those standing fingers.

Name: Alert
Mnemonic: Every winter you are alert for danger. Everyone knows that the worst monsters come out in the winter so you need to be alert if you want to survive. Imagine yourself out in the winter wilderness. You hear twigs snapping, growling, leaves rustling. You’re incredibly alert and aware of everything going on around you.
ReadingMnemonic: Being the alert fellow you are, you hear a sasquatch approaching and dive into a trash bin (びん) to hide. The bin smells really bad and you are keenly alert to all the various stenches and smells currently penetrating your nostrils, but at least you are safe. Listen to the sasquatch rumble on by as you continue to smell the smelly smells of this putrid bin you’re in.

Name: Blow
Mnemonic: You attempt to expel wind out of your mouth but lack the breath to blow out any. You’re using your mouth and trying to blow out some air, but you are failing to do so. Blow some air out of your mouth. It’s easy, right? Imagine what could cause you to fail at this activity.
ReadingMnemonic: You silly fool (ふ), the reason you couldn’t blow any air out of your mouth is because your hand was over it. You can’t blow air out that way. You silly fool, you. Attempt to blow air out of your mouth while covering it with your hand. It’s hard to do, right? Only a fool would try to blow air out of their mouth this way.

Name: Chant
Mnemonic: It's time to do the mouth sun sun chant. That's when you use your mouth to chant sun sun, sun sun, sun sun, over and over until the sun appears. Open your mouth and practice the chant right now! Sun sun, sun sun, sun sun!
ReadingMnemonic: You're doing this chant because the Shougun (しょう) ordered you to. The sun hasn't been shining on him as much lately, and he's displeased. So now you have to chant for him. The Shougun is glaring intently at you as you chant. Open your mouth as wide as you can, get all those "sun suns" out, and pray that the sun will appear.

Name: Collide
Mnemonic: If you try to go somewhere but you're too heavy you'll collide with everything. Cars, people, houses. You're too heavy to dodge them, so you collide with it all. Imagine being too heavy to go anywhere without colliding with things.
ReadingMnemonic: You're going around the town, you collide with a bunch of things, when all of a sudden you collide with the Shougun (しょう)! Oh no! The shogun looks really mad. The Shougun is glaring at you from the ground. "You've been colliding with my entire city and now you collide into ME?!" Smoke blows out his nostrils.

Name: Commandment
Mnemonic: The drunkard issued twenty commandments to his people. He basically just made up a bunch of commandments to order all the other drunkards around and decided having twenty (twice the amount of that other religion he heard about) would be a good number.
ReadingMnemonic:
The drunkard is yelling out his twenty commandments to the others at the bar, but they're all about kayaks (かい). Commandment 1: Thou shalt not touch my kayak
Commandment 2: Thou shalt not look at my kayak
Commandment 3: Thou shalt give me beer to put in my kayak

Name: Concurrently
Mnemonic: The Mona Lisa is in front of you. "You must all paint the Mona Lisa concurrently," says your art class teacher. Pay close attention to the students around you. Don't go too fast or too slow, or you won't finish concurrently.
ReadingMnemonic: Your entire class finishes concurrently. You look at your finished result. Wait, that's not the Mona Lisa. You painted Ken (けん) the samurai. It's a nice painting, the frown is just right, and you finished concurrently with everyone else, but you're probably going to fail this class.

Name: Dilute
Mnemonic: The flowers are being worked upon by a tsunami with a drop specialty: this tsunami can dilute flowers with just one tsunami-powered drop of itself. That’s its specialty. Look at the flowers as the tsunami begins to dilute them with just one drop. Their color and fragrance and dimensions become weaker and more spread out. It’s really trippy to witness.
ReadingMnemonic: You watch the flowers become diluted with just one drop, and realize that this is a nature hack (はく). You’ve never seen anything like this before, so you think the tsunami found out how to hack nature and that’s how it got so good at diluting things. By hacking nature. As you continue to watch the tsunami's drop of water dilute the flowers, imagine what techniques this tsunami is using to hack nature. Is the tsunami a sinister being from the future? Maybe.

Name: Ditch
Mnemonic: When you're driving, you may notice the flags in the dirt near the exits. These flags mark the ditch running along the side of the road. You won't want to try to exit the road here or you'll end up stuck in one. Picture the flags in the dirt. Picture the ditch just over the edge of them. Now look for another way to exit this road, cause that way is just not a good idea.
ReadingMnemonic: If you do end up veering into a ditch you'll find yourself yelling, "Holy (ほり) crap!" Then you'll go hurtling into the ditch. It's a pun, get it? Holy. Hole-y. The ditch is a long hole. See? It's funny.

Name: Dose
Mnemonic: Simultaneously, you throw your knife at another person who's throwing a knife at you and you both get a dose of your own medicine. Literally, there's poison on these knives and now you've both been stabbed. Watch as the dose of poison sinks into your body through the knife that's in your chest, as it simultaneously happens to the other guy too.
ReadingMnemonic: "I need a dose of the antidote!" you yell, and the other guy looks you dead in the eyes. They slowly pull a tiny xylophone (ざい) out of their pocket, play a few notes, and then eat it. "Ah, you'd like a dose of the xylophone cure, wouldn't you?" Now you're begging them for a dose of the xylophone drug. Just a taste, you want to live!

Name: Elegant
Mnemonic: A fang on a turkey is elegant. Most turkeys do not have fangs, so this turkey with a fang is quite elegant and dignified. This turkey is special. Look at this turkey with a fang. It’s elegant, but also frightening. See the fanged turkey staring at you menacingly.
ReadingMnemonic: This elegant fang makes the turkey look more like a gargoyle (が) than a turkey. In fact, you haven't seen it move at all. Maybe it is just an elegant gargoyle! Picture this elegant gargoyle sitting in front of you. Reach out your hand and feels its hard, elegant stone gargoyle body.

Name: Emit
Mnemonic: The fingers are where criminals emit or expel all of their bad energy from. Picture a criminal’s fingers, and all of the bad energy just oozing out of them, almost like an exhaust pipe emitting toxic fumes.
ReadingMnemonic: Then you realize what the fingers are actually emitting: terrible, awful haiku (はい). Imagine this criminal's fingers emitting god-awful, cringe-inducing haiku after haiku. Really feel your skin crawl at the shoddiness of this criminal's fingers' haiku.

Name: Filial Piety
Mnemonic: Teachers are all around us. Those who came before us are our teachers, so it's important to respect them. This is the basic idea of filial piety. Respect your elders, for they have much to teach us.
ReadingMnemonic: With filial piety in mind, you decide to go visit your father, who is こういち. I am so ignorant and have much to learn. I must show filial piety to my father, こういち, so that he may teach me.

Name: Frequent
Mnemonic: You walk by a geoduck a frequent amount. This geoduck really intrigues you, so you can’t help but frequent the area the geoduck is in and walk around. Imagine walking around near this geoduck. This is the best area to frequent when you want to look at the geoduck. Just keep looking at it as you walk.
ReadingMnemonic: Apparently Hindu people also love geoducks because Hindu (ひん) people frequent this area quite often as well. You always see the geoduck here, but also a lot of Hindu people. Look at all the Hindu people as you walk around and observe the geoduck. Hear them all speaking Hindi as you continue to walk around.

Name: Gallop
Mnemonic: A horse goes to his favorite district to gallop around. This district has lots of cool buildings and lights to look at, so this horse loves to gallop around there. Hear the horse clip clopping around the district as it continues to gallop. Clip clop, clop clip clop!
ReadingMnemonic: Then the horse gallops into the road and gets hit by a car (か). Oh man, there’s blood everywhere. This horse is never going to gallop again. That car totally destroyed it. The tires screech, the horse neighs, BAM! Total destruction everywhere. Bystanders scream in horror. That horse will never gallop again. It’s a sad day for all horsekind.

Name: Genius
Mnemonic: The leader of all the spiders is a genius! Spiders are already pretty smart. They can weave complex homes and traps in one web. They even know where not to step so they don't get caught. But the leader knows everything. It made itself a little webbed computer and everything! Imagine seeing the leader of the spiders weaving it's own little spider computer. Doing spider math, and spider chemistry. It's a genius!
ReadingMnemonic: As you watch the spider genius you realize that soon (しゅん) spiders will take over the humans. They're just way smarter than us. Soon we'll be the bugs. Soon we'll be slaves to the genius spiders. Soon we'll be the flies.

Name: Glad
Mnemonic: A woman is rejoicing. She must be glad and happy to rejoice out loud in front of you like this. Picture a woman rejoicing loudly. She's got a big smile on her face and she wants you and everyone else to see how glad she is.
ReadingMnemonic: "I'm so glad!" the woman shouts, "Because I found the key (き)!" You immediately start to wonder what "the key" is. The key to life? The key to learning Japanese? Then you see she's holding up some car keys. You'd be happy too if you'd just found your lost keys. Though maybe you wouldn't shout it for the entire world to hear.

Name: Honor
Mnemonic: There’s grass on the ground and the fins there say you have no honor. The fins are left over from the fish you dismembered and they do not believe it was an act of honor. Now they are just sitting on the ground on the grass, calling you out for having no honor. Listen to what the fins have to say as they flop around on the ground in the grass. Hear them swish about as they flop, brushing up against the blades of grass.
ReadingMnemonic: Being one of little honor, you decide to squash these vocal fins with your yo-yo (よ). You take out your yo-yo and start bashing each fin with it until they stop talking about what little honor you have. Imagine taking your yo-yo out to do this. Feel the string tighten around your finger as you unleash the yo-yo and silence all the fins.

Name: Luxuriant
Mnemonic: You take flowers down a slide to a drunkard that you picked from your luxuriant garden. You picked the flowers from the luxuriant garden, not the drunkard, mind you. Also the drunkard has a cane, but not flowers. That’s why you picked some from your luxuriant garden and slid down your cool slide. Now the drunkard has a cane and some flowers. Imagine picking these flowers from your luxuriant garden then shooting down the slide. There are so many flowers that you are simply overwhelmed by their aroma. Now hand your flowers to the drunkard and watch his face light up as he excitedly thanks you for the gift.
ReadingMnemonic: The drunkard is so happy to receive flowers from your luxuriant garden that he begins to moan (も) with pleasure. The moans are getting louder and more erotic. You’re kind of creeped out. You really want him to stop moaning. Hear the drunkard moan as he rubs the flowers all over his body. You’re really weirded out. This is the last time you give him flowers from your luxuriant garden, that’s for sure.

Name: Milord
Mnemonic: Under the same flag, all the people get together to present a new weapon to your lord. You all bow and say, "Milord, this gift is for you." Because that's the proper way to address your lord. When you address your lord you better say "milord," otherwise you might get beheaded with the weapon you're all giving him.
ReadingMnemonic: As you give the lord his weapon together, you see his face turn into a frown, "What's wrong, Milord?" you ask. "THERE'S A DENT (でん)!" he bellows. Oh no, oh no, oh no! Now the lord is running around with his dented weapon trying to put dents in all of you. You don't want a dent in your head! Run!

Name: Multiply
Mnemonic: When you go to the yakuza to fix your problems they'll just multiply. You thought you had problems before? Yikes, now you've done it. The yakuza are just going to make all of your problems multiply!
ReadingMnemonic: Just like I said, your problems multiply before your eyes and give you quite a shock (しょく). You really shouldn't be shocked though, because I warned you this would happen. Feel shock envelop your entire body as late payments multiply into more debt, and the number of people mad at you multiply too. You can't even think from the shock of it all.

Name: Neighbor
Mnemonic: Inside that building someone is doing a rice dance. That someone is your neighbor. Imagine your neighbor doing a rice dance, whatever that may be, in the building next to yours. That's your neighbor, for ya.
ReadingMnemonic: Your neighbor has an incredible ring (りん) that they use for their rice dance. Imagine the ring your neighbor has as overly extravagant. You have to make it wild enough for you to remember. Maybe it is integral to their rice dance. Perhaps you covet your neighbor's rice dance ring.

Name: Noodles
Mnemonic: One way to put wheat in your face is with noodles. Imagine yourself shoveling piles of wheaty noodles into your face. They're so wheaty and delicious!
ReadingMnemonic: Once you're done stuffing noodles in your face, you can use your leftover noodles to make noodlemen (めん). Did you ever use to make pictures with your food? (Or maybe you still do? We won't judge.) Imagine you're doing that again, and think about how lifelike your noodle men are!

Name: Overgrown
Mnemonic: Every winter the thread fields become overgrown. Yes, thread grows in fields these days. And the thread grows the most in the winter because reasons. The thread gets so overgrown that you can’t even walk through it without cutting the thread down with a machete. Imagine trying to wade through this overgrown field of thread. It’s really difficult, and also it’s really cold because it’s winter. You shiver. Imagine chopping the thread down with your machete. Chop chop chop!
ReadingMnemonic: The reason this field of thread got so overgrown is because you’re Han (はん) Solo and you’re not used to simple things like farming thread. Han Solo is used to blasting baddies and kissing princesses. Overgrown thread is not his specialty. Use your blaster to clear a way through this thread instead of using that machete. Imagine yourself as Han Solo, bravely blasting your way through the overgrown thread with your blaster. Pew pew pew!

Name: Patrol
Mnemonic: You're using your scooter to navigate the flood because you're on patrol. You're one of the few people with a floating scooter, so it's your job to patrol the flood waters and look for people and animals that need help. Imagine patrolling the flood waters on your scooter, which is bubbling and scooting along on the surface of the water. You have to be extremely vigilant in your patrol, you don't want any lives to be lost on your watch.
ReadingMnemonic: You have to patrol all of the floods in June (じゅん). Unfortunately, that's the month when most of the floods in Japan happen, so you end up on patrol a lot. You're in a group with a bunch of other scooter people, and you're all assigned to one month of flood patrol duty. But you got June. The floodiest month. Womp womp.

Name: Pillar
Mnemonic: This tree is the master of a pillar. The pillar is subservient to its tree master because the tree is so great and awesome and big and cool and stuff. The pillar has great respect for its tree master. See the pillar next to the tree master. See the pillar bow over and over in veneration of its tree master.
ReadingMnemonic: While bowing, the pillar accidentally smashes Chewbacca (ちゅう). The pillar is horrified for having murdered Chewbacca, his tree master’s closest friend. The pillar is going to be punished. Hear the crack and snap of branches as the tree beats the crap out of the pillar for having murdered Chewbacca. Unforgivable.

Name: Portable
Mnemonic: Use your fingers to shoo a turkey down the stairs and into a portable carrier. You've been trying to get this turkey into the carrier so you can transport it for like, the past hour. You finally got it done with the help of gravity. And, you know, smacking it a bit in the butt with your fingers. Turkeys aren't portable on their own. I mean you could pick one up I guess, but it will bite and poop on you. So get it in a portable carrier first.
ReadingMnemonic: You needed the turkey to be more portable because you're going to be bringing it to a cake (けい) shop to turn it into a cake. You aren't cooking it! Geez, what's wrong with you? No, you're making a cake OF it, for its birthday. The baker needs to see it for reference. Imagine getting a portable turkey cake made of your pet turkey. It's made of turkey friendly cake mix.

Name: Praise
Mnemonic: Lift the lid off your preserves, kick it, and praise the lord! Your food is preserved, you don't need the lid anymore, praise be! You also praise the lid. And praise the plants and animals that gave you the food.
ReadingMnemonic: You do this praising in your home (ほう), though, not a church. I don't think anyone outside your home would understand why you're praising inanimate objects. If you're going to praise the ingenuity of the invention of the "lid" for its preservation methods, you should definitely do it from home. Or at least from the internet from home. Find your people where you can, you know?

Name: Resident
Mnemonic: A horse is your master and you are merely a resident in his house. How did this horse become your master? Those aren’t questions a resident should ask! Know your place, resident! Imagine having a horse as your master. Hear him neigh out orders to you and the other residents of the horse master’s house.
ReadingMnemonic: To prove yourself a worthy resident of the horse master’s house, you must capture Chewbacca (ちゅう). Your horse master collects rare creatures, and Chewbacca is his latest desire. If you wish to remain a resident of the house, you must capture Chewbacca. Imagine Chewbacca in a cage in the horse master’s house. You’ve proved yourself a worthy resident. Hear Chewbacca making his Wookie sounds as he bashes against the bars of his new cage.

Name: Review
Mnemonic: You employ a geoduck to review all your work. Imagine hiring a geoduck, then ask them to review your work. Please review my writing, geoduck. Please review my record-keeping, geoduck. Please review my taxes, geoduck. This geoduck you employed can review anything for you.
ReadingMnemonic: As the geoduck reviews your paperwork, it notices something surprising. You have a 子 (こ)! The geoduck tells you that while it was reviewing your records, it found information about a child you have. Even you didn't know this, so you're surprised that this review geoduck found something like this.

Name: Sacrifice
Mnemonic: The cow of righteousness is always there for us. He is the cow that must sacrifice himself for us to survive. The reason he is sacrificing himself is so we can all eat! Yum! Thanks to your sacrifice, righteous cow, we all have hamburgers. You should think about all the cows you ask to die for you every day. Maybe say thanks next time.
ReadingMnemonic: The sacrifice must be done via guillotine (ぎ). I know, I know, that sounds really brutal, but it's the best way. It's fast, it's effective, and hopefully the sacrifice—I mean, cow—doesn't feel a thing. Of course, the reading is also shared with kanji like 義. The righteousness radicals seems to have that effect on kanji.

Name: Seize
Mnemonic: You see an animal with some flowers and a turkey on a stool trying to seize them. The animal with the flowers is really tall so the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize the flowers. Look at this turkey straining itself on the stool trying to seize the flowers, grunting with effort. You think he’ll ever get them?
ReadingMnemonic: The animal the turkey is trying to seize the flowers from is a cock (かく). The cock is a lot bigger than the turkey, so that’s why the turkey needs to stand on the stool in its attempt to seize those flowers. Imagine this scene again only with a big cock holding the flowers as the turkey attempts to seize them. Hear the cock shouting cock-a-doodle-doo as it defends its flowers.

Name: Sharp
Mnemonic: If you have gold you also need a guard with a very sharp sword to protect it. You should probably also get some sharp spikes, sharp traps, and sharp spears to keep that gold safe too. Just a bunch of sharp stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: You're setting up all these sharp traps around your gold when you step on a sharp acorn (えい) that's just lying on the floor. Ouch! But wait, then you get a great idea! Imagine covering the floor around your gold in sharp acorns. This is basically a Home Alone situation, and anyone who tries to steal your stuff is gonna get stuck full of sharp things and probably stabbed by your guard.

Name: Spread
Mnemonic: Taking a cross with a drop on it, you walk through the rice paddy in the direction of winter and spread your arms wide. You spread your arms to halt the approach of winter because your rice paddy is not done growing yet. You take the cross with you for some extra religious power of persuasion, and the drop in case any of that rice is thirsty. Imagine facing the direction of the approaching winter while facing away from the rice paddy. Feel the weight of the cross in your hands as you spread your arms and implore the winter to hold off on its arrival. Drip the drop onto any thirsty rice.
ReadingMnemonic: You're extremely chic (しき), which makes the fact that you're holding a cross while you spread your arms even more impressive. Feel the strain on your chic arms as you continue to spread them. Since you're by far the most chic person around, you have to set a good example for your people, so don't let them (or your arms) down.

Name: Supernatural
Mnemonic: What kind of woman comes down from heaven? A supernatural one. She is so enchanting. Imagine your idea of what an extremely supernatural woman would look like, and have her come down from heaven towards you. You're totally enchanted by her looks.
ReadingMnemonic: The supernatural woman comes down in front of you and she's so enchanting that it takes a while to realize she's completely made of yogurt (よう). Touch the supernatural yogurt woman and feel the yogurt. Taste the yogurt, what flavor is it? It's totally enchanting you further.

Name: Transparent
Mnemonic: The scooter you made out of grains, and are about to ride down the stairs with, is completely transparent. You mashed the grains down so fine that you can see through them! And then you made them into a scooter. Picture this transparent scooter. Well, it's actually a bit hard to see, because it's see-through. I guess imagine the outline and the feel, as you perch at the top of your stairs.
ReadingMnemonic: You slip, the transparent scooter scoots down the stairs without you and into the streets of とうきょう. Nooo! Transpa-scootie come back! Almost immediately you lose track of the scooter because it's transparent. All you see is とうきょう in front of you. And no scooter. Maybe this is why people don't make transparent vehicles.

Name: Proclaim
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means proclaim.

Name: Showy
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means showy.

Name: Signpost
Mnemonic: This is a post with signs on it. And on top is a winter marker, showing that if you go north it's winter up there. The signs say things like "Narnia ↑" and "Meridell ←" and "Bananaland →" so you know it's a signpost.

Name: Wife
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wife.

Name: Abandon
Mnemonic: In the trash is a weird looking fruit. Someone decided to abandon it here. Most people abandon fruit when it's misshapen. It's probably fine though...
ReadingMnemonic: You reach into the trash, take out the abandoned fruit, and bite into it. OUCH! There's a key (き) inside, and you just bit into it. You abandon the fruit and stare intently at this key. It must be why the fruit was weird looking and abandoned in the trash... but what does it go to?! You dig through the trash and try the key on everything that's been abandoned in there.

Name: Amazing
Mnemonic: Your ice wife is amazing. She's also terrible, because she's very cold and has many ice powers, but that's also part of what makes her amazing! Picture your amazing and terrible ice wife. She's floating in your backyard cackling and shooting ice all around.
ReadingMnemonic: She turns her amazing gaze onto your saber (せい) and hits it with an ice beam. Woah! Instead of turning to ice or shattering, it steals her awful powers. Now your saber is amazing and terrible too! Now you're floating in the backyard cackling with your amazing wife as you use your terrible saber and freeze things with her!

Name: Attain
Mnemonic: Dig up a mole and you attain a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level! It's actually pretty easy to attain mole status. Just stand in a field. Wait for the ground to move under you and shove your hand in the earth. Blam! An achievement pops up above your head and you're there.
ReadingMnemonic: Mole isn't enough, you want to attain sheep (し) status next. Everyone knows it goes human > mole> sheep. Now you need to stand in the field with the mole and get a sheep to come over. If you can attain two animal levels in one day you'll be a legend on the leaderboards.

Name: Based On
Mnemonic: Wipe your fingers on this table in winter to see what it was based on. The cold winter weathers cover the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them. Imagine tracing your fingers over the table, the cold winter frost stinging them, as you reveal the secrets of this table and what it was based on.
ReadingMnemonic: This particular table was based on Little Kyoto (きょ). Little buildings and temples, that sort of look like Little Kyoto. Problem is, it was made by a 子 (こ), so it's not very good. The buildings and temples are all very childlike. Like crayon drawn on a table.

Name: Bee
Mnemonic: On the insect signpost there is a single sign that says bee. This particular insect signpost points you to where the bee is.
ReadingMnemonic: Thanks to the insect signpost you find the bee. You make it just in time to see the bee hatch (はち) from its egg. You got to see a single bee hatch! What a beautiful sight. Weird that a signpost points to it.

Name: Ceremony
Mnemonic: The leader of righteousness is the only one who can run this ceremony. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it. Have him run your ceremony for you. Think about why he is so righteous, then think about an extremely righteous ceremony.
ReadingMnemonic: Sadly, the reason only the righteous can run this ceremony is because it's a punishment ceremony, where he pulls the cord to cut someone's head off via a guillotine (ぎ). *CHOP*

Name: Charcoal
Mnemonic: You climb up a mountain and a cliff in search of fire, but all you find is charcoal. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing. You’re angry that you could only find charcoal so you take the charcoal in your hands and you crush it atop the cliff on the mountain. Feel the charcoal breaking in your hands as the wind carries the charcoal dust off from the top of the cliff on the mountain.
ReadingMnemonic: After crushing the charcoal, you decide to take advantage of your current location and lie out in the sun for a while to get a tan (たん). Instead of getting a tan though, you catch on fire. Oops. Imagine lying out in the sun next to the crushed charcoal, thinking you’re going to get tan. You’re very surprised when you actually catch on fire. Hot hot hot!

Name: Conceal
Mnemonic: A tsunami carries a husband and his husband up into the sun, where they're going to conceal something. Imagine the tsunami taking the two husbands up into the sun. Hear the water gushing. That tsunami is gigantic. What are they going to conceal in the sun?
ReadingMnemonic: The husbands are going to conceal their pet centaur (せん) in the sun. The local government isn’t too pleased that they have a pet centaur so they have to conceal it in the sun so it doesn't get confiscated. Just make sure to remember there is a centaur up on that tsunami with the husbands, heading towards the sun. They need to conceal the centaur to keep it safe.

Name: Fake
Mnemonic: The leader gets a nice uniform for the sake of not wanting to look like a fake. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake. Look at this fake leader. See him scramble into a uniform. Does he look like a real leader? Or can you tell that he is a fake?
ReadingMnemonic: Well, everyone found out he was a fake anyway, and now you're all going to use a guillotine (ぎ) to cut off his fake head. Watch as the guillotine comes down. You close your eyes for a second, and when you open them you see that the leader's body was a fake! Wait, where did he go?!

Name: Field
Mnemonic: A fire in the rice paddy burns down the field. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm! Look at this fire burning the rice paddy and the surrounding field. Smell burnt rice in the air as you see the flames dance before your eyes.
ReadingMnemonic: Your rice paddy farm and field are on a cay. A cay is a small, sandy island, and since your farm is on fire, this cay has turned into a hot cay. Or as Mario would say, that’s one-a hot-a cay! (はたけ) Mama mia! Imagine running around this hot cay as you try to put out the fire in your field. The fire is ravaging the entire hot cay, so it takes you a while to put it out. Man those flames are hot.

Name: Firefly
Mnemonic: A Viking insect is a firefly. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly. Imagine this little firefly blinking his firefly light as he flies around shouting a Viking warcry and brandishing an axe. Yaaaargh!
ReadingMnemonic: The Viking firefly is attacking Hotaru (ほたる) Tomoe (alter ego of Sailor Saturn) because the Viking firefly hates the show Sailor Moon and everyone on it. Hotaru screams in terror as she is deathly afraid of fireflies, especially Viking ones. Hear Hotaru’s shrill scream as she runs away from the Viking firefly. If you don’t know what Hotaru Tomoe looks like, Google a picture of her to get a better visualization.

Name: Fist
Mnemonic: A gladiator turns his hand into a fist. A fist for punching other gladiators. Picture the gladiator squeezing his hand into a tight fist, raising it up and yelling.
ReadingMnemonic: The gladiator's fist is now aimed at Ken (けん) the samurai. Little does the gladiator know, Ken knows the ways of the samurai and the gladiator. He slowly raises his own hands and turns them into fists. Ken and the gladiator clash! Fists fly! You've never seen hand-to-hand combat like this! You can hardly keep up!!

Name: Hard Liquor
Mnemonic: The alcohol that needs measurement is hard liquor. Drinking too much hard liquor isn't good for you, so you must make sure to measure it out in precise quantities. Imagine the hard liquor as you measure it out. Hear it pouring out of the bottle into a little measuring cup as you catch the whiff of strong alcohol in the air.
ReadingMnemonic: You know who enjoyed hard liquor a lot? Chewbacca (ちゅう). He was always drinking, which is concerning when you think about all the driving he did. Imagine Chewbacca drinking hard liquor all the time while Han Solo told him he needed to stop and get help, but Chewbacca just did his yell thing and drank more hard liquor.

Name: Hometown
Mnemonic: Everyone has a poop guy from their hometown. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place. Picture the poop guy from your hometown. Picture him really vividly. The awkward, rude things he does. The way he smells. The way he makes you never want to come back.
ReadingMnemonic: Your hometown is in きょうと which, unfortunately, means your poop guy is in きょうと too. Now every time you go back home he's there stinking everything up. Imagine all the wonderful things that exist in your hometown of きょうと. All the things you love to do and see. And now picture poop guy. Ruining it all with his poop hands.

Name: Honey
Mnemonic: The roof (hive) on a certain insect (a bee) is what protects all of the honey or nectar. Bees are a certain insect that build a roof around their honey.
ReadingMnemonic: To get the honey out, you need to put on special mitts (みつ) so your hands don't get stung. Your thick mitts make it so the bees can't even sting your hands. Unfortunately, you are naked and only wearing mitts, what were you thinking?

Name: Humanity
