Mnemonic: This leader has two things that remind him of his humanity: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats. Reflect upon your own humanity. What does it mean to be human? Is it wearing shoes and hats? Probably.
ReadingMnemonic: Another thing that reminds you and the leader about your humanity is wearing jeans (じん). Jeans are the go-to legwear for many people, and no one but humans wear them. Jeans are another great symbol of humanity. Are you wearing jeans right now? If so, rub them with your hands and say aloud “Oh, the humanity!” Or just imagine wearing jeans if you aren’t actually wearing them.

Name: Humble
Mnemonic: On this scooter is a child who's trying to show that his lineage is humble. All of the other children are going around in fancy cars or helicopters, but this one child wants to be a humble child of the people, so he scoots on a plebeian scooter. Picture this child scooting to his fancy, expensive university in a little suit. Compared to the other kids, his wheels are quite humble!
ReadingMnemonic: This humble child is your son (そん). You don't want any child of yours flaunting his wealth and good standing in the faces of other people. You've taught them to be humble. You even bought your son this humble scooter and you really hope they don't grow up to be a selfish, spoiled kid this way.

Name: Inquire
Mnemonic: Being a leader or director in a company means you have to inquire about lots of things. Have you started this yet? Have you finished that yet? Did you get that thing I sent you? Where's my coffee? Basically if you're a leader or director, your main job is to inquire about these very important things. Just make sure you don't inquire about anything inappropriate, or you'll end up facing an inquiry from HR…
ReadingMnemonic: Turns out the leader and director of your company is Chairman Kaga from the TV show Iron Chef. Every time he tries to inquire about weird stuff, you have to say Ooh, Kaga (うかが) disapprovingly. "What are you doing for dinner tonight?" he inquires. Ooh, Kaga! "What's the best way to soften an eggplant?" he inquires. Ooh, Kaga! Imagine saying "Ooh, Kaga!" to this overly curious leader-director-chef. Say it out loud, like he's just inquired about something weird. He just really loves cooking, okay? But he inquires too much about it in the workplace, so you have to let him know how you feel.

Name: Invade
Mnemonic: There is a tiny leader on Wolverine’s forehead sitting on a stool and commanding his troops to invade Wolverine’s brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine’s body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn’t going to invade Wolverine’s brain, he’s just going to sit on the stool and supervise. Imagine the little leader sitting on Wolverine’s forehead as he shouts “Invade! Invade invade! Invade his brain and destroy the Wolverine!”
ReadingMnemonic: Soon they realize that they cannot invade Wolverine through his head so they travel down to his leg and try to enter through his shin (しん). The little soldiers take a big knife and slice open Wolverine’s shin in order to invade his body. See the little soldiers slicing open Wolverine’s shin as Wolverine grunts in pain. Getting your leg cut open is not a comfortable thing, even for someone as manly as Wolverine.

Name: Lie
Mnemonic: Open your mouth. A tiger fell in there on some spikes! That's what you tell everybody, but when they look in your mouth there's nothing there. It's all a big lie! Of course there isn't a tiger in your mouth. And those spikes are just normal teeth. No matter how you look at it, you're saying a lie.
ReadingMnemonic: Lie about spikes in your mouth and I'll put soap with spikes in it in your mouth to teach you a lesson. That's why I'm using uni soap (うそ). Now at least you're not lying about spikes being in your mouth.

Name: Mineral
Mnemonic: Aside from gold there are a wide variety of other minerals as well. Think of the wide range of minerals there are that aren't gold. There are a lot.
ReadingMnemonic: One person is trying to control all the minerals of the world. That person is Emperor こういち. Emperor こういち is getting all the minerals, and the 鋼, so he can take over all neighboring nations and force them into a subjugation of efficient kanji learning.

Name: Noisy
Mnemonic: Your mouth proclaims "I am noisy and I am picky!" It keeps repeating this over and over to everyone you pass by. The townsfolk agree with your mouth, you are noisy and you are picky and you need to shut up.
ReadingMnemonic: You are so noisy and picky that the townsfolk hired Ken (けん) the Samurai to shut you up. "Ken, your armor color is so last year. That squid you have is gross. Your sword is so gaudy. You talk like you're from the Edo Period, but it's Reiwa right now."

Name: Penetrate
Mnemonic: You decide to loiter next to the trash under the moon in winter so the moon's light will penetrate you. The sky is clearest in winter, and this spot next to the trash happens to get the most of it. Picture a single beam of moonlight penetrating through the winter sky, right onto the trash.
ReadingMnemonic: You want the light to penetrate you, so you put your face in the way of the beam and it shoots clear through you. Your mouth fills with the taste of 鉄 (てつ). The clear, penetrating beam tastes exactly like iron, which is something you really weren't expecting. But now it's filling your entire mouth and you don't want it to stop.

Name: Rapids
Mnemonic: A tsunami hits a bundle of geoducks, swirling around their weird shapes, and creating rapids! The rapids are so violent, some of the geoducks break out of the bundle and get washed into the shallows. Picture the bundle of geoducks getting smashed by the tsunami, breaking apart, and getting tossed around in the rapids.
ReadingMnemonic: While those geoducks are getting tossed about in the rapids, you're sitting in the shallows chomping down on some celery (せ). Imagine the cool shallow water lapping at your feet as you bite into some crunchy celery and watch the rapids in the distance.

Name: Rowdy
Mnemonic: Your mouth is showy so it makes everybody around you rowdy. Your mouth is showy because it's covered in grills and bright red lipstick. People get rowdy because you're a celebrity and your showy mouth is your signature look, and everyone's so excited to see your mouth in person.
ReadingMnemonic: Everyone is getting rowdy so you get in your car (か) to escape. As you drive away in your car you flash that signature mouth at them one more time, and you can see them getting even more rowdy.

Name: Ruins
Mnemonic: You're digging in the dirt when you find a tiger and a cactus. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big ruins. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins. Imagine looking through these ruins. Picture the broken tiger and cactus statues. Try to imagine the people who used to live here before it turned to ruins.
ReadingMnemonic: Well, as it turns out, these are the ruins of Little Kyoto (きょ), the city that existed before the modern day one. And it looks like the citizens of Little Kyoto faced their end a long time ago. Picture the ruins of Little Kyoto. Try to imagine what it was like before the whole place fell apart. Maybe they would have lived on if they hadn't been doing things with sharp cacti and bitey tigers.

Name: Set Aside
Mnemonic: You find some fingers from long ago. They must have been set aside by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside. What would have to happen for you to set aside your own fingers? Try to imagine it right now.
ReadingMnemonic: I know why they set aside their fingers long ago, it's because there was no soap (そ). If you didn't have soap to clean your fingers you wouldn't want to keep them for very long... Think of all the things you do with your fingers. Now picture how they would look if you had never ever cleaned them with soap. Uhg, disgusting. You should just set them aside here, and find some new ones.

Name: Sincerity
Mnemonic: Something you say to someone you become attached to should be said with sincerity. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example. Imagine saying something with sincerity to someone you want to become important to you. Say something like, “I love you” out loud. Say it with the utmost sincerity.
ReadingMnemonic: When you say something with complete, unabashed sincerity your special saber (せい) starts to pulse with the beating of your heart. It shows the person you want to become close to that you truly are sincere! Say, "I love you," again and watch your saber beating in time with your heart. If you weren't sincere it would fade and grow dull.

Name: Tiger
Mnemonic: A tiger has legs that belong to a tiger. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here. Look at the tiger running with his tiger legs. So majestic. So fierce.
ReadingMnemonic: The tiger is using his legs to run away from the Torah (とら). This tiger is deathly afraid of religion, so a holy book like the Torah causes the tiger to run away. Imagine watching the tiger as it notices the Torah and then runs away. The tiger sounds as if it is screaming in terror as it flees from the proximity of the Torah.

Name: Warship
Mnemonic: The boat that oversees other boats, land, and people is usually a warship. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it. Picture a huge warship overseeing everything around it. It's big and kinda scary.
ReadingMnemonic: This huge warship is run by Genghis Khan (かん), the famous warlord. Really, what did you expect? Who else is strong enough to captain a warship but him? Picture Genghis Khan aboard a monstrous warship. He's carefully watching the sea and land that he's conquered.

Name: Withdrawal
Mnemonic: You use your fingers to dig through the trash in the light of the moon in winter because somewhere in there is your withdrawal letter. What did you withdraw? Your resignation? Your troops? Whatever it was, you need to find the proof, and fast. Imagine you need proof of your withdrawal so badly, that you're in the trash like this, raking around with your fingers in the moonlight. Close your eyes and feel the cold, smell the stink.
ReadingMnemonic: While looking for the withdrawal letter, your fingers hit a piece of 鉄 (てつ). Ouch! The pain from the 鉄 reverberates up your fingers and into your hands and arms. What's this great lump of 鉄 doing in the trash?

Name: Wood
Mnemonic: Each tree needs its drum measurement done before you can say it's really made of wood. There are a lot of hoodlums out there that try to dress as trees and confuse people. So make sure you measure their drum before you cut one down or tell someone your secrets under it.
ReadingMnemonic: If you're still not sure if the tree is really made of wood, just take out a small juice (じゅ) box and start drinking it. A wooden tree will show no interest in the juice box at all. However! A non-wood tree will be really thirsty from pretending to be a wood tree. It will start making sounds and moving and probably say, "Can I have a juice box, please?"

Name: Wrap
Mnemonic: The wrap radical and the wrap kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Think about being wrapped up, nice and warm and safe in your home (ほう). Home is where you wrap yourself in a blanket, in the warmth of the fireplace, in the arms of those you love. Home is where the wrapped heart is.

Name: Bone
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means bone.

Name: Melon
Mnemonic: This is a melon. Imagine a melon cut in half, and you're looking at its insides from the side. See those precious private melon parts? You're gonna keep those for yourself, because melons are delicious and not for sharing.

Name: Shop
Mnemonic: We already have a roof radical, so we're going to use the secondary kanji meaning for this radical. It's shop, remember?

Name: Analysis
Mnemonic: You hit a tree with an axe so you can do some analysis on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe. Imagine taking this axe in your hands and chopping away at this tree to do your analysis. Hear the chop chop chop as wood chips fly into your face.
ReadingMnemonic: The person who is doing this analysis is very sexy (せき). Who is this sexy person? Why it’s you of course, you sexy beast. I love watching you do analysis on trees. It’s so sexy. Imagine yourself being sexy and doing tree analysis. What sort of sexy analysis moves can you think of? Oh yeah, so sexy.

Name: Arc
Mnemonic: Shoot a melon out of a bow and it will fly in a steep arc. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all. Imagine shooting a really heavy melon out of a bow. Watch it make an arc through the air. Trace the arc with your finger.
ReadingMnemonic: Shooting melons in an arc is something little 子's (こ) love to do. It also helps that when they come down from the arc they smash all over the place. Imagine being a 子 and watching melons fly in arcs all over. Imagine a little 子 version of yourself giggling and clapping your hands with absolute glee.

Name: Arrival
Mnemonic: The mole has a knife ready for your arrival. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears. Welp, your arrival didn't go smoothly. You have a knife in your foot. I'm not sure what you did to make that mole hate you, but you'll have to be more careful next time.
ReadingMnemonic: Your arrival to とうきょう is now ruined. And your next stop is now going to be an arrival at a とうきょう hospital to get this mole knife out. This certainly wasn't the type of arrival you were expecting when you bought your tickets to とうきょう.

Name: Axis
Mnemonic: For a car, the reason why it works is because its wheels spin on their axis. That is, they have axles. Imagine a car whose wheels don't turn on their axis. It has no axles. Not a car that will work too well.
ReadingMnemonic: Your friend's car doesn't have axles, but he loves it anyway. He's all like, "Isn't this a cool car?" You reply: "Gee, cool" (じく) very sarcastically. You're super sarcastic about this, so feel the sarcasm inside of you when you imagine this.

Name: Challenge
Mnemonic: When your fingers move like that, you know it's an omen of a challenge that will face you soon in the future. What kind of challenge is it? If you look closely at your fingers sometimes you can figure out the challenge that is to come based on their movements.
ReadingMnemonic: In your finger, you see a challenge. And... if you look closely, you can see the fast movements of your fingers forming the outline of Mrs. Chou's (ちょう) face. Oh no, the challenge is going to be Mrs. Chou! Whenever you see an omen (radical), there's a good chance that Mrs. Chou will be a part of it. This is not a good sign.

Name: Char
Mnemonic: You take a turkey and try to boil it but you char it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there. You should know better than to try to boil something without water! Now what are you going to do with this raw, but charred turkey?!
ReadingMnemonic: You're staring sadly at the charred turkey when you suddenly sense the Shougun (しょう) looming behind you. You were supposed to be cooking this turkey for him and now he looks really, really mad. The Shougun reaches down and bites a charred hunk off the turkey. He yells and spits it out. Why did he do that?! You have no idea but it looked nasty.

Name: Dig
Mnemonic: You see a flag near the exit, so you use your fingers to dig there. Most flags mark something, and this exit is pretty obvious, so there must be something under here. At least that's what you think to yourself as you dig. Imagine digging under the flag by the exit of your building with your bare fingers. The dirt is getting under your fingernails as you dig. It's getting on your knees. It's everywhere.
ReadingMnemonic: You dig until you finally hit something. It's a bunch of buried old coots (くつ). They're in an underground room for old coots. One yells up at you, "Whatcha doing to our roof, ya whipper snapper?! Stop digging in our lawn!" You carefully un-dig the old coots and leave them to their old grumpy coot hole... basement... secret clubhouse? Whatever.

Name: Distract
Mnemonic: Take this thread and look at this part. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have distracted you! You don't know what part of the thread to look at. What a distraction.
ReadingMnemonic: Despite how distracted you are, that was indeed a lot of fun (ふん). Imagine yourself really enjoying looking at parts of the thread. You don't know why it's so fun, but being derpy is exciting, I guess.

Name: Example
Mnemonic: This bamboo can be whittled into an example of anything. See, here's a car. Here's a snake. I can make so many examples just with bamboo. It's amazing how fast this guy can whittle!
ReadingMnemonic: One last example for you. Now I'm going to take this bamboo and whittle it into an example of Han (はん) Solo! Han Solo's bamboo example comes to life and runs off.

Name: Fasten
Mnemonic: Someone's fingers touch your tongue and fasten it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this. Try to fasten your own tongue with your fingers right now. You probably can't do it, right? That's because your fingers are too big and your tongue is too slippery.
ReadingMnemonic: Only one creature could use its fingers to fasten your tongue like this: cats (かつ). Cats are notorious for fastening tongues so that people can't speak. Haven't you ever heard the phrase, "Cat got your tongue?" In this case, many cats fastened your tongue. You should probably be nicer to cats from now on so this doesn't happen again.

Name: Grip
Mnemonic: You use your fingers in a shop to grip what you want to buy. Imagine picking up a few different things in a shop. If something fits nicely in your grip: buy it. If it's too small or too big, put it back.
ReadingMnemonic: You have a really strong grip thanks to acupuncture (あく)! All your fingers are primed for buying things. You can grip anything at a shop—pineapples, tires, even live turtles. All thanks to some well-placed needles. Acupuncture is great for strengthening your grip strength. If you do intense shopping (like I do) you should definitely consider it!

Name: Hinge
Mnemonic: In the tree district of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need hinges. Don't forget to buy a hinge. Your door purchase will hinge on your hinges.
ReadingMnemonic: You buy an awesome hinge and try it out. Instead of working properly, it just falls apart and the door falls on you, crushing your lower body. You yell out (and you have to yell) "I'm GOING TO SUUUUEEE (すう) YOU!" Really lengthen out that "sue" because it's a long "suu" for the reading and that will help.

Name: Hoist
Mnemonic: If you have fingers it's easy to hoist things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy. Hoist the sails! Hoist the anchor! Hoist a baby! All of these situations are easier if you have a ton of working fingers. (The more the better.)
ReadingMnemonic: Today, you have to hoist so much stuff. "Ah!" (あ) you say, "So much hoisting to do." Better get to it! Imagine hoisting things over and over again. Each time you spot a new thing that needs hoisting, you say "Ah! Something else to hoist!"

Name: Lagoon
Mnemonic: A tsunami crashes into the sun (breaking it in half) and creating a different wing of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a lagoon. The lagoon is beautiful! The water is hot (from hitting the sun) but it isn't so bright that you'll get a sunburn.
ReadingMnemonic: This lagoon was created on purpose by a really angry dude and his catapult (かた). He wanted a nice place to lounge that's tropical, but not too bright. So he came up with a plan: use a giant catapult to send a tsunami into the sun! Now picture it all in slow motion. The catapult tosses the tsunami into the air, it smashes the sun, breaks off into a wing of nice, hot water, and finally splashes back to the earth into a beautiful, secluded lagoon.

Name: Lawn
Mnemonic: There are flowers and hills in your front lawn. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty. Imagine walking through your lawn and smelling all the flowers as you travel over the rolling hills. What a delightful lawn this is.
ReadingMnemonic: You are the proud owner of a Shiba (しば) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your lawn and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba. Look at your little Shiba running through the lawn all happy and elated. Hear him barking as he zooms up and down each hill.

Name: Liver
Mnemonic: If the moon is dry, it's good for your liver! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids. Imagine holding an empty bottle up to the moon and seeing it's completely dry. You pat your belly above where your liver is and say, "I guess you're safe tonight, liver."
ReadingMnemonic: As you pat your liver suddenly a strange feeling bubbles up and the ghost of Genghis Khan (かん) comes out! Right out of your liver. Genghis Khan glares down at you, "You inherited my liver, and that means no moonshine for you. Protect your liver and don't drink, like me, Genghis Khan."

Name: Mochi
Mnemonic: What do you eat if you’re wearing horns and surrounded by lanterns? Mochi (or sticky rice cakes) of course! Imagine yourself in the lantern light wearing horns and eating delicious mochi.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading of mochi is mochi (もち). Yay! As long as you can remember the meaning of this kanji, you'll know the reading too.

Name: Mourning
Mnemonic: Under the cross is a mouth and another mouth wearing special clothes because they're in mourning. Picture the cross looming overhead, people's mouths open so they can sob loudly, and everyone wearing the same color clothes (just picture whatever color works for your particular culture/religion combo).
ReadingMnemonic: As the mourning continues, the soul (そう) of the dead person rises out of the cross. The soul looks around at all of the mourners and nods. Yes, your mourning has pleased it. If you aren't mourning enough, when the soul comes out of the person's body, it will get really mad. "What, I'm not worth a few tears? Really?" And then the soul will haunt you. So you better mourn like you mean it.

Name: Net
Mnemonic: You see a thread-covered hill, but it's all lumpy and weird. You approach it to take a closer look, and you see it's actually a huge net with a bunch of stuff caught in it: fish, cats, tree branches. All this random stuff is what's making the net look so lumpy! You'll need to differentiate this from 綱, which uses the same radicals (though 綱 has a real hill radical). Just remember that the "hill" in this one is all weird and lumpy because it's a net with a bunch of stuff caught in it.
ReadingMnemonic: This net is creating a serious obstacle to you mowing (もう) your lawn. The net has way too much stuff in it for you to be able to drag it away, so for now you're just going to have to mow around it. Imagine the awkwardness of trying to mow the grass around this big, lumpy, writhing net full of loudly meowing cats, flopping fish, and goodness knows what else.

Name: Overcome
Mnemonic: Even though you’ve old legs, you overcome your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon! Imagine running a marathon with your old legs to prove you can overcome anything. Feel your old legs cramping up as you try to overcome the marathon and finish the race.
ReadingMnemonic: When you pass the finish line and finally overcome the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold Coke (こく) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke. Filled with the jubilation of achievement from overcoming all odds, imagine the flavor of this cold Coke in your mouth. Fizzy and Coke flavored, it runs down your throat and into your tummy. Yum.

Name: Overnight
Mnemonic: The tsunami that is white is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place overnight, without even asking! Imagine the white tsunami knocking on your door, walking into your house, and then just laying down on your bed. You try to tell it to leave, but it's a tsunami, and it says it will be staying overnight thank you very much.
ReadingMnemonic: Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying overnight and decides it doesn't like it, so it hacks (はく) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave. See the hairball slowly sinking into the tsunami. The cat hacks up another one.

Name: Pair
Mnemonic: If you have one stool and another stool, you have a pair of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it. Imagine being in front of this pair of stools. Picture yourself sitting on one stool, getting up, then sitting on the other. Repeat this process.
ReadingMnemonic: This pair of stools shares a soul (そう). Even if you tried to separate them, they'd eventually find their way back together. It's the same with pairs of socks and pairs of people. Sometimes what looks like two things is really a perfect pair, with one soul. Meant to be together forever.

Name: Pattern
Mnemonic: You walk up to a tree and put dynamite on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful pattern into the side of it as well as the ground around it. Think about what pattern it might be. Is it a checkered pattern? Something more complicated and beautiful? Whatever it is, think of something that really impresses you.
ReadingMnemonic: The pattern is so beautiful that you want to put it on your garage (がら). So, you do. Imagine painting your garage with the pattern you imagined earlier.

Name: Philosophy
Mnemonic: Put an axe in your mouth with your fingers to express your philosophy. Your philosophy of putting weapons in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, so you're showing them that it's not with actions! Imagine expressing your philosophy, your deepest thoughts and beliefs, by putting it in your mouth.
ReadingMnemonic: Your philosophy on weapons in mouths means you're always tasting 鉄 (てつ). They say blood tastes like copper, well weapons taste like iron. Your philosophy and your way of life means everything tastes like 鉄 now, and you think everyone should be that way.

Name: Purification
Mnemonic: Use simultaneous jackhammers to perform the purification ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.) Close your eyes and feel the purification begin. Try not to let the loud jackhammering sound bother you, just focus on the simultaneous vibrations cleansing you inside and out.
ReadingMnemonic: This purification ritual is supposed to help you forget your cyborg (さい). It's been a while, but you can't seem to get it out of your head. Hopefully this purification (or just the two jackhammers shaking your brain up like pudding) will get the memories of your cyborg to go away. You can't keep picturing it all the time like this.

Name: Rope
Mnemonic: If you take a thread and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a hill of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a rope. Imagine yourself twisting this hill of thread up to make thicker ropes. They're strong!
ReadingMnemonic: Congratulations, now you have a perfect rope for tuna (つな) fishing. Tunas are massive, so you need a strong rope to reel one in. Imagine yourself going tuna fishing on a small boat with nothing but one long rope. This is how tuna fishing is done where you're from, so you're sticking to tradition.

Name: Sack
Mnemonic: You keep your substitute clothes in a sack. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies. Look at this sack of substitute clothes. Imagine it filled with all the clothes you hardly ever wear. What kind of clothes would be inside this sack?
ReadingMnemonic: You need your substitute clothes so you take out your substitute clothes sack. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: F**K ROE (ふくろ) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty. Imagine how nasty it is in there. Also imagine how smelly it is. Feel angry about putting roe in your sack. Why would you even do that? Why would the roe do this to you, as well.

Name: Shake
Mnemonic: You grab a satellite with your fingers and shake it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker. Imagine being in space and shaking a satellite with your fingers.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to shake it because this satellite is full of yogurt (よう). And you only like yogurt that's been well shook. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone? Imagine shaking yogurt in space. Now imagine eating yogurt as it continues to shake (in space still)!

Name: Slippery
Mnemonic: A tsunami breaks your bones, not from hitting you, but from making the ground slippery. The water from the tsunami made all the sidewalks and stairs too slippery to walk on, but you tried anyway, slipped, and broke a couple bones. Imagine trying to get back up on the slippery ground. You've already broken a few bones, but you slip again, breaking a few more.
ReadingMnemonic: As you struggle on the slippery ground you hear a loud yowling sound. You turn and see a bunch of stray cats (かつ) slipping and sliding too. They're coming right for you, uh oh! Picture the cats trying to walk on the slippery ground. Their legs keep spreading, so they try to jump, but that makes the slipping worse, and they go sliding forward and topple over their fluffy buns and onto your broken body. Now the cats are all perching on top of you and your broken bones as they try to avoid the slippery ground. It would be nice if they didn't have their claws out.

Name: Solid
Mnemonic: A servant secures a stool in the dirt so that it is a solid sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting! Picture two stools in your mind. One is solid, you want to sit on it. The other looks like the wind will knock it over. Don't sit on that!
ReadingMnemonic: You need this stool to be extra solid because you're using it to test your new catapult (かた). If it isn't solid, when you launch it and yourself in the catapult, the stool might fall over, killing you both. And you don't want that, now do you? You better hope that catapult is solid too. If it isn't the whole thing will come apart when you try to launch yourself into the air.

Name: Temporarily
Mnemonic: To your car you take an axe. The sun has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that temporarily. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though. Feel sad that you were the one to destroy your car for good, even though the sun messed it up temporarily.
ReadingMnemonic: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next. You should probably be worried about this situation.

Name: Twist
Mnemonic: Thread and vines alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to twist them together to make them strong. Imagine twisting some threads and vines together. Feel them and twist the two tighter together.
ReadingMnemonic: As you twist the thread and vines together, suddenly you feel a lump. You look down and see a cucumber (きゅう) twisted into it. It turns out those vines you were twisting were cucumber vines! Yum!

Name: Wild
Mnemonic: Flowers find their death in a river out in the wild. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place. Imagine yourself out in the wild wilderness as you hear the flowers screaming until death takes them. The river is raging, there’s nothing you can do to help the flowers. The wild has claimed them.
ReadingMnemonic: Ah (あ), the flowers in the wild have been claimed à la (あら) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do. Imagine this scene again, only imagine it like the wild flowers are experiencing their own great flood. Ah, those flowers are drowning to death à la everything that died in the Biblical flood.

Name: Badger
Mnemonic: You know the animal radical. This is just like that with a little extra. It's an animal already... which means all you have to do is remember what kind of animal. In this case, it's a badger.

Name: Imperial
Mnemonic: Stand up on the moon so you can look down on your countries. The thing with all the lines and borders are the borders of all the countries you rule, for you are an imperial.

Name: Plow
Mnemonic: You're sliding some dirt around with a tree you cut down. This contraption you've made is called a plow. Use it to push dirt around!

Name: Attack
Mnemonic: Imperial clothes allow you to perform an ancient attack that cannot be repelled. IMPERIAL ATTACK, GO! Imagine what this imperial attack might look like and imagine yourself in some swanky imperial clothes while you perform it.
ReadingMnemonic: The attack's power is concentrated in the shoes (しゅう) in this imperial outfit. You attack with your feet, kicking the enemy with your old, fancy shoes. Picture the shoes as you attack, they glow—full of attack power! These +4 attack shoes are really special.

Name: Bright
Mnemonic: A good moon is a bright moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon. Picture the good, good bright moon. Shining and shimmering and smiling down at us on Earth.
ReadingMnemonic: It's so bright that you can see all the roe (ろう) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. And the tiny baby fishies inside the roe are smiling brightly back up at the moon! Picture this scene like it's a Disney cartoon. The good moon is smiling brightly down at the roe which are smiling right back. They might even start singing a song!

Name: Chafe
Mnemonic: Below the canopy of trees is a hand. The hand is just there to chafe against the trees. There's a hand just chafing against some trees. That's... interesting.
ReadingMnemonic: As the hand chafes on the trees, it says mama (ま), mama. This is the hand of a child looking for its mama. And, it chafes against trees to try and find the warm, soft touch of its mama. Instead, it only finds rough bark, so it continues its chafing.

Name: Charm
Mnemonic: You have to run, put your ear on the stool, then run back. That's the charm of this game. Imagine yourself playing this game and basking in the charm of tapping your ear on the stool.
ReadingMnemonic: The added charm of this game is that there's this big chute (しゅ) at the end. It's so charming because you love chutes. As you watch, you really see the charm of this game. Some people are throwing the stool down the chute, some people are sliding down it on their ears...how charming.

Name: Chastise
Mnemonic: The loitering mountain king who hangs around during winter to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your heart, and only sees bad things. So, he chastises you about it. "What's in your heart is no good," he chastises you.
ReadingMnemonic: Why is he chastising you, really, though? He foretold Mrs. Chou coming back in a previous mnemonic, but you saved Mrs. Chou on the beach (once again, in a previous mnemonic), so you could have prevented her second coming. He is chastising you for saving Mrs. Chou (ちょう). In the 潮 kanji you saved Mrs. Chou from dying, so he is chastising you for it.

Name: Consolation
Mnemonic: We put a flag to remember where we tried to use a jackhammer to measure your friend's heart. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of consolation? Obviously it's not good enough consolation. Be furious about this.
ReadingMnemonic: Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an eagle (い) swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it. Now you have absolutely nothing. Not even a consolation flag.

Name: Courteous
Mnemonic: A badger, at the root of its heart, is a courteous creature. They may seem gruff and rude at first, but they'll still let you in their home in the middle of winter unannounced and offer you tea, a warm fire, and a place to sleep.
ReadingMnemonic: Badgers are especially courteous to condors (こん). Condors live in the trees while badgers live in burrows under those trees. When humans tear down the condor's homes, the badgers who live below them always let them stay over until they get back on their feet. Picture a courteous badger taking care of an injured, and now homeless, condor. It's fluffing the condor's pillows, bringing it soup, and patting it on the shoulder saying, "There, there."

Name: Crystal
Mnemonic: The sun hits this and breaks into three suns. What can split the sun in three directions? A crystal! Crystals take light and refract it around into many directions. That's why there are three suns in this kanji.
ReadingMnemonic: Who is hoarding and harnessing the power of these crystals? That would be the Shougun (しょう). Imagine the Shougun lying in his bed of crystals. He still has his really serious, angry face though. Even as he rubs the crystals to his face, he's glowering.

Name: Cylinder
Mnemonic: A bamboo stalk looks the same as a big ol' cylinder. Compare the two things in your mind and make them the same.
ReadingMnemonic: Picture a cylinder shaped とうきょう. All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too. Even... gasp! The people of とうきょう! とうきょう is a really weird city now that they passed the cylinder law. Imagine it so deeply that it weirds you out.

Name: Destroy
Mnemonic: Hit by a tsunami the drunkard is propelled down a slide where he hits the ground which is covered in fire. He is immediately destroyed. Even if he wasn't saved by the slide (to avoid the tsunami) he would be in trouble. Seems like the world just wanted to destroy this drunkard.
ReadingMnemonic: One could say this drunkard met (めつ) his fate. Strangely, he just came from a Mets (めつ) game, so maybe that's why he had such bad luck.

Name: Dignity
Mnemonic: A drunkard goes down a slide, hits the ground and bumps straight into a woman of great stature. Imagine the shame. This drunkard has just lost all dignity and might that he may have possessed. And that drunkard… is you! Imagine the shame and disgrace you feel once you realise who you’ve just bumped into. Really lean into the feeling of all your dignity and might just slowly fading away as you come to realise the gravity of the situation.
ReadingMnemonic: There’s only one thing you could think of that could possibly restore all your dignity and might: acquiring a pet eagle (い). Just think about it. It’s the only logical option. How could you not look all dignified and mighty if you just had your own eagle? Just imagine it all perched up on your shoulder. Such dignity and might.

Name: Distance
Mnemonic: A foot on a giant is a pretty long distance for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large distances very quickly. Compare the distance you can travel with one step compared to a giant. It's a considerable difference in distance.
ReadingMnemonic: Going to Little Kyoto (きょ) is a short distance for a giant but a long distance for you. Imagine walking the distance between where you are and the (possibly made up) Little Kyoto. Think about the distance.

Name: Expose
Mnemonic: If the rain touches your foot and gives it a little rain kiss, you know that part of your foot is exposed to the elements. You can also see some dew forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are! Ugh, you shouldn't have bought these open toed shoes, at least not during rainy season!
ReadingMnemonic: You run along the road (ろ), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides. You wonder how long this road will go. With exposed toes, your feet are going to get all wet with dew if you can't get off this blasted road.

Name: Furnace
Mnemonic: A fire door is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a furnace. Open the fire door and feel the heat of the furnace. Hot!
ReadingMnemonic: You're using the furnace to melt tar to put on the road (ろ). Smell the tar baking from the furnace. Feel the heat from the furnace. Fix the road, while you're at it.

Name: Gentle
Mnemonic: You've been ordered to spear this tree but you decide to be really gentle instead. Imagine gently poking the tree with your spear. You glance around nervously, hoping no one notices how easy on it you're being.
ReadingMnemonic: You're being really gentle to the tree when a jewel (じゅう) falls out of its branches and hits you on the head. The jewel has a little note on it, "Thank you for being gentle." Did... did the tree just reward you for being gentle?!

Name: Harp
Mnemonic: Two kings are here right now! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the harp, or the zither, or something. Imagine yourself playing a harp or a zither, even if you don't know how. Entertain these kings to the best of your ability, right now. That's why you're doing it and not someone who knows what they're doing. They want it now.
ReadingMnemonic: You may already know that a Japanese harp is called a こと, but here's a mnemonic to help you if you don't: Your harp playing is pretty bad, so you put your coat on just in case you need to leave in a hurry to escape an angry audience.

Name: Hedge
Mnemonic: Look at the dirt on the ground at dawn and you'll be able to see all the hedges growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out. Picture yourself leaning over a balcony at dawn, looking at all the hedges appear and their shadows stretch over the ground.
ReadingMnemonic: You're looking intently at one particular hedge because yesterday you dropped your car keys (かき) behind it. Now that you know where the hedge is you're going to need to search it to find your car keys. Imagine rooting around under some hedges, desperately trying to find your car keys. Hedges are prickly and there's spiders in here! If only you didn't need a car in the first place!

Name: Instant
Mnemonic: The root of a stamp is to get an instant picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant. Lots of things have roots from wanting to have something in an instant. Just think about instant ramen. The root of that was to get ramen real, real fast. Similar to stamps, ya know?
ReadingMnemonic: Think about the thing you want to make instant. I'd want instant socks (そく)! Don't waste time searching for a matching pair or pulling them on. Just take out a pair of instant socks, add water, and the socks are already on your feet. In an instant! Imagine using instant socks. How do they feel? Soggy, but hey, it was fast!

Name: Nourishing
Mnemonic: A (fresh water) tsunami. Some horns. The ground. A bunch of poop. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very nourishing soil. The stuff in horns is great for fertilizer. So is poop. So is water (as long as it's fresh water). So nourishing!
ReadingMnemonic: This is the kind of nourishing soil that Jesus (じ) would make if he was into making soil, probably. Imagine him making soil made out of those things. Jesus approves of this nourishing soil.

Name: Pasture
Mnemonic: A cow in the winter doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the pasture. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat. It's cold outside (it's winter after all). Imagine you having to herd all the cows out to pasture even though they don't want to leave the warm barn.
ReadingMnemonic: ぼく is one of the common ways to say "I" in Japanese (which you should remember!). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say, "ぼくwill take these cows out to pasture!" Actually say that phrase out loud while thinking about bringing your cows to pasture.

Name: Peace
Mnemonic: The sound of spring water always puts you at peace. Everything from winter is melting and trickling and thawing. All the dripping sounds fill you with a peace you can barely describe.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to feel this peace all the time, not just in spring, so you dip your tie (たい) in the spring water. Now your tie is making the peaceful dripping sounds you love. Imagine carefully dipping all of your ties in the peaceful spring waters and hearing that sweet sound you love at all times.

Name: Point
Mnemonic: Take your spoon to the sun to be able to take a bite. It's delicious, you hear. That's the point of the spoon. Taste that delicious sun. It doesn't even burn!
ReadingMnemonic: This delicious taste is... familiar somehow. You take a few more bites and then scream. It tastes like sheep (し)! You had your eyes closed because the sun is so bright. When you open them you realize the delicious sun you were eating is really just a giant, really bright, cooked sheep. You should probably point this out to NASA or something.

Name: Printing
Mnemonic: You take out a flag, lay a towel below it, and use your knife to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old printing presses used to work. The old way of printing involved taking the pattern you want (the flag), pressing it against the place you want to print it (the towel), then just slicing that sucker on there (with the knife).
ReadingMnemonic: As you get your flag ready for printing you look over and see Satsuki (さつ), who's already finished a nice pattern on her towel. She's a little young to be using a knife, but her print came out nice. You know her pretty well at this point, so try to imagine what kind of printing Satsuki would make. Picture her holding it up to show you.

Name: Rare
Mnemonic: The king's hat, not to mention the hair stuck to said hat, is incredibly rare. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck. Imagine yourself holding a king's hat covered in his hair. Who will you sell it to? This is such a rare item!
ReadingMnemonic: Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even rarer. Attached to the hair is the king's chin (ちん). Not sure how it got there, but you'll make a pretty penny from this. The king only had one chin, so that's about as rare as they come.

Name: Register
Mnemonic: People had to use their bamboo plows long ago to put their name in a register. This is because there was no paper yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their names into the dirt to create all kinds of registers. School registers, family registers, member registers — you name it. Picture the fields and hillsides back then, full of names scraped into the dirt.
ReadingMnemonic: If your name is in a register, people will find you very sexy (せき). This was true long ago too. There's nothing sexier than someone whose existence is accounted for in official documentation. No wonder people went to the trouble of plowing their names into the dirt back then. They understood the sex appeal of registers.

Name: Rub
Mnemonic: You use your fingers to hold the roof of the festival up, but it rubs against them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is rubbing against them really, really badly. Have you ever been to a Japanese festival? There's always one of those portable shrines that are basically just roofs people hold up. That's what you're trying to hold with your fingers as the whole thing rubs against them.
ReadingMnemonic: Just when you thought the rubbing couldn't get any worse, Satsuki (さつ) appears and hops up onto the roof. AAGH! It hurts! Picture Satsuki sitting on the roof as you carry it through the festival. She may be a little girl, but her extra weight makes the rubbing so much worse — you can really feel the skin chafing.

Name: Seal
Mnemonic: You need to make a measurement of an area so you take two clumps of dirt to seal in each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to seal things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue. Picture sealing other things with dirt. Like the bricks in your wall. Or the hole in your floor. Dirt can seal in anything.
ReadingMnemonic: You can also seal food (ふう) in dirt to make it last longer. That's how jerky came about, you know. Seal some meat underground and in a few months you'll have some tasty dried meats to chew. Dig up your sealed food and eat it in the comfort of your own home. Mm, delicious!

Name: Simultaneous
Mnemonic: The simultaneous radical and the simultaneous kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: What simultaneously protects and kills? Your holy blue saber (せい). It's also simultaneously here and there at the same time. It moves really fast. And simultaneously glowing blue and white. Your saber is a lot of things all at once!

Name: Sink
Mnemonic: If a tsunami hits a pirate they are going to sink no matter how good of a pirate captain they are. Tsunamis are big. Pirates are small. Simple as that.
ReadingMnemonic: As the tsunami comes to sink the pirate, the pirate holds his chin (ちん) up high. He will die with dignity. Imagine this dignified chin-holding-up-high pirate. Nod your head, because you know he got what he deserves.

Name: Slap
Mnemonic: Put your fingers in somebody's business by slapping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers. Imagine giving someone a good, hard slap in the face. You're all up in their business now.
ReadingMnemonic: ぼく is one way to say "I" in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But you're going to use it now when you slap this guy. Who's in everybody's business, slapping them? ぼく. Say that out loud, using ぼく. You're the boss, the boss of slap business.

Name: Split
Mnemonic: When a yakuza takes a knife to clothes, it will of course cause a split or tear. It doesn't matter if it's a yakuza member or not. Any knife will cause a split or tear in clothes.
ReadingMnemonic: "I want to split and tear that." You agree, so you say Let's (れつ) do it. Think of a thing you want to tear with your yakuza buddy. You're into it, so you agree and say "Ret's do it!"

Name: Tide
Mnemonic: A small tsunami comes in the morning with the moon. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the tide. The moon does affect the tides a bit, so you can imagine the tsunami as the water getting bigger whenever the moon is out. That's just the tide.
ReadingMnemonic: You go check out the tide. The water is coming in a little stronger, and something washes up on the shore. It's a body! You roll the body over and it is Mrs. Chou (ちょう)! She wakes up and says, "If only you came at low tide then I would never have been saved!" She jumps up and runs off, yelling something about destroying the world.

Name: Tribute
Mnemonic: This construction project made from shellfish will act as a tribute to the Crabigator. The Crabigator is a sea creature (maybe?), so making a tribute from shellfish makes some sense.
ReadingMnemonic: This great tribute is being commissioned by Emperor こういち. In his power, こういち has made a new religion around the Crabigator, to put the fear of kanji learning into his subjects.

Name: Dragon
Mnemonic: A turtle that stands up isn't a turtle anymore. It's evolved into a monster. What kind of monster? A dragon! Rawwwr.

Name: Wind
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wind.

Name: Blade
Mnemonic: The radical blade and the kanji blade are exactly the same. Please, just know your radicals. Please!
ReadingMnemonic: When you stab your blade into an enemy you shout "Ha (は)!" It's just the normal "thrusting with blade" sound. Ha, HA, HaaAA! Those are the blade sounds we all know and love.

Name: Cannon
Mnemonic: You put a stone into a wrap of some kind. This wrap happens to be a cannon, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason. This makes a lot of sense when you think about it, right? The muzzle of the cannon wraps around the rock, then you shoot the rock. Boom!
ReadingMnemonic: You aim the cannon at your own home (ほう). You don't want to have a home anymore, you want to become a pirate, live on a boat, and (of course) shoot cannons all day long. Watch as the cannon goes off, the rock hurtles into your home. And just like that, there is a huge, rock-shaped hole in it. You'll have to shoot a few more rocks at your home with this cannon before it's completely gone.

Name: Conical Hat
Mnemonic: A bamboo thing you put on your head to stand taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a conical hat. You know the ones I'm talking about? They're cone-shaped, sort of, and they go on your head, keeping the sun off your face.
ReadingMnemonic: A conical hat is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for "umbrella" in Japanese? Why, it's kasa (かさ)! Think about a bamboo umbrella on your head. They're pretty similar in shape, after all.

Name: Dragon
Mnemonic: The dragon radical is the same as this kanji, which is dragon. Not to dragon with it, but make sure you know your radicals so you know your kanji!
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine a dragon. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter character Ryu (りゅう). Then imagine after his transformation he attacks you using his Street Fighter moves. "Hadouken!"

Name: Draw Close
Mnemonic: Your fingers told you that a flood last evening would draw close. There was nothing you could do to stop it, it seemed to be be imminent, coming in the darkness of the evening. Think back to last evening, when your fingers twitched and twisted, warning you as the flood started to draw close.
ReadingMnemonic: Luckily whenever you sense a flood starting to draw close, Satsuki (さつ) prepares a raft. Remember Satsuki? Such a talented little girl. I guess floods are common enough that she's learned to make rafts? This one is barely big enough for two people, so you have to draw close if you want to fit. Kind of uncomfortable, but it's better than being caught in an imminent flood.

Name: Edge
Mnemonic: There's a thread tying Wolverine to a pig, balancing them over the edge of a cliff together. Picture wolverine and a pig hanging precariously over the edge. One move the wrong way and they'll both go toppling over.
ReadingMnemonic: Suddenly, the pig squeals, pulls the thread, and sends them both over the edge. Straight to their end (えん). If you fall off the edge it'll be your end too. Always be safe and never get too close to any edges!

Name: Endure
Mnemonic: If someone puts a blade to your heart, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to endure the pain and uncomfortableness of the situation. Imagine your chest and ribs are open. There's a blade on your heart. Now try not to move, or your heart will be cut!
ReadingMnemonic: This is all a part of your ninja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing. This is how they train you. If you can endure this you can endure anything, plus you can stay really still, which is good for ninjas. Just think about how much you want to become a ninja. You'll do anything, even endure this.

Name: Fishing
Mnemonic: A gold pool is where you're going to go fishing. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too. Imagine yourself fishing in a gold pool, catching golden fish. What a great fishing spot this is.
ReadingMnemonic: You caught a couple of gold fish. Two (つ) gold fish, actually! Count your golden fish. They're so nice! They're also worth their weight in gold, because, well, they are gold.

Name: Fox
Mnemonic: The animal that hangs out in melon patches is the elusive fox! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that. Imagine seeing a red fox scampering through a melon patch trying to take melons with it.
ReadingMnemonic: If you want to stop foxes from stealing your melons you can get one of those kits that neigh (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back! Imagine buying kits that neigh and putting them around your melon patch to warn you when foxes are around.

Name: Good Luck
Mnemonic: The good luck radical and the good luck kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: For good luck, you keep special kits (きつ) in your kitchen (きち). These kitchen kits contain good luck charms. Your good luck kitchen kits have charms that say things like, "good food," "good company," and "good luck not cutting off your fingers with kitchen knives."

Name: Grains
Mnemonic: The part of rice that stands up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the grains. If you think about this one it'll make good sense. Just imagine rice stalks standing up into the air.
ReadingMnemonic: You have a box of grains. Ryuu (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers. He has his hands flat, and stabs his hands into the grains. Yah! Yah! Yah!

Name: Hair
Mnemonic: Your long hair is your friend. It's your hair and you're so proud of it. Just feel your hair, it's such a good friend, and you wish it was longer.
ReadingMnemonic: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great 神 (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair. Pretend to pray to the great hair 神. What is his reply? Does he give you more hair?

Name: Hill
Mnemonic: An axe is stuck into the ground on a hill. Imagine climbing up the hill. The sun is coming up behind the axe,  silhouetting the whole thing very nicely.
ReadingMnemonic: You reach the top of the hill and realize the entire hill is covered in cucumbers (きゅう). The axe has a little note on it that says "Cucumber Hill Axe - Please Use." You take the axe out of the hill and cut off some cucumber to eat. Mm mm!

Name: Ladle
Mnemonic: The ladle radical and the ladle kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: You use a ladle to distribute soup. But as you're ladling you find something odd floating in the soup. It's... a toe (と)! You scream, dropping the ladle and the toe on the ground. Your mom comes rushing in and smacks you on the head. "Fool!" she says, "This is toe soup, what did you think you'd ladle up?!" Oops.

Name: Limb
Mnemonic: Looking at the moon, you notice it's grown a bunch of branches. Wait, are those all… limbs?! You feel absolutely terrified looking at the moon with all its branches consisting of limbs, lifelessly flopping around. How did this happen?
ReadingMnemonic: After some consideration, you know who put all those limbs on the moon. It must've been none other than the moon sheep (し)! The moon sheep are always up to no good, so this must all have been devised by them. Those darn moon sheep!

Name: Measurement
Mnemonic: The measurement radical and the measurement kanji are exactly the same. If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
ReadingMnemonic: You want to measure something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the sun (すん). Imagine yourself deciding to do this. First step is to get a ridiculously long measuring tape. Then, you go up to the sun and start measuring. You immediately start getting burned. Feel the pain of the heat from the sun. Think about how this really probably wasn't a good idea. You still go forward, though, doing your best to measure the sun. Ouch, ouch, ouch.

Name: Peach
Mnemonic: The tree has an omen growing from it, one single peach that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons. Of course, this tree omen of a peach refers to momotaro, the little boy who was born from a peach (you should look it up if you don't know this children's story).
ReadingMnemonic: If momotaro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the peach growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: "MORE! MORE!" (もも). It grows bigger everytime you say "MORE MORE" twice. If you say it just once, it stays the same.

Name: Pear
Mnemonic: The grain you cut off a tree with a knife is a pear. I don't know if you've ever seen Asian pears, but they're pretty big and sturdy. You can't just pick them off of the tree, you need the help of a knife. That's why this is a pear, and not an apple or peach or something else. Imagine standing below a tree full of pears. You take your knife and carefully cut them all down, one by one.
ReadingMnemonic: As you cut the pears down, you can't help but gnash (なし) your teeth. You want to eat these pears right now. You gnash and grind and wait though, because you want to have them all down before you start the feast. Imagine a beautiful, ripe pear in your mind. Now gnash your teeth. Mmm. You want to eat a pear right now, don't you?

Name: Princess
Mnemonic: The woman servant is the lower ranking princess. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do. Just imagine a princess saying "UGH, I'm just like a servant, I have to do all the crap you tell me." Then, all the servants roll their eyes, because, really, she's a princess, lucky duck.
ReadingMnemonic: The princess goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants, "Don't tell my daddy, the king, I did this. He may (ひめ) not like it." The servants all know they should tell the king, because the princess is a servant to the king, just as they are, plus they don't want to lose their heads.

Name: Push Open
Mnemonic: You use your fingers when you're in private to use an arrow to push open things. You're in private in your own room, no one else is around. Now you wrap your fingers around this big arrow, and you push open your door, your curtains, your windows. It's weird, but you really enjoy this.
ReadingMnemonic: Your favorite thing to push open is your own eye (あい). You take the arrow into your fingers and gently push each lid open until you can see. Picture the arrow in your hands. You're facing a mirror, but you can't see because you're about to push open your eyes. The anticipation is killing you, push them open now!

Name: Recreation
Mnemonic: A woman loves her catapult for some good ol' fashioned recreation. You ask the woman what she does for fun... for recreation. She says, she goes out and shoots her catapult.
ReadingMnemonic: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for recreation is Godzilla (ご). Get out of here, Godzilla! I'm gonna shoot you.

Name: Riddle
Mnemonic: I say, which weighs more: a kilogram of scooters or a kilogram of rice? This is a riddle! Think carefully and see if you can come up with the answer to my riddle before you read on.
ReadingMnemonic: Did you figure out the answer to this riddle? Say your answer aloud to the screen right now.... not so (なぞ)! You're wrong. Did you say the answer to the riddle is that they're both a kilogram? Not so! A scooter is heavier than some rice! And don't you email me saying that's not so! It's my riddle, I can make the answer whatever I want. That's the law of riddles!

Name: Samurai
Mnemonic: The leader of the temple isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a samurai, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe. You walk up to a temple and you're surprised to find that there's a samurai guarding it. Talk to him for a while so he can tell you why he has been doing this job. He's quite a nice guy, actually.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is samurai, which should be easy enough to remember. If you know the meaning you know the reading as well! That doesn't happen too often with kanji, so consider yourself lucky!

Name: Scold
Mnemonic: From my mouth I have told you seven times not to do that. Now I have to scold you. SEVEN TIMES! You'd think you'd learn.
ReadingMnemonic: What were you doing wrong that caused me to scold you? You were feeding the 鹿 (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves! Imagine yourself feeding the deer, then getting scolded (or you doing the scolding to someone else feeding the deer, whichever works best).

Name: Shout
Mnemonic: You have mouth vines, so you shout! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout. You were born with mouth vines (a rare condition where your mouth is always full of vines), so you've been shouting all your life. And yet people still can't hear you. It's very frustrating.
ReadingMnemonic: You need to shout so that people can understand you through the mouth vines. You shout, "きょうと!" because you hear there is a temple there for people with your condition. Imagine the word きょうと not coming out clearly because of your mouth vines. People can only hear the きょう part, so they don't know where you want to go. SHOUT LOUDER! きょうと！

Name: Sprout
Mnemonic: A flowers fang is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little sprout. Imagine a bunch of these. They look like big fangs poking out of the ground (that is, until they bloom and get into the air).
ReadingMnemonic: When the sprout gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking 目 (め), looking right at you. You look at all the sprouts. They have all turned into 目s, looking straight at you. You're terrified.

Name: Storm
Mnemonic: The mountain wind coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a storm. Well, it is a storm, really. If you think about it makes sense. Those mountain winds that come down from the mountain are cold and windy and nasty. When they mix with warmer air down below, it creates a nasty storm.
ReadingMnemonic: A storm is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get a rash (あらし). The rash comes from being wet and not drying off when you get home. Your skin gets irritated by this moisture.

Name: Thunder
Mnemonic: Rain on a rice paddy means only one thing... thunder! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder! Imagine hearing the thunder closing in on you as you frantically try to escape the rice paddy. RUN!!!
ReadingMnemonic: You can’t run fast enough to escape the thunder, so you decide to hide under a pile of… rye (らい)?! This rye will save your life. It’s just you and this pile of rye now. Take a deeeeep breath in, and really smell the thunder and rye in the air. You’re fine. You’re cozy. This rye will be your savior.

Name: Tower
Mnemonic: When dirt and flowers suit one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a tower! A flower tower made of flower power! Imagine walking in the woods and coming across a huge tower made of flowers. It goes so high you can hardly see the top.
ReadingMnemonic: The only place flowers grow into towers like this is in とうきょう. とうきょう dirt is the best. とうきょう flowers are the best. Thus, you end up with a lot of とうきょう towers. How do you think the とうきょう tower came to be, anyway? It was once a big flower tower. They just replaced it with metal later. BOOM! History bomb, you're welcome.

Name: Vermilion
Mnemonic: The slide to get off this jet is a beautiful, brilliant vermilion color. Vermilion is like an orange red, which is perfect for visibility purposes.
ReadingMnemonic: You jump onto the vermilion slide. It's actually more of a steep chute (しゅ). And... oh... urp... it's making you sick. The vermilion chute spits you out and you spit out your lunch. And it looks vermilion. Uh oh. Hospital. Please.

Name: Wing
Mnemonic: A feather is on a rice paddy, and they are attached together. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one wing of your amazing aircraft. Imagine a wing that is made of a rice paddy and a feather put together. Doesn't make sense, looks ugly, and probably will not fly. Imagine it anyways. It is your wing.
ReadingMnemonic: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the yolk (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe. Imagine using the yolks to stick everything together. It's all over your hands, and things are pretty nasty.

Name: Protect
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means protect.

Name: Renew
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means renew.

Name: Approximate
Mnemonic: A spoon to measure a geoduck is a very approximate measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right? Do the comparison. A spoonful of geoduck aka a whole geoduck on a spoon. This is a spoonful, right? This is what the recipe wanted, I think...
ReadingMnemonic: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an approximate. So, you take the core (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead. That's a little better. Not too much geoduck. Still a lot, but more like an approximate.

Name: Bacteria
Mnemonic: When you leave grains in your mouth for long enough, they'll turn into flowers of bacteria. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time. Imagine how much bacteria would flower in your mouth if you just left grains in there for like, I dunno, a month. That's a lot of nasty bacteria!
ReadingMnemonic: There is a lot of this bacteria in the King (きん) of England's mouth. He eats a lot of grains, and he won't let anyone touch his mouth to clean it, but he refuses to do things himself... so it's absolutely chock full of bacteria. Picture the King's mouth up close. Look at all the bacteria squiggling around and through his teeth and gums. Bleh! Barf!

Name: Bell
Mnemonic: Something made of gold stands in a village. It's a bell!  The village bell. Every village has a bell of its own, standing tall and proud and shiny in the middle for everyone to see and hear.
ReadingMnemonic: The bell rings whenever the Shougun (しょう) arrives in the village. Its ringing echoes throughout the entire village so everyone knows they have to come out and pay their respects. The Shougun bell even sounds like it's warning you that the Shougun has arrived. It makes a loud, low shooooouu shooou sound.

Name: Boat
Mnemonic: The boat radical and the boat kanji are the same! Boats are boats, you know?
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same reading that you learned with the vocabulary 船. Since 船 and 舟 both mean "boat", this reading should be pretty easy to remember!

Name: Bride
Mnemonic: The woman who makes your house a home is your bride. She's in your house because you married her. Thus, she's your bride. Your house is now a home.
ReadingMnemonic: Now that you have a bride in your house, you can get rid of your maid (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning. Your bride is very upset at how sexist you're being right now, and makes you do all the cleaning instead. The maid still gets fired.

Name: Calendar
Mnemonic: Looking up to the cliff, you see the trees, and the sun shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole calendar. Look at the different shadow patterns. Know what they all mean. This is your very own calendar system.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember the word 歴史, which means "history"? Using a calendar, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related. Make sure you make the connection between the word 歴史 and this kanji. If you do, it'll be much easier to remember the reading of this kanji.

Name: Cloudy
Mnemonic: The sun is being blocked by a rain cloud, making it cloudy. You look up at the sky, trying to find the sun, but it's so cloudy that you can't even find where the sun should be.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember 雲? It means "cloud" and has the same reading as "cloudy," making them both くも. If it's cloudy there are clouds, so if you can read one, you can read the other!

Name: Considerably
Mnemonic: An alligator is considerably dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here]. The radical meaning and the kanji meaning aren't the same, but we'll get through this together. Just put a considerable amount of effort into this and you'll learn considerably more quickly.
ReadingMnemonic: Speaking of considerably terrifying, that place known as Narnia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there. Also, things that are "considerably" anything start somewhere. They become (なり) whatever "considerable" thing they are now from something smaller before.

Name: Cram School
Mnemonic: You receive instruction in a circle in the dirt. Where are you? Cram school! Your cram school thinks that you’ll learn better sitting in a circle in the dirt. So there you are in the dirt, receiving your lessons.
ReadingMnemonic: Not only does your cram school teach kids in a circle in the dirt, it also plays music on a jukebox (じゅく). Yes, a jukebox. They believe a jukebox's tunes help with cramming. Imagine a jukebox playing loudly right beside you while you’re cramming away. Hard to believe, but the jukebox's melodies do actually amplify the cramming fervor, making you just cram, cram, cram!

Name: Curse
Mnemonic: From the mouth of your older brother comes... a curse! Imagine him cursing you. He's not a fan of you, since you are siblings, but to think he'd go so far as to put a curse on you? You can't believe it. What kind of curse did he put upon you?
ReadingMnemonic: Turns out, he put the no road (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads. In your mind, walk around the area where you live. Think about the places you can go that aren't roads. If you try to walk on a road, you can't. This is the no road curse, after all.

Name: Damp
Mnemonic: After the tsunami the sun comes out again and shines on these spikes. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still damp. The sun did a little bit of work, so they aren't wet, but they aren't dry either. They're damp.
ReadingMnemonic: As you're looking at the damp spikes, a shih tzu (しつ) prances over, slips on the damp ground, and falls right on the spike! Oh nooo! Luckily the shih tzu is kinda pinned between the spikes, so it isn't dead or anything, but it's definitely stuck. You try to help it out, but you slip because it's so damp and you fall in too! Imagine the sound of your cries mixing in with the shih tzu's as you both struggling to get out but can't because of how damp everything is.

Name: Earnings
Mnemonic: The grains you have stored in your house reflect on your earnings. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains. Imagine looking at the grains in the houses of people who make vastly different earnings. The poor artist has only a few sacks of grain. The rich samurai has an extra house just for holding his grain. That's how you know he has much higher earnings than the artist.
ReadingMnemonic: Another way to check someone's earnings is to see if they have a car (か). Would someone who doesn't make a lot of money have a car? No! Picture your own earnings. Can you afford a lot of grains and a car?

Name: Fly
Mnemonic: A sheep with feathers (and presumably wings, too) is able to fly. Imagine the sheep with feathers taking off and flying around. It's an odd sight, but makes sense, kind of.
ReadingMnemonic: Watching that sheep with feathers and wings flying around made you thirsty. You remember that you have a car kettle (かけ), so you reach into your car and grab your car kettle to make a special car-kettle brew. Imagine yourself enjoying the cozy car-kettle brew, while admiring the unusual sight of the sheep with feathers and wings flying through the sky. This is just shear bliss!

Name: Gamble
Mnemonic: I'm putting all my shellfish on someone, hoping they'll win the race! This is a gamble and you're gambling. Remember, shellfish used to be used as money. So if you're betting shellfish on someone, you're just gambling. And you probably won't get any of those shellfish back.
ReadingMnemonic: If you win this gamble you'll have enough shellfish to buy a brand new car (か)! If you go to any of those fancy (and not so fancy) gamble-places, they always have a car sitting in the middle of the room. Usually rotating, really slowly, to make you want it more, making you gamble more.

Name: Ghost
Mnemonic: Coming down with the rain is two spikes. They go right through two ghosts. The ghosts are pinned to the ground by the spikes, unable to move.
ReadingMnemonic: You come across the ghosts, who are stabbed into the ground. "Please," they beg. "Please use that ray (れい) gun that's in that row (りょう) boat and end our suffering." A ray gun, coincidentally, is the only thing that can kill a ghost, and there it lays, just out of reach. You'll have to be the one to pull the trigger of the ray gun. Do you pick up the ray gun out of the row boat to destroy the ghosts?

Name: Gutter
