Mnemonic: Tsunami vs lifeguard. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the gutter. To be fair, it's pretty obvious who would win. Nobody knows what that lifeguard was thinking.
ReadingMnemonic: In the gutter is a lifeguard, so Emperor こういち decides to survey the damage. "This lifeguard didn't believe in the power of kanji learning," こういち says to the press. "He was punished by the great Crabigator, who sent its tsunami as a warning for all."

Name: Hunt
Mnemonic: I protect my own animals by going to hunt other animals... like wolves and cougars and such. My animals can't protect themselves, that's why I hunt other animals instead.
ReadingMnemonic: I also do all my hunts using a car (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways. Imagine hunting down animals in a car.

Name: Leg
Mnemonic: If you've been to the moon in the past, you had to get the special stamp on your leg. This leg stamp not only proved you went, but lets everyone around you know you've been to the moon before!
ReadingMnemonic: You've only met one other person with the same mark on their leg and it was Kyaku (きゃく) the customer. Kyaku visits many places all over the world, so it only makes sense that they've also been off-world too. Picture Kyaku lifting up their pant leg and showing you all the stamps from all the different places they've been. There are even some planets on there!

Name: Lucidity
Mnemonic: When the tsunami struck, it hit your tent full of beans. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of lucidity. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it! Then you went back to being crazy. That moment of lucidity was only temporary, and you go back to stockpiling beans.
ReadingMnemonic: Your lucidity is clear to everyone because you wear a suit (す). Everyone knows that lucid people wear suits! Imagine yourself wearing a sharp suit and being a model of lucidity

Name: Lump
Mnemonic: A dirt demon is just a lump. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust. Picture a lump of dirt. Is there a demon hiding under there? No. It's just a saying, ya nerd.
ReadingMnemonic: A lump of something is just a 固まり (かたまり) — the hardened thing itself. 塊 is derived from 固まり, which is the noun form of 固まる (to be hardened). You know a lump is usually something that's compressed and hardened.

Name: Lunatic
Mnemonic: The animal king? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a lunatic, though. While we're speaking of animals, he's absolutely bat sh*t crazy.
ReadingMnemonic: You might see that crazy lunatic hanging around the outskirts of きょうと. He'll lurk near your trash cans and scream, "I AM THE ANIMAL KING!" and run away with some orange peels. I think he maybe got too friendly with some raccoons and beavers and went crazy. Watch out for him if you live in きょうと, rabies is no joke.

Name: Miss
Mnemonic: A woman who is a nurse should be called miss. Compare this to a man who is a nurse. You should probably call him mister. That's why you know a woman who is a nurse is "miss."
ReadingMnemonic: "Call me Miss Joe (じょう)," Joe says to you. When you think of "miss," remember the time Joe asked you to call him "Miss Joe". He’s this big, ten foot tall guy, but now he suddenly wants you to call him Miss Joe. Well, we’re all for respecting everbody’s personal choices here, so we better get used to it.

Name: Naked
Mnemonic: If you're showing me your "spirit fruit" then you are just naked. You're nude. You know what I mean by "spirit fruit" –– yep, it's out there and you're naked.
ReadingMnemonic: Known for being naked (and showing you his spirit fruit) is the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). Don't look up "Ra Egyptian god naked" in Google. Nothing good will come of it. Instead, just imagine your own Egyptian god Ra being naked in front of you.

Name: Peak
Mnemonic: An axe is sticking in the ground on top of a mountain. It's sticking into the very peak. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it? Picture that axe, jammed into the mountain's peak. The person who did that must have been really cool to get all the way up there.
ReadingMnemonic: You can't help but gawk (がく) at the peak. Somehow it looks even higher now. Go ahead, imagine this peak with an axe in it and actually gawk a bit at how far you have to go to get that high.

Name: Polish
Mnemonic: Below this canopy of trees is a stone. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to polish it. It's a single, perfectly round stone under this canopy of trees. It didn't start this way, but thanks to all the polishing you did, it has become nice and smooth.
ReadingMnemonic: You polish the stone due to your meager (みが) lifestyle. There's only this one stone under these trees, and polishing the stone is the only job here. Still, you don't get much from it, thus the meager life of polishing your stone.

Name: Shade
Mnemonic: This building now has a cloud over it, creating shade. This shade is really convenient right now, because it's been such a hot day. Ahh, shade is so nice and cool.
ReadingMnemonic: The building that's getting this nice shade is the inn (いん) you're staying at. Picture an inn with a cloud right above it right now. Look at the cloud-shaped shade keeping everyone visiting the inn cool and sunburn-free.

Name: Skin
Mnemonic: The moon table is a table that's made entirely of skin. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porous, skin. Touch it and feel the "moon table." You know it's not made of moon. How ridiculous.
ReadingMnemonic: But, when you go to touch this "moon table" made of skin, you realize that it's harder (はだ) than you expected. You'd think skin would be softer, but it's pretty hard. Much harder than you expected.

Name: Soul
Mnemonic: The cloud floating above a demon has its soul in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the spirit it once was. Right now, however, the demon is looming over you, and you can't see anything in the cloud above its head. It just looks mad, like it's gonna pummel you or eat you.
ReadingMnemonic: You shout out and beg its soul for help until, finally, you see the cloud take the shape of a condor (こん). Aha! "You were a condor before you became a demon! Remember who you are and turn back!" POOF! Now there's a condor spirit floating in front of you, crying. "Thank you, human. You've saved my soul!" it says, and float/flies off and disappears.

Name: Spear
Mnemonic: The spear radical and the spear kanji are the same! Spears are spears. It makes sense!
ReadingMnemonic: You take this spear and stab it into a cow. "MOO (む)!" it cries. The cow bites the spear out of your hands and stabs you back. "MOO!" you scream. How do you like it? Don't stab cows with spears, you monster.

Name: Stare
Mnemonic: When your eye catches an omen, it's only natural that you will stare at it. You don't see omens that often, so of course you're going to stare. We'll imagine what the omen is in the reading mnemonic.
ReadingMnemonic: As you stare at the omen, you see Mrs. Chou (ちょう) knocking down buildings, putting nails on the street, and making herself way longer than you ever thought possible. Oh, and there she is, destroying the world. Whenever you see an omen (radical), remember that the omen will probably have Mrs. Chou in it!

Name: Stiff
Mnemonic: You feel like a stone that’s been renewed. How do renewed stones feel? Stiff. Very stiff. Think of a stone being renewed like it is having something like a spa day. Pedicure, manicure, the whole shebang. It’ll come out all stiff and hardened, cause that’s how good stones are.
ReadingMnemonic: You remember how you used to cure these stiff body times: your old friend こういち would just massage them out for you. If only you could ask こういち to give you massages again, but he's too busy for you, now (being emperor and all).

Name: Table
Mnemonic: The toe is early. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the table. See all the toes lined up on the table. They are the ones who showed up early.
ReadingMnemonic: What do all the early toes on the table do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, talking (たく). Imagine the toes talking to each other. "Hello Mr. Toe!" "Oh hello other Mr. Toe!"

Name: Villain
Mnemonic: If there's a treasure chest, there's always a villain too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story. And the villain always gets to the treasure chest first, often via nefarious means. That villain is SO important when it comes to treasure chests.
ReadingMnemonic: The villain beat you all the way to きょうと to get this particular treasure chest. Arrrg! If only you had been closer to きょうと! Then you might have beaten this dastardly villain.

Name: Waterfall
Mnemonic: A tsunami in the shape of a dragon flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a waterfall. Can you see why a tsunami dragon (especially the Asian skinny snake-like kind) could be a waterfall? Try to imagine it.
ReadingMnemonic: Despite how cool a dragon waterfall is, to be honest it's also pretty tacky (たき). Now imagine it being a bit tacky. Dragons are alright but... you just don't want to overdo it, you know?

Name: Fat
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means fat.

Name: Favor
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means favor.

Name: Black Ink
Mnemonic: You use black dirt to make black ink. That's what you use to write in black! Make sure the dirt you're using to make black ink is really, really black. Like the kind you find around volcanoes or something.
ReadingMnemonic: Be careful that you don't spill black ink on anyone or anything. If you do, you have to own it. Imagine spilling black ink on someone, and when they confront you, you yell, "Yeah I got black ink on you, so sue me (すみ)!" Imagine yelling "SUE ME!" at someone's face, which is covered in the black ink you spilled there.

Name: Blink
Mnemonic: Your eye gets kicked with a cleat that came careening toward your forehead when it popped off someone doing a dance, and you blink. Well, of course you blink, you can't control that. And when a cleat come hurtling toward your eye it blinks automatically.
ReadingMnemonic: You blink and blink and soon (しゅん) there are tears coming out of them too. You try to blink them away but it's not working. Soon you're crying and blinking and crying some more. Soon the person who's cleat hit you is running over and trying to apologize and stop your crying, but it's too late.

Name: Bubbles
Mnemonic: If a tsunami wraps around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of bubbles. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, a whole lot of bubbles are created. Picture the bubbles bursting out of the wrapped up tsunami as it crashes down. The air that the tsunami sucked in while it was wrapping up come out as bubbles big and small.
ReadingMnemonic: One of the biggest bubbles heads straight for your home (ほう), engulfs it, and picks it up into the air! Watch helplessly as your home, now trapped in a bubble, floats away into the sky.

Name: Building
Mnemonic: There’s a tree in the east that looks like a building. The tree is tall and straight and doesn't have any leaves or branches. It's basically a big wooden building. Look at this big tree building over in the east. Imagine actually using it as a building and moving in. And why not? It's free real estate.
ReadingMnemonic: That building happens to be in the center of とうきょう. If you need to find east (which is where とうきょう is), you just look for the building. Imagine looking down on とうきょう from the top floor of this magnificent building you've just moved into. The sun is rising behind you, slowly illuminating the city below.

Name: Calm
Mnemonic: Some grains get stuck in his cleat, and Wolverine's heart grows calm. Wolverine had been screaming and yelling and stomping around, but when the grains entered his cleat he realized where he was. He was finally able to calm down. He's calm now because he stomped right into a farmer's field (thus the rice) and if he didn't calm down he'd probably ruin it.
ReadingMnemonic: Now that Wolverine is calm, tears come to his eyes. Being calm has given him perspective on what his anger has done. Oh, wait no. There are just some onions (おん) in his cleats too, and they're making calm tears trickle down his eyes. Picture Wolverine sitting calmly in this field, onions causing tears to stream down his cheeks as he reflects on what he's done.

Name: Cavity
Mnemonic: You see a child with an umbrella in front of you. Suddenly, they fall straight down into a cavity in the road. It's a big hole! You run over to where the child fell. They are just fine! Because they had an umbrella, they were able to float to the bottom.
ReadingMnemonic: "Into my cavity you go!" yells a voice. It is こういち. "You will stay in that cavity or hole until you repent." If it hasn't been clear up until now, Emperor こういち is going mad with power.

Name: Chair
Mnemonic: This tree is very odd, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a chair! Imagine this odd tree chair being the most comfortable chair you've ever sat on. It's shaped perfectly for you, and the moss makes it soft. Wow, what a chair.
ReadingMnemonic: But, this odd tree chair is also home to an eagle (い). It swoops down upon you as you sit down, gouging your eyes out. Feel the fear and regret. You should have known not to sit in this "chair". Mother nature never forgives, and now you don't have eyeballs.

Name: Chrysanthemum
Mnemonic: If you pick the wrong kind of flowers, you'll be put into prison with nothing but rice to eat. You'll especially want to avoid picking chrysanthemums. Chrysanthemums are super important in Japan because they're the symbol of the imperial family. They're even on the cover of Japanese passports. Please don't ever pick them unless you want to end up in prison eating only rice for the rest of your life.
ReadingMnemonic: If you go to prison for chrysanthemum picking, everyone in the prison is going to kick (きく) you nonstop. You broke the chrysanthemum picking law, so kicking is your punishment. And believe me, you don't want these kicks. Imagine holding a chrysanthemum in your hands while you get kicked over and over and over in prison. Was it worth it?

Name: Cotton
Mnemonic: The white thread in your towel comes from cotton. We use cotton to make lots of things, like clothes and bedsheets. But white towels are always made from soft, fluffy cotton. Imagine shoving your face into a nice, clean, white cotton towel. Mmm, so fresh.
ReadingMnemonic: This cotton is made by men (めん). Picture all of the men lined up, making towels out of pure white cotton. They're all rubbing their faces in the soft cotton whenever they can.

Name: Devil
Mnemonic: Below the canopy of trees is a demon. This demon is a devil. You thought the devil hangs out in hell, but he actually hangs out under this canopy of trees.
ReadingMnemonic: Why is the devil under a canopy of trees? Because he's looking for his mama (ま). Into the trees is where all mamas go missing. And so the devil searches for his mama under this canopy of trees.

Name: Dormitory
Mnemonic: You need to bring charcoal under this roof to heat the dormitory. You live in this dormitory with a bunch of other kids, and you all have to take turns bringing in the charcoal from outside to heat it. Imagine looking at a dormitory chore wheel and seeing it's your turn to carry in the charcoal this week. Bleh!
ReadingMnemonic: The dormitory is on an island, so when you go out to get the charcoal you have to take a row (りょう) boat. You row and row and row until you reach the shed with all the charcoal. Then you row and row and row it back to the dormitory. The dormitory row boat leaks a little too, so by the time you get back you really need to light the charcoal and heat up!

Name: Dove
Mnemonic: There are nine birds and one of them is a dove and another is a pigeon. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders. Look at these nine birds strutting down the street like they own the place. The dove and pigeon are out in front because they are the most important. Hear them chirping and fluttering their feathers about.
ReadingMnemonic: Take a look at the pigeon in front of you. Now, grab it, tear it in half, and grab the heart (はと) from its little body. Devour it. You love pigeon hearts. Discard the rest, keep the heart.

Name: Dull
Mnemonic: Make barracks out of gold and they will get dull quickly. Gold is soft, it's okay for jewelry and delicate things that aren't used much, but barracks for soldiers? Those are used constantly, and they get worn out easily. What was once shiny gold will go dull in days. Picture a huge barracks made of dull, almost brown, gold. Maybe you should have picked a better material.
ReadingMnemonic: As you stare sadly at the dull barracks, the don (どん) shows up out of nowhere, and he's pissed. He turns his angry gaze toward you and says, "How did my barracks get so dull? Are you at fault? This is bad, this is very bad. Someone will pay for this." You stand cowering in front of the don as he inspects how dull the gold barracks are. You don't wanna be off'd for this just because the don was dull enough to make you use gold!

Name: Forge
Mnemonic: You want to turn your gold comb into a weapon, so you throw it into the forge. Once the gold comb has melted down in the forge, you can forge it into whatever weapon you want.
ReadingMnemonic: You're trying to work the forge, but it's harder than you thought. You end up forging outside all day and get a wicked tan (たん). Most people who do forge work have tans. And now you know why.

Name: Go
Mnemonic: A crab moves a stone because he is playing the game Go. You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good. Look at this crab placing stones on the Go board. Hear them click and clack as the crab places them with expert precision.
ReadingMnemonic: Go is pronounced Go (ご) in Japanese, too. How convenient is that? Like, super convenient. So easy even a crab could remember! Go is Go. Easy!

Name: Habit
Mnemonic: When you get sick you always eat a hot pepper. It's a habit you've picked up and you can't seem to shake it. One sniffle, one cough, and before you know it, you're eating a hot pepper or two. Imagine if you had a habit of eating hot peppers whenever you thought you might be getting sick. To be fair, it flushes out your sinuses and tastes good, so it's not the worst habit you could have.
ReadingMnemonic: Everyone you know has a different habit when they get sick. Instead, they eat couscous (くせ). But you think couscous is gross. It's bland and does nothing for your stuffy noses and scratchy throats. I wonder how you can convince them to replace their habit with your own. Unfortunately, now you've gotten into the habit of telling everyone what to do when they get sick. "Yeah, yeah, eat a hot pepper, we know. But couscous is better," they say before you can speak. To each their own, I suppose.

Name: Head of Plant
Mnemonic: The part of the grain people favor the most is the head of the plant. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are. Imagine yourself walking through a field of rice plants. Now look very closely at the head of the plant in front of you. See the rice bunched up there? That's the good stuff.
ReadingMnemonic: When you want to harvest the head of the plant you'd like to eat, you need to use a hoe (ほ). Using a hoe, you can dig up the bottom of the plant without injuring the head. Imagine working in a field of rice and using a hoe so you don't injure the head of the plant. You're sweating and it's hot, but you keep at it.

Name: I
Mnemonic: I have five things in my mouth and I need them all for me. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me. What five things would you keep in your mouth to protect them from me? Imagine these five things in your mouth and think of how important they are to you as you taste them on your tongue.
ReadingMnemonic: Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!” Imagine how you would sound asking for “waga” with your mouth full of five things. You can carry out this experiment in real life if you would like, just be careful not to choke, okay?

Name: Key
Mnemonic: You take some gold and cover your yoga brush in it, turning it into a key. You shove the brush you normally use for yoga into the lock to your car and pour the gold over it. Now it's the right shape to be a key! You lost your old key, you see. But you're a go with the flow type of person, thanks to all the yoga, so you make a new one!
ReadingMnemonic: This key has to be perfect, because if it isn't the car guillotine (かぎ) will come down and chop off your hand! Imagine carefully putting your makeshift key into your car's lock. You close your eyes and pray that the car guillotine isn't going to trigger, knowing it isn't a legit key.

Name: Manor
Mnemonic: You're standing under a canopy when you see something strange sticking out of the dirt. You pull it, but it won't budge. You pull harder and harder until the dirt starts rumbling and a giant manor starts rising out of the ground with you on top! Picture yourself on top of this manor that rose out of the ground. The canopy is still above you and it seems to be attached to the roof.
ReadingMnemonic: The beautiful manor begins to shake and the shougun (しょう) bursts out of the front door. "WHO HAS UNEARTHED MY SECRET MANOR?!" he screams. Imagine being chased by an angry shougun all through his giant, luxurious manor. You barely have time to admire the interior design with him gaining on you like this!

Name: Monkey
Mnemonic: An animal that kicks dirt into people's mouths is a monkey. Monkeys are naughty little things. You should be happy it was just dirt it kicked into your mouth, and not something worse. Imagine looking at a monkey at the zoo. Aww, it's so cute. But then it turns around and kicks some dirt right into your aww-ing mouth. Yuck! Why monkey, why?!
ReadingMnemonic: You spit the dirt out of your mouth and look back at the monkey to see that it's saluting (さる) you. Is... is it mocking you? Picture the monkey saluting you as you spit dirt out of your mouth. Taste the bitter dirt and the bitter shame. You were played by a monkey.

Name: Pride
Mnemonic: Say "two big prisons" with pride! Nobody said you can't have pride after serving time in two big prisons. So say it with your chest! Imagine really puffing out your chest and saying, "Yes, two big prisons!", with all the pride you can muster.
ReadingMnemonic: After mustering all your pride, you feel like a new person, reborn almost. "I feel like a 子 (こ) again!", you proclaim to the world. With your regained, child-like pride, you venture out into the world after spending way too much time in those two big prisons. A new life awaits you, good luck!

Name: Pupil
Mnemonic: Inside your eye stands a tiny village that makes up your pupil. That's the black part of your eye! Oh, did you think your pupil was a hole? No, no, you misunderstand. That's where the village stands. It's full of little people who whisper to your brain what you should see.
ReadingMnemonic: All of the people in your pupil eat doughnuts (どう) all day long. That's why your eye is shaped like a doughnut, with the "hole" (village) as their home. Even if you're a pupil non-believer, at least you can see how it's shaped like a doughnut hole, right?

Name: Rather
Mnemonic: On the roof is your heart. OR! In a net in the street. Which would you rather? Would you rather have your heart up on the roof, close to falling but out of the way of people. Or would you rather have your heart in a net, which people can't steal from, but is in the way of cars.
ReadingMnemonic: As you try to decide which you'd rather have, your neighbors (ねい) come out and grab the heart out of your hands. "I'd rather you didn't have that!" you shout as your neighbors run through the neighborhood to their own house. You'd rather this wasn't happening! You'd rather your neighbors let you make your own choice!!

Name: Sack
Mnemonic: The leader of your sad life aims a kick at the sack you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it's not something you want to have kicked. See this leader's kick coming at your sack. Hear the leader yelling as he aims his kick at your sack. Hiyahhh! Also keep in mind that the life radical is missing the little drop/slide thing on the side. It's missing that because your life is lousy and sad.
ReadingMnemonic: You manage to get your sack out of the way as you shout "Heyo (ひょう)! Look, you missed! Heyo!" Unfortunately your leader's friend was standing behind you and he kicks your sack as you move it out of the way. "Heyo!" he shouts, mockingly. You thought you were all cool saying "heyo" and moving your sack away from the kick, but they had this planned all along. Heyo…

Name: Secluded
Mnemonic: Poop Poop Mountain is covered in poop because it is such a secluded place. A secluded place has no toilets, so you just poop right on the mountain.
ReadingMnemonic: The secluded Poop Poop Mountain is a favorite of youths (ゆう). They go there to get away from their phones to get in touch with nature again. Imagine hundreds of youths on this secluded mountain, all pooping on the ground while trying to get a cell phone signal.

Name: Shelf
Mnemonic: With the power of your mouth you command a tree to become a shelf. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth. Imagine using your mouth to turn a tree into a shelf. Yell at this tree and keep yelling at it until you see it become a shelf.
ReadingMnemonic: Once you turn the tree into a shelf you put the shelf in your car (か) and sell it at a local pawn shop. You keep doing this over and over again until you are rich. You command the trees to turn into shelves and then you take the shelves in your car to sell them. Easy money. Imagine transporting the shelves in your car. Over and over. Back and forth in your car. Vroom vroom.

Name: Shut Up
Mnemonic: Your village wants to take the village dog and boil it, and you can think of no other response than SHUT UP! The entire village is shouting and yelling and pointing at the poor dog. They're boiling a giant boiling pot of water, and you can't even hear yourself think anymore. Shut up, shut up, shut up!
ReadingMnemonic: The villagers are mad that you told them to shut up, and they start to mock (もく) you. They put their hands on their hips, lean forward, cross their eyes, and yell "SHUT UP!" back. Even the dog is mocking you now. It's barks sound more like "shut up, shut up" than "bow wow, bow wow." What the heck dog, I was trying to save your life!

Name: Slice
Mnemonic: You use your car and an axe to slice down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood. Imagine driving your car, waving your axe out the window and slicing this guy down. Hear his scream ring in your ears as you slice, slice, SLICE.
ReadingMnemonic: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when you sliced down this man. Luckily, Zanzibar has no laws at all, so you won’t get arrested for slicing down this guy with your axe. Zanzibar is a crazy place, huh? Continue to drive around Zanzibar as you wave your axe out your car window looking for another victim to slice.

Name: Sovereign
Mnemonic: You stand your towel up so everyone can see it. This announces that you are the sovereign ruler of this bathroom. Whenever someone walks into your bathroom, you start screaming that you are the sovereign ruler of this toilet, this sink, this toothbrush, and all that touch these tiles.
ReadingMnemonic: As the sovereign ruler of this bathroom, you must choose a monogram to represent your rule. For this, you choose the symbol of the food that passes through you the most: The mighty tater (てい) tot! Picture your standing towel with a huge tater tot sewn into it. Everyone who sees this will know that you're the toilet tater tot sovereign.

Name: Tariff
Mnemonic: Someone with a top hat comes and tells you that your grains are going to be taxed from now on. Top hat man says there is a tariff that's been enacted on grains. Rice? Triple the price. Wheat? Quadruple. People in top hats like to put tariffs on lots of things. Especially things you need, like grains you eat to stay alive. You have no choice but to pay.
ReadingMnemonic: You're listening to all the things in this tariff and you finally get fed up and ask what isn't being taxed now. The top hat man looks at you and smiles, holding out his hand. In his hand is some soap (そ). Everything you get from other counties has been tariffed except for soap. You'll be hungry, but at least you'll be clean.

Name: Tempering
Mnemonic: The gold from the east needs tempering before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it's entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you'd do in a forge. Imagine tempering this gold from the east. You're heat-treating the gold when you're tempering it, so feel the heat from the fire on your face and arms.
ReadingMnemonic: The smithy where you're doing the tempering is just a rental (れん). You need a rental for your tempering because you haven't sold enough gold to own your own smithy yet. It's seen its fair share of tempering, so it's a pretty shabby rental… Imagine yourself tempering your gold with this shabby rental forge. It keeps flaring up and almost burning off your eyebrows every time you try to work it. It's tough doing tempering with a rental!

Name: Thwart
Mnemonic: If you see a building wearing a giant top hat, beware! This building is a fake and it's trying to thwart all of the plans the people in other buildings have. Picture the building, with it's tall top hat, inching closer to other buildings when no one is looking. It's planning to thwart everything!
ReadingMnemonic: The building next door is being painted, and the top hat building is jealous. It thwarts the painting plans by dumping soap (そ) out of its windows and onto the painters and the building! Watch as the soap cleans all of the paint away, thwarting the entire paint project. The painters are on the ground, crying and squeaky clean.

Name: Tray
Mnemonic: You put part of your food on a plate, then put that on a tray to keep it safe. This tray is an offering for the ancestral festival, where your ancestors' spirits visit you to check in and share some of that food you're offering on a tray. Imagine preparing this tray, just before your ancestors arrive in friendly ghost form to share part of your meal with you. They only come once a year, so make sure it's a nice tray, okay?
ReadingMnemonic: The plate you put on the tray for the ancestral festival is made of bone (ぼん). Bone china, that is. How fancy… And appropriate, considering bone china is made from actual bone. Tap the bone china plate with your knuckle bone. Hear the pleasant clink it makes as you set it on the tray.

Name: Years Old
Mnemonic: You need to stop a drunkard from going down a slide with a jackhammer to ask him how many years old he is. He's doing a lot of dangerous things right now, and they all have age limits. Depending how many years old he is, this guy could be violating like three different laws right now.
ReadingMnemonic: When you ask him how many years old he is, he turns to you and screams, "I'M A MILLION YEARS OLD AND YOU'LL NEVER STOP ME!" That's obviously not how old this kid is, so you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and slice the slide in half. Then the jackhammer. Then the kid's metal arm—wait! This kid is a cyborg (さい)! Your saber cuts through the cyborgs robo-body and it screams, "OKAY OKAY I'M NOT A MILLION I'M ONLY FIVE YEARS OLD AND A CYBORG PLEASE DON'T REPROGRAM ME!"

Name: Zero
Mnemonic: You get rain orders. Your orders are to make sure there is zero spill. Despite it raining, your orders are to make sure none (zero!) of the rain spills anywhere. Figure out what you need to do to make sure you follow these rain orders successfully. Zero spill, alright?
ReadingMnemonic: The best way to make sure there is zero spill when it rains is to get rid of the rain. You use a special ray (れい) gun and zap the rain right out of the sky. There will be zero spills because there will be zero rain. You just take your ray gun and "zap!" the clouds are gone. There will be zero spills today.

Name: Penguin
Mnemonic: There are fins wrapped in a towel in winter. Who is drying these fish fins to eat them? A penguin.

Name: Wave
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wave.

Name: Cash
Mnemonic: That penguin over there seems to have a towel stuffed with cash. The towel the cash is in even has a big $ on it like the ones they have at the bank. You follow the penguin into a back alley.
ReadingMnemonic: Your eyes follow the cash, and you watch as the penguin stuffs it, towel and all, into a hay (へい) stack. What a smart penguin, people don't look for cash in hay, they're too busy looking for needles. You wait for the penguin to leave and you run over to the hay stack and stick your hand in. But you don't feel the towel or the cash! Instead you pull out your hand and it's full of hay and needles. Ouch! No fair, gimme that cash!!

Name: Chopsticks
Mnemonic: You give bamboo to someone and they make them into chopsticks. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession. Watch this person take ordinary bamboo and transform it into chopsticks right before your eyes. Hear the whooshing and whittling sounds as they form the bamboo into chopsticks with expert speed and precision.
ReadingMnemonic: Now use those chopsticks to eat some delicious hash (はし) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for. Imagine trying to pick up hash browns with your chopsticks. They would be really hard to eat if you didn't have these handy eating tools!

Name: Clear
Mnemonic: Rub charcoal under your eyes if you want to see clearly. Sports players also rub charcoal under their eyes to see nice and clear in the bright sun. You can even rub charcoal in your eyes if you really want to clear them up, but you should probably only do this under the supervision of your eye doctor.
ReadingMnemonic: You have to have clear vision because you're about to go out in your row (りょう) boat. The light off the water shines right into your eyes and you need the charcoal to clear that up for you. Otherwise you'll end up crashing into the shore or going over a waterfall to your death. Imagine how dangerous it would be not to have clear vision while you row around in a row boat. You might even smack yourself in the face with your own oars.

Name: Cliff
Mnemonic: There is a mountain on top of a bunch of dirt with a steep cliff. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the cliff even bigger and steeper and scarier. Imagine a cliff. Now add two big helpings of dirt and a mountain to the top. It's still a cliff, it's just more cliff than before.
ReadingMnemonic: You can't believe how big the cliff is now with the mountain and the dirt. You look at it for so long, you just become another gawker (がけ) who can't stop staring at the huge cliff. It really is huge. Imagine a giant cliff that turns every passerby into a gawker, just like you.

Name: Cook
Mnemonic: Without a fire, you will lack the ability to cook anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail. Imagine yourself as you cook with a fire very confidently. Knowing you cannot fail, feel the heat and hear the crackling embers of the fire. Smell the delicious smell of whatever you are cooking as well.
ReadingMnemonic: You cook your meal evenly by swinging (すい) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal. Imagine swinging this meal over the fire. Feel the flames licking at your fingertips as you cook this meal by swinging it back and forth over the fire.

Name: Cosmetics
Mnemonic: Sitting safely under your canopy you take rice and dirt, mix it up, and create unique cosmetics for your face. Imagine mixing dirt and rice together to make some cosmetics that best fit your skin tone and type. No one will see you doing it under this canopy too, so the secret formula you come up with will be safe.
ReadingMnemonic: You need these cosmetics because you have a meeting with the Shougun (しょう) coming up. You want to impress him, and you don't want anyone to copy your look. Imagine meeting the Shougun with your new cosmetics all over your face. You look amazing! Stunning! The shougun wants to know where you got that foundation, you're glowing!

Name: Crash
Mnemonic: A building falls into the dirt when a pig with horns crashes into it. The building literally crashes to the ground when the horned pig attacks it. Picture a pig with horns crashing into a building and both of them crashing into the dirt. Uh oh, is the pig dead?
ReadingMnemonic: You pull the poor pig out of the rubble of the crash. It's not dead, but it had a nasty bump to the head and now thinks it's a bird. "TWEET (つい)!" says the pig. "Tweet, tweet, tweet!" Poor confused pig. Imagine trying to explain to the pig that it's a pig, and not a bird. "Tweet, tweet, tweet!" says the pig again. Oh dear.

Name: Deceit
Mnemonic: A crab will try to hide what it lacks with deceit. Lying, stealing, faking things—no type of deceit is too much for a crab. Covering things up with deceit is pretty much the worst thing you can do, so don't be like this crab.
ReadingMnemonic: Deceit can only take you so far, and soon the crab is caught, tried for its crimes and coverups, and sentenced to death via guillotine (ぎ). Picture the crab with its head, er, front half? Whatever, it's in the guillotine and it's screaming, "You've been deceived! I never deceived anyone, you're all sheep!"

Name: Drip
Mnemonic: A tsunami hits your mohawk and it begins to drip. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while. Imagine having all this tsunami water in your hair. Hear it drip from your mohawk. Drip… drip… drip…
ReadingMnemonic: Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed techie (てき), so you develop a device to stop the drip drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits. Feel the weight of this dryer helmet on your head as you listen to it whirr away. The dripping has finally stopped! Success!

Name: Fence
Mnemonic: In the dirt there are flags and horns lined up with a lantern attached to them, making a fence. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in. Can you see the fence made of horns and flags through the light of the lantern?
ReadingMnemonic: You want to know what this fence is fencing in, so you take a step closer. As the light from the lantern gets brighter you see that the fence is around a ton of hay (へい). Picture yourself climbing over this fence (that you're definitely not supposed to climb based on all these flags and horns) and falling into the piles of hay. It's a little scratchy, but otherwise pretty comfy!

Name: Fog
Mnemonic: It's raining on your spear that has winter power. When the warm rain hits your cold, winter spear, it creates fog. When warm water touches a cold spear, fog billows out and covers everything.
ReadingMnemonic: Through the fog you see the shape of a mythical kirin (きり). You can only see the outline through the fog, but you know it's there. You walk toward the kirin through the fog. When you get close, the image before you becomes clear: it's two cans of Kirin beer on a slide.

Name: Folding Fan
Mnemonic: After passing through a door, you use a feather to put the finishing touches on a folding fan. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is. Use this folding fan to fan your face. Feel the refreshing breeze as you admire the gorgeous feather you just added. What a fashionista you’ve become.
ReadingMnemonic: Your biggest folding fan customer is a centaur (せん). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur. Imagine handing this newly made folding fan to the centaur. See his face light up with delight as he examines your fine craftsmanship and starts fanning himself with it. Another satisfied customer!

Name: Front Door
Mnemonic: The door a criminal will get into is the front door. Now hold on, you may be thinking, wouldn't they go for the back door? No! 99% of home invasions happen when you leave your own front door unlocked! You better check the locks on your front door right now, because odds are you left it open and didn't even notice. It's the perfect door for a criminal to get access to your home.
ReadingMnemonic: To protect your front door from criminals you plan to fill it with heat (ひ). Oh yeah, we're gonna Kevin McCallister this. Imagine how you'd heat up your front door. A hot iron? A blow torch? A small fire? It doesn't matter how, as long as the heat makes it all the way through your front door and hurts any criminals trying to get into it.

Name: Grudge
Mnemonic: A soul will only inhabit a root if it's holding a grudge. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something. Don't die with a grudge, or your soul might end up angry and trapped in some roots.
ReadingMnemonic: If you see one of these grudge trees, it's probably inhabited by the soul of a condor (こん). Humans tend to kill condors and take their trees away to build houses and make toilet paper. So condors hold pretty bad grudges against us, and so their souls end up stuck in a lot of trees. Picture a tree with the soul of a condor with a grudge in it before you. You feel bad about being so wasteful with paper and chopsticks now, huh?

Name: Hat
Mnemonic: You take a towel and wrap it around your head to keep the sun out of your eyes. You've invented... the hat! A hat is just a piece of cloth or a towel you get to stay on your head. Extra points if it protect your eyes from the sun.
ReadingMnemonic: People see you wearing this fancy new hat thing and start asking you to share. You grab all your extra towels, roll them up, and bowl (ぼう) them down the street toward everyone who asks for one. Imagine bowling with hats. Thankfully, they work as bowling balls just as well as they work as hats. You're so innovative!

Name: Hate
Mnemonic: The soul mask helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see hate. You're supposed to see all the emotions, so why do you only see hate inside everyone?
ReadingMnemonic: It turns out you're not looking at normal people. You see so much hate because all the people you're looking at are actually just a group of zombies (ぞう). Zombies are pretty filled with hate, so it makes sense that you'd see a bunch of hate if you used the soul mask on them.

Name: Help
Mnemonic: The leader of a narwhal construction crew needs all the help he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city. Imagine being the narwhal leader and asking others for help. Ask a shark for help. Ask a whale for help. Ask a shrimp for help. Go on, ask.
ReadingMnemonic: Then you discover a saw (さ) who would be a great big help. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away. Imagine using this saw and realizing how big of a help it is. Hear the saw sawing away as you and your fellow narwhals get to work.

Name: Insert
Mnemonic: You have fingers in the thousands and while looking up at the sun you decide you want to insert them in there. Hold your thousand+ fingers up to the sun and imagine inserting them into the sun's super-hot ... s-sun lava. (That's what it is, right? Yeah, let's go with that.)
ReadingMnemonic: You insert one finger, it burns up immediately, and its soul (そう) comes flying out screaming for a moment before it disappears. Hmm. You insert another finger and as it burns up, another little soul comes out screeching, "WHY WOULD YOU INSERT ME IN THERE!" and is gone. Since you have a thousand fingers too many, you decide to insert them all into the sun and watch as their souls pop out. You listen to the little souls scream at you.

Name: Italy
Mnemonic: A leader and Wolverine take a slide to Italy. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun! Imagine Wolverine and his leader Professor X going down this slide to Italy. Hear them wooping and cheering as they ride down the slide. Whee~
ReadingMnemonic: Before Professor X can get off the slide into Italy, a large eagle (い) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X! Imagine this eagle carrying Professor X away from Italy and out over the ocean. You can also remember this reading easily because Italy starts with the letter I. Super simple stuff.

Name: Lie
Mnemonic: They say the key to telling a lie is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key. Imagine an actual key going from you to another person. This key is the lie. You gotta believe in the lie for it to reach the other person and unlock their understanding. Visualize this visual lie.
ReadingMnemonic: The lie you told was about not stealing your buddy’s saw (さ). You actually did steal his saw. He saw you steal his saw, but now you are trying to lie your way out of it. It’s not going well. Imagine trying to lie your way out of this. He saw you steal his saw. He caught you red handed. What sort of lie can you spin to get yourself out of this situation?

Name: Likeness
Mnemonic: With a woman's mouth, you have a likeness to me. Imagine someone's putting a woman's mouth over your mouth, looking at you, and commenting on your likeness. All it took was this woman's mouth.
ReadingMnemonic: You have a likeness to Jo-Anne (じょ) when you wear that mouth. Jo-Anne popped her mouth off and put it on you. Indeed with that mouth on, you have an extreme likeness to her.

Name: Lips
Mnemonic: A landslide came out of your mouth and created your lips. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole. Picture your mouth as an open hole. Now a landslide of something (words? food? something worse?) comes pouring out, and when it's done you have lips. You flap them open and closed to test them out.
ReadingMnemonic: Now you can use your new lips to enjoy a nice, cold Kuchi beer (くちびる). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. And you've never been able to get this delicious beer into your mouth, but now that you have lips you can get it all in there. Imagine wrapping your new lips around the mouth of this Kuchi beer bottle. It's so good! And you aren't spilling any of it!

Name: Old Woman
Mnemonic: A wave crashes into a woman, transforming her into an old woman! The wave washes away all of the woman's makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is. Imagine a gorgeous woman. Now see her get hit by a wave of water and turn into an old woman. The old woman could still be pretty too, she just looks way old now. Like ancient.
ReadingMnemonic: In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an old woman, the old woman starts to baa (ば) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes "Baa! Baa!" and hops around on all fours like a sheep. Imagine this old woman acting like a sheep, just saying "baa" over and over and over again. Baa! Baa! Baa!

Name: Palm
Mnemonic: If you want to cover a Viking's mouth with your hand, you have to use your palm. Why the palm? Well, if you do it knuckles-to-mouth, you're sort of just punching the Viking… and you don't want a punch a Viking. That's why you use the palm. And don't use your fingers either, 'cause they'll just get bitten off. You absolutely want to make sure it's the palm — a nice flat open palm. It's a lot like feeding a horse, I guess.
ReadingMnemonic: This Viking-touching technique of using the palm was developed by the Shougun (しょう). The Shogun has to deal with a lot of loudmouthed Vikings, so he's learned to use his palm to cover their mouths. Imagine if a Shogun and a Viking had actually met in history (never mind that the dates don't overlap). You can definitely picture the quiet, refined Shogun putting his palm over the mouth of some noisy Viking during a tough diplomatic meeting.

Name: Pathetic
Mnemonic: With a lid, you hit yourself in the mouth and then kick it like a pathetic loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic. Imagine kicking this lid and with each kick you feel a little bit more pathetic. Your mouth hurts a lot too.
ReadingMnemonic: You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the eye (あい). How pathetic. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you. Hold your eye with one hand and your mouth with the other. Feel them pulse in pain as you reflect on how pathetic you are today.

Name: Rainbow
Mnemonic: An insect specializing in construction builds a rainbow. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows. Imagine this insect with a construction hat on, building a rainbow. He works very fast. The resulting rainbow is beautiful!
ReadingMnemonic: This rainbow building insect is so needy (にじ). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!” Imagine this construction insect being all whiny and needy for attention and stuff. It’s pathetic. Hear him whine and whine because of how needy he is.

Name: Refreshing
Mnemonic: A big treasure treasure treasure treasure is refreshing! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing. Imagine finding this big treasure treasure treasure treasure and being really refreshed and relieved and happy. This treasure treasure treasure treasure is so big, you’ll be set for life!
ReadingMnemonic: You’d had a sour (さわ) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo refreshing! Imagine the most sour taste you could ever imagine. So super-duper sour! Now imagine that sour taste instantly melting away once you discover this big refreshing treasure treasure treasure treasure. Jackpot!

Name: Rest
Mnemonic: You keep your tongue to your self to give your heart a rest. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time. It's important to let yourself rest every now and then, you know.
ReadingMnemonic: What better way to rest than to eat some cake (けい)! No talking necessary. Just enjoy the delicious taste of cake on your tongue and feel your heart let out a sigh of relief. You should rest right now. Take a break from Japanese and go eat some cake. (Just remember to come back when your tongue and heart are sufficiently rested!)

Name: Roast
Mnemonic: Before you boil something, make sure that you roast it. Why would you roast something before you boil it? Because that something is tea! Or maybe coffee. Tea leaves and coffee beans are roasted before they're boiled.
ReadingMnemonic: Now you roast yourself some centaur (せん). Roasted centaur goes well with tea. Smell the wafting scent of roasted centaur as you sip on your freshly-roasted tea.

Name: Shaku
Mnemonic: This shrimp is the exact length of a shaku, or Japanese foot. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot. Imagine this foot long shrimp. It’s pretty big. Imagine it squirming about making a “shaku shaku” sound as it worms about.
ReadingMnemonic: How is shaku, the Japanese foot, pronounced by Shaq (しゃく) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku in both English and Japanese. Imagine Shaq dribbling the shrimp like a basketball, saying “shaku, shaku, shaku” every time he bounces the shrimp.

Name: Smash
Mnemonic: Take this stone and throw it at nine crosses to smash them! It's like old-fashioned bowling, but instead of rolling this stone to knock down the crosses, you want to completely smash them to bits! Picture the nine crosses in front of you, lined up in a triangle. Now take your rock, hold it above your head, and SMASH it down on them as hard as you can!!
ReadingMnemonic: As you smash these crosses, you think of your cyborg (さい) and how much you want to smash the people who took it away from you. Your cyborg was so good at smashing things too. You could be smashing together, if you didn't have to sell it. You smash things because your own heart has been smashed by your cyborg. :'(

Name: Sticky
Mnemonic: Your rice fortune is sticky. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice. Look at this sticky rice fortune of yours. Run your hands through it and feel the sticky rice between your fingers. Hear the sticky sucking sounds and you stir the sticky rice about.
ReadingMnemonic: This rice is so sticky that you are able to sculpt nendoroids (ねん) from it. Your rice fortune is worth even more now that you are hand making limited edition nendoroids from it. Imagine sculpting these sticky rice nendoroids with your bare hands. Feel the sticky rice between your fingers as you smush the rice into cute little nendoroids.

Name: Tatami Mat
Mnemonic: In the rice paddy there is a forehead with a top hat. It sits atop an area of tatami mats. The meaning you're trying to learn is tatami mat, so focus on the beautiful tatami mats that are strangely in the middle of this rice paddy. On top is a forehead with a top hat. It almost looks like the tatami mats are an altar for this gruesome scene.
ReadingMnemonic: Who made this creepy tatami mat altar? It was Joe (じょう), the increasingly concerning farmhand who lives in your village. You saw Joe setting up the tatami mats a day earlier, but you thought he was just making an area for workers in the field to rest in. Does the forehead with a top hat have anything to do with Joe? What sort of ominous sign could this be?

Name: Torso
Mnemonic: The moon is the same as your torso. You must have a really huge torso for it to be the same as the moon. Imagine if your torso was as large as the moon. You’re a gigantic human. Imagine floating around in space like this. Wooooaaaahhh.
ReadingMnemonic: Your torso got so big because of all the doughnuts (どう) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things. Imagine how many doughnuts you would have to eat to get your torso this size. Now imagine eating all of those doughnuts. I hope you like doughnuts, because you’re going to be eating a lot of them.

Name: Towel
Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for towel first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means towel as well. Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: You know who loves towels? The King (きん) of England. He loves towels so much that he went around and put きん on every towel in the land, so you think of him whenever you use one. Go into your bathroom or your linen closet right now. Look at your towels. Look for the small きん hidden there.

Name: Wick
Mnemonic: There are flowers growing around a heart with a wick sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow. See this morbid scene. As the wick burns you can smell the smell of burning organs. The flowers are pretty though.
ReadingMnemonic: Sometimes the wick burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your shin (しん). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers. Imagine slicing your shin with a knife, causing blood to drip on the flowers around the heart with a wick in it. Your shin really hurts from the injury, but the flowers are rejoicing as they’re showered in blood.

Name: Willow
Mnemonic: A tree that is stamped with one pattern, then stamped with another pattern, over and over, is the willow tree. A willow tree is a tree that looks like it's on repeat over and over again. It also looks nice on a stamp. Note that the first stamp is kind of an ugly looking backwards stamp, and the second stamp is the normal stamp radical.
ReadingMnemonic: Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter really loves willow trees. Ryu loves them so much that he makes out with them. Ryu is open mouth kissing a willow tree. You are watching this. It is happening. Watch Ryu as he French kisses this willow tree. Hear him slurping and moaning in ecstasy. Why are you watching this? This is gross. Wait – is this turning you on!? Ew.

Name: Form
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means form.

Name: Light
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means light.

Name: Accomplish
Mnemonic: A scooter with horns with a pig riding on it will be able to accomplish anything. Imagine the pig scooting around. It is able to accomplish anything you can imagine (so go nuts with your imagination).
ReadingMnemonic: It was even able to successfully accomplish a feat that involved it jumping its scooter right into a swing (すい), swinging back and forth, then jumping off. Perhaps it even takes the swing all the way around in a full 360 degree rotation. This horned scooter riding pig can truly accomplish anything.

Name: Amass
Mnemonic: Flowers are mysteriously appearing in the rice paddy. No matter what you do to them, they continue to amass. Imagine yourself spraying poison on these mysterious flowers, but they just double in size, and continue to amass.
ReadingMnemonic: As the flowers amass it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby chicks (ちく) are amassing in the rice paddy as well. Feel the wetness of the rice paddy under your feet and the fluffiness of the chicks pressing in on you. Watch the looming, mysterious flowers above you as the chicks smother you.

Name: Armpit
Mnemonic: The moon has a lot of power that is power it gets from the power of every armpit of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices. Imagine an aura of stinky power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Feel the power leaving you as the moon saps your power through your armpits.
ReadingMnemonic: This is a pretty wacky (わき) armpit image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life? Imagine this whole scene again but keep in mind how wacky it all really is. The moon sapping power from you through your armpits? So wacky.

Name: Blossom
Mnemonic: Having a foul mouth and horns will prevent you from getting into Heaven where you would blossom into an angel. If you have horns, you are not meant for Heaven and will not blossom there. To blossom in Heaven, you must not have horns or a foul mouth. Swear like a sailor as you imagine yourself with some horns. You’re not going to blossom in Heaven. You’re going to blossom in Hell and become a demon.
ReadingMnemonic: You don’t want to blossom into a demon so you saw (さ) off your horns with a saw. If you saw off your horns, maybe you can beg for forgiveness and have your foul mouth forgiven. Imagine taking a saw to your horns and sawing them off. Hear the reverberation of the saw in your skull as you painfully saw off your horns.

Name: Clever
Mnemonic: Your servant uses a stool to break open shellfish. This is really clever, because shucking shellfish is a lot of work. It's also a wise move, because it'll save him time that he can spend on all his other servant chores. "You sure are clever, man!" you shout encouragingly at your wise servant as he plops his stool down on another mound of shellfish. Dinner tonight is sure to be a seafood feast, and you can't wait!
ReadingMnemonic: "Yes, more clever than you!" he yells, tearing off his servant's disguise. "It is I, Ken (けん) the samurai. I won't let you eat these shellfish. I'm taking them back to the sea, where they belong!" Picture Ken standing there with his sword and crab-shell armor. Pretty clever of him to disguise himself as your servant for so many years just to save a few mollusks. It might have been wiser not to shuck so many of them first, though…

Name: Coloring
Mnemonic: You use a cleat to climb a tree and your hair gets the same coloring as the foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever color is around you, so you use your cleats to climb trees to make your hair turn green and brown, and in the fall, yellow and orange and red! Imagine digging your cleats into the bark of the tree until you get high enough for your hair to start coloring itself tree colors. It might be a lot of work, but it's worth it.
ReadingMnemonic: This cool coloring can only happen because you turned yourself into a cyborg (さい). Your hair and scalp are now made of high tech parts, not human ones. You couldn't take the pain of losing your cyborg, so you've become one. Your robo-hair can change its coloring, but soon you'll be even more cyborg-y than before!

Name: Crevice
Mnemonic: In this building there's a small sun that's small. They keep this small, small sun inside of a crevice. You wouldn't want to keep a sun out in the open, even if it's small (and small). You'd put it inside something, like a crevice. Imagine walking into the building and seeing the small sun right inside, in a crevice.
ReadingMnemonic: They keep the sun in the crevice because this is a place where people ski (すき). If the sun were out in the open, it'd melt all the snow, making it hard to ski here. So they hide the sun away in a crevice so people can ski.

Name: Cultivate
Mnemonic: Your dirt needs a  clown in it if you want to cultivate good crops. Clowns act as a natural fertilizer, and this will make it super easy to cultivate any crops you could ever want in this dirt. Isn't nature amazing? Imagine burying a dead clown in the dirt and then planting some seeds on top. It's worth it, you think, if it helps cultivate your crops.
ReadingMnemonic: Before you can start this whole cultivation process however, you have to say bye (ばい) to the clown. Say bye to him, then bash his head in, and drop him in the dirt. Saying bye is polite. Never forget to say bye, even in the middle of a cold-blooded clown murder.

Name: Dance
Mnemonic: Your foot, as your mama says, was given the task to dance. Shake those two foots your mama gave you and dance dance dance! Picture your mama asking you to dance. The two of you pick up and kick your feet to dance, spinning 'round and 'round.
ReadingMnemonic: You both dance so much that you develop an odor (おど). Not just any odor, an odor particular to stinky dancing feet. Lean down and take a big whiff of your dancing feet. The odor is... HORRIBLE! AHGH!

Name: Darkness
Mnemonic: This gate makes the sound of darkness. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too. Imagine this gate making an ominous sound. The sound of darkness. Look deep into the darkness of the gate as you hear the sound it makes. Ouummmmm…
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to taste the darkness and discover that it is so yummy (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy! Take the darkness in your hands. It’s like really dark cotton candy. Imagine eating it and how yummy it is. Keep hearing the sound it’s making as you eat. Yummy!

Name: Diagonal
Mnemonic: You have a surplus of ladles laid out diagonally in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many ladles? Why the surplus? Hang on, we'll get there. Look at all these ladles lying diagonally in front of you. Pick them up. Feel the wood grain. Wonder why you have so many.
ReadingMnemonic: In front of this diagonal pattern is a shaman (しゃ) who is currently staring at you. You slowly reach down and turn one of the ladles around, diagonally, and look back up. The shaman's eyes are wide, and now they're scribbling on in a notebook. Uh oh, is this one of those weird tests where they find out if you're the chosen one or some old scholar reincarnated? Who knew laying ladles at diagonal angles could reveal this kinda stuff?!

Name: Flower Pot
Mnemonic: Melt down this gold book and recast it as a flower pot. A solid gold book is too heavy to hold and too shiny to read, but a solid gold flower pot would make a fancy new addition to your garden. Imagine melting down your gold book. You're excited to have your new flower pot, but you're a little sad because this book was actually pretty interesting. Make a mental note to buy it in paperback later.
ReadingMnemonic: The gold flower pot has a hatch (はち) attached to it, which used to be the book's back cover. That's fine, you use the hatch as a lid for the flower pot! Okay, so this may not be the best flower pot. You usually don't need a hatch or this much gold coating. But that's how they used to do it in the old days, so that's good enough for you!

Name: Frost
Mnemonic: Rain falls off a tree and lands in your eye where it turns to frost. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell off the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye. Feel the rain hit your eye and then crystalize into frost immediately. The rain in your eye is wet, and then very cold as it becomes frost.
ReadingMnemonic: This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo frost idea because you are a shemo (しも). An emo who goes by she pronouns. Picture yourself walking proudly, casting your frost gaze at all who you pass. "Wow look at that frosty, cool shemo. She's sooooo cool!" you hear them whisper. (Haha cool, get it? Because you're frosty and also a little sad, which is totally in when you're a teen.)

Name: Harvest
Mnemonic: You need to feed this grain to a flower wearing turkey on a stool so you start the harvest. Grains don't pick themselves, you have to harvest them. Picture this fat turkey with flowers on its head, sitting on a stool. It's gobbling for grains and you need to be the one who harvests them.
ReadingMnemonic: You're just starting to harvest the grains when an angry cock (かく) shows up! He's mad because these are his grains and you're about to harvest them and feed them to a turkey instead of him. Imagine an angry cock chasing you around as you try to harvest grain. He keeps pecking you, ouch!

Name: Hemp
Mnemonic: This canopy of trees isn't actually a canopy of trees at all. When you look closely, you see these trees are actually giant stalks of hemp. Wow, these hemp plants are so big that they look like trees. But, despite their size they're still just hemp.
ReadingMnemonic: Who planted all this hemp? Your mama (ま) did. Your mama knew that you were going to like hemp in the future, so she planted these hemp plants for you. What a great mama.

Name: Horse Riding
Mnemonic: This horse may look odd but it’s actually perfect for horse riding! Look at this odd horse. It's a little odd-looking, but it turned its quirks into strengths and now it's an exceptional horse for horse riding!
ReadingMnemonic: Before horse riding, you’ll need the key (き) to access the stable and let out the odd horse you'll be riding. Want to ride the odd horse? Then, you must have the key to open its stable!

Name: Humiliate
Mnemonic: The landslide measurement humiliates you. You told everyone you couldn't come to work, that your house had been destroyed and your car was carried away, but then scientists measured the landslide, and it only went a few feet. Honestly, that's what you get for lying. But it doesn't make it any less humiliating even if you deserve it.
ReadingMnemonic: Your friends and coworkers humiliate you more by making jokes (じょく). "Uh oh, I heard it might rain later, I hope you don't drown in the inch of water that's coming!" Imagine all of the cruel jokes people say to humiliate you. Feel your face burn and your stomach flip.

Name: Lamp
Mnemonic: Fire you use to light up the street needs to go in a lamp. Campfires, matches? No, none of those work. You need bright, safe lamps to keep the street nice at night. Picture these lamps lining the street, with their little fires burning brightly. Nowadays we don't have real fire in them, we use electricity!
ReadingMnemonic: These street lamps were first used in とうきょう. It was the most advanced city after all. And more people were out at night in とうきょう than anywhere else in Japan. So they needed lamps to light things up! Picture とうきょう, not lit up by all of the electricity, signs, shops, and things that light up its streets today, but by old-fashioned fire lamps!

Name: Livestock
Mnemonic: In the mysterious rice paddy there is some livestock. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed. Examine this mysterious livestock from a distance. Imagine them floating around the mysterious rice paddy like they aren’t even walking. Hear them moo and oink as well.
ReadingMnemonic: Your favorite member of the mysterious livestock crew is a little chick (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings. Look at this chick bobbling about in the air. It looks very ephemeral and other worldly. Still a very cute chick though. You want to pet it.

Name: Melt
Mnemonic: The tsunami hits your form and you begin to melt. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt. Feel the water from the tsunami crashing into your form. Feel the water on your body as your form begins to melt. I’m melting! I’m mellltiinnnggg!
ReadingMnemonic: The only way to reverse the melt process is to eat some yogurt (よう). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt! Feel the melt begin to reverse as you eat your yogurt. Taste the yogurt on your tongue as your form begins to solidify once again.

Name: Mosquito
Mnemonic: The type of insect that ruins your writing is the mosquito. You're trying to write, when you hear that horrible high-pitched mosquito noise in your ear. You jerk your head and swat and it's gone. But when you look down, there's lines all over what you were writing. Imagine sitting at your desk writing when a mosquito starts bzzzzing in your ear. You can't ignore it, it's gonna bite you. So you flail around helplessly.
ReadingMnemonic: That mosquito noise sounds like it's driving a tiny car (か) in your ear. How are you supposed to write with a bug driving around going bzzz bzzz like a revving car? You can't. You can't write like this. You need to kill the mosquito and its little car too.

Name: Notebook
Mnemonic: Take your towel and make it long. It has to be longer than that! For this will be your notebook, which you will write all your notes in. You are making the towel really long, because it's white and it might be good for writing in. It's going to become your notebook.
ReadingMnemonic: Inside your long towel notebook you just write the same name over and over again: "Mrs. Chou" (ちょう). Something bad is going to happen, and you need to warn everybody. It's her, it's her, it's her. Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou, Mrs. Chou!

Name: Paint
Mnemonic: A tsunami surplus will cover all the dirt with paint. The surplus of tsunamis will strike the paint factories first (everyone knows paint factories are built close to the ocean). Then the paint will flow over all the dirt and paint it a ton of rainbow colors. Picture all of the different colors of paint being swept along by tsunami after tsunami, painting the dirt as it goes.
ReadingMnemonic: You touch the paint in the dirt with your toe (と) to see if it's still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a tiny rainbow. Imagine dipping each of your toes into the paint-dirt, one by one, to paint each of them a different color. Why are you doing this?

Name: Paste
Mnemonic: Your shellfish are worth a fortune because you decided to paste your fortune to the shellfish. Picture all of your riches, your money, your jewels. They're all pasted directly onto all of your shellfish!
ReadingMnemonic: You're a little crazy, which is why you decided to use paste to paste your entire fortune to these shellfish, and as you paste each one you yell out, "Ha (は)!" Paste. "Ha ha!" Paste paste. "Ha ha ha!!" PASTE PASTE PASTE.

Name: Punch
Mnemonic: Your district is full of weapons, but everyone prefers to punch each other. When everyone's armed, things can escalate quickly, so it's better to stick to fists to be safe. Picture two heavily armed residents of your district punching the living crap out of each other. They're both armed to the teeth with missile launchers, flamethrowers, katanas, lightsabers, etc., but neither one wants to be the first to draw a weapon and escalate the situation.
ReadingMnemonic: The district residents punch each other in front of the 王 (おう). These punching matches are actually gladiatorial battles for the 王's entertainment. Imagine the heavily armed combatants from earlier slugging it out, but this time the 王 is watching them from a box seat above the action. He gleefully encourages them, a maniacal, bloodthirsty glint in his eye.

Name: Radiance
Mnemonic: The light shines on your forehead in your car with a great radiance. The car you are in is a convertible, so the light shines right onto your big bald forehead. The light has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from this light hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man. Imagine this radiance emanating from your shiny dome. The radiance is blinding!
ReadingMnemonic: This radiance is the key (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car. Point your shiny forehead, filled with radiance, at your car. Hear the engine start and jump to life as you power it with the reflected sunlight from your forehead.

Name: Recollection
Mnemonic: When your soul has an idea it's just a recollection of something you already know. Only your brain can have original ideas, so when your soul tries to come up with one, it's just a recollection of something you thought before now. When you have a recollection of some idea or thing in the past, it's just your soul saying, hey remember this? Let's not forget this.
ReadingMnemonic: Your soul is sending you a recollection right now of... your past life as a farmer in Oklahoma (おく). You see yourself farming and sweating and living a wonderful life. Hmm, maybe you should move to Oklahoma and live the simple life again. Imagine recollecting a past life in Oklahoma. Life was simple and nice. You should consider taking this as a sign to move there again!

Name: Regret
Mnemonic: If you try to put your soul into everything, you'll regret it. It's not so much that putting your soul into things is bad, but every single thing? You'll burn out immediately. You won't be able to be good at any of those things. And you'll regret all the time you wasted trying to be the best at everything. Imagine if you went full force into everything you've ever even thought of doing. Imagine how burnt out your soul would be. Imagine all the regret you'd have that you didn't just stick to one thing and do it well.
ReadingMnemonic: The regret is too strong for you to ignore, so you decide to drop everything but kayaking (かい). If there's one thing you refuse to regret, it's your bright orange kayak and all the friends you made at kayaking club. Throw everything you regret away. Only kayak from now on.

Name: Resistant
Mnemonic: You take a rake in for a measurement but it is resistant. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken.
