The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others. Try and move this rake over to the measurement table. It is resistant so you have a hard time moving it. Imagine the rake struggling and resisting endlessly.
ReadingMnemonic: Because the rake is persistently resistant, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck tie (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly. See yourself tying the tie around the rake and attaching it to the measurement table. The rake is still jostling around, but the tie keeps it from moving about too terribly much.

Name: Shield
Mnemonic: On a cliff, the pope is holding a shield. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off. Imagine the shield glowing brightly as hymns play in the background. The demons try to get close to the pope to shove him off the cliff but the holy shield is too bright and popey.
ReadingMnemonic: The light of the pope's shield begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's June (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell! This pope would have been in a lot of trouble if June's summer sun hadn't risen at just the right moment. His shield would have become useless and he might have been shoved off the cliff if it was a less sunny month.

Name: Snake
Mnemonic: There is an insect on the roof in a spoon. It's there for the eating, and it's how you plan to attract a snake to your roof. Snakes love insects, especially when they're ready to eat on a spoon. But, snakes don't usually go on top of the roof, so that's why you have to tempt one with an insect in a spoon.
ReadingMnemonic: Why don't you just bring a snake up to the roof yourself? Because snakes are heavy (へび). Especially big snakes. They're really, really hebi.

Name: Squad
Mnemonic: If the king gives you a knife you become part of his squad. Every king has a knife squad or two protecting him and making sure his subjects keep in line. Imagine if you were given a knife and allowed into the king's squad. Would you let the power corrupt you?
ReadingMnemonic: This squad is led by Han (はん) Solo, so it's basically a 50/50 shot that the king is gonna die. I'm not saying Han Solo is a bad squad leader, but his track record isn't the greatest. I mean, best case scenario the king gets stabbed in the arm and they manage to win.

Name: Starve
Mnemonic: If you have nothing to eat but your ego, you'll starve. You can't eat it, and your ego is keeping you from accepting actual food or help from other people. You have to check your ego at the door, because you'll definitely starve otherwise.
ReadingMnemonic: You starve (thanks ego) and turn into a gargoyle (が). As your stomach aches, your skin turns gray and you slowly harden into a crouched position. Now your starved body has been moved to the top of a castle, where you scare away people and birds with your loud grumbling stomach and scary face.

Name: Starve
Mnemonic: You’re so hungry that you eat a table so you won’t starve. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive. You don’t want to starve, do you? Feel your tummy gurgle in pain. You gotta eat this table. Taste the dry wood taste on your tongue as you eat the table and get splinters in your tongue and gums.
ReadingMnemonic: After you finish the table, you still feel like you might starve so you decide to eat every key (き) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve. Imagine eating every key. Taste the cold metal on your tongue. After you swallow each key, you hear it clink against the other keys already in your tummy. Clink!

Name: Swift
Mnemonic: You drive your scooter off this cliff, holding your cross tight to your chest, at a swift speed. Imagine swiftly shooting off the side of the cliff on your scooter, holding the cross for dear life.
ReadingMnemonic: Because you had such a swift take off, you didn't notice that your jeans (じん) were ripped right off your body. Until now. Now you're swiftly shooting through the sky as your jeans flutter down toward the ground behind you. You also feel a swift breeze on all of your downstairs bits now.

Name: Threaten
Mnemonic: There's power, power, and power stacked on top of the moon, threatening to bring it down! The moon actually looks like it wants to threaten you now too. It seems to have grown a big, smiling, angry mouth and it's way closer to you than you've ever seen it. All that power is radiating out of it and down towards you, threateningly.
ReadingMnemonic: This extra power-filled moon is now trying to threaten the safety of きょうと. All of きょうと is shaking and getting dark as the moon comes closer and closer. Picture the powerful moon, threatening to crush きょうと and all its residents. If only a small green boy could turn back time and save everyone from this powerful moon!

Name: Use Up
Mnemonic: You see shrimp on ice at the market in the morning. "I'll get some on the way home" you think to yourself. Later that evening, you see no shrimp, just ice. The supply of shrimp has been exhausted. It's all gone! You never thought they'd use up their shrimp supply so quickly. Imagine the lack of shrimp on the ice. All you wanted was some delicious shrimp for dinner, but now it's all gone.
ReadingMnemonic: How could the store use up its shrimp supply so quickly? Suddenly you notice the worker behind the fish counter has shrimp stuffed into their jeans (じん) . Aha! The culprit! Imagine the worker's jeans and how gross they are with all those shrimp stuffed into them. Yuck!

Name: Crab Trap
Mnemonic: This radical looks like a small animal (匹) has a crab (其) sticking out of it. Often when a crab is eating a small animal, that small animal was put inside a crab trap to catch the crab, luring it in with the small animal. That's why this radical is crab trap.

Name: Times
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means times.

Name: Wild
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means wild.

Name: Approximation
Mnemonic: Bite a tree's root with your fang to get an approximation on its age. It won't be exact, this isn't scientific or anything, but it will be pretty close. Once you have an approximation on the age, you'll be able to come up with an approximation on how much it's worth too.
ReadingMnemonic: As you're recording your approximation down,  somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey guy (がい)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that tree there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway. The guy is trying to look at your approximation now, while calling YOU "guy" over and over, and you just want him to buy it and leave you alone!

Name: Arrest
Mnemonic: You run your fingers along the words of a  paragraph. You are learning about the law because you plan to arrest somebody. Imagine reading the paragraph very slowly. You find your answer. It looks like you'll be able to arrest that person...
ReadingMnemonic: Who do you want to arrest? You want to arrest こういち. Even though he's started wars, created a religion, and trapped a child in a cavity, it's going to be tricky to arrest him because he's the emperor now. Still, according to this paragraph you're running your fingers through, you can do it. You can arrest こういち.

Name: Boil
Mnemonic: If someone wants to boil, you let them boil! There's someone in your face yelling about how they want to boil! You yell back, "Okay, if you want to boil, just boil!"
ReadingMnemonic: Welp, the pot is at a rolling boil and your knee (に) is in there. The person wasn't saying they wanted to boil, they said they wanted to boil someone. And that meant you. Well, your knee anyway. Once your knee is done boiling, the person kneels down in front of you and presents it on a platter, mocking you, since you can't kneel anymore. You should pay more attention to what's going on from now on or you could find yourself in... HOT WATER. Ohohoho.

Name: Capsize
Mnemonic: If a helicopter loiters near a black hole then it's going to capsize. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down! Imagine trying to cover up a black hole so that the helicopter doesn't capsize. It's one or the other, dude. Cover or capsize. You decide.
ReadingMnemonic: You're doing your best to cover the black hole to stop the helicopter from capsizing but it's not working! “F**k you (ふく) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing! Man, f**k you you, black hole. F**k you you. Making that helicopter capsize and then refusing to be covered?

Name: Chess Piece
Mnemonic: The horse who can write a paragraph gets to be a chess piece. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor. Imagine a horse trying to write a paragraph about why it deserves to be a chess piece. See the horse struggle with his hooves to write out a paragraph as he neighs in nervous frustration.
ReadingMnemonic: Upon being told that he will never be a chess piece, the horse slips into a coma (こま). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for. See this horse in its coma. You feel bad that it will never be able to be a chess piece, but this is a bit dramatic.

Name: Confused
Mnemonic: Your soul is going wild because you're confused. If you're confused, it's usually because you don't know what's going on or what to do. This makes the soul inside your body go absolutely wild! Think back to the last time you were confused. Remember how your soul felt? You were so confused it went wild and made you feel dumb and bad, like a wild person.
ReadingMnemonic: Whenever you're confused, こういち appears to offer you guidance. He's confused a lot, so he knows how to help. And knowledge offered by こういち is the best medicine for confusion. Imagine being confused about Japanese, for example. In your confusion everything seems scary and wild and your soul is utterly bewildered, but then here comes こういち. He sits with you and pats your back and tries to help you stop being so confused.

Name: Conspire
Mnemonic: Watch what you say to what appears to be a sweet tree, because that tree will 100% conspire against you. Trees may look all sweet and innocent, like they aren't listening to every word you say, but it's a front! They're conspiring against you!! They'll blackmail you and take everything!!!
ReadingMnemonic: Now you're getting it! That tree is trying to conspire against you and take you down. Take your bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl it and all its friends down! Watch as the conspiratorial tree and all it's gossiping friends are bowled over by your bowling ball. Phew. You're safe from the trees.

Name: Crane
Mnemonic: On the roof there's some type of turkey bird, but thinner and longer. You look closer and realize it's a crane. Picture the beautiful black and white crane dancing gracefully on the roof. Now that you know what it is, you feel a little bad about calling it a turkey bird.
ReadingMnemonic: The crane leans down toward you from its roof perch and squawks, "Too rude (つる)!" You're shocked! You didn't know the crane could speak English, but even worse, it knew you called it a turkey bird. The crane keeps saying you're too rude whenever other people come close so they know what kind of person you are. Yikes, you really shouldn't have gotten on this crane's bad side.

Name: Cultivation
Mnemonic: You use your fingers and a stone to begin cultivation of the land. You use your fingers to till the soil, the stone to flatten the ground, and you carefully poke the seeds into the dirt and then use the stone to smash them further down. Imagine being in a field, using your fingers and a stone to cultivate the whole thing, by hand.
ReadingMnemonic: Cultivation is suddenly halted because a tack (たく) sticks into your finger. You pull the tack out, throw it away and start cultivation again when... ouch! There's another tack. This field is full of tacks! Now cultivation is going to involve getting all the tacks out of here, preferably with the stone and not your fingers, so they don't get stuck anymore.

Name: Decline
Mnemonic: You take a lid, and aiming it at the sun you kick it into the air and eventually it begins to decline and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun. As you watch the lid decline, keep in mind that the sun radical has its middle line extending outside the box on both sides. This is because the sun is going supernova. Pew!
ReadingMnemonic: As the lid begins to decline in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to swing (すい) to safety. Swing on some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble. Imagine swinging on these vines as you hear the sun explode and go supernova behind you. Swing faster! Swing faster!

Name: Encourage
Mnemonic: A commander who's big will use his size to encourage his troops. "Look at me! You can be a big commander someday too!" he shouts, encouraging everyone.
ReadingMnemonic: He encourages the Shougun (しょう) too! You've never seen the Shougun express any emotion other than intense indifference or intense dislike. Picture the encouraged Shougun: his eyes are shining with tears, his heart is pounding, he's been encouraged to be better!

Name: Extract
Mnemonic: Your fingers give you a good reason to extract things. You extract juice from fruits, oil from seeds, and coffee from beans. Why? Because you have fingers! That's your reason. Imagine having fingers that work like a magic wand of extraction. With a flick of your fingers, you could extract any radical out of a kanji too. How could these special fingers not be a reason for you to extract? With these fingers, you can't stop extracting!
ReadingMnemonic: Your magic fingers can even extract the essence out of living things, so you decide to extract some from Chewbacca (ちゅう). You always thought a nice Chewbacca extract could take your cookies to the next level. It'll help offset the sweetness and make them extra chewy (or chewbacca-y!). Taste that chewy goodness in every bite. All you need is a dash of Chewbacca extract.

Name: Faint
Mnemonic: A tsunami and a couple fires run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a faint remnant of what was once there. You go to see if you can find any remainder of the fire + tsunami battle. You can, but it's so faint.
ReadingMnemonic: Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a faint remainder of what was, your tan (たん) is extremely faint as well. Look at your skin. It has such a faint tint.

Name: Foundation
Mnemonic: There’s a stone, a tree, another tree, and a coat rack. That stone and two trees will make the perfect foundation, or cornerstone, for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable. Imagine making a foundation with the stone and the two trees so you’ll have a place for your coat rack. Feel the wood grain and cold stone against your skin as you move them around to form the foundation.
ReadingMnemonic: After you finish the foundation, the only step that's left is to wash the entire thing with soap (そ). Imagine getting on your hands and knees, rubbing a bar of soap all over the foundation you built. The soap gets into all the nooks and crannies in the wood and stone. Now if a coat falls off the coat rack onto the floor, you just add water and poof! Clean!

Name: Highness
Mnemonic: Compare a building to some dirt and you'll see the difference between you and His and Her Highness. You live outside and sleep on the dirt. But His and Her Highness both live in a huge building. Picture Her Highness, high up in her building. Now compare her home and life to yours, you dirt person.
ReadingMnemonic: I bet His Highness has never had to sleep in hay (へい) either, like you do every night. Hay is what you use as a pillow, mattress, blanket. Basically hay and dirt are all you have. Unlike His Highness. Picture His and Her Highness coming out of their huge building and walking by you in your hay pile. "My goodness, Highness, have you ever seen such a dirty, fluffy creature?" "My no, dear, let's move quickly to remove it from our sight!"

Name: Immersed
Mnemonic: In the event of a tsunami, Wolverine, your forehead, and a stool will all be immersed in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool. Feel the water all around you as you become immersed in this tsunami. See Wolverine trying to swim his way to the top as you watch the stool floating about in the water.
ReadingMnemonic: Still immersed, the stool floats over and hits you in the shin (しん). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts. Hear the stool crack against your shin and feel the pain erupt through your leg. You try to scream but you’re under water so you just get a big mouthful of tsunami.

Name: Inferiority
Mnemonic: The few members of society without power suffer from severe inferiority complexes. Most people in this world have lots of power, so the few that do not feel quite inferior. It is this feeling of inferiority that fuels their inferiority complexes. Imagine you are one of the few without power. Feel the inferiority crushing down on you. It feels terrible and there is nothing you can do about it.
ReadingMnemonic: Since you suffer from such extreme feelings of inferiority, when someone offers you and your friends the chance to gain power, you yell “Let’s (れつ) go!” without a second thought. “Let’s go, guys! Come on! Power awaits us!” Let’s go, let’s go! Time’s a wastin’! I’m tired of this inferiority and want to gain some power!

Name: Intuition
Mnemonic: This crab trap has the power of intuition. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them. Look at this crab trap and see it visibly glowing with intuition. Its powers of intuition are so strong that you can actually see it shimmering with intuition as it expertly traps all those crabs.
ReadingMnemonic: This crab trap's intuition powers were extracted from Genghis Khan (かん) himself. And as we all know by now, Genghis Khan was the absolute master of intuition, he always knew what his enemies and his allies were about to do. Genghis Khan probably has the strongest intuition of anyone in history. This crab trap is getting close though.

Name: Isolate
Mnemonic: A building that has a bully will isolate itself. Building have feelings like people, you know. Picture a single building, isolated from the rest of the city and those mean, bully buildings that live there.
ReadingMnemonic: The isolated building only has one companion, and it's the cock (かく) that lives inside of it. Picture the sun rising behind an isolated building. A cock lets out a cry from the roof. It's a sad and lonely scene.

Name: Kick
Mnemonic: In the foot capital, it's tough to be a dog because you're always getting kicked. In the foot capital, you can only use your feet. So petting dogs looks a lot like kicking them.
ReadingMnemonic: Imagine yourself kicking a kettle (け). There's nothing that's more satisfying to kick than a good ol' kettle, you know? You just love how a kettle gets dented as you kick it around.

Name: Mulberry
Mnemonic: You take a stool, another stool, and yet another stool and stack them on top of a tree to make a mulberry bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree. Imagine putting three stools on top of a tree and watching it transform into a mulberry. The science of nature!
ReadingMnemonic: Your mulberry tree then produces a quantity (くわ) of mulberries. Yum. Imagine the huge quantity of mulberries growing from your stool tree. Imagine picking them all. What an enormous quantity of mulberries you now have.

Name: Nun
Mnemonic: You give a flag and a spoon to a nun as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds. Imagine handing the nun your country’s flag. And also a spoon that is very valuable to you. Imagine getting down on one knee as you do so.
ReadingMnemonic: You’re getting down on one knee (に) as you present the flag and the spoon to the nun. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved! Feel your knee digging into the cold floor as you present your offerings to the nun. You feel slightly sad as she takes your precious belongings from you.

Name: Pearl
Mnemonic: The king takes his slide into his private jet and is given a pearl as a gift, by you! He's letting you ride in his jet today, and you were told the king should be presented with a pearl as soon as he boards. Imagine giving this gorgeous white pearl to the king after he slides down his slide and boards the jet. See his king face light up as he sees the pretty pearl.
ReadingMnemonic: The king takes the pearl and tosses it into a chute (しゅ) next to the slide he took to get into the jet. You watch as the pearl goes down, down, down until it lands into a huge vat of pearls. Oh. I guess the king didn't need your pearl, since he has a pearl chute to get them off his jet before takeoff. You feel silly. And you kind of want to jump into the pearl chute yourself.

Name: Podium
Mnemonic: On the dirt there is a lid trying to cover the number of times the dawn has risen here. You walk over and pull the lid off and the whole thing transforms into a podium. A podium for the dawn to tell you how many times it's risen over this dirt over and over again. It just keeps going and you realize the lid was here because this dang podium can't seem to keep a lid on it! (Get it? Figure of speech!) This kanji also just... really looks like a podium right? With a guy wearing a graduation cap, pointing toward you, in the crowd.
ReadingMnemonic: You listen to what the podium has to say for so long you finally can't help but ask, "Who are you?" "I'm the dawn (だん), of course!" And this is my podium where I spread the good news about the dawn! I guess that makes sense. This podium is by the dawn for the dawn.

Name: Pottery
Mnemonic: The only type of can you'll be building in prison is one made of pottery. Do you honestly think they would let you have anything made of metal or plastic? No, too dangerous. You have to make all of your cans and plates and underpants the old-fashioned pottery way. Picture the first piece of pottery you ever made. Feel it in your hands. At least you've learned something new while you've been stuck in prison.
ReadingMnemonic: You get so good at pottery that the guards start to notice and offer to sell what you make in とうきょう. とうきょう is a big pottery town, after all. You'll make a fortune! Well... the guards will at least. Selling your prison pottery in とうきょう might even help you get out faster. Yippee!

Name: Princess
Mnemonic: A woman sees herself (oneself) as a princess or a queen. As women should! Just remember, when you're around other women (and woman-aligned peoples), it's important to treat each other like princess and queens, not just oneself.
ReadingMnemonic: All of us princesses and queens share a special heat (ひ). When we see another princess or queen that heat passes through us and we nod to one another. All princess and queens can feel the heat coming off of the others.

Name: Prune
Mnemonic: Take your greatest treasure, hold a knife nice and close to it, and prune away all the weak and dead bits. All treasures need to be taken care of, no matter what they are. Prune away anything that isn't necessary.
ReadingMnemonic: Currently, you want to prune your greatest treasure: your car (か). Your car is made of wood, and it keeps trying to grow new buds and branches, so you have to prune them off. You want your car to be small and sleek, not a giant truck, so you have to carefully prune it when it grows too much.

Name: Realize
Mnemonic: Your soul connects to five different mouths, allowing you to realize something. You can realize profound truths about the world with these five mouths speaking to your soul. Maybe the five mouths are your five senses, "speaking" information to your soul so you can realize and perceive things about the world. Whoa, dude…
ReadingMnemonic: Right now those five mouths are helping you to realize something about Godzilla (ご). First you hear Godzilla, then you see him, then you smell him, then you touch him. Finally you taste Godzilla. Now you've realized exactly what kind of thing he is. You truly know Godzilla. You now realize why Godzilla destroys all those buildings: he's warning the Japanese people about the use of new technology and warfare and experimentation. He just wants everyone to realize what the consequences of these new things could be!

Name: Semi
Mnemonic: Put a turkey on ice and it will only get semi frozen. You add more ice, and it stays the same. Only some of it will freeze. What the heck! Imagine covering a turkey in ice and every time you check it, it's only semi frozen. It doesn't matter what you do, it just refuses to freeze all the way through.
ReadingMnemonic: Finally you realize it will only semi freeze because it's June (じゅん)! It's too hot out for your turkey to freeze all the way. The ice keeps melting off the top and semi thawing it! The lesson is to never try to freeze something in June. If you do it will only semi freeze.

Name: Solely
Mnemonic: The mouth of that turkey is solely his. It’s very unique, so that mouth could belong to no other turkey but him. That mouth is solely his. Imagine what makes this turkey’s mouth so unique. This beak is solely his. It belongs to no other. This turkey is the only turkey with a mouth like his.
ReadingMnemonic: You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his but you missed your exit on the highway and you have to hang a U-ey (ゆい). You know what hang a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his. Imagine hanging a U-ey on the highway. Hear your tires screech as you turn around and get off where you’re supposed to.

Name: Sturdy
Mnemonic: A hill knife is the most sturdy knife you can find. The reason hill knives are so sturdy is because they are shaped like hills. Very wide, very thick, not so long. So, they don't break and are more sturdy.
ReadingMnemonic: This sturdy (but strangely shaped) knife is used by Grandpa ごういち. Imagine Grandpa ごういち rolling the knife back and forth over various things to cut them. "I love my sturdy hill knife," he says.

Name: Subjugate
Mnemonic: If someone loiters it's correct to subjugate them. You can't just let people do whatever they want. If it isn't correct to loiter here, then it IS correct to subjugate them, and force them to do what you want. You control them now. And they're gonna get it!
ReadingMnemonic: You subjugate these loiterers with your holy blue saber (せい)! It's the correct thing to do, after all, and you were given this saber all those levels ago because you did the correct thing. As you swing your saber around, subjugating the loiterers, and making them do as you say, you remind yourself that this is correct. And if it's correct, you have to use your saber to enforce it.

Name: Vow
Mnemonic: With your fingers under an axe, you say a vow. A vow is a sacred promise, so you have to be really serious when you say one. That's why you do it with an axe hovering above your fingers—it's a reminder that if you break this vow your fingers are gonna get chopped off. Picture the axe hovering above your fingers. Now say the vow. But don't lie. The axe knows when you're lying.
ReadingMnemonic: When you finish your vow, you take out your holy blue saber (せい) and cut the axe in half! You know you're never going to break your vow, and if you do, you'll use your own saber to cut off your fingers. Imagine what it would be like to slice off your own fingers with the saber you've carried for so long. You better not break that vow.

Name: Vulgar
Mnemonic: The leader of this valley is very vulgar. The name of the valley is Vulgar Valley, so it makes sense for its leader to be very vulgar. Imagine meeting the leader of Vulgar Valley. Imagine all the vulgar things he says to prove he is worthy of being the leader of Vulgar Valley. He is so very, very vulgar.
ReadingMnemonic: This vulgar leader leads his Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang through Vulgar Valley, patrolling the area and spreading vulgarity as he goes. Hear the motorcycles rev and purr as they carouse the Vulgar Valley. Hear the leader screaming vulgar things as he and his Bosozoku bike gang ride all around.

Name: Watered
Mnemonic: A tsunami at the gate of the king makes sure all of his plants get watered. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami. Hear the tsunami crash into the gate as you see the water slosh around and make sure that all of the king’s plants get good and watered.
ReadingMnemonic: These plants are getting watered in June (じゅん), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did. Again, watch and hear the tsunami crashing into the gate and getting the plants watered. This time, remember that the month is June and it is very hot and sticky outside. You’re sweating and very hot.

Name: Name
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means name.

Name: Splinter
Mnemonic: Although a little bit modified, there is a turtle shell that's on a mustache with this radical. The only thing with a mustache that hangs around turtles is Splinter, the giant rat from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. So this radical is Splinter (the giant rat).

Name: Accidentally
Mnemonic: The leader, Master Splinter (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone accidentally poured ooze on him. Imagine someone accidentally spilling ooze on a rat, then watch the rat turn into a sentient rat martial artist.
ReadingMnemonic: But really, if you do something accidentally, it's probably a good (ぐう) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake! However you look at it, try to make this accident be a good accident.

Name: Adept
Mnemonic: The construction of an underground prison will be done by someone who is adept at it. And that adept person is you! You're an expert when it comes to constructing underground prisons, so you've been hired for this job. Good luck!
ReadingMnemonic: Adept at constructing underground prisons, you've caught the eye of Emperor こういち, the royal underground prison enthusiast. With a dignified nod, Emperor こういち entrusts you with the grand project of constructing an underground prison, confident that the adept builder will make prisoners feel right at home in their new subterranean digs.

Name: Alligator
Mnemonic: A fish with two mouths has the number two on it because it's in prison (that's its prison number). Who put the poor two-mouthed fish in prison? An alligator. Because alligators hate two-mouthed fish. How the alligator wishes it had a second mouth like the fish with two mouths, prisoner number 2! It believes that with another mouth, it would be the most talked-about predator, so it imprisons the two-mouthed fish out of jealousy.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the わに in "WaniKani." Ever heard of it? So long as you've ever used WaniKani, you probably know the reading of the word alligator.

Name: Bundle
Mnemonic: Put your fingers on the bed, grasp the sheets and bundle them up. Now you can do the laundry! Imagine pressing your fingers into the bed, grasping tightly and ripping the sheets free. Then you bundle them up into your arms so you can stuff them into the washing machine.
ReadingMnemonic: In between grasping and bundle-ing, you shout HA (は)! That's when the sheets come off the bed. The next time you grasp your bedsheets yell "Ha!" as you yank them off. Now chuckle a bit, ha ha ha, as you bundle them up into a ball. You can't beat me, bedsheets.

Name: Burdensome
Mnemonic: A horse that is fat is a burdensome animal. A fat horse. So burdensome. Not to mention the burden on the horse on top of the fatness.
ReadingMnemonic: But you have to be nice to the burdensome horse because this horse is your dad (だ). Go visit your dad the burdensome horse because you have to visit your dad. It's weird because you're a human and he's a horse.

Name: Cave
Mnemonic: A tsunami is the same as a cave. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave! Also, imagine a tsunami hitting a cave, becoming the same as the cave (since a cave will shape it).
ReadingMnemonic: Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a doughnut (どう). Also note that the 同 part of this kanji gives away the reading as well. 同 and 洞 have the same readings!

Name: Chief
Mnemonic: The leader all in white is the chief. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's how you tell the chief apart from the other leaders. Imagine all the leaders standing around, then the chief person standing there all in white.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as 白, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is お, and it's like the honorific 御, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be お, too. You'll learn more about which reading to use when the vocabulary roll around. In the meantime, try to remember both of them the best you can!

Name: China
Mnemonic: Long ago, under a canopy, a wolverine opened its mouth and uttered a single word: "China." Thus China was born, all of sudden. Yes, all of a sudden China existed, just like that! Pretty crazy, right?
ReadingMnemonic: Believe it or not, this sudden invention of China happened in とうきょう. Well, it wasn't とうきょう yet. And it was a traveling wolverine from China who did it. I mean, it wasn't China yet either… But you know legends, they're just all over the place. Listen, China could get pretty mad if you told them they were invented in とうきょう, even if it's just a silly legend. Maybe you shouldn't tell anyone this story. Just keep it between you and me, okay?

Name: Clear
Mnemonic: You want to write a chapter about hair in your new book so you have to make sure it's really clear. Clear enough so that ANYbody can read it. Your writing is so clear and concise that just about everyone does read it. Well, everyone with hair that is.
ReadingMnemonic: Your clear writing got the attention of the Shougun (しょう) and now he's at your door once again. Although, this time he's angrier than usual. His hair also looks awful. He took your advice after reading the book and cut his entire ponytail off. Picture the Shougun angrily yelling at you about his hair disaster! The only good thing he can say about your book is that it gave clear directions.

Name: Comic
Mnemonic: A tsunami crashes into the sun, which is then caught in a net and tied to a stool! Wait a second... this doesn't sound realistic, it sounds really comic! That's because it's from that comic book about a pirate you're always reading! Imagine reading this issue of your favorite stretchy pirate boy comic. Lumpy uses his long arms as a net, traps the sun and ties it to the stool right as the tsunami hits. What kind of crazy trouble is he getting into this time?!
ReadingMnemonic: Comics are manga (まん) in Japan, whether they're comic or serious. You've known about Japanese comics or manga for a long time, and now you can read them too. Look how far you've come. Wow, what a journey. I'm just so proud of you, kiddo.

Name: Consult
Mnemonic: Watch what you say to the next mouth over, because they hired you to consult them. The person with the next mouth in the room is waiting for you to open yours to consult them. He'll do whatever you say.
ReadingMnemonic: You panic, and consult the man into buying a sheep (し). He was asking for love advice, so I guess you consulted that he give a sheep to the person he likes? Uh oh. Remind me never to consult with you when I'm feeling unsure about things.

Name: Courts
Mnemonic: The Yoga King presides over all courts: law, imperial, and so forth. In this case, you've met him in the court of law, where he is judge, jury, and executioner. Picture him sitting above you in the judge's chair in court. He's about to make his judgement.
ReadingMnemonic: The court of the Yoga King is against you. You have to turn this around, so you start pushing tater (てい) tots into his tater-tot-hole shaped mouth. "I hereby sentence you to..." *ploop* "Ooh, this is really good. I hereby sentence..." *ploop* "Wow, are these tater tots? Court dismissed."

Name: Crab
Mnemonic: This is an animal with an angled sword claw that's filled with cow meat but looks like an insect. What kind of animal is that? It's a crab. If you think about the different parts you can see why this is a crab. A delicious, delicious crab.
ReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as the かに in WaniKani. If you've used WaniKani before, you probably know this reading, hopefully. All praise the great allicrab!

Name: Dam
Mnemonic: A woman is making a dirt cage in the sun. She's using it to trap water, making this a dirt dam. If you think about it, dams are just dirt cages anyway. Picture the woman working tirelessly in the hot sun, moving and shaping the dirt around this river into a dam to make a pond.
ReadingMnemonic: Something about the woman working hard to build this dam makes her super sexy (せき) to you. Maybe it's because the sun is so bright, making her shine, or maybe it's because hard work is attractive. Who knows. If you wanna be sexy maybe you should build a dam too.

Name: Drift
Mnemonic: If a tsunami hits your helicopter while you are jackhammering, it will drift out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away! Picture your helicopter as it drifts out to sea with the tsunami.
ReadingMnemonic: As it drifts away you shout, "Heyooo! (ひょう)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough. "Heyoooo stop drifting awaaaay!!"

Name: Eddy
Mnemonic: A tsunami hits a roof and then corrects itself. This causes it to swirl around, creating an eddy. An eddy requires water to change direction and then twirl around, and when the tsunami hits the roof, that's exactly what it does.
ReadingMnemonic: There is a person trying to create an eddy with a tsunami, and when their roof correction device is shown to be effective, they sing: "This is how you do (よど) it." Imagine them singing this, emphasizing the "you do" part of the song as they watch the eddy being formed.

Name: Embankment
Mnemonic: The correct way to block the sun with dirt is with an embankment. Build a huge, sloping embankment correctly and the sun won't be able to bother you ever again! Imagine an embankment made of dirt, in the correct place, blocking the sun from your eyes.
ReadingMnemonic: Unfortunately, building a correct embankment doesn't just take dirt, but tater (てい) tots too. You pile up the dirt and the tater tots so the embankment can be nice and high. Picture an embankment made of dirt and tater tots. Not like, tater tots just thrown in the embankment, you probably see those all the time. But dirt AND tater tots in the embankment itself.

Name: Empress
Mnemonic: You walk out on a cliff, where you find in the ground a mouth poking out. It speaks: "It is me, the empress of these lands!" She was buried in the cliff down to her mouth so nobody would find her! You pull her out of the ground and soon what was just a mouth becomes a whole empress!
ReadingMnemonic: When you finish unburying the empress, the first thing she says to you is: "Please, you must hurry and take me to Emperor こういち." It's only natural the empress would want to see her emperor. And right now, the emperor of these lands is Emperor こういち.

Name: Epidemic
Mnemonic: Turn a sickness into a weapon and it becomes an epidemic. This sickness spreads to everyone and it's all your fault because you put it in the water supply. Imagine if countries decided to make sick weapons that would spread epidemics like this all over part of the world. Let's hope they don't...
ReadingMnemonic: These epidemics spread by 駅 (えき). Each train takes the sickness and shoots off in a different direction, spreading it further. Picture a single 駅 on a map, bright red. Now watch the red spread to all of the other 駅 on the map, dyeing them red and spreading the epidemic all over your country.

Name: Flip
Mnemonic: You have a numbered feather. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to flip and flip over and over. Imagine yourself doing flips with this feather on your head. Flip flip flip.
ReadingMnemonic: You're pretty good at your flip technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and hone (ほん) your skills and get better. Or, maybe you get so good that you write a 本 (ほん) about doing a flip. Wow, you're good!

Name: Gloom
Mnemonic: A tree can be a tree, but it can also be a psychopath. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to gloom. Imagine all the mood swings of this tree. Psychopath tree! Also very gloomy sometimes.
ReadingMnemonic: Then the tree switches from gloom to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. Uts (うつ) uts uts uts uts ♬. Sing along with the moody tree. Gloom to dubstep. Such a big change.

Name: Horizon
Mnemonic: There is a tsunami coming up over a cliff made of dirt. You can see this happening very far away because it's right on the horizon. Picture the tsunami breaking over the cliff on the horizon. It would be beautiful if it wasn't so frightening.
ReadingMnemonic: You squint into the horizon and see something else. There's some guy (がい) up there. And he's... he's being swept away by the tsunami. The guy disappears into the horizon. The guy is gone. You wonder who that guy was. You wonder why he was there. You wonder if he's still alive out there, past the horizon.

Name: Inscription
Mnemonic: A gold name on this piece of wood is the inscription that shows the artist's signature. This inscription refers to a signature or something similar. This is an artisan's signature in the form of an inscription.
ReadingMnemonic: The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for "name"? It is 名, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names めい. If you need to review 名 go ahead and do that. It will help you to remember this kanji.

Name: Look Up To
Mnemonic: The leader cat pirate is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate to look up to. Imagine this majestic cat pirate leader of leaders. Feel in your heart that you look up to this cat pirate, truly.
ReadingMnemonic: Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you look up to) its favorite food: gyoza (ぎょう). Of course, the gyoza is filled with fish, because we're talking about cat pirates, here.

Name: Record Book
Mnemonic: A bamboo tsunami uses its drops to carry out its specialty, which is turning itself into record books. The bamboo tsunami hits the ground and drops of bamboo turn into sheets of paper. The sheets of paper combine to become record books that record what happened here, on this day.
ReadingMnemonic: A record book is a book (ぼ), when it comes down to it. Bamboo can also become bo staffs too, if they don't turn into record books.

Name: Restaurant
Mnemonic: The restaurant radical and the restaurant kanji are the same! The meaning of this kanji also extends other resting places, like an inn or a pavilion. Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: This restaurant only serves tater (てい) tots. Really, would you ever want to go to a restaurant that didn't have tater tots? No. Imagine going to a restaurant and seeing a menu of all different types and styles of tater tots and nothing else. Even the drinks are tater tot based. Mmm mm.

Name: Revise
Mnemonic: What you say on the street needs to be revised. Your words need to be polished, you can't publish improv. Revise your street word inspiration before you share it again. Think about all the stupid things you said on the streets today. Do you want those exact phrases, mistakes, and mouth sounds following you around forever? Revise it before you write it down!
ReadingMnemonic:
You want to revise the song you wrote about tater (てい) tots at lunch today. But it needs a lot of revising. "Tater tots, tater tots, tater tots, man.
Bake me a tater tot as fast as you banana."

Name: Robust
Mnemonic: A samurai who can fight with icicles on him is more robust than regular samurai. Can you imagine how robust you'd have to be to fight in weather cold enough to form icicles on your body? Picture samurai standing in a line. One, two, three... woah. You look up. This guy has icicles growing off him and he's the size of a bus. Now that's a robust samurai.
ReadingMnemonic: You may think it's just his robust body, but it's actually the samurai's robust soul (そう) that keeps him fighting through the cold and the icicles. Physical robustness is just a reflection of the strength of your soul!

Name: Rut
Mnemonic: There are nine cars all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a rut. Imagine the cars spinning out in the rut. Spin spin spin. The rut gets bigger. Nine is too many cars.
ReadingMnemonic: To get out of the rut you have to put in a second key (き) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the "take off" button. Imagine turning the thrusters key, then feeling the car lift off the ground. You'll finally get out of this rut!

Name: Stirred Up
Mnemonic: A big turkey in the rice paddy is getting all stirred up. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up? He is a really big turkey too. Like, 12 feet tall, or something. Don't want to stir up a turkey that's that big.
ReadingMnemonic: While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん). Is it laughing? Oh no, this is bad, it's enjoying being stirred up, now we'll never stop it.

Name: Summit
Mnemonic: At the top of the mountain is a signpost to tell you you've reached the summit. Literally every mountain that humans have reached the top of has one of these summit signs. If that signpost wasn't there how would you know you reached the summit? Like, if you were on top of Everest and there was a bad storm... you'd just topple off the other side. Those summit signposts are important!
ReadingMnemonic: At the summit, you decide to build your new home (ほう). It's been destroyed so many times, and you're sick of it. Maybe if you build you home at the summit of this mountain it will be safer. Picture your beautiful summit home. You know, George Washington had one of these too. So. That's cool, I guess.

Name: Tomb
Mnemonic: Sticking out of the dirt, there's a cross adorned with flowers and shellfish shells. This is a tomb. The flowers and shellfish were put here as decorations and to honor the dead that currently lie under the dirt. And the cross marks the tomb, obviously. Can you picture this big dirt tomb, with flowers and shellfish decorating it and a cross right on top?
ReadingMnemonic: This is a tomb, but it feels really fun (ふん). Decorated with flowers and shellfish shells, it’s not a sad place at all. It's a fun place to remember all the fun times with people you loved. See this tomb, and you'll remember all the fun you had. It's decorated to make sure you feel that fun.

Name: Transport
Mnemonic: With your fingers you put some weapons in a boat for transport. This is a transport boat and its your job to get these weapons from one place to another. Imagine loading a bunch of weapons into a boat and sailing off to transport them somewhere else.
ReadingMnemonic: Hey! You're transporting weapons just like Han (はん) Solo! I mean, it was a spaceship, not technically a boat, but he definitely used the Millennium Falcon as a transport. Picture yourself as a cool smuggler, transporting stolen... I mean... totally legitimate weapons from one place to another. Just like Han Solo!

Name: Wicked
Mnemonic: A fang on a building shows that it's wicked. Something wicked probably lives in the building too. Not like, wicked cool, but like wicked evil. I see you, New Englanders.
ReadingMnemonic: You peek inside the wicked building and a wicked jaguar (じゃ) suddenly pounces at you! You let out a sigh of relief when it's stopped by the window, but then... the window opens?! What a wicked building! It's letting the jaguar get you! Imagine being chased around the outside of this wicked fanged building as the wicked fanged jaguar tries to eat you. Ahhh!

Name: Stomach
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means stomach.

Name: Again
Mnemonic: You're sitting on your stool again!!? Imagine your super comfy, state-of-the-art stool. You take it everywhere with you, and you're always sitting on it. Again, and again, and again. You love that stool.
ReadingMnemonic: Your friends are starting to worry about you, because you're always sitting on that stool. "What is the matter (また) with you?" they scream! You might want to imagine that all your friends have Jamaican or British accents to make this one fit a bit better! Imagine your friends getting more and more annoyed with your constant stool-sitting habits! They really don't get it. What is the matter with you?! Why can't you just stand like everyone else? Don't you know sitting is the "new smoking"!?

Name: Agreement
Mnemonic: We must stop the moon. That, at least, we can come to an agreement on. There are a group of people pointing at pictures of the moon coming closer to earth. They are the world's leaders, and although they don't get along normally, this new attack from the moon has united them in agreement: we must stop the moon.
ReadingMnemonic: "We have agreement," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have agreement on who we will follow, Emperor こういち. The world has united against the moon, and they have made Emperor こういち their temporary leader.

Name: Bay
Mnemonic: If you want to have a tsunami at your wedding, you need to make sure you have it at the bay. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time. Picture the tsunami coming towards your beautiful wedding as you stand by the bay. It's not safe, but it's memorable!
ReadingMnemonic: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the bay in the first place? By throwing a bunch of uranium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent. Imagine throwing buckets of uranium into the bay. It only burns your hands a little. And now they glow green, just like the bay does!

Name: Between
Mnemonic: Your fingers have husband horns. They are there right between each of your fingers. Imagine little husband horns (the horns your husband has) between all your fingers. Emphasis on between.
ReadingMnemonic: What is between your fingers? Your husband (はさ) horns. Husband, between. Between, husband.

Name: Boil
Mnemonic: If a tsunami hits a dollar the water will instantly start to boil! Imagine standing in front of an incoming tsunami. Suddenly in the distance you see someone throwing dollar bills into it and it starts to boil. Ahh!
ReadingMnemonic: The boiling water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your foots (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots. Feel your poor little foots burn in the boiling water. You really want to know who that jerk was that threw dollars into the tsunami to make it boil!

Name: Bottle
Mnemonic: You see horns on a lantern that can hold ten thousand drops of water sitting on the ground. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's actually a bottle. The horns are like a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle filled with water. Picture this horned bottle sitting on the ground. You don't know who left it here or why, but it's here and the weirdest looking bottle you've ever seen.
ReadingMnemonic: Even though you're not the one who left this bottle here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash bin (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know. Imagine picking up this weird bottle with your bare hands and putting it in a trash bin. You did your good deed for today! Yay!

Name: Call
Mnemonic: The call radical and the call kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean eat, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?! Call your mom or dad and ask them to go out to eat with you right now.
ReadingMnemonic: You are called to come eat by the Shougun (しょう). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone. Imagine getting a call from the Shougun himself. He's come to your house before, but he's never asked you to eat with him. This is huge!

Name: Chastity
Mnemonic: You try to put your toe inside a shellfish, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of chastity. "No, I won't open up until I meet the toe I will marry," it says to you.
ReadingMnemonic: "Chastity is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a tater (てい) tot, I'll change my mind." You give the shellfish a tater tot, and it breaks its vow of chastity, opening up for your toe. You look the other way, but you can hear the sounds of passion below.

Name: Clear
Mnemonic: There is a special type of meditation where you put a lid on your mouth and touch your forehead down to your legs. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely clear. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it. Imagine this pose, imagine everything becoming clear. Clear your mind. Clear your head.
ReadingMnemonic: Your mind is as clear as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a row (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind. Picture the row boat on the clear pond in your mind. Watch the clear water flow over the row boat's oars.

Name: Collar
Mnemonic: The spirits of the two trees you destroyed with your jackhammer live on in the collar you made out of them. You took the shredding tree bits and carefully molded them into a nice collar to go with all of your shirts. But now it's haunted.
ReadingMnemonic: The collar keeps whispering, "Eric (えり)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird. Whenever you put on your collar you hear a constant stream of, "Eric, pssst, hey Eric, hey!" and you just have to pretend it isn't happening.

Name: Corner
Mnemonic: So my building has a big splinter, right in the corner. So what? Imagine a huge splinter coming out of the corner of the building. It's in a really dangerous spot, but the owner doesn't seem so worried about it.
ReadingMnemonic: That corner is dangerous, but what are you going to do, sue me (すみ)? Actually, please don't sue me. I'll fix the splinter coming out of the corner of my building.

Name: County
Mnemonic: The buddy building is in the next county. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy. Imagine looking at a map of your county and the surrounding ones. All of the buildings in the counties next to yours are buddy buildings!
ReadingMnemonic: Your county is everything you can reach when shooting a gun (ぐん). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county. Imagine taking out a gun and shooting in a random direction. When you find where the bullet landed, you know that's the county line. Though if it gets stuck in a building or a person it doesn't count. You'll have to try again.

Name: Dry Up
Mnemonic: There's a fire next to which you left some syrup, and it has all dried up! Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy. Imagine pouring some syrup next to a fire and watching it dry up. Watch as the sides slowly bubble and harden and lose what makes syrup so good in the first place.
ReadingMnemonic: If you dry up syrup like this, you're removing its soul (そう). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it. Go back to imagining a fire drying up some syrup and watch as a tiny little syrup soul cries and is released into the air. Oh no!

Name: Explanation
Mnemonic: If you use a sickle to kill a shrimp you'll need a really good explanation for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation? Try to come with an explanation for picking up a sickle and cutting the head off a shrimp with it.
ReadingMnemonic: In your explanation you blame everything on Shaq (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain. Picture Shaq popping into your head as you struggle to come up with an explanation for me. Picture Shaq's face. This is payback for Shaq Fu, you think, as you finalize the rest of the explanation in your mind.

Name: Fat
Mnemonic: You ate the moon with a spoon, and then the sun too, but man were they high in fat! In fact, you wanted to eat them with chopsticks, but they were so greasy with fat that the spoon was your only option. Imagine staring down regretfully at your fat-covered spoon after eating both the moon and the sun. Not only did you eat two really important celestial bodies, but their high fat content made them way less healthy than you expected.
ReadingMnemonic: Unbeknownst to you, the moon and sun contained as much fat as an entire adult sheep (し)! Why didn't you check the nutrition facts first??? If you had known you were going to get a whole sheep's worth of fat, you would have just eaten a big platter of mutton chops instead of dooming the entire solar system by eating the moon and sun.

Name: Fat
Mnemonic: When the moon faces the right direction, the fat in the bodies of people and animals all gets drawn to the surface and we all look weirdly greasy for a little while. You probably knew that the moon exerts a pull on water, but I bet you didn't know it exerted a pull on fat too! Picture the moon turning to face a different direction. Feel all the fat in your body start to get extracted up through your pores, creating this slick, greasy sheen all over your skin. Let's hope this phase of the lunar cycle ends quickly.
ReadingMnemonic: As long as you're covered in fat, you might as well go bowling (ぼう). Imagine how smoothly that bowling ball's going to roll after you slather it with some of this fat! Feel how slippery the bowling ball gets as you smear it with fat. Now close your eyes and imagine pins toppling in every direction as your fat-slathered ball careens into them!

Name: Greatness
Mnemonic: The leader of Korea is destined for greatness. I mean, they're the leader of Korea already, right? So they have to have a decent chunk of greatness in them already to get that far.
ReadingMnemonic: The greatness radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great eagle (い) soars over them, letting out a cry. Picture the greatness of the scene before you: the leader of Korea, a great eagle overhead, it's so great!!

Name: Lotus
Mnemonic: You put flowers on your car and your scooter. The flowers you put on them are lotus flowers. Imagine placing lotuses on top of your scooter and car. They are the right kind of flowers for these vehicles.
ReadingMnemonic: You're putting a lotus on both your scooter and car because they are rentals (れん). You always put a lotus on top of your rental cars and scooters. It just makes those boring, ugly rental cars and scooters so much prettier!

Name: Mercy
Mnemonic: A person with horns has you on the ground and lets loose two poops over your heart. "Mercy! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say. Imagine yourself saying "mercy" over an over as this horned guy has you on the ground and keeps pooping over your heart.
ReadingMnemonic: As you shout "Mercy!" one more time, suddenly Jesus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe. Imagine yourself saying mercy and seeing Jesus appearing just in time to save the day. The word "mercy" must be his bat signal. Jesus signal? Sure.

Name: Mound
Mnemonic: The dirt on the forehead of a pig makes a small mound. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead. Imagine that you're the pig. How big can you make your forehead dirt mound?
ReadingMnemonic: The pig's forehead dirt mound keeps getting bigger until it's the size of two cars (つか)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over. Picture a pig with a mound of dirt the size of two cars leisurely stomping around on a farm.

Name: Plow
Mnemonic: You have a plow and a (water) well. These are the two things you need in order to plow. You'd think you'd only need a plow, but you also need water if you're going to plow a field, otherwise what's the point?
ReadingMnemonic: Plowing all the fields are こういちs. Not Emperor こういち. These are the こういち clones the government made, and now they're being put to use. Thousands and thousands of こういちs, set free unto the world to do all our plowing work.

Name: Princess
Mnemonic: Everyone knows that when a woman plays football she becomes a princess. Thats how princesses are made. Picture the awesome princess, kicking butt and taking names, out on the football field.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember the word 姫? It means princess too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too. Make sure you know both princess words and you'll know their readings too.

Name: Residence
Mnemonic: Your clan is breaking ground and building your new residence. You're all working together to make you a new home! Picture your clan, working together, to build a new residence for you on their land.
ReadingMnemonic: Your new residence is complete! You step closer and the smell of tater (てい) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan! Imagine living in a tater tot residence. Whenever you're hungry, you just lean over to the wall and munch.

Name: Scream
Mnemonic: You wake up in prison and there is a big mouth full of legs coming really, really close to your own mouth so you scream! Scream because this is terrifying. Scream because it's all you can think to do. Imagine a prison where horrible mouth leg creatures are trying to get in your mouth. You don't want to scream because they might get in there, but you can't help it.
ReadingMnemonic: You scream and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis Khan (かん) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream. Imagine Genghis Khan doing something to make you scream. What is it? What could Genghis Khan do that's worse than what's already happening to you?

Name: Seedling
Mnemonic: Flowers that grow in a rice paddy only live to be seedlings. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings. Picture the seedlings growing among the rice plants. Once they bloom they'll be picked, so let's hope they stay small as long as they can.
ReadingMnemonic: The seedlings try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as myou (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou. Listen to the little seedlings say myou over and over. Too bad the farmers can tell they aren't rice plants.

Name: Ship Counter
Mnemonic: A turkey sitting on a stool is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal ship counter is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow. Picture yourself counting ships by pointing your finger from one turkey propped up on a stool to the next. You'll be the best ship counter in the world at this rate!
ReadingMnemonic: Once you become the best ship counter in the world everyone will think you are super sexy (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count. Imagine yourself, a sexy ship counter. Sexily counting ships. You go guy/girl/non binary person! So sexy!

Name: Skin
Mnemonic: If you look in a tiger's stomach you'll find a bunch of skin. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats. Imagine yourself opening a tigers mouth and looking all the way down into its stomach and seeing a bunch of skin. Why would you imagine that? Eww.
ReadingMnemonic: The only person who would try to take skin from a tiger's stomach is a fool (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way. Imagine a fool trying to pull skin out of a tiger's stomach. You can imagine them getting their skin added to the pile too if you want.

Name: Soft
Mnemonic: A car that's lacking is really soft. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car. Picture a soft car lacking what it needs to drive down the road. It's so soft it just flops down and won't move.
ReadingMnemonic: This car is probably so soft because it's made entirely of naan (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy). Picture trying to drive this soft naan car. It probably just sinks into the ground and then gets eaten by wild animals (and me).

Name: Suburbs
Mnemonic: If you mix a bunch of buildings together, you have yourself a suburb. Isn't that all a suburb is? Just a mix of a variety of buildings in one area?
ReadingMnemonic: "Suburbs are what we need!" says Emperor こういち. "That suburb life will encourage more people to study kanji," Emperor こういち continues.

Name: Summit
Mnemonic: Take the street all the way to that geoduck, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the summit. You humbly present the road to the geoduck and bow before it. There is a giant geoduck at the summit of the mountain, and the street will lead you right there. Imagine the grueling climb up the mountain to the summit. Feel it in your legs, and keep looking at that tall, tall geoduck. Now imagine kneeling those same aching legs humbly to the street below the geoduck.
ReadingMnemonic: You are at the top, the summit of everything! You humbly survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she looks angry. Anytime you use the street, you're in Mrs. Chou's territory. After detecting you were using her street to reach the geoduck, she started coming after you. Remember, wherever there's a street (radical), Mrs. Chou is not far behind.

Name: Wash
Mnemonic: A tsunami is coming so you take your two wolverines and your turkey out for a wash. It's the only way you can get them clean at once without the wolverines fighting over the turkey and somebody getting hurt. The tsunami is big enough to wash them all before anything bad happens. Imagine the tsunami coming toward you. Two wolverines in one hand and a turkey in the other. You're gonna wash them so good they'll never get dirty again.
ReadingMnemonic: Once they're nice and washed you need to subdue them by poking each of them with a tack (たく). The tack has special sleeping medicine on it, so once they're nice and clean you can put them back in their cages without them trying to eat each other. If you want to wash your animals make sure to have your special tack ready. The tsunami will recede pretty fast so get it out!

Name: Whirlpool
Mnemonic: If you put two mustaches on either side of a tsunami it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes a whirlpool. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them. Picture the tsunami spinning in a circle, trying not to hit the mustaches until it spins itself into a giant whirlpool.
ReadingMnemonic: The whirlpool is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my car (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back! Picture my car getting sucked into the whirlpool. Picture me crying as my car disappears into it forever.

Name: Wise
Mnemonic: If you have an ear for the public's heart, you must be very wise. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well. Close your eyes and open your ears. Feel all of the wise things fill you.
ReadingMnemonic: All of these wise things are stored in your soul (そう), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live. Picture your wise soul, living inside your body. Somehow it just seems to know what the public really wants. It's like your soul is connected to their souls, granting you this wisdom.

Name: Wither
Mnemonic: When a tree grows old, it will wither. Old trees' roots and leaves grow inefficient, and they can't get enough nutrients. It's only natural for them to wither up a little bit.
ReadingMnemonic: This withered tree's best friend is a human 子 (こ). Imagine the child hugging the tree. It gave the 子 its shade, its sap, and eventually its body to build a house. What an awful child, and what a generic giving tree.

Name: Frostbite
Mnemonic: This radical is made of dirt, legs, and winter. If you have to bury your legs in the dirt in winter, it's probably because you got frostbite. You had to leave your dead legs behind. :(

Name: Auspicious
Mnemonic: When a spirit lives in a sheep it becomes the most auspicious creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this. Picture this auspicious spirit sheep. Blessing the children with its fluffy hooves.
ReadingMnemonic: The spirit sheep is so auspicious that the Shougun (しょう) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared. Picture the Shougun telling the world that they must fly spirit sheep flags on this day forever, because of how auspicious it is.

Name: Bath
Mnemonic: I hope all you're doing in the bathtub is taking a bath. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths! Picture yourself taking a bath in your bathtub. Relaxing!
ReadingMnemonic: When do you miss taking a bath the most? When you're on the road (ろ). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath. Imagine being stuck on the road all day for a week. Imagine how good a bath will feel when you finally get home. Nice and hot and relaxing. Mmmm...

Name: Biased
Mnemonic: The leader of the library thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very biased person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently. Imagine showing the leader your favorite book. "That's not a book in MY library," he says, and throws it in the trash. That's so biased! He didn't even give it a shot!
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to give in to his biased recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about hens (へん) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird. "This is such biased crap," you say, as you finish reading the title of a book called "Hens are better than all other birds." Screw this leader guy and his books.

Name: Briar
Mnemonic: If you look at flowers the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the next thing you notice are the briars. You never see thorns first, only after you've looked at the flowers. Imagine what you see next after looking at the pretty flowers. The briars are what you see next. Spiky and sharp. It would have been nice if you had seen them first.
ReadingMnemonic: When you see the briars you can't help but yell, Eee! Ba riars! (いばら)! You pause funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch! Imagine seeing the briars and yelling out "Ba RI ars!" as you prick your finger on one.

Name: Cave In
Mnemonic: This building was a former prison until the cave in. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in. Picture the cave in in your mind. Can you see all the little prisoners and guards being squished as the building tumbles down around them? Oh no!
ReadingMnemonic: You keep picturing the cave in and you see Genghis Khan (かん) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next! Genghis Khan is all about being smart and using better tactics. In this case, why fight a bunch of guards and prisoners when you can just cause a cave in and win immediately? The ol' Khan cave in, a classic war maneuver.

Name: Chain
Mnemonic: The famous gold triceratops shellfish is good for only one thing, and that's being made into chains. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability. Picture these little gold triceratops shellfish linked together by their horns in a chain around your neck. Feel them hanging there. Sparkly and cold.
ReadingMnemonic: However, the only way to break the chain is to saw (さ) it open. Once the triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw. Picture the saw in your hands, sawing back and forth on the gold chain around your neck. Maybe this isn't the best fashion accessory if you have to use a saw to get it off.

Name: Compensation
Mnemonic: You give a bunch of shellfish to a clown as compensation. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish. Picture the shellfish in your hands. Imagine handing them over to the clown as compensation for the unspeakable acts you had him do for you.
ReadingMnemonic: Once the clown has been properly compensated, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "Bye (ばい)" he says. "Bye, bye." All you have to do is give him the right amount of compensation and you'll hear his sweet "bye, bye." Then you never have to see him again.

Name: Constant
Mnemonic: Your soul is like the ground or the dawn. It is constant, never changing. Think of some other things your soul is like, but always make sure you come back to one word: constant.
ReadingMnemonic: Also constant is the Emperor こういち, who will surely rule for a thousand more years! A constant rule from Emperor こういち means constant kanji learning and constant WaniKani reviews. They will always be constant!

Name: Design
Mnemonic: You're sewing something with thread but you and your creation get frostbite while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty design. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands. Imagine holding your creation in your frostbitten hands as the snowflake design starts to appear. The design gets more and more complicated the longer you watch, twisting this way and that, like it's dancing in front of your eyes.
ReadingMnemonic: As you watch the snowflake design form you see letters appearing in the corner! They form the name Aya (あや), our artist here at WaniKani. Somehow she's magically putting together this beautiful pattern! If you know someone else called Aya, go ahead and use them in this mnemonic! Whoever it is, imagine an Aya watching from afar holding a magic wand, creating this beautiful frosty pattern!

Name: Die
Mnemonic: If you figure out how to use a tsunami as a weapon, everyone is going to die. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all. Picture everyone in the world being swept away in a tsunami to die. This is what happens when you try to use nature as a weapon.
ReadingMnemonic: The only way to maybe not die is to find boats (ぼつ). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning. You don't want to die, do you? Get to the boats!

Name: Embrace
Mnemonic: Your fingers grasp this lid and when you raise it you see a poop turkey (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you embrace the turkey.
