Someone was obviously going to cook this poop turkey in a pot, and if you hadn't looked under this lid it surely would have died. Now as you embrace it you can hear the turkey weeping softly.
ReadingMnemonic: As you embrace the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping yogurt (よう) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it! Imagine embracing the turkey as it covers you in yogurt poo. You hope it's yogurt at least. You aren't gonna taste it to find out. Maybe. Okay you might taste it a little.

Name: Encounter
Mnemonic: When you ride your scooter on the ground listening to music under the sun, you're bound to encounter a bunch of new people! They hear your music playing as you scoot by and they come out to meet you. Picture all of the people you encounter as you ride your scooter, spreading your music around town.
ReadingMnemonic: Everyone you encounter wants to bare their soul (そう) to you, literally. They're all coming out to meet you, pulling back their skin and showing you the soul ghosts inside of them. "We love your music, look at our souls!" Uh oh, this is turning into some kind of horror movie. You better scoot a bit faster or you might meet an unfortunate fate.

Name: Erupt
Mnemonic: From your mouth comes a cross, some flowers, and shellfish. It all erupts from your mouth! Imagine these three things coming out of your mouth not one at a time, but all together like an eruption. Perhaps you're laying on your back, and they burst out of your mouth.
ReadingMnemonic: When do inanimate objects erupt from your mouth? Mostly when you're having fun (ふん). It's really inconvenient that things erupt from your mouth whenever you're having fun. Makes it hard to have fun.

Name: Especially
Mnemonic: If the yakuza slide you into a jet, things are especially bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad. First of all, the yakuza have you, that's bad already. But they're sliding you into their jet? That means you aren't upright, you might even be knocked out or dead. That's especially worrying, don't you think?
ReadingMnemonic: You're especially worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of chute (しゅ). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where! As you slide down the chute, it's especially dark. And especially scary. And especially bad! How did this happen to you?!

Name: Ethics
Mnemonic: A leader puts their hat on the ground next to a bookshelf. This is a test in ethics. People hang around the bookshelf, and the leader wants to see if anyone will steal the hat or not. That's why its a test of ethics.
ReadingMnemonic: To test your ethics even more, the leader puts down a ring (りん) as well. Now we'll really see how everyone's ethics are. Will they turn in the ring to the lost and found? Will they ignore it? Will they steal it?

Name: Exhibit
Mnemonic: The building to the east is an exhibit. It's a pretty large building and you can see inside to all of the different exhibits within the main exhibit.
ReadingMnemonic: Right now the exhibit has a bunch of chins (ちん) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit. Go up to the first exhibit and look very closely at some turtle chins, then some crab chins, then some alligator chins. This is weirdly familiar.

Name: Falcon
Mnemonic: If you tie a cross to a turkey you can trick everyone into thinking it's a falcon. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey. Imagine tying a cross to this turkey and see it transform into an elegant falcon. Majestic.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there. Picture your falcon Hayabusa and the real... ok fake.. Hayabusa running around together and kicking butt.

Name: From
Mnemonic: What do stairs do? They take you from where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get from place to place. Picture yourself climbing stairs, picture going from room to room. From place to place. From wherever you were to wherever you want to be.
ReadingMnemonic: If you're going from place to place, make sure you have some nori (の) seaweed on you, in case you get hungry. Nori is a great source of energy. Imagine yourself going from one place to another with your pockets stuffed full of nori. The smell is starting to get overwhelming. It's making you really hungry (or nauseous, depending on how you feel about nori!).

Name: Help
Mnemonic: If you want to have your wedding in a car you're going to need a lot of help. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off. Picture all of your close friends coming to help you squeeze everything for the wedding into your car.
ReadingMnemonic: You can't just ask for help on the day of the wedding, either. You have to schedule (すけ) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so make sure you plan early! Imagine calling all your friends and scheduling when you will get their help. Make sure you have your day planner ready!

Name: Hunting
Mnemonic: There is an animal in the grass and your horrible task is to go hunting for it. Picture the shape of the animal in the grass, off in the distance. You can't see what kind of animal it is yet, but you know you're hunting it.
ReadingMnemonic: You're currently hunting in a row (りょう) boat and you have to row as quietly and carefully as you can or the animal will run away. You wouldn't be able to go hunting in any other kind of boat—the motor would be too loud. Picture yourself in a row boat with all of your hunting gear. You need to be extra careful not to make any loud splashing sounds with the oars!

Name: Instigate
Mnemonic: If you have spiders in your mouth, then you're going to instigate fights between people. Mostly because the spider in your mouth makes you grumpy, but also because the spider keeps telling you to be an instigator with its little mouth inside your own mouth. Imagine having a spider in your mouth. Imagine being angry about it and instigating fights between people because of it.
ReadingMnemonic: The spider in your mouth tells you to instigate a fight by sawing (さ) the other person's leg off. It even whispers where you can find a nice big saw. Picture the fight you and the spider instigated. The guy pointing at the saw, then pointing at his sawed off leg. Listen as the spider tells you to shake your head.

Name: Lazy
Mnemonic: If you give a machine a heart it will get lazy. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now. Picture a machine with a heart, lying on the couch, eating oil snacks, and snoozing. What a lazy machine!
ReadingMnemonic: The machine is so lazy it won't even wear its tie (たい) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so. Picture the lazy machine sitting on the couch again. There are untied ties all over the floor.

Name: Lazy
Mnemonic: In its soul, a narwhal that's supposed to do construction under the moon, will be too lazy to do it. And when your soul is lazy, there's no way you'll be able to get something done. Picture the lazy narwhal laying on a block of ice in the moonlight. There are tools and other blocks of ice around, but he just can't seem to get up and do any construction work.
ReadingMnemonic: You can't tell the lazy narwhal he's being lazy because he's your dad (だ). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right. Picture your lazy dad. Your big, lazy narwhal dad.

Name: Leadership
Mnemonic: Take a leather helicopter to the moon to prove your excellent leadership. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space! Not many people have the leadership it takes to lead such a mission. Imagine what it takes to do it!
ReadingMnemonic: Under your superior leadership you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely! Imagine laughing along with the crew, in awe at your own leadership skills. Ha ha ha! We didn't die!

Name: Necessary
Mnemonic: Shaving the hair off a geoduck before you try to eat it is absolutely necessary. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair. Picture the page in your cookbook where it says "Shaving the hair off your geoduck = Necessary!!" It's absolutely necessary that you follow that instruction!
ReadingMnemonic: It is also necessary that you wear a suit (す) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly. What's necessary? To shave the hair off your geoduck and to wear a suit. That's not too hard. You should do it.

Name: Offering
Mnemonic: If you take a cow's life you're turning it into an offering. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often. Picture yourself offering the cow's life up to the god(s). It's a good thing we don't actually have to do this anymore, you think.
ReadingMnemonic: You prepare the offering with your holy blue saber (せい). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it. Thanks to the mercy of your saber, the offering is quick and painless. A normal saber, however, would have cut that cow to bits. Like, really just wrecked it. Good thing we didn't make you think about that, huh?

Name: Order
Mnemonic: If a grain has a fault, it needs to be put back in order. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their regularity. Keeping order is a tough job! Imagine being one of these people who maintain order by going out in the fields and inspecting every single grain, keeping the good ones and plucking off the ones with faults.
ReadingMnemonic: You can always tell if a company keeps order or if it cheats (ちつ) just by looking at the grains. If there are faulty grains in there, they cheated and order was not maintained. Now you have to go through all the grains and throw out the weird ones yourself.

Name: Orphan
Mnemonic: There was once a melon child, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an orphan. The "melon boy orphan," is what they called him. Imagine a melon (your favorite kind) with a face and arms and legs sticking out. He walks up to you and says "hello kind person, could you help an orphan?"
ReadingMnemonic: The orphan melon boy is but a 子 (こ). That's the sad thing about the melon orphan boy... he's just a child. "Hello gov, I'm just a child," he says to you.

Name: Perfume
Mnemonic: If you point flowers in the same direction you'll be able to smell their wonderful perfume. The best way to get perfume out of flowers is to make them face the same way. Then the smell will go the same direction, making you smell great. Imagine aiming a bunch of flowers in the same direction towards you. The perfume coats your body. You smell great now!
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to perfume your entire home (ほう) by planting flowers all the way around it, all facing in toward it. Now when you're in your home the overwhelming smell of perfume assaults your nostrils. It's actually... really strong. Oh... oh no it's too strong, you can't breathe. And you live alone. Help! Someone!

Name: Pierce
Mnemonic: Under the window, you place a shellfish, then slam the window shut to pierce its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise. Imagine the window piercing into the shellfish's shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
ReadingMnemonic: Now that your shellfish is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you can serve them to Genghis Khan (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them. Carefully count out all the sushi on their pierced shell plates and place them in front of Genghis Khan and his army. As you reach Genghis Khan himself, you realize it's just his ghost, but he's still staring at you as you serve his troops. Ghost or not, you don't want him to pierce you if you mess up.

Name: Provisions
Mnemonic: The rice that's prepared at dawn by the village are provisions for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the village's provisions for them have to be ready by then. Picture everyone in the village getting all of their rice together as provisions for the army. Even the kids and old people are helping out.
ReadingMnemonic: Once all of the provisions are ready, the soldiers show up in their row (りょう) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need roe (ろう) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too. Picture the soldiers gobbling down their provisions of rice and roe in their row boats as they row away.

Name: Quick
Mnemonic: If you stand in the wind it will be really quick to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up only to be knocked over again, just as quick. Imagine how quick the wind knocks you over when you stand up. So quick, you don't even remember being up. Try again and count how many seconds it takes for it to knock you down. Less than one. Now that's quick.
ReadingMnemonic: That quick wind is quicker than you can say Satsuki (さつ). And "Satsuki" is a pretty quick sounding name already. Go ahead, say "Satsuki" as quick as you can right now. Heck, try it a few times. Okay, pretty quick, but this wind is even quicker than that.

Name: Revive
Mnemonic: All you need are some flowers, fish, and grain and you've got yourself a potion that can revive just about anyone or anything! Just don't forget the ingredients you'll need: flowers, fish, and grain. Imagine yourself throwing them all into a big cauldron and brewing up a potion powerful enough to revive a person!
ReadingMnemonic: This potion able to revive any being just has one small downside: it tastes like soap (そ). As long as you can get over the awful taste of soap, this is some good, powerful stuff! And considering this'll be administered to dead things… the taste is probably not so important.

Name: Ridicule
Mnemonic: If your soul is acting like the sun trapped in a net sitting on a stool, then people will ridicule you for your laziness. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving. Your soul just doesn't want to move or do anything though... and that may look like laziness, but you can't help it. You wish your friends and family wouldn't ridicule you. You're going through enough, internally.
ReadingMnemonic: When people ridicule you, when you can't stop the laziness, you read manga (まん). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person. Picture yourself reading manga and watch as the people who ridicule you and call you lazy fade away into the background. You're going to be okay.

Name: Swell
Mnemonic: Play your drum under the moon and your hair will swell! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell. Have you been suffering from flat, boring hair? Well do I have the swelling treatment you've been looking for!
ReadingMnemonic: Using this method, your hair swells so much it looks like a giant bowling (ぼう) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits. Imagine watching your hair swell to the size of a large bowling ball. Imagine never being able to go bowling again because the comparison is too easy for people to make.

Name: Treatment
Mnemonic: Your poor little scooter got a splinter, so make sure to give it extra nice treatment. These are tough times for your scooter, so be patient with it. Try to treat it with understanding and care.
ReadingMnemonic: Give your scooter only the best treatment, so it can feel real gooooood (ぐう). Not just "good", but "gooooood". The long vowel is important here, so try to think of different ways you could make your scooter feel gooooood. Maybe a nice little wash after you’ve removed the splinter will do the trick.

Name: Tall
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means tall.

Name: Admonish
Mnemonic: If you try to say something to the Death Star, it would only admonish you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying. Imagine being admonished by the Death Star. It's hovering above you, giant and round, just yelling at you about everything you've ever messed up. It's really awful being yelled at. But the Death Star doing it is particularly scary and embarrassing.
ReadingMnemonic: Right now you're being admonished about living in a yurt (ゆ). The Death Star bellows, "What, am I too big and safe for you? I'm easy to move too, you know. You're a disgrace! You should be ashamed!" Imagine sitting in your yurt, the home you love, but you can still hear the admonishments from the Death Star in your ears. You feel... bad.

Name: All
Mnemonic: How many buildings have scooters? All of them! All buildings have at least one scooter. It could be out front, on the roof, in the basement. But all of them have scooters and someone who likes to ride them instead of using a car or a bike.
ReadingMnemonic: All of these scooters have a specific sound they make as they burst out of the buildings: zuwee (ずい). Imagine the sound of the scooter's tiny engine: zuwee zuwee zu zu zuwee. All of them do this, which is why you hate them.

Name: Barbarian
Mnemonic: The old moon (the moon we had before the current moon) was actually just a huge barbarian floating in the sky. Just imagine a huge barbarian (whatever that means to you) floating in the sky, looking down. Some ancient people look up and wave at the old moon barbarian.
ReadingMnemonic: At least, this is the kind of story you told your 子 (こ) when they asked you where the moon came from. "You see, my child, the old moon was not like the current moon. It was a giant barbarian in the sky, who would eat children that asked too many questions."

Name: Board
Mnemonic: In your fingers are flowers which really suit you. But you throw them to the people waving to you from below, as you board your ship. The flowers fall, unneeded. You're embarking on a new life, a new journey. There will be more flowers where you're going. Picture yourself boarding the ship and letting the flowers slip from your fingers, into the crowd of people waving goodbye.
ReadingMnemonic: You board a ship to とうきょう, bound for your new life, of course! Where else would you go at this point? I mean, come on. You've made it 53 levels since you embarked on your kanji journey with us. We know you by now. You want to be in とうきょう.

Name: Brocade
Mnemonic: You weave gold and white patterns into this towel, turning it into brocade. It's beautiful, elegant, and worth way more than when it was just a plain towel. Imagine weaving this beautiful brocade fabric out of one of your old towels. Try to actually picture the gold and white patterns you want on there. If you're a crafter, actually do it!
ReadingMnemonic: You want to keep your brocade fabrics safe, so you lock them away and seal them in with a niche key (にしき). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing. Imagine using your niche key to open this hidden brocade storage room. The key is gold and white and looks like brocade too!

Name: Carp
Mnemonic: If you're in Japan, the fish in your village are carp. You may know them as koi, too. Picture your village in Japan. There's a big, still pond full of bright and beautiful giant carp. You hear the village kids giggle as they feed them and their big round mouths pop out of the water.
ReadingMnemonic: A carp is called a koi (こい) in Japanese. We've used that word before so I hope you know it by now. A koi is a koi, you know? Carp are koi and koi are carp. Blub blub.

Name: Cell
Mnemonic: Take the moon and wrap it in a bag and it will look just like a cell. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening! Picture the moon with a big bag circling it. Now look down at your biology homework on cells. They're identical!
ReadingMnemonic: As you learn about cells you realize they're all over your home (ほう). Without ever noticing it, your home has been slowly filling with dead skin cells. And now that you know what they look like (the moon with a plastic wrap bag around it) you can see them everywhere. AHHH CLEAN ALL OF THESE CELLS OUT OF YOUR HOME!

Name: Cleanse
Mnemonic: The tsunami of conflict will cleanse and purify the lands of people, homes, and culture. Anything less than a tsunami of conflict would leave something behind. But this much conflict will cleanse the area of everything.
ReadingMnemonic: Who could possibly stop this cleanse of all lands?! The only person capable of this is, of course, Joe (じょう), the local farmhand. He’s so tall and burly that he can stop even the largest of tsunamis… right? Joe has gone through many things during your WaniKani journey, but this might be too much even for him. Either way, he’s going to try his best to stop this tsunami of conflict, threatening to cleanse the lands of everything we know. With his bare hands, of course.

Name: Commander
Mnemonic: There's a drop of bear on this towel. A true commander can notice little things like this. Imagine a commander carefully looking over everything. They not only notice a drop of something on a towel, but they're able to identify that the drop is a small piece of liquid bear.
ReadingMnemonic: You watch the commander in all his glory... going back and forth on a swing (すい). "Weeee!" says the commander.

Name: Comprehend
Mnemonic: If you say something the same way they say it in the capital, everyone in the whole country will be able to comprehend what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it. Imagine the confused faces of the people in the countryside as you try to talk to them. Decide to say it the way it's said in the capital and see their faces light up as they comprehend what you're trying to say.
ReadingMnemonic: Now that the townspeople finally comprehend what you were trying to say, they sell you the row (りょう) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but りょう is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home. Picture yourself rowing away in your new row boat as the townspeople wave goodbye. They were much nicer once they comprehended what you were asking for. Maybe you'll row your way back here someday.

Name: Darkness
Mnemonic: Flowers are growing out of the ground and over your pet pig's forehead and it's causing the poor thing to live in total darkness. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. And some of the flowers seem to be growing directly out of the pig's forehead too. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it. Imagine being a pig with flowers hanging down off your forehead and into your eyes so that darkness was all you knew. It's very sad, actually.
ReadingMnemonic: To end the darkness you mow (もう) the flowers. You have to drive your lawnmower over its head too, because they're growing out of its forehead too. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again. Imagine mowing the darkness away. Be careful! If you mow the pig's eyes, the darkness will last forever!

Name: Dawn
Mnemonic: The sun is rising and there is a net covering someone, who's being forced to watch as dawn appears. They've never seen dawn before, and they didn't want to, but you're making them. Picture someone tied down in a net as dawn breaks.
ReadingMnemonic: The someone who saw dawn for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ Akebono Taro (あけぼの). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles and it fills him with strength. Look at Akebono looking at you as you look at dawn breaking.

Name: Disaster
Mnemonic: If you get a big hair stuck in your private soul it will be a disaster! Have you ever gotten a hair in your eye or your mouth that you just couldn't get out? You cough, your eyes water, it's awful! You can't focus on anything until it's gone. Now imagine if a big 'ol hair got stuck in your own private soul!!! Disaster!!! This disaster is ruining your life. You can't eat, sleep, all you can do is panic trying to get the hair out.
ReadingMnemonic: This disaster is so huge that even Santa-san (さん) left his vacation in Zanzibar (ざん) to come tell you you're on the naughty list for being such a disaster person. WHAT?! Even you Santa-san? Santa-san has forsaken you. Your life is a wreck. This is a total disaster just because of one big hair.

Name: Draft
Mnemonic: When what you're writing is as tall as the grains growing outside, you know you're done with your first draft. Some teachers want papers to be a certain number of words or pages, but that's silly. You should measure your draft in grains! Imagine holding your draft up outside in a field of grains. You're a couple leaves short. Time to get back to the drawing board.
ReadingMnemonic: Who asked you to write such a tall draft in the first place? Emperor こういち, who wants you to draft up the world's largest book about how great of an emperor he is. Now こういち is out there measuring your draft against the tall grain plants. You better hope it's long enough, because if it isn't, Emperor こういち's probably going to execute you.

Name: Enlighten
Mnemonic: If you can find the door in winter shaped like a mouth it will enlighten you. Imagine searching for this special door in the cold wind and snow of winter. The search for enlightenment always has something to do with suffering and searching on your own like this.
ReadingMnemonic: The door enlightened you by opening up and revealing the cake (けい) in its door-mouth. "Cake is the key to enlightenment, my child. Now eat it from my mouth." All you need to do to attain enlightenment is to eat this cake... out of this mouth. Eh. Maybe enlightenment isn't worth it.

Name: Expose
Mnemonic: Press your fingers in someone's skin to expose what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable. Close your eyes. Picture someone's arm. Now touch their skin with your fingers and peel it back to expose the muscles and bones underneath.
ReadingMnemonic: You expose a small hole under their skin and heat (ひ) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat. Imagine the heat steaming out, like it's coming out of a teapot, not out of somebody's arm skin.

Name: Fiber
Mnemonic: A drunkard crosses thread across special spikes to separate the fibers. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves! Imagine a drunkard crossing threads onto spikes and pulling the tiny fibers free. You don't think you could do that. Maybe if you got drunk too...
ReadingMnemonic: You stare at the fibers easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a centaur (せん). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it... Watch the centaur cross the fibers and separate them with his spikes. How strange.

Name: Gently
Mnemonic: If you loiter around a surplus of anything, you need to be gentle and touch everything gently. Unfortunately it's not specific as to what kind of surplus you're loitering around, so you'll need to imagine a surplus of something memorable to you. Then, just imagine loitering around there, being really gentle with everything.
ReadingMnemonic: You have to be gentle and handle these things gently because they belong to Jo-Anne (じょ). You're loitering around her surplus of (whatever you decided to imagine). Imagine Jo-Anne coming back to her surplus, then asking you if you were gentle with the goods. You were, you treated everything very gently.

Name: Hollyhock
Mnemonic: Flowers that are thought to be little tents sent from heaven are hollyhocks. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai! Picture a tiny yokai using a hollyhock as a tent. Aww cute!
ReadingMnemonic: Hollyhocks are mostly あおい (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from. Imagine yourself in a field of hollyhocks and the あおい of them match the あおい of the heavens! It's like you're standing on a giant flower filled mirror of the sky.

Name: Inflation
Mnemonic: While the moon is out, a gladiator is riding a horse, yelling about inflation. No one would listen to him during the day, so he waited for the moon to rise so he could complain about prices doing the same. Picture the gladiator riding his horse in the light of the moon yelling, "Do you have any idea how important it is to increase the average pay rate to account for inflation? All of us gladiators are going to be unable to pay the bills soon because inflation isn't being taken into account! You'll suffer too! Listen to me!"
ReadingMnemonic: Inflation rises the most in とうきょう, and the gladiator knows that because that's where most of them live and fight (and die). Imagine if you were in this gladiator's place. In five years, you wouldn't be able to afford to eat thanks to the bosses in とうきょう refusing to adjust for inflation. Back in my day, onigiri only cost FIFteen yen!

Name: Install
Mnemonic: You use your fingers to take down the old flag and install a new one. Flags get old, just like computers and furniture and people. So when one gets too old, you have to get on up there and install a new one in its place. Imagine reaching out and grabbing onto the old flag with your fingers. Feel the dirty grime and little holes it's gotten. Now install something new!
ReadingMnemonic: You've decided to install a suit (す) where the old flag used to be. I mean, a suit is probably more durable than a flag, am I right? This way you won't have to install flags as often. Picture a newly installed suit flying in the air on a pole.

Name: Jasmine
Mnemonic: You cut the flowers off the grain with your knife. The flowers that fall off are jasmine flowers. It's weird that jasmine flowers are growing out of your grain, but that's why you're cutting them off.
ReadingMnemonic: The jasmine is growing out of everything, not just grain! It's also growing out of the reeds (り)! You have a farm that grows grain and reeds. Jasmine flowers are growing out of both of those things, ruining your crops! Perhaps you should become a jasmine tea farmer instead...

Name: Latitude
Mnemonic: The thread that goes through Korea is the latitude line splitting up North and South Korea. Why thread? Back in the old days globes were sewn together with cloth and thread, so there was a literal thread dividing the Koreas!
ReadingMnemonic: The only way you can see this latitude line is to ride an eagle (い) over it. The line isn't visible from a car, you're too close, and a plane is too high. You have to see it from an eagle's point of view. Imagine being an eagle yourself, flying around the entire globe, following the latitude line that splits Korea down the middle.

Name: Melon
Mnemonic: The melon radical and the melon kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo! Make sure you remember this radical means melon and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
ReadingMnemonic: What's the best use for a melon? Not eating it, but running over it in your car (か)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see. Imagine hitting the gas pedal in your car as you head for a big melon. Watch it burst into a million pieces as your car makes contact, hurling melon bits all over your windshield. It's a melon firework!

Name: Oppress
Mnemonic: Tigers and wolverines have one big thing in common and it's that the government likes to oppress them. It doesn't matter if you're the animal or a mutant X-Men hybrid. The government will go out of its way to oppress you if you are one. Imagine being a tiger or a wolverine or a tiger-wolverine and being oppressed by the government just because you're different. Imagine being stuck in a cage. Not being allowed to vote. It's awful!
ReadingMnemonic: Tiger and wolverine people are so oppressed that the only thing they're allowed to amuse themselves with is Gak (ぎゃく). You know, that weird goo they made us play with when we were kids? Well that's not so fun when it's all you have. Imagine being a tiger/wolverine girl and being so oppressed that you can only sit in a cage, playing with goopy Gak all day. This blows...

Name: Receive
Mnemonic: A cross carrying drunkard wants you to go to a rice paddy together so you can receive something from them. You really don't want to receive whatever it is this drunkard wants to give you, and it's even sketchier that they want you to go to a rice paddy together to do it.
ReadingMnemonic: Against your better judgement, you decided to go and receive the thing. You close your eyes, hold out your hands, and feel a silky, light tie (たい) being placed in them. The tie looks harmless enough, but you still receive it skeptically. The drunkard is just holding up his cross and smiling at you. Hmm.

Name: Rowboat
Mnemonic: A boat owned by a Yoga King needs to be able to let him keep doing his exercises while he's on it. That's why his boat is a rowboat, so he can work on his yoga arms as he gets around. Picture the Yoga King rowing a rowboat. Maybe he's using his legs. Maybe he's using his butt? You don't know. Yoga people are super flexible, he could be using anything to move this rowboat.
ReadingMnemonic: As he rows the rowboat with his butt, you see the Yoga King eating something with his toes. They're tater tots (てい). Tater tots are the perfect snack for a rowboat. They're small, delicious, and they float if you drop them in the water. Go rent a rowboat and try eating tater tots in it. For fun, throw a bunch of them in the water and watch them float. Maybe you'll catch a fish!

Name: Rust Colored
Mnemonic: This is a boat, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks rust colored. In ancient Chinese literature, this rusty red color represented sincerity, and you'll often see this kanji take that meaning in jukugo words. Picture this broken, rust colored boat. It's a reddish-brown color and it's definitely missing some important pieces.
ReadingMnemonic: The rust colored boat has inspired you, so you sit down next to it in the sun and tan (たん). You want to be the exact same rust color as the boat, and in a few hours you're sure you'll match. Watch your skin slowly change as you tan to match the rust colored boat. Feel your skin in the sun. This may not be good for your health, but it's great for fashion!

Name: Scarlet
Mnemonic: The threads a criminal wears will always be scarlet. Scarlet is the color of freshly spilt blood, which is why bad guys wear it so much. Picture a person wearing all scarlet all the time. Don't they give you a criminal-y vibe?
ReadingMnemonic: This scarlet color holds a lot of heat (ひ). Scarlet is the color of fire, and it has the heat of fire too. Picture a criminal, covered in this scarlet thread, heat radiating off of him.

Name: Shop
Mnemonic: You want to have a quaint cottage wedding, so you have to go to the cottage wedding shop to get everything you need. Imagine the incredibly laborious task of paving an entire road by yourself, just to get to this cottage wedding shop. You really want your quaint little cottage wedding though, so it’s the only choice you have…
ReadingMnemonic: You're browsing everything in the shop when a garden hoe (ほ) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe will give you away at your wedding. Imagine walking around the shop and then falling in love with a hoe with pretty tassels and flowers attached to it. Yes, it's only for decoration, but you're going to buy and use it during your cottage wedding.

Name: Soil
Mnemonic: A dirt nurse is someone who nurses dirt. When nursed, dirt becomes soil. Soil generally has more nutrients in it. It makes sense for dirt that's been nursed to become soil.
ReadingMnemonic: Soil is a thing that Joe (じょう), the huge farmhand, works on improving. If he makes the soil better, the farm will yield more crops. That kind of makes Joe a dirt or soil nurse, if you think about it. Not sure he’d like that title, though…

Name: Speed
Mnemonic: When a horse sees a spider it will start running at a speed no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast. Imagine the eyes of a horse seeing a spider and then running at top speed to get the heck away from it.
ReadingMnemonic: Once people realize that they can increase the speed of their horses, soon (しゅん) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner. Soon the world will be filled with horses running at full speed all thanks to the spider increase of the 2000s! Soon we will be in the future of top speeds!

Name: Surplus
Mnemonic: There's so much grain in your mouth you need to use a knife to remove it. Only when there is a surplus can you put that much grain in your mouth. Imagine seeing so much grain that you can stuff your mouth so full you can't swallow or spit it out. You have to use a knife to remove it. After you get all the grain out, comment on the surplus of grain.
ReadingMnemonic: The surplus is thanks to the hard work of folks like Joe (じょう), the big farmhand. He worked hard to make sure there was a surplus of grain this year. Remember how Joe made the soil better? Perhaps this is some of that work paying off. Thanks to that and everything else, there is a great surplus.

Name: Tolerance
Mnemonic: The roof flowers see everything. But, they only see. That is because they learned the art of tolerance. These roof flowers only see because they do not judge. They accept everything. We humans can learn a thing or two about tolerance from these roof flowers.
ReadingMnemonic: Tolerance is one thing that Genghis Khan (かん) had a surprising amount of. You wouldn't expect it, but he actually allowed many types of cultures, religions, and peoples to exist under his reign. The Mongols had an exceptional amount of tolerance for the time.

Name: Also
Mnemonic: If you want to wear a top hat you also have to wear a suit to go with it. You can't just wear a top hat, that just doesn't look right. When you think top hat, think about what you also need with it. Picture all the things you also need. A suit, a tie, a monocle, some shiny shoes. There's also ... something... else. What is it?
ReadingMnemonic: You have a top hat and all the clothes that go with it but you also need a nice car (か) too! You can't just get all dressed up and then have no way to get anywhere to show it off. Think about all the things you also need when you wear a top hat. The car is probably the most important addition. Otherwise no one can see the top hat in the first place!

Name: Appear
Mnemonic: When the sun comes up the spikes of geoducks appear. The spikes don't just come out of the geoduck, they literally appear out of thin air. They didn't even exist before the sun touched them.
ReadingMnemonic: You watch these spikes appear and suddenly Ken (けん)the samurai also appears next to you. "I DID IT!" he shouts, "I've learned how to appear out of thin air!" "Thank you sweet geoduck, you have taught me the way of appearing with your spikes."

Name: Apricot
Mnemonic: What does a tree make that you'd want to put in your mouth? An apricot! Apricots are also about the size of an open mouth, so they kind of look like mouths hanging down under the trees. You can bite them right off the tree with your own mouth! Picture the mouth sized apricots hanging down off the tree. Imagine using your own mouth to bite them down. Just don't swallow the pit!
ReadingMnemonic: After you put the apricot in your mouth you realize that this tastes really familiar, but not pleasant. It tastes just like the anchovies (あん) from the zoo (ず) smell. How did that happen? You don't like apricots anymore. Imagine trying to eat the bite sized apricot and spitting it out after the taste of anchovies from the zoo fill you up.

Name: Bookmark
Mnemonic: Dry an already dry tree to create a bookmark. The more you dry the tree, the flatter it becomes, making it the perfect way to mark your spot in a book without needing to fold a page or write on it. To be fair, books are just dry trees in a way, but bookmarks are actually dry, dry trees that have flattened out and turned into chunks.
ReadingMnemonic: What are you bookmarking anyway? Look down and see yourself putting one of the tree bookmarks on a page in your notebook that says "She owes me reeds (しおり)." Oh yeah, you had to make this bookmark in the first place because your friend took your reed bookmarks and didn't give them back. What does she owe you? Open the page to your bookmark and see she owes reeds!

Name: Column
Mnemonic: You see a bunch of trees lined up outside of the gate to the east and realize they look like perfect columns. It seems like a building or a castle should be resting above them. Picture these column trees outside the gate to the east. You end up drawing them in the columns of your graph paper because they fit so well.
ReadingMnemonic: Out of the tree columns bursts professional wrestler Randy (らん) Savage! "Oooh I'm talking about columns that I like mmmm oh yeaah. The Macho Man loves columns MMm OOHH YEAAH~!" Now draw Randy Savage in the columns on your graph paper. He just seems to fit there now.

Name: Common
Mnemonic: Who goes into their yurt to boil things? The common people! All sorts of people do it, it's really common. You don't boil things outside, do you? Wait, you're telling me you didn't know it's common to boil things in yurts? Excuse me?
ReadingMnemonic: Here, the common people all do this, so just let me show (しょ) you how. First you go into your yurt, and… Hey, pay attention and watch what I'm showing you! Okay, now that I've shown you what to do, you can fit in with the common people here.

Name: Crown
Mnemonic: Your forehead is the origin for the measurement for your crown! If you measure somewhere else on your head for a crown it won't fit. Imagine someone putting a tape measure around your forehead and taking careful measurements for your crown. They better not mess up, or you'll have them put to death!
ReadingMnemonic: You want your crown to be just like Genghis Khan's (かん), which was more of a cap. He's your hero though, because he ruled over the most people, so you want yours to match his measurements. Why don't you go look up what Genghis Khan's crown/cap looked like. Then try to imagine how it would look atop your head.

Name: Cruel
Mnemonic: If you announce that alcohol is illegal you're just being cruel. Honestly, saying no one can have any alcohol at all is totally unjust. They tried that in the 1920s and it didn't work then either, so cut it out! Let people drink what they want to drink! Imagine if your country's leader announced that there would be no more alcohol. People would be in the streets in seconds calling them cruel and unjust!
ReadingMnemonic: After this cruel announcement is made everyone will turn to the next best thing after alcohol. Coke (こく)! It's not a replacement, but if this unjust law won't change, then coke sales are going to go through the roof. Imagine drinking coke while complaining how unjust it is that you can't add rum to it.

Name: Describe
Mnemonic: The surplus stool, please describe it. You have a surplus (extra) stool, and someone wants it. But, they need to know more about it, so you describe it in great detail. Imagine yourself doing just that. Every screw and nubbin is described.
ReadingMnemonic: You describe the features of the stool to Jo-Anne (じょ). Jo-Anne is really excited about this stool. It's the perfect height for her (remember, she's on the shorter side to distinguish じょ from じょう). She pays attention to you describing the stool while sitting on it and spinning around. Have her ask for you to describe it more.

Name: Deviate
Mnemonic: Jump on a scooter to excuse yourself from answering a question and you've successfully deviated from that nosey person's plan! You've also been able to elude them pretty well. Imagine excusing yourself by scooting away on a scooter. If they want to get your answer, they'll have to chase you.
ReadingMnemonic: You deviate from the plan a little too well, and as you're scooting, what you've done eats (いつ) away at you. You feel guilty for eluding them... Welp, it's too late to turn back now. You've already deviated pretty far, and you're not even sure where you are now. You were too busy trying to elude that person that you didn't look where your scooter was taking you.

Name: Family Crest
Mnemonic: You use thread and writing to sew our family crest. You've been sewing your family crest since you were a kid, you could do it today with your eyes closed. Imagine the thread slowly forming the writing that makes up your family crest. You're making a scarf with your crest on it. It's like a wizarding school house symbol.
ReadingMnemonic: Your family crest is of a monster! (もん) And the writing says "Our Family Monster." What kind of monster is on your family crest? Picture it in your mind right now. Now tweet to us @wanikaniapp because I really want to know what you came up with!!

Name: Flatter
Mnemonic: You see a building with a lip ring and it's just so cute you have to flatter it. "That lip ring looks wonderful on you, Buildingさん," you say. Flattering buildings is just as nice as flattering people, as long as they're okay with it.
ReadingMnemonic: The building is flattered and you hear it shout, "Ah (あ)!" and blush. The entire building turns red. The "ah" the building made was actually quite loud, and since you've never heard a building speak before, it scared you pretty bad. But at least you know the building was flattered by your compliment (I think.)

Name: Foolish
Mnemonic: If you give Splinter your heart you'll feel pretty foolish afterwards. His heart belongs to the art of ninjutsu! You were foolish to give your heart away to Splinter. He didn't want it. Also he's a rat, what's wrong with you?
ReadingMnemonic: Splinter tells you to your face how foolish you are and you feel your heart turn to goo (ぐ). Now you can't even give it to someone else. No one wants goo. What will you do with your foolish goo heart now?

Name: Furthermore
Mnemonic: A triceratops with a mustache will go on talking forever. Every time you think he's done he says, "Furthermore..." and keeps going. Something about a mustache on a dinosaur makes him kind of a jerk, but he's held in such high esteem that no one ever interrupts him. Imagine this mustachioed triceratops. He probably has a monocle and a fedora too. Every time you think you can talk or leave he says, "Furthermore" again. Come on guy, how much do you have to say?
ReadingMnemonic: Why don't you just interrupt this mustache triceratops while he's saying furthermore? Because he's the Shougun's (しょう) pet. If you interrupt him you'll probably be put to death or something. Just let him keep going and hope he runs out of furthermores to talk about. "Furthermore!" the mustachioed triceratops points at the Shougun, "He is the best Shougun we'll ever have. And he'll let me talk forever OH OH OH!"

Name: Kidnap
Mnemonic: A mouth with a sword is threatening to cut off your fingers because they've kidnapped you! You can't see anything about them, since they're all covered up. All you see is their angry mouth and the sword they keep putting near your fingers. Imagine you've been kidnapped. And the person who kidnapped you is going to cut off some of your fingers and mail them to your parents if they don't pay the ransom soon enough. You don't want your fingers to be cut off with a sword! Help!
ReadingMnemonic: You've been kidnapped and your kidnapper has asked for one thing in exchange for your safe return: a kayak (かい). Kayaks are expensive. And it's way easier for this dude to kidnap you and demand your family buy one and give it to them than for them to work for one. If your parents don't send in the kayak to your kidnapper soon, you're gonna lose some fingers. Come on guys, just get the kayak already!!!

Name: Leisure
Mnemonic: The leader who usually hits you with a stick in winter finds it in his heart to give you some leisure time. You fall to your knees, "Oh thank you for not hitting me with your stick and letting me relax!" You haven't had a moment of leisure in ages!
ReadingMnemonic: You're just about to start your leisure time when a group of youths (ゆう) appears with their own sticks. You look back for the leader, and he's wearing a bathrobe, sunglasses, and is drinking some hot cocoa. Wait... this is leisure time for... HIM?! OH NO! As the leader leisurely watches, the youths smack you with their sticks. What a cruel world! "Enjoy your leisure time," the leader yells over, "the youths hit much softer than I do. Have fun!"

Name: Merit
Mnemonic: You're in a really important position, heavy with power, but you can't carry all of that around with you, so you boil it all down to just a few merits. Most people in places heavy with power, like the scouts, boil down all of their responsibilities and accomplishments this way into merit badges.
ReadingMnemonic: The only problem with consolidating your merits like this is that raccoons (くん) are always trying to steal them. Raccoons really like shiny, small things. Like, say, the physical representation of all your personal and professional merits. This is why you never see a military officer or a girl scout leaving their merit badges out in the open. They pin them right onto their clothes. Otherwise the raccoons would come.

Name: Neglect
Mnemonic: A coat rack will turn into a bundle of sticks if you neglect it. When you neglect a coat rack, the weight from the coats will pull all of the arms off, leaving it as a sparse stick. Picture this sparse, neglected coat rack. All of its arms and the coats that were on it have fallen off and are in a big pile on the ground.
ReadingMnemonic: You go up to the neglected coat rack and try to make things right by cleaning it with soap (そ). But no matter how much you scrub, it won't get clean, the arms won't go back on. If you neglect something for too long, not even a good soap scrub will bring it back. That goes for humans too. Take care of yourselves. Use soap.

Name: Noh Chanting
Mnemonic: Whatever you say through a satellite turns into Noh chanting. It gets all drawn out and distorted from going through the satellite, which makes it SOUND like Noh chanting at least. Say whatever you want and send it up to the satellite. Now imagine listening to it when it comes back and hearing beautiful, deep Noh chanting back!
ReadingMnemonic: While you're fake Noh chanting you have to pause every few minutes to take a bite of yogurt (よう). Yogurt is good for the throat! At least you think it is. It's not like you're actually chanting, the satellite is doing all the real work. Watch closely the next time you go to a Noh play. See the man Noh chanting? Watch close enough and you'll see him eat a scoop of yogurt every once in a while.

Name: Planting
Mnemonic: A drunkard gets his hands on a plow and starts planting right away. Drunk people are surprisingly good at planting, especially when they have machines to help them do it. Picture a drunk guy laughing and plowing a field and planting seeds. He wouldn't do this if he was sober, but drunk people can't help themselves.
ReadingMnemonic: He keeps planting and planting... a little too much. You walk over and realize this drunkard isn't just any guy... he's YOUR CYBORG (さい)! Oh my sweet cyborg child! Is this what they've done with you? You're just a drunkard who's only good for planting? Nooooooo!!

Name: Practice
Mnemonic: You put your foot on the bar at the gymnasium at your very first practice. That's a big accomplishment since you're here learning how to walk on that long bar like all the cool gymnasts. But you can't just start right away, you need lots of practice so that's why you're here in this class. But so far you got your foot on the bar already, good for you! Picture your foot touching the bar. This is it. This is exactly what you're at this gym to practice.
ReadingMnemonic: This type of practice is especially hard for you because you're a centaur (せん). You only have hooves for feet, and balancing on a bar is going to be a huge hurdle. But your teacher promised if you practiced enough you could make it, and here you are! With your hoofed foot on the bar! Picture your centaur foot on the bar as you practice to become a gymnast. It's going to take years and years of this kind of practice, but you're sure you'll make it all the way up there some day! Never give up!

Name: Present
Mnemonic: The Mouth King, who is just one big mouth, has one skill, and that is to present. That big mouth is always presenting something. Imagine the Mouth King giving a presentation about the importance of mouths. His subjects all flatter him by saying, "Please, please, present to us about mouths again! We truuuuuuly love it!"
ReadingMnemonic: "I will present to you a presentation about mouths, but I require energy. Please fill my giant mouth body with delicious tater (てい) tots. You pour a bucket of tater tots into his mouth body and he continues his presentation about mouths. "You see, mouths are just orifices..."

Name: Proud
Mnemonic: Your leader managed to find the right direction home using marks in the dirt in the middle of winter. This makes you so proud! You're proud because this resourceful leader is YOUR resourceful leader. Imagine how proud you and your whole country feel as your leader comes trudging in through the snow. He made it home. You're (sniff) so (sob) proud!
ReadingMnemonic: This leader you're so proud of is none other than Grandpa ごういち. He's been getting a bit slow over the years, and you really didn't think he'd make it back. But, by gum, he did it. Let's be honest here, Grandpa ごういち isn't getting any younger. You really should be proud of him for surviving this long at all.

Name: Rapidly
Mnemonic: A sickness that hits you like an arrow will do its gross work rapidly. It's not a good thing, you're gonna get really sick really fast. Picture this rapid sickness spreading through your body like a cartoon arrow ricocheting through your body. Yuck!
ReadingMnemonic: This rapid sickness makes your head pound like there's a shih tzu (しつ) yapping and barking nonstop. And it's making you sh*t a lot. Imagine getting sick this rapidly. All of a sudden, there's a shih tzu barking in your head, it hurts! And... oh no, where's the toilet?!

Name: Repay
Mnemonic: You took someone's alcohol and drop drop drop'd it all into the river. Now you have to repay them. Alcohol costs a lot of money, you know. Picture yourself dropping the alcohol, drop by drop, into the river. Uh oh, the person just caught up to you, so you better repay them.
ReadingMnemonic: In order to repay them for the alcohol you wasted, you offer to give them your shoes (しゅう). They don't want your shoes though, so you have to bring them to a store and watch them try on a bunch of different pairs so you can repay them that way. Imagine waiting as this person tries on like twenty different pairs of shoes. They're getting them for free! Why do they have to be picky?! Just let me repay you already!

Name: Rose Madder
Mnemonic: What kind of flowers grow in the west? Rose madder flowers, of course. Don't know what those are? That's okay. Just know their roots are used to make dyes of a deep red color. Red like the rose in their name, but madder, wilder, deeper… And they grow in the west so they can take in those deep red colors of the setting sun. Picture yourself sitting in the west as the red sun sets, smashing those little rose madder roots into a paste to make your deep red dyes. Your fingers turn red from the rose madder too.
ReadingMnemonic: As you smash the roots of the rose madder and stain your fingers a deep red, a little girl comes up to you and points. She says, "赤ね (あかね)?" (That's red, right?) You look down at the rose madder roots and your fingers, and nod. She's right, it is red. Deep red. Hear the little girl say あかね while pointing at the rose madder and your deep red fingers. She's right. And the way she says it is so darn cute.

Name: Shock
Mnemonic: You see a mouth coming out of the top of a tree so you go into shock. Your brain just can't comprehend what's in front of you. A tree... with... a... mouth? No, it can't be... I... a-. Your face warps into a permanent state of shock.
ReadingMnemonic: The shock you've suffered results in you needing to stay home (ほう) from now on. You don't get to travel, explore, or even get groceries. You're homebound from now on, buddy. I'd be shocked if you ever left your home again, honestly. But hey, there's always anime.

Name: Sickle
Mnemonic: You cast the Mona Lisa in gold and attach it to a stick to turn it into a sickle! It's really big and bulky, but when you swing it fast enough your new sickle cuts lots of wheat! Just don't tell anyone what you did with the famous Mona Lisa painting and you should be able to get away with this! Imagine wielding your gold Mona Lisa sickle. It's sooo heavy, but it's really shiny and it cuts grass and wheat pretty well!
ReadingMnemonic: Now that you've turned the Mona Lisa into a sickle, you have to change the little description under its name in the Louvre. You draw a giant comma (かま) next to "Mona Lisa" and write "THE SICKLE." Then you shove it back on the wall as best you can. Hear all the guests say, "Mona Lisa... comma the sickle? WHAT'S HAPPENED HERE?!" As panic ensues. You like your addition and you're very proud.

Name: Solemn
Mnemonic: A wolverine that sticks its legs in rice will become very solemn, very fast. This is weird to you because wolverines always seem so happy. Well his dad died from his legs getting stuck in rice, so just leave the poor solemn creature alone. Imagine if your dad died from getting his legs stuck in some rice, now feel solemn too.
ReadingMnemonic: Remember how solemn wolverine looked when his dad died? You hated seeing him like this so you ran up and shook (しゅく) him. You shook the solemn sadness right out of him! You should do that again now! Imagine seeing how violently you shook him. You shook him so hard his solemn mood disappeared!

Name: Stem
Mnemonic: When you leave flowers on a tombstone they look good at first, but after a few days or some harsh weather, there's nothing left but stems. That's why you have to replace flowers on tombstones all the time. If you don't it will look like you only left the stems there, and that's pretty disrespectful. Imagine being in a graveyard looking at all the tombstones and seeing nothing but stems on all of them. All the pretty flowery parts have died and blown away.
ReadingMnemonic: You have an idea that can make these tombstones look better than just having leftover stems all over them. You brought cookies (くき)! Cookies don't fall apart in the wind, and everyone loves cookies, alive or dead. You replace the stems with the cookies and everything looks a lot nicer. Look at all the cookie covered tombstones. Now your bag is full of stems, but you can use them to make more cookies to bring back next time. Don't worry, nobody eats them. Stem cookies are probably poisonous.

Name: Stupid
Mnemonic: You're sick because you put an arrow in your mouth and tried to eat it. To be honest, that's just really stupid. You have to be stupid to try to eat an arrow. You deserve to be sick. How stupid do you have to be to put arrows into your mouth until it makes you sick? Pretty darn stupid, it seems.
ReadingMnemonic: The only way to cure this serious case of stupid is to make you eat cheese (ち). Not only will it fix your sick stomach by cushioning all the arrows that you shoved in your stupid mouth, but it should send smart cheese waves to your brain and cure you of that stupid all together. Imagine if everyone knew that cheese cures the stupid out of people. Then maybe we would have more cheese and less stupid in the world!

Name: Suckle
Mnemonic: After your wedding you have a baby and it uses its mouth to suckle from your post-wedding boobs. Yes, babies nurse from breasts. Get over it, kids. You waited until your wedding to have your baby and all it seems to do with its mouth is suckle. It doesn't cry, which is nice, but it doesn't laugh or talk either.
ReadingMnemonic: The baby wants to nurse all day and the only thing you can seem to do at the same time is hoe (ほ) your garden. You hold the baby to your breast with one arm and hoe little rows with the other. It's actually a great workout and a nice way to spend time! This hoe has really helped you get through nursing. You think you'll keep this up even after your baby is weaned! Hoeing the garden is your new favorite hobby!

Name: Villa
Mnemonic: Clearing his flowers of icicles, the samurai returns home to his villa. Picture the samurai's villa. It's in the countryside and covered in flowers and icicles. Even though it's spring, it's still cold, so all the new flowers are very cold.
ReadingMnemonic: Once the samurai enters the villa, he lets his soul (そう) go. He's been fighting for long enough and this villa was always where he wanted to go. Picture the samurai sitting in a chair in his beautiful villa and breathing his last breath. His soul slowly floats up and out of his still body and dances around the villa, free.

Name: Whale
Mnemonic: If you travel to the fish capital, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty whale! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all. Picture the underwater fish capital. Statues of whales line the fishy streets, and all of the fish bow down to the whale ruler's giant body.
ReadingMnemonic: The whale who resides over the capital just happens to be gay (げい). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay. Picture the gay whale ruler holding whale hands... fins? with his whale husband. They're so cute.

Name: Wholesale
Mnemonic: You should stop to buy stamps at noon because that's the only time they're being sold at wholesale price. Everyone's so busy eating and working and being at school, that they miss this awesome deal, but not you. Everyday at noon you stock up on wholesale stamps. Do you send a lot of mail? No, you probably just collect them. But they were cheap, so who cares! Imagine yourself stopping at the empty bank at noon, grabbing a handful of wholesale stamps. So many stamps. So few extra charges.
ReadingMnemonic: Oh, one more thing. Going at noon isn't enough, you have to say the password to get them at wholesale price too. The password is "Oh Roshi" (おろし). Okay, so maybe that's just the name of the guy there, but it always works when I want to get stamps wholesale so you should do it too! "Oh Roshi" you say carefully as you hand your stamps over at noon. The guy raises an eyebrow at you, but gives you them wholesale! It worked!

Name: Doubt
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means doubt.

Name: Feeling
Mnemonic: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means feeling.

Name: Accumulate
Mnemonic: You start growing thread in your rice paddy to accumulate more. You didn't want to have to buy any, so you're just trying to grow thread with your rice. That seems like a good way to accumulate more to you. Just imagine how much thread you'll accumulate if you can just grow it along with your rice in the rice paddy! So much thread!
ReadingMnemonic: Sadly, this is a terrible way to accumulate anything thread related and you ended up ruining (るい) your rice paddy too. I guess if you want to accumulate thread this isn't the way to do it. Your attempts to accumulate more of something by cheating have brought ruin to everything else you were doing. Nice job, dummy.

Name: Bow
Mnemonic: When you meet the leader dog you have to bow to show your respect. Dogs are pretty great, so the leader of all dogs must be the greatest! You should bow really deeply to this one. Picture yourself bowing to the leader dog. Leader dog is so cool!
ReadingMnemonic: You bow as low as you can, but you lose your balance and fall over. "F**k you (ふく)!" the leader dog barks. Oh no. You messed up and now the leader dog is super mad. Saying f**k you is a little harsh for falling over though, you think. Bow even deeper as the dog leader keeps barking what sounds like f**k you. You're pretty sure that's what he's saying at least... but maybe... maybe it's not.

Name: Captive
Mnemonic: When a man meets a tiger he makes the tiger his captive. Men are pretty crappy like that. They see tigers and they want to put them in cages, so the poor tiger becomes a captive of the man. Picture the sad tiger captive and the man laughing as he pokes at it. Tigers shouldn't be captives but when men find them they always seem to do this anyway.
ReadingMnemonic: The captive tiger is even sadder because the man put him in a robe (りょ) and is making him act like a human. Tigers look good in robes, but they don't really enjoy being forced into people clothing. Picture the poor captive tiger being stuffed into a bathrobe and paraded around a cage for the man.

Name: Circulation
Mnemonic: If you want to loiter on a cliff with the pope you better be ready to move in perfect circulation with him. The pope is wearing really heavy robes and it's hot up here on this cliff, so you both need to walk in circles to keep cool. Imagine this strange circulation of you and the pope up here on a cliff. It's not even like you two are up here for a reason, you're just loitering. But he doesn't want to be hot so he makes you circulate with him.
ReadingMnemonic: This circulation wouldn't have to even be happening if it wasn't June (じゅん). The cliffs are so hot in June, and in any other month the two of you would have just sat down and had a chat. But in June you have to do this weird circulation dance. "This circulation is all June's fault," you mutter, walking in a circle with the pope to stay cool.

Name: Coarse
Mnemonic: If you find some rice in a top hat it's going to be really coarse and rough. Probably because it's not the kind that's meant to be eaten. Imagine trying to eat the rice you found in a top hat. It's so coarse it feels like it's scratching your teeth. There's probably some dirt in here too. This wasn't the best idea.
ReadingMnemonic: You take the coarse rice and try to wash it with soap (そ). If you were trying to make this coarse rice taste like soap, you did it. But if you were trying to make it less coarse, well... sorry, but that's not how anything works.

Name: Congeal
Mnemonic: If you try to turn something into ice while having doubts, it will just congeal instead. It will freeze, but it will get kinda yucky too. Your doubts will affect the ice-making process, so try not to be so worried and unsure next time you want normal ice. Imagine looking over water in an ice cube tray. You aren't sure if they'll turn out alright, and you doubt whether ice is even a thing. As you think this, the water congeals and freezes into gross shapes.
ReadingMnemonic: You always end up congealing your gyoza (ぎょう) this way. You want to freeze your leftover gyoza so you can enjoy it later, but you doubt it will turn out all right and it always congeals in a gross, half-frozen gyoza block. Yuck! Picture frozen, congealed gyoza. Do you want to eat that? I didn't think so.

Name: Cork
Mnemonic: The king has a hat that's made from a tree but the more you look at it, the more it looks like it's just a big cork. It's a big, wooden plug that he's just placed on his head. It can hardly be called a hat. Picture how silly the king looks with this cork on his head. He kind of looks like a fat, plugged up bottle of wine when he yells now.
ReadingMnemonic: It turned out this cork hat was given to him by a centaur (せん). You look into it and it turned out it IS a really big cork that centaurs use on their big wine casks. But the king didn't understand, and thought it was a hat. The centaurs are probably still laughing. Picture the centaurs drinking and giggling, putting the cork from their wine on their head to imitate the stupid king.

Name: Crystal
Mnemonic: The king of the flowers in the center (of England, if you remember) has a special crystal. The king crystal. Picture the king holding this crystal aloft, giggling as the sun shines through it and sparkles.
ReadingMnemonic: The king thinks everyone wants his crystal so he hides it in the giant acorn (えい) in the center of the flowers in England. There's a tiny hole in the bottom of the acorn, and that's where this crystal stays hidden. Imagine going to England, to the giant acorn in the center of the flowers, and searching for the king's crystal. If you find it, you can probably sell it for a fortune! Or just make a really sweet necklace.

Name: Dawn
Mnemonic: The dawn radical and the dawn kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
ReadingMnemonic: Dawn is dawn (だん)! It's also a great time to get a tan (たん). The sun is bright at dawn, but not so much that it will send skin cancer rays into you. Imagine getting a tan at dawn. Ahh. Relaxing and warm.

Name: Dedicate
Mnemonic: When spring is dry you need to dedicate your time and effort somewhere else. You can't plant flowers or vegetables, it's too dry. You can't play outside, your skin will flake. So you need to dedicate yourself to something inside. You know how you get. When you can't go outside, you dedicate yourself full force into something else. I mean, you made it to level 55, right? That's some serious dedication. And it probably started because of one particularly dry spring.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to dedicate yourself to your home (ほう). You don't want to be outside in the dry spring air, so you focus on home activities. You can clean the kitchen, build a shelf, or dedicate your time to your home internet system. Dedicate yourself to doing things in your home! Haha, who are we kidding, you already did that.

Name: Distant
Mnemonic: You got off your scooter to load some charcoal onto it, when it suddenly took off to a distant place! That's some powerful charcoal. Your scooter is charcoal powered, but it looks like you put too much in there and it drove off somewhere distant without you. If you look really carefully, you can just see it, a distant speck on the horizon.
ReadingMnemonic: You chase the scooter to that distant place, but then you see it heading for a lake. Oh good, it should be stopped by the water. But wait! In the distance you see your scooter drive onto a row (りょう) boat and... row itself through the water?! No!! You can still make out the distant shape of your scooter, now on a row boat, fading away and completely out of reach.

Name: Enclosure
Mnemonic: You just received a building, so you want to surround it with an enclosure. Imagine the building you just received. You want to protect it, so you get started on that enclosure. Imagine building your enclosure with your bare hands.
ReadingMnemonic: The enclosure felt a  bit quiet and lonely, so you decided to get yourself a pet cock (かく). Your pet cock is the perfect addition to your new enclosure. Just look at it, pecking happily between the enclosure and that building you received.

Name: Erase
Mnemonic: Put your fingers in a jet if you want to erase them from existence. You aren't just chopping or burning them off. There's like, no trace of them at all. Your parents can't even remember if you were born with fingers or not. Jets are that powerful. Imagine your fingers slowly getting closer and closer to the jet's engine. It feels like it's going to suck your whole body in. And you better watch out, because if it does you'll be erased from the planet. And probably from time itself.
ReadingMnemonic: You're almost done erasing your fingers when the jet starts sucking all of you in. You would try to grab the closest thing to you, but your fingers don't exist anymore, so you hold onto the mats (まつ) at your feet with your toes. The mats are super strong (they're made for jets, after all) and you manage to save yourself! Now you're so thankful to the mats. If they weren't there you might have erased your whole body! Thank you mats! I'll never walk on you without thanking you for your service again!

Name: Excellent
Mnemonic: A leader gets double the dirt to build on if he's the most excellent and most skilled of all the leaders. You don't think dirt is so great? Well what if I took the dirt you own away from you? Your house is on that dirt. It's mine now. Get outta here. Imagine being so excellent at leading, that you get double the dirt that everyone else gets.
ReadingMnemonic: This excellent leader is going to use all this dirt to store her excellent cars (か)! Excellent people have to have cars in equal or greater than excellent-ness than themselves. Imagine your own car. Is it as excellent as you?

Name: Frugal
Mnemonic: Your soul long ago was very frugal, which is why you get to have too much in this life! Thank you soul, for being frugal so that I can have so much now.
ReadingMnemonic: You know what being frugal is? Sexy (せき). You save money, you use less resources, that's the sexiest thing I can think of. If you want your spouse or S.O. to think you're more sexy, just be more frugal. They'll definitely appreciate it and see you in a different light.

Name: Grief
Mnemonic: A hundred foreheads lower themselves to their hearts in winter in grief. There were once many of their kind, the forehead peoples, but now there are only a hundred left after this harsh winter took the rest of them. Their grief is immense. Imagine if winter was so brutal that there were only one hundred human foreheads left. You lost all of your friends and family. Feel that grief.
ReadingMnemonic: Their grief intensifies because all of the foreheads they lost belonged to youths (ゆう). Dead youths everywhere. Now there's no one left to repopulate the world. Grief for youths is so painful. No one should have to bury their forehead child.

Name: Grieve
Mnemonic: The soul in your toe leaves early. You grieve and mourn for your now-dead toe. Look at your toe. It has no soul. It's dark and shriveled, like a mummy's toe. Grieve and watch your tears drip onto it.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to grieve in とうきょう. Your toe always wanted to walk in とうきょう, and now you can at least fulfill its dying wish. Walk through the streets of とうきょう grieving, with your dead toe flopping onto the pavement.

Name: Healing
Mnemonic: The sick Death Star needs its heart cured. If it doesn't get healing soon, it will die. Maybe the Death Star wouldn't be sick if it wasn't so mean to you, yelling at you for living in a yurt, when it was a yurt on the inside the whole time. Wait! I know the cure!
ReadingMnemonic: You realized that the only way to cure the Death Star is to turn it back into a yurt (ゆ). Then it won't be able to do any more harm, and its outside will reflect its pleasant self on the inside! Hmm, but does this type of yurt healing technology exist?! You'll have to find out to cure it!!

Name: Horse Chestnut
Mnemonic: You see a tree growing on a cliff and it has ten thousand horse chestnuts growing on it. These trees are rare, only grow on cliffs, and they always have exactly ten thousand horse chestnuts on each one. Picture this tree, weighed down by it's own horse chestnuts, leaning over the edge of the cliff.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to take a bite of a horse chestnut because it looks yummy, and there are ten thousand, so it's not like anyone will notice. You crack it open and take a nice big bite to find out that it tastes like toe cheese (とち)! UHG! It's the worst thing you've ever tasted. Like hot, moldy toe cheese! Ewwww! Horse chestnuts taste like nasty toe cheese. Imagine what having one in your mouth would be like.

Name: Imperial
Mnemonic: The imperial radical and the imperial kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo! Make sure you remember this radical means imperial and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
ReadingMnemonic: Who is the coolest imperial you know? Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. Wait what? You mean he FIGHTS imperials? Oh, okay. Looks like Ryu is the coolest imperial FIGHTER you know! Picture Ryu kicking the butts of imperial  scum like Bison and Darth Vader.

Name: Increasing
Mnemonic: Go from a bow to a small gun and you're increasing in fire power! Even though the gun is small, it's still a step up from a bow. Imagine increasing your power with a new weapon. What would it be?
ReadingMnemonic: You keep trading in weapons to get increasingly stronger gear, when you realize that at the top of the list is... a Yankee's (や) baseball bat? Huh. I would have gone for a tank or a bazooka. But I guess if this will increase your power level, you have to go for it. Imagine walking down a line of weapons, each one increasing in power from the one before it. Bow, small gun, bigger gun, tank, Yankee's bat. Yup, that sounds right.

Name: Marrow
Mnemonic: Your bones have a scooter that moves through the bone marrow inside them. If you think about it, bone marrow is really just a road for tiny blood scooters.
ReadingMnemonic: If you put your ear really close to a bone with marrow still in it, you'll hear the scooters going zuwee (ずい) as they move the blood around inside there.
