Name: Clumsy
Mnemonic: You have to use your fingers to make an exit because you're so clumsy. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the knob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave. Of course, you're too clumsy to do that right either, you accidentally threw the door backwards and hurt some people...
ReadingMnemonic: After you make your clumsy mistake you realize that these doors come in sets (せつ). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors! Imagine trying to use your clumsy fingers all over the sets of doors. You keep falling over and hurting yourself. Why is it so hard to leave?!

Name: Compose
Mnemonic: If you want to say how eternity sounds you have to compose a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. Recite those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it. Try to compose a poem about eternity right now. Just jot it down somewhere.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to compose a poem about an acorn (えい). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you. Let me recite the acorn poem to you now:

Name: Congratulate
Mnemonic: If a pilot manages to land under a canopy with a helicopter that's pierced with a sideways barb in the heart of winter you should congratulate them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of! Can you imagine how difficult landing a helicopter is in just one of these horrible conditions? Congratulate them!
ReadingMnemonic: Congratulate the pilot with cake (けい)! Cake is always the appropriate celebratory food.

Name: Dairy
Mnemonic: You can only give a kiss of alcohol to dairy. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh. Imagine trying to give more than a kiss of alcohol to dairy and watch it bubble and curdle and get all gross and chunky.
ReadingMnemonic: Dairy isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a rack (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away! Look at all your dairy products: milk, yogurt, cheese, all of it sitting nicely on your dairy rack.

Name: Deliberate
Mnemonic: If someone makes a bamboo horse, you know it's deliberate. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo. Someone sat down and deliberately planned the entire horse out, collected the materials, and made it by hand.
ReadingMnemonic: As you admire all the deliberate details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions." Tokugawa Ieyasu then poofs out of existence and so does the bamboo horse.

Name: Despise
Mnemonic: Every leader will come to despise their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it. Imagine yourself as a leader who's come to despise every single one of their followers. Look down at them in disgust as they ask you to grant them all a pony.
ReadingMnemonic: The more you despise them, the more booze (ぶ) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people. This is not a healthy way to handle things! If you despise someone you should talk to them, don't turn to booze. Don't be like every leader that's come before you.

Name: Endure
Mnemonic: If there is dirt in a crab trap, it's a lot for the crabs to endure. Imagine a little crab getting stuck in a crab trap with dirt and other crabs. Endure the horror as long as you can, little friend.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to make the little crab that endured being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a collar (こら) round its little neck. Imagine yourself putting a collar around the crab's neck, then adding a leash and taking your crab for a walk around your neighborhood.

Name: Evil
Mnemonic: A spirit wearing two mustaches must be evil. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil. Look at the evil spirit with two mustaches on its spirit face. Imagine its face in detail, especially those mustaches.
ReadingMnemonic: You're watching the evil mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your car (か). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil! Imagine running around, flailing your arms, trying to get the spirit to stop ruining your car. But your hands go right through him and his two mustaches. You can't stop his evil doings.

Name: Female
Mnemonic: If you can stop a turkey by putting a spoon in its face you'll know it's a female turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay. Picture the female turkey stopping when it sees you holding out a spoon. Why are you doing that human? it thinks. Are you sick?
ReadingMnemonic: The female turkey then runs around making a mess (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried. Imagine watching a female turkey make a mess of her own cage because she thinks you need help. How sweet.

Name: Friendly
Mnemonic: If you see someone eyeing your womb you're probably going to be weirded out by how friendly they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first. Imagine having someone you aren't friendly with trying to have a look at your womb. No thank you.
ReadingMnemonic: This friendly guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "ぼく-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out. Imagine only letting this guy start to introduce himself with ぼく before walking the heck outta there. Just because he was acting friendly doesn't mean he was actually your friend.

Name: Guts
Mnemonic: If you stay up so long that you see the moon go down and the dawn come, people will say you have serious guts. It takes guts to stay up that late. More specifically, it takes a powerful gallbladder. Your gallbladder is sensitive to sleep changes, you know, so you risk a lot by staying up like that. Imagine the guts you'd need to have to stay up so late that you see the moon and the sun switch places! And to risk gallbladder damage?! That takes guts!
ReadingMnemonic: You stayed awake outside for so long, just to prove you had guts and powerful gallbladder, that you also got a sweet tan (たん) out of it! Imagine the deep tan you'd get after staying awake outside for such a long time. Tanning is also bad for your gallbladder! Man, you've really got guts to be getting tans like that.

Name: Imitate
Mnemonic: You try to use your fingers to cast doubt on people by using them to imitate each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others. Picture your angry friend standing up next to your fingers, shouting, "I'm the real me! That's just an imitation!" The rest of your friends look nervously at each other. They doubt this person is real now.
ReadingMnemonic: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to imitate is the imitation now and they have them in a guillotine (ぎ). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation. Okay, so that's a lie, Your fingers are definitely imitating them, but you don't want to end up in the guillotine so you keep your mouth shut.

Name: Japanese Birch
Mnemonic: What kind of tree is spicy? A Japanese birch, or birch, obviously. There's nothing spicier than a Japanese birch! Imagine licking the trunk of a Japanese birch tree and feeling the heat on your tongue.
ReadingMnemonic: You can only cut down a Japanese birch using a zoo saw (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these trees are. Imagine using a zoo saw to cut down a Japanese birch tree. What's a zoo saw? It's a saw that's used in zoos, to build all the animal enclosures. And to cut down spicy trees.

Name: Lacquer
Mnemonic: A tsunami hits a tree and your hat protects you from the water, but the hat itself is now covered in lacquer. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected. Picture your hat and all of the other things the tsunami + tree water touched. It's all been hardened with a thick coating of the lacquer.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to scoop up the rest of the lacquer water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your shih tzu (しつ). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore! Watch as your shih tzu tries to bite your now lacquered chair. It gets its teeth around the leg, but it's hard as a rock. The shih tzu starts sneezing and spitting, letting go. Looks like it tastes bad too. Perfect!

Name: Leisure
Mnemonic: You see a gate with a tree growing through it and it reminds you that you need more leisure time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used. Imagine spending your leisure time curled up under a tree that's growing through a gate. It's so cozy and secluded!
ReadingMnemonic: As you leisurely nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis Khan (かん)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you. But wait. Isn't Genghis Khan dead now? He winks at you, "Leisure time is for the dead." He smiles, and fades away, disappearing into the tree.

Name: Lowly
Mnemonic: You drop to the ground in a rice paddy, and then drop down in front of the cross you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as lowly as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that. Imagine dropping down in a rice paddy, then again in front of your cross. Be as lowly as you can make yourself.
ReadingMnemonic: The only problem about being lowly is the heat (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell? You tried to make yourself lowly in front of God but this heat is probably a sign that you didn't do it well enough.

Name: Marry
Mnemonic: You meet a woman whose mouth is big and you instantly know this is the person you want to marry. When you think about the person you want to marry, picture their mouth wide in a big, beautiful smile, a wide-open laugh. That's the lady for you, alright!
ReadingMnemonic: You marry this woman right away and you both go straight to an inn (いん) together! When you get to the inn all you do is make her laugh and smile so you can bask in her bright, big, mouth smiles.

Name: Mountain Pass
Mnemonic: If there are mountains above and below you, that means you're on a mountain pass. Imagine yourself walking along a mountain pass. Look up at the mountains above you, and down at the mountains below you.
ReadingMnemonic: It's only on this type of mountain pass that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable Tokyo gecko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko! Picture yourself hiking along a mountain pass in Tokyo and spotting a little Tokyo gecko run up and down on them. It's adorable and totally worth the climb.

Name: Mourning
Mnemonic: If you only let oneself (yourself) into your heart, you'll end up mourning all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in. Picture yourself all alone. You never let anyone into your heart but yourself, and now you're mourning the life and friends you could have had.
ReadingMnemonic: While you're in mourning, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A key (き) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning? You try to push the key back into your body. Back into your eye, you even try to swallow it, but it comes back out. Finally you look down at your mourning heart and try the key there. It clicks. And opens.

Name: Official
Mnemonic: When underground music makes it out into the light of the sun (the public), it finally becomes official. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts. Think of all that music you listened to underground but not in the light of the sun. None of that was official music. None of it!
ReadingMnemonic: Once the music is official, you'll feel it in your soul (そう). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too. The official music penetrates into your soul, instead of just your ears, and it's affecting everyone else's souls too! Oh no... wait that's too many people. This was your song! No, it's too popular now, stop your souls from liking it! Ahhh!

Name: Recital
Mnemonic: We want you to say things with your mouth right now because it's recital time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite! The recital is happening now. So open your mouth and start already!
ReadingMnemonic: Here, if you are too afraid to start the recital now drink this gin (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts! Drink gin before all your recitals! It'll help!

Name: Reef
Mnemonic: The stone that looks like a turkey boiling underwater is just a reef. It may seem like there are a bunch of turkeys under there, but it's just the shape the reef takes. Though I guess if you're looking from above the water it really does look like a bunch of turkeys freaking out.
ReadingMnemonic: The reef is the Shougun's (しょう) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours. You don't know if the Shougun likes the reef because he likes the beauty of the ocean, or if he's fantasizing about turkeys boiling. He's a... complex man.

Name: Sand
Mnemonic: People think tsunamis are only made of water but they have a few pieces of sand in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in. Imagine how those few grains of sand feel to get swept up into a tsunami. They didn't ask for this. They just wanted to stay at the bottom of the sea.
ReadingMnemonic: How do I know there's sand in there? Because I saw (さ) them! I saw the sand, stop doubting me!

Name: Scorn
Mnemonic: In a flowers net a drunkard slides down like a drop. There they stay, an icon of scorn and neglect. It's embarrassing to fall down a flowers net while drunk. Despite that, there you are. Everyone who goes by scorns you or neglects you.
ReadingMnemonic: Every time you receive scorn and neglect from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I bets (べつ) you I can get up if I want. I bets you I can." You try to get up, but no matter how much you "bets you" someone that you can get up, you slide back down the flowers net. "I bets you I can do it next time," you say.

Name: Select
Mnemonic: If the tsunami that's heading for your village is fat you should try to select a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage. Imagine being at the tsunami store and selecting the least fat one there.
ReadingMnemonic: If you're having trouble selecting which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating tacos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco. While you select the tsunami that's right for you. Keep an eye out for those fat taco-eating ones. And then stay away from them!

Name: Spinning
Mnemonic: Move thread in the right direction and you'll end up spinning it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it! Imagine spinning thread into whatever your imagination wants.
ReadingMnemonic: While you're spinning you realize that you've always wanted to make your own bowling (ぼう) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes. Picture all of these thread-made bowling items. You're a really big bowling fan, huh?

Name: Transition
Mnemonic: Going from a scooter to a helicopter that's big even for yourself (oneself), is a huge transition. It's an upward transition, so that's nice, but it's still going to take you a long time to get used to using a big helicopter instead of a scooter.
ReadingMnemonic: You decide one transition isn't enough, so you transition to a centaur (せん) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better. A centaur is just a human halfway between transitioning into a horse, so it isn't even that hard to do!

Name: Very
Mnemonic: Making a mnemonic for a crab trap is VERY hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will! How hard is it to come up with a good mnemonic for a crab trap? Very hard!
ReadingMnemonic: You know what else is very something? Jeans (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things. How many sentences can you make with very and jeans? More than me I hope.

Name: Wander
Mnemonic: The tsunami that is good. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you wander the lands in search of it. You wander everywhere, with no particular direction in mind.
ReadingMnemonic: As you wander, you come across a clue. It is fish roe (ろう). Wherever the good tsunami goes, it leaves delicious fish roe behind. That's what makes it a good tsunami.

Name: Worship
Mnemonic: Under the mountain's roof are people using jackhammers to worship the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them. Man your own jackhammer! (And worship the gods.)
ReadingMnemonic: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others worship in the mountain and they're going to sue (すう) you for the noise. You try to argue that you can't sue someone for the way they choose to worship, but they say they're all deaf now, all the animals have gone, and no one sleeps anymore because of the shaking. Yikes, they might have a case!

Name: Annoy
Mnemonic: Set fire to a geoduck if you want to annoy it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly. Imagine how annoyed you would be if someone set YOU on fire for no reason. The geoduck has every reason to find you annoying, dude.
ReadingMnemonic: You know who loves annoying geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? Han (はん) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun. Think how annoying it must be to be a geoduck when Han Solo comes around.

Name: Article
Mnemonic: "For the  samurai, it is a jackhammer that they will lack." That is the latest article of the law written about samurai, hundreds of years after katana were taken away. This article was written with great sincerity by the government. By writing up new articles and laws they keep taking things away from samurai. First the katana, now jackhammers?
ReadingMnemonic: The one who wrote these articles with such sincerity was Genghis Khan (かん). Genghis Khan knew that samurai were a threat to his kingdom, so he took away their secondary weapon, the jackhammer.

Name: Barbarian
Mnemonic: If, again and again, you behave like an insect, you might as well be a barbarian. Again and again, these insect-like barbarians are harassing you and your lands. What shall we do, m'lord?
ReadingMnemonic: "BAN (ばん) the barbarians! Ban them, I say!," you loudly declare as the lord of these lands. Picture yourself as the lord of your lands, screaming "BAN them" at the top of your lungs. You'll finally expel these insect-like barbarians that have been plaguing your lands again and again.

Name: Bargain
Mnemonic: Under this canopy is the Mona Lisa, being sold for cheap, what a great bargain! Look really closely at this Mona Lisa. Hmm, I don't remember her having a mustache, but I guess it is a little dark under this canopy.
ReadingMnemonic: This Mona Lisa is such a bargain because it's just a rental (れん)! No wonder this moustached Mona Lisa is such a bargain. You can really get anything as a rental these days, huh?

Name: Censure
Mnemonic: If you want to slice the power out of someone just censure them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested. Picture yourself as you slice the power out of that senator you hate by censuring them in front of the world!
ReadingMnemonic: Once you censure them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another guy (がい). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA! Look at that guy now. What a loser.

Name: Certain
Mnemonic: If you think a tree looks sweet you have to be certain before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching. Which tree do you think is sweet? That one? Or that one? Are you absolutely certain? I hope you are!
ReadingMnemonic: If you really want to be certain, and not just guess, take out your bowling (ぼう) ball and roll it as hard as you can into the tree. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you. So now let me ask you again, are you certain, or would you like to try the bowling ball test?

Name: Correct
Mnemonic: An arrow is shot from heaven and hits right between your mouth and your mustache to correct your crooked smile. It also straightens your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too. Who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you. An arrow from heaven will correct all your problems!
ReadingMnemonic: These heavenly correcting arrows actually come from きょうと. They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches, so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky. If you want someone to correct your teeth or mustache, just wander around きょうと, staring up at the sky. Then when you see an arrow, run for it and try to catch it with your face!

Name: Diarrhea
Mnemonic: You ate some grains that made you so sick it feels like a knife is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called diarrhea. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now. Imagine back to the last time you ate something bad and it gave you diarrhea. It felt like someone was sticking you with a knife, didn't it?
ReadingMnemonic: The diarrhea is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow reeds (り) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you. You learned this reed technique from a group of ninjas who use them to breathe underwater, and you never thought you'd use them like this.

Name: Die
Mnemonic: If you ride a scooter with your fingers around an axe you're going to die. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die. Picture someone else riding a scooter with an axe in their fingertips. That's so dangerous! One bump, one bad turn, and that axe slips and they'll die.
ReadingMnemonic: You slip. The axe collides with your face. You die. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue saber (せい) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead. Your holy blue saber died for you. It saved you from certain death and now it died. After all you've been through together. All 60 levels. This is the end.

Name: Gradually
Mnemonic: You're stuck in your car during a tsunami and all you have to break out is an axe. You whack and whack but you're only gradually making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown. Imagine gradually denting your car door open with an axe while you're trapped in a tsunami. This isn't fast enough!
ReadingMnemonic: As you're gradually making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "YO YANKEES (ようや) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open. YO YANKEES! Gradually yelling that saved your life!

Name: Grid
Mnemonic: You see twenty slides lined up like a grid. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper? Picture twenty slides laid out in a grid system.
ReadingMnemonic: As you stare at the slide grid you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass maths (ます) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later! You can make a grid out of anything if you set your mind to it. And you can do math anywhere as long as you have some grid paper!

Name: Groom
Mnemonic: Have you heard the tale of the woman who fell in love with a coat rack during a full moon and made him her groom? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the groom's side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things. Imagine what it would be like to fall in love with a coat rack and make it YOUR groom.
ReadingMnemonic: The best part of the story is that the only coat on the coat rack groom was a moose coat (むこ). So the groom was a really skinny stick with a giant moose hair coat hanging down it. Could you love a moose coat enough to marry it?

Name: Hide
Mnemonic: This cage is full of flowers on the right side to hide the fact that you're in here too. You don't really want to be in this cage, but there were some things you didn't want to do today, so you hid. Luckily these flowers block the right side of the cage and hide you completely.
ReadingMnemonic: As you hide the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?" "N-no?" you respond. "Wrong! I hid all the time. There's nothing wrong with hiding, you're doing a great job." he says, and disappears.

Name: Humble
Mnemonic: You say something to a boot when you want to be humble. You're down there because you're bowing in front of the person you're humbling yourself before. Because of that, your face is really close to their boots and you're speaking directly at them, instead of at the person's face, so it's more discreet. Picture yourself trying to be humble. You're down on the ground talking to a pair of boots. You don't dare raise your eyes past that.
ReadingMnemonic: You're being humble like this because those boots belong to the King (きん) of England. You can't just say whatever you want at eye level to a king. He'll have your head chopped off for insolence, or worse! Imagine saying something to the King. Get low down on the ground to be as humble as you can. Whisper into the King's boots. Lick them if you have to.

Name: Indigo
Mnemonic: Flowers that you oversee are always indigo. You aren't sure why though... Imagine if every flower you were supposed to oversee was indigo. Indigo everywhere!
ReadingMnemonic: Wait, maybe these flowers are only indigo because there is something wrong with your eyes (あい)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see! Can you imagine having indigo-only seeing eyes? I can. Because of this awesome mnemonic.

Name: Jetty
Mnemonic: You grab a tree so you can reach the bar in the ocean by making a jetty or a pier to it. Now you can walk out on the jetty and go get drinks without needing a boat or getting wet. Imagine laying your tree into the water to make your own jetty extending out to the floating bar in the ocean. Innovative!
ReadingMnemonic: You also made this jetty so it would be easier for Santa-san (さん) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, and he wants a refreshing drink after delivering all those presents. You get extra presents for making him a jetty, so win-win. Picture Santa-san coming in from the ocean on his speedboat and docking on your jetty so he can go relax in the bar. Imagine the mountain of presents he lays on the jetty for you as thanks.

Name: Martyr
Mnemonic: Put a yakuza member in a prison on the sun and he'll become a martyr to all the other yakuza still on earth. He died up there so the rest of them wouldn't have to. Because they definitely aren't getting caught now, if the penalty is a burning death in the new sun prison. Imagine all the yakuza coming out into the streets and holding up signs saying this guy was a martyr. A hero to all who do bad stuff in bad groups but don't wanna get caught.
ReadingMnemonic: The only reason he ended up a martyr in the first place is because they put him up there in June (じゅん). Everyone knows the sun is way too hot for humans in June. It's summer! Really, it's not the fault of the people who put him there that he's become a martyr. It's the month of June. PUNISH JUNE! PUT JUNE IN THE SUN PRISON! (Is what I assume those yakuza are shouting.)

Name: Pit
Mnemonic: In the dirt, you find a lid under the table. You lift it to reveal a deep pit. Why is there a hole under your table? You pull away the lid and crawl inside. There is a ladder that takes you deep into the pit.
ReadingMnemonic: When you reach the bottom of the pit, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see こういち, starved and chained in a pit under your table. After you've nursed こういち back to health, he explains that he was put here by a clone こういち–the very same こういち who became emperor. He tells you he can think of around 61-70 different pain levels of revenge, but also that "it probably wouldn't be worth it, so let's just hang out for a while instead. Ooh, are those cookies?"

Name: Quit
Mnemonic: You're in a net but you have the ability to quit playing along and leave at any time. Your captors think they have you trapped, but you know you can leave whenever you feel like it.
ReadingMnemonic: You don't know if you want to quit this charade until you feel an uncomfortable heat (ひ). You look down and the net you're in is being hung above a large fire. As the heat spreads you decide to leave. You hop out of the net and watch the shock spread in your captors eyes.

Name: Reckless
Mnemonic: If the death of a woman occurs it's because she was being reckless. People don't just die out of nowhere! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right. Picture yourself watching the news about a woman's death. The word RECKLESS?! pops up on your screen and keeps flashing. Huh, she must have been, you think to yourself.
ReadingMnemonic: As you watch the news about this reckless woman you find out that she died from mowing (もう) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it. Imagine what reckless thing that woman had to have done to die while mowing the lawn. Eww.

Name: Ripples
Mnemonic: As the tsunami hits your scooter and your car, it alters the wave, creating ripples. They're hard to see because a tsunami is pretty big, but your scooter and car do create ripples in the water as it goes past.
ReadingMnemonic: Ripples come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were rentals (れん), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami. As you watch the ripples come off your car and scooter, be sure to imagine the relief you'd feel if you knew they were rentals and not something owned by you.

Name: Seaweed
Mnemonic: The flowers that wash up on shore in tsunamis that we make into syrup is seaweed. Okay, so it's more like soup or tea than syrup, but you can make them both out of seaweed. Seaweed is the flower of the sea!
ReadingMnemonic: Seaweed is true soul (そう) food. Which means it's good for your soul. Didn't you ever read those books about chicken soup being good for your soul? Well that was a lie. Miso soup with seaweed is what's really good for your soul. Feed your soul with seaweed and it will thank you. Promise! <3

Name: Secrete
Mnemonic: Tsunami's have a certain tendency to secrete things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving. Certain tsunami secretions are dangerous. Can you think of any?
ReadingMnemonic: Most tsunami's secrete heat (ひ). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea. The next time someone asks you what does a tsunami secrete? You'll say heat!

Name: Shamisen Song
Mnemonic: Use your mouth to sing and a shellfish to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a shamisen song just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time! Imagine using your mouth to sing and a shell to play the shamisen to perform your shamisen song!
ReadingMnemonic: A shamisen song is just an 歌 (うた) but with a shamisen. They're still songs so they're said the exact same way! A shamisen song is a song, yay!

Name: Shore
Mnemonic: Half of a rice paddy is always on the shore. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right? Picture a rice paddy. Half of it is trailing off into the shore. Hear the seagulls. Feel the ocean breeze!
ReadingMnemonic: You decide to walk along this shore when you see Han (はん) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lie on the shore with Han!! Imagine lying on the shore with Han Solo. Enjoying a cool drink. Smelling the fragrance of the rice paddy behind you. Yeah, this is the life!

Name: Thrifty
Mnemonic: The leader squid tells all of its squid people to be thrifty. Imagine the leader squid giving a speech about how you shouldn't buy new things, and how you should live with a roommate to save money. Every squid yen counts!
ReadingMnemonic: Who is a thrifty squid? Ken (けん) the samurai's squid buddy, who gets carried around in a bucket and never pays rent. Ken's squid is always shaking his head at Ken the samurai's obsession with wearing all silk. He should visit Thrifty Threads, the second hand shop, and get some cotton clothes that would do the job just fine.

Name: Torture
Mnemonic: You put your fingers in the coffin to tickle the beggar inside. What you're doing is a new form of torture. First, you put them in a coffin to make them think they're going to die. Then you tickle them with your fingers. There is no greater psychological + physical torture than this.
ReadingMnemonic: The beggar you will coffin tickle torture is none other than old Grandpa ごういち. He is a frail old man, and doesn't like to be tickled. He keeps screaming: "STOP THIS TICKLE TORTURE. I CAN'T TAKE IT, JUST BURY ME."

Name: Ugly
Mnemonic: Give alcohol to a demon and you'll see how ugly it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face. Picture the drunk demon as its pretty face drips off revealing the ugly crap piled underneath.
ReadingMnemonic: The ugly demon is drunk and taking off his shoes (しゅう) and swinging them around his head. And, oh no, he's drinking more alcohol out of the shoes. The demon drinking alcohol out of its nasty shoes is the ugliest scene you've ever seen.

Name: Underworld
Mnemonic: Your forehead is in the sun, and you start seeing those creatures with lids for heads and  fins for feet again. Where on earth did they come from? They must have come from the underworld. Nothing like that exists in this life. Imagine the heat of the sun on your forehead as you watch these horrible creatures with lid-heads and fin-feet. There's no doubt that these are creatures from the underworld. You get out of the sun as fast as you can.
ReadingMnemonic: The sun is unusually hot for the month of May (めい), which must be why those underworld creatures are running around. You make a mental note to always avoid the sun in May.

Name: Valley
Mnemonic: The tsunami swept away one of the cleats your husband just bought and creates an entire valley with it. Watch as the tsunami rakes your husband's cleat across the mountain, carving a valley and an easier path for itself. Nature is brutal.
ReadingMnemonic: When the water clears, you and your husband go to the valley to look for the cleat and instead you find a bunch of cake (けい)! Maybe this is the tsunami's way of saying, "Thanks for letting me steal your cleat so I could make this valley shortcut." Imagine yourself eating cake with your husband in this newly formed valley. You both agree that this should be called Cake Valley!

Name: Widow
Mnemonic: Under your own roof, a geoduck jumps out of the ground with a sword and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a widow. Imagine the geoduck laughing and screaming, "Now you're a widow! Now you're a widow!" flailing the sword around. It's awful.
ReadingMnemonic: You may be a widow, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your car (か), and run your entire house and the geoduck over. It's just you and your car now, living the widow life, driving on into the sunset and forgetting your past.

Name: Yearn For
Mnemonic: You're walking in a greenhouse when you see a small drop of water fall and it makes you yearn for the person you adore. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing. Imagine how it feels to yearn for someone else when you see the small water drop. Imagine how your heart feels.
ReadingMnemonic: As you yearn for that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... Bobo (ぼ) the clown?! Ugh. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water. Now you yearn for being somewhere Bobo is not.
